fulltext.ft_body: Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania THE HRD-1LASER DISPLAY SYSTEM P. A. Woodsford Laser-Scan LaboratoriesLtd., Cambridge, ENGLAND The Laser-Scan HRD-1 is both a large screen, high resolution interactive storage display and a high quality precision film plotter. It is therefore relevant to both the interactive editing and the production aspects of computer graphics systems, and its characteristicsare particularly suited to application areas such as automated cartogra­ phy, in which large amounts of graphical data have to be displayed and manipulated. 1. PRINCIPLES AND CHARACTERISTICS. The heart of the HRD-1 is its computer-controlled laser beam deflection system, which combines speed and flexibility with high definition and reproduci­bility. Drawing speed is such that a typical 1 : 1250 map of central London or, for instance, a com­plex A0 architectural plan can be plotted at X10 reduction on fiche size film (148 mm x 105 mm) in about a minute. Alternativelythese can be dis­played, rather more quickly, on the 1.0m x 0.70m screen of the system. The drawing speed on this screen is 5m/sec. The reproducabilityand accu­racy of the HRD-1are derived from the use of interferometriccontrol techniques, the laser de­flection system being random access and oriented towards line drawing. Because of its high speed the machine can, of course, be programmed for shading and area filling applications. Effectively continuous control of the laser's intensity makes possible the production of grey scale shaded pictures. The flexibilityof the deflection system ensures that drawing time is substantially insensitive to the complexity of the drawing, well formed characters and other fine detail being produced at much the same speed as uniform straight lines. The basic optical layout of the system is shown in fig. 1. The light source is a CW Argon Ion laser. The light modulator serves to maintain a line drawing intensity independent of velocity profile, the actual intensity level being programmable as a 10 bit quantitywith absolute and incremental con­ trol. The dynamic focus lens serves to focus the writing beam in the film plane, independentlyof the position addressed. The proprietary X-Y de­ flectors position the beam with linear rate con­ trol. The deflectors are based on those used in Sweepnik, an ancestor of the HRD-1 originating from the Cavendish Laboratory,Cambridge and used for automatic measuring of bubble chamber film (1). These deflectors are based on interferometric control, with an angular unit of approximatelyone microradian. Two film planes are selectable by switching the position of a mirror. These two positions give rise to the display mode and the hard copy mode, the former involving projection at X10 magnificationonto the HRD-1 screen. FIG. 1. HRD-1 OPTICAL LAYOUT. In addition, in the display mode, a separate opti­cal path gives rise to a refresh mode, superim­posed on the stored (projected) image on the screen Use of laser light and simple, diffraction limited optics results in a spot size well below 20 microns. For film plotting on an area of 148mm x 105mm., resolution is therefore in excess of 7000 x 5000 lines. For display purposes a smaller area is used, giving 5000 x 3500 resolvable lines on the screen. Addressability is to within one tenth of a line width. The HRD-1 is controlled by a minicomputer, inter­face's to the DEC PDP 11 and EDP 15 being currently available. The interface, which is based on 16 bit word transfers, is parallel, asynchronous and inter­rupt-driven. Basic software, in the form of FOR-TRAN callable subroutine libraries, has been developed to make all the facilities of the HRD-1 available to the applications programmer. The philosophy is based on that of the long-established GINO graphics software package (2) , without, at present, the 3D emphasis. The basic software is developed most fully on the PDP 11/45 computer. 2. DISPLAY USE AND INTERACTION Fig. 2. shows a picture of the display. The cabi­net behind the console is the optics unit, which contains the laser, deflection system and film wri- FIG. 2. THE RD-1 CONSOLE (1.0 m x 0.70 m SCREEN). The (1.0m x 0.7m) display screen of the HRD-1 can be viewed under normal lighting conditions, the image appearing as dark lines on an orange/yellow background. This is obtained by writing with the laser on a photochromic film (3) of this colour, which is projected onto the screen.A reel of this film on a computer-controlled film transport is used so that the screen can be cleared at any time by advancing to new film. Image retention time on the screen is around twenty minutes, during which the image fades slowly Outside the projection system, fading (which is a thermal effect) is much slower. Once clear, the film may be reused so, in practice, a given reel of photochromic film is cycled a large number of times The key to the interactive capabilities of the HRD-1 is its refresh mode. This permits non stored information to be superimposed on the screen. Re­ fresh information appears in blue. Refresh mode resolution is somewhat lower (around one quarter) than that of the stored picture. Lines and charac­ ters equivalent to a screen diagonal can be dis­ played, repetition rate being the only limitation. A cursor, steered by a tracker ball, is available and completely general refresh patterns can be programmed. Refresh mode may therefore be used as feedback when graphical items are selected ("picked") with the cursor, trial positions of items (eg. special symbols) are considered, or operator messages are displayed. A set of 16 function buttons and an alphanumeric keyboard are also provided. Graphical edits are indicated on the storedimage, a suitablv updated version being re-drawn on clear film as reauired. A useful tech­niaue is to subdivide the screen, so that immediate history is still viewable. 3. FILM HARDCOPY. The HRD-1 also contains a station for writing on to fiche sized diazo film. This film is daylight handable and is developed by a simple desk-top machine, providing permanent hardcopy with clear lines on a dark background, ideal for reproduction. High quality, "full scale" masters can he produced by photographic enlargement (an A@' drawing is pro­ duced with X10 magnification). Provided an in­variant reprographic process is used, output on the fiche (which in this case services as an interme­diate master) can be calibrated so that the resul­ting "full scale" master is accurate to within a fraction of the line width. The correction invol­ved is non-linear, resulting from distortions in the recording process (eg. those arising from wri­ting on a flat plane in terms of angular displace­ments) and in the reprographic process, but it can be adequately represented by cubic polynomials. Alternatively, paper hardcopy suitable for edit purposes can be obtained from the fiche using sim­ple viewer printers. For this purpose (and for all but the most accurate1 simple linear correction suffices. Hardcopy from the HRD-1 is suitable for use in pro­ duction drafting systems such as may be found in engineering and architecture. In this connection, the display feature provides a valuable "quick look" facility. Some of the special features of the HRD-1 are particularly suited to cartography. Characters can be generated in all point sizes, styles are available in hardware and lines of any weight can be generated by the computer. 4. INTERACTIVE EDITING. The HRD-1 provides an interactive graphics facility with the information handling capacity and size of a drawing board. 69 It makes possible interaction with large quantities of graphical data, without having to make exces­ sive use of windowing techniques. Applications in which large quantities of graphical data al­ ready exist in forms suitable for computer manip­ ulation are particularly suitable. Examples in­ clude automated cartography, and the creation of large engineering and architectural drawings using libraries of standard components, and the verifi­ cation, modification and completion of the output of routeing algorithms in network applications. Also, the high-resolutionand large screen area of the HRD-1makes it suitable for the design and appraisal of smooth curves and three dimen­ sional surfaces. A storage display avoids the necessity of holding large amounts of information in fast core. Not only is this expensive in terms of hardware, but may well make excessive demands on a refresh system due to repetition rates. The ability to combine a complex picture held in stored mode with superimposed dynamic information offers many ad­vantages. To select items for deletion or modification a cursor symbol is used. This is positioned on the screen by the operator using a tracker ball. Since association is by proximity, a confirmatory stage is used to avoid possible ambiguities. The item closest to the cursor symbol is highlighted in refresh (blue), informing the operator of the computer's interpretationof his intentions. This interpretationcan be confirmed or rejected by use of the appropriate function button. If rejected, the next closest item is selected. In this way any item can be selected very rapidly, and the operator can be sure that no error or ambiguity has occurred. The actual deletionor modification of items is achieved by making appropriate changes in the data structure. Changes to the displayed pic­ ture are made by "scrubbing" items, or parts of items, that have to be removed and drawing in the new information. Changes to the data structure are made to a temporary copy, which can be dumped as a permanent file at any stage. Back-up to defined earlier stages is thus pro­ vided. Editing of a large graphical data set (eg. a map) thus proceeds by a sequence of operations, in­ volving item selection and editing commands. The simple and most common of these commands are issued by the use of function buttons. Exam­ ples of these would be item deletion, insertion of line elements or translation of item. More complex commands such as that required to an­ notate with a specific type size and at an angle, providing at the same time, the label information,involvethe use of an alphanumeric keyboard. At any time an updated version of the graphical dataset may be requested. The screen is cleared and the new version drawn, in the case of a com­ plex picture, in one to two minutes. Alternative­ ly, only a portion of the screen need be redrawn in a few seconds, if the area of interest can be identified. The HRD-1 is thus admirably suited to the inter­active modification of large and complex graphical datasets. This is particularlythe case if the changes that have to be made are in the nature of detailed "tidying up" rather than complete geo­metric reconfigurations. This is the case in automated cartography,where the bulk of raw data is available in nearly correct form, or where digital maps have to be updated. The large screen and visual quality of the HRD-1 ensure that fea­tures can be selected for modification from a dis­play of the whole map, or from a portion of the whole, where relevant. 5. CARTOGRAPHIC SOFTWARE. Applications programs for use with cartographic data have been developed for use with the HRD-1. The data is assumed to consist of items which may be point strings, character strings, circular arcs or symbol (macro)references. Point strings may be joined by linear interpolation (line strings) or by high order interpolation (curves). Typi­cally, third order interpolation is used. Within the internal data structure provision is made for each item to have associated with it both graphi­ cal and non-graphical information. Both types of information can be inspected and modified at the HRD-1 screen. Graphical information is qualifying information determining how the feature is ren­dered (eg. line style, line weight, character size, character font). Non-graphical information is typically a feature code, categorising the item in some cartographic sense. Provision is made for displaying and manipulating subsets of the data defined by particular selections of fea­ture codes ("layering"). The internal data structure used assumes that the order of items is immaterial, in that it reorders items for the convenienceof its search algorithms This reordering is performed when a new dataset is first encountered; at the same time translation from the external user format takes place. A wide range of editing commands is provided in­cluding:­ (i) delete item or part of item (ii) create new item (iii) extend existing item (iv) change position of item (v) join items (vi) copy item A set of constraints can be invoked when creating new items or extending existing items. Typical of these aids to construction are:­ (i) parallelism/perpendicularity (ii) interpolate fractional point (iii) building squaring (iv) fillet (join linear items with an arc). A typical case of cartographic editing is illus­ trated in figs. 3. and 4. which demonstrate some of the changes that can be made using the HRD-1 screen. In particular, the dataset under consideration is the union of two datasets which are imperfectly matched across their common (geometrical) boundary. Editing commands are used to make good the imper­ fections. This operation is termed "edge-panel­ ling". A related operation is that of "edge-match­ ing" where two datasets are made consistent across an edge without losing their individual identities. Three forms of symbols (macros) are dealt with. Instances of one point symbols are always geo­metrically similar. They are specified by ref­erence number and one or two pairs of locating coordinates. A mechanism is provided for defin­ ing and modifying libraries of symbol definitions, external to the editing operation. The final type of symbol, termed function symbols, require com­putation for each instance. These are implemented by program subroutines. Considerable attention has been paid to data se­ curity and back-up. The currentdata can be dum­ped at any stage by the operator to provide back­up stages. Deletion or change of any item only becomes irrevocable at the next redraw operation. Until this time deleted items exist in a "limbo" state from which they can be recalled by the op­erator. Development of the HRD-1began in 1971, with co­operation between Laser-Scan and the Cambridge University Computer Laboratory. The first HRD-1 was installed there late in 1973, for use in com­puter aided design. Of the systems now in the field, a significant proportion are used in auto­mated cartography. Ongoing hardware and software development is concerned with integrating data capture and interactive editing. Acknowledgements The author is pleased to acknowledge the contri­butions of his colleagues at Laser-Scan Labora­tories. In particular the hardware has been de­veloped under the leadershipof Dr G. S. B. Street and the cartographic software has been written by R. Fairbairns. Data for figs. 3. and 4. was pro­vided by courtesy of the Rijkswaterstaat Meetkundige Dienst at Delft Holland. It was man­ipulated using an interactive editing program written for the HRD-1by H. D. Stewart of the Cambridge University Computer Laboratory. References (1) Brown, C.R., Elcombe, P.A., Lang, J. A. and Raja R. "The Sweepnik System Performance". Nuclear Instruments and Methods 118 (1974) 1838. North Holland PublishingCompany. (2) Woodsford, P.A. "The Design and Implementa­tion of the GINO 3D Graphics Software Pack­age". Software -Practice and Experience, Vol. 1, No. 4 (1970), 335-65 (3) Baldwin, G.D. "Behavior of Photochromic Film Under High Power Laser Excitation". Applied Optics, Vol. 8, No. 7 (1969) 1439. article_rec.title: Architecture-by-yourself
article_rec.subtitle: an experiment with computer graphics for house design

abstract.par: Architecture-by-Yourself is an experiment in computer aided design that applies the medium of computer graphics, used by a general populace. The research program confronts the delicate balance between insightfulness and paternalism toward a user who ultimately bares the risk. The paper reports on a case study, on the underlying philosophy's of the French architect Yona Friedman, and on a computer implementation called YONA. As part of a larger research effort, Machine Recognition and Inference Making in Computer Aids to Design, we postulate further developments that will exercise input and visualization techniques in a relentless setting, relentless in the sense that the user is demanding, the problem is hard, and the product is a personal, one-of-a-kind design.

au.affiliation: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts
Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts

To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania ARCHITECTURE-BY-YOU RSELF An Experiment with Computer Graphics for House Design' Guy Weinzapfel and Nicholas Negroponte Architecture Machine Group, Department of Architecture Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts Architecture-by-Yourself is an experiment in computer aided design that applies the medium of computer graphics, used by a generalpopulace. The research program confronts the delicate balance between insightfulness and paternalism toward a user who ultimatelybares the risk. The paper reports on a case study, on the underlying philosophy's of the French architect Yona Friedman, and on a computer implementation called YONA. As part of a larger research effort, Machine Recognition and Inference Making in ComputerAids to Design, we postulate further developments that will exercise input and visualization techniques in a relentless setting, relentless in the sense that the user is demanding, the problem is hard, and the product is a personal, one-of-a-kind design. 1. INTRODUCTION design "actions," participating only to provide graphic representations where they were needed and to suggest "next steps" when the Architecture-by-yourself is an ongoing applications work unit of a couple's efforts were frustrated. computer graphics research project titled, "Machine Recognition and Inference Making in Computer Aids to Design" [1]. As its title sug­ gests, Architecture-by-yourself is concerned with the development of design aids for "do-it-yourself" designers -people designing their own homes or apartments. We see these users as designers, but designers who, unlike architects, are not trained or practiced in the skill. For this reason, their requirements for design aids differ significantly from those of aids created for architects. Most importantly, unpracticed designers require much greater assistance in visualizing their goals and potential form solutions for those goals. They also require assistance (not paternalism) in the process of design -direction, if you will, as to how to go about designing, what steps to pursue next, what to do when progress has stopped. Also, we can argue that they, unlike architects, bear a risk! It is these demands-to visualization and for strategic assistance­ which make design aids for unpracticed designers especially appealing to the Architecture Machine Group, for the Group's major interest is "to understand the makings of architecture; the interfaces between people, machines, and the real world" [2]. It is our expectation that the demands of the unpracticed will push forward developments in the other components of our research program. Focusing on appli­cations for the "by-yourself designer" will accelerate development of graphical input techniques, display capabilities and design strategy systems. The goal of Architecture-by-Yourself is to allow people to design their own homes without either a middleman or a middle machine creating whole solutions for them. This goal diverges from other ef­ forts in computer-assisted architecture which either have generatedcomplete designs for the "user" (such as the ARCHIT system devel­oped at the University of Oregon [3] ) or have required of him a skill and an experience completely at odds with a novice's role (IMAGE would be an example of such a system [4]). 2. DESIGN CASE STUDY To test our hypothesis about the needs of unskilled designers, and to get a sense of the difficulty of what we hoped to do, a simplefirst step was undertaken: a case study of a young couple design­ing their own home, a home which they would actually build and live in. This experiment was naively constructed, yet produced very instructive results. The couple met each week for 8 weeks with the Architecture­by-Yourself staff. The staff did not function in a conventional archi­tectural fashion. Rather, they served as observers of the couple's 74 Additionally, the couple was never able to visualize what proposed de­signs would look like. This proved to be a difficult task for the ob­servers as well. Perspectives, showing how a building or space might appear, are time consuming and difficult to draw -sufficiently diffi­cult so that the staff seldom had enough time to provide a represent­ation which was adequate for the couple to make decisions. Conclusions from the case study verified our hypothesis: any design aid developed for unpracticed designers would have to be based on a methodology which incorporated a clear, step-by-step strategy. This was needed to serve as a basis for directing users when they were halted. 3. YONA FRIEDMAN'S GRAPH THEORY PROCESS The design method proposed by Yona Friedman in his book Towards a Scientific Architecture [6] provided just such a framework. His notion is that the linkages of the house -the connections (doorways)between its spaces -provide both the backbone of the design and the largest payoff in terms of describing the designer's objectives. Friedman represents the rooms of the house and the linkages between them as a graph': The graph enables the designer to see simple difficulties in his link­ages. The use of a graph representation also permits an observer to monitor the designer's progress and to use graph theory to spot troubles early on. These "troubles" might include: 1. the need for multilevels 2. enclosed spaces (implying size and window limitations) 3. impossible access between groups of spaces. Yona Friedman's approach also proposes a series of functions or steps which form a procedural strategy for the inexperienced designer to follow. By determining first a graph, then bubbles over the graph,then shapes over the bubbles, this approach introduces completeness to the design without undue complexity. After the user has learned to deal with one component of design with confidence, the next con­cept is brought forth. The problem is elaborated until the user is able to deal with an assemblage of concepts and to cycle among them. The strategy is sufficiently flexible so that a user can jump about on his own initiative if he wishes. Perhaps most importantly, Friedman's approach decomposes the de­sign problem, not by abstract concepts of form and function, or by service spaces and areas served, but by the more tangible factors of room placement, connectivity, size, shape, and 3D form. The graph theory approach is additionally pleasing inasmuch as it incorporates the notion of using different representations, each of which is uniquely appropriate to a specific function: 1. planar graphs for room placement relative to other rooms, to sun, wind, and view 2. "bubble diagrams" to visualize areas 3. plan diagrams to determine room shape 4. THE YONA SYSTEM The happy correspondence between (1) our interests in graphic com­munications and nonpaternalistic guidance, (2) the conclusions derived from our case study, and (3) the capabilities of the graph theory approach led quite naturally to the implementation of this approach on the Architecture Machine Group's min-computers. This implementation, titled YONA, runs on any of the Group's Interdata machines (these enclude a Model 70, 7/32s and an 85). Each machine has 64K bytes of core, and any differences between models is transparent to the implementation. User/machine communication is entirely graphical, using IMLAC dynamic displays. Until recently, a light pen had been used for input, but this device proved to be cumbersome and inaccurate. A Touch Sensitive Display tablet [7] has been fitted in place of the IMLAC's implosion shield so that users can manipulate objects on the screen by pointing at them with their fingers.. This eliminates one of the more serious barriers between naive users and the machine. It is illustrated at the top of the next page. 75 All of YONA's routines are written in PL/1, the support for which was developed by the Group s software support staff. The size of the system is sufficiently large so that an overlay is used for each of the system s six major functions. Programs within each overlay are organized so that any action taken by a user will receive immediate foreground attention, while periods of user inactivity permit the system to analyze consequences of the user s actions in a back­ground mode. 4.1. MAKE SPACES. In this first of the system s six functions, the user identifies which spaces he wishes to include in his home. He does this by pointing at candidate space names in a menu beside the display window. He may also type the names of those spaces which he does not find in the menu. Created spaces are displayed and an indication of area is in­cluded adjacent to the name in the form of a bar spanning from very small to very large. A pointer is located on the bar, set initially to the center (average) location, and a numerical value for that pointer location is printed at the end of the line. The user can adjust the size of a space by pointing at the area arrow and sliding it to a new position. While he does this, the numerical value is updated in real time. When the arrow is released, background rou­tines total the present areas and print the sum along with a range of probable construction costs at the bottom of the screen. In this way, the user is kept abreast of the cost consequences of each change in his specification. By manipulating areas relative to cost estimates, the user can deal with his trade-offs immediately, avoiding unnecessary disappointments later in the process. This simple feature has proven to be one of the most useful in the system, and one which is entirely out of the question in a conventional process. When the user has created all the spaces he wants, he goes on to the next step simply by pointing at LINK SPACES in the upper menu. The screen is blanked and a message appears, PLEASE WAIT. OVERLAYING NEW ROUTINES. , until that operation is completed (approximately 5 seconds). 4.2 LINK SPACES. Instructions at the top of the screen inform the user that spaces are linked by first pointing at one space, then at the space with which it is to be linked. The first space identified begins to blink and continues to do so until it is pointed at again. In this way, one space can be linked to several others in rapid succession. A redundant matrix of the linkages is displayed and updated as each new link is added. This has been shown to be of great value, as a user can read across any set of links to verify that the appropriate connection has been made. Links are deleted simply by pointing to the name of either of the linked spaces where it appears in the IS LINKED WITH portion of the window. That is, a link between kitchen and entry could be deleted by pointing either at kitchen where it appears to the right of entry, or entry to the right of kitchen. As each additional link is created, background routines, using graph theorems [8], test that the graph implied by linkages is still planar. Where it is not, a message is displayed at the bottom of the screen: NO SINGLE LEVEL ARRANGEMENT CAN BE FOUND FOR THIS SET OF LINKS. The user is then referred to a training manual which explains his options: 1. deleting links 2. adding circulation spaces and relinking 3. dealing with multiple levels in separate graphs. It is interesting that. to date. no naive user has yet triggered this message. 76 4.3 ARRANGE GRAPH. An initial graph configuration of the specified "home" is generated for the user in which no links are shown crossing. At present, a simple, heuristic approach is used for this generation. However, it is known that the heuristic will not work for all cases, and a determin­istic technique [9] is to be implemented shortly. 4.4 MOVE SPACES. The user rearranges the graph by pointing at any "node" and sliding it to a new location. Crossed links provide graphic "warnings" that the connections involved are impossible. Background routines being developed will warn if "NO ARRANGEMENT IS POSSIBLE WITH-OUT SOME ENCLOSED SPACE." * Further background routines may be added to check that orien­tation for views, sun, and wind are maintained. Development of these routines have been postponed because we are concerned that soliciting the necessary information may be too taxing for users of the system. It may be better to ask and do less. Experiments in the next year will address this issue. 4.5 PRE-SHAPE SPACES. After a satisfactory arrangement is achieved, "bubbles" of the appro­priate areas are displayed over each node/space. The bubbles are drawn using a closed B-spline curve algorithm [10]. The splines are "fitted" within polygons which are formed by the dual of the graph and an outside perimeter which matches the boundary of the graph. 77 4.6 SKETCH SHAPE. REFERENCES Using the sized bubbles as area guides, the user sketches the actual shapes of the rooms. To simplify this task, a grid is displayed to which the sketched lines are snapped. Only straight lines and arcs are possible at this time. As the shapes are completed, the bubbles are deleted. Checking for the reporting of major deviations from area requirements are done in the background. And our adjusted cost estimate is dis­played. (These are not shown in the previous figure as these rou­tines are only now being interfaced with the system.) 5. FUTURE DEVELOPMENT Two additional capabilities will be added during the next year. The first of these will translate the sketched room shapes into more com­plete plan representations, showing wall thicknesses and door and window locations and enabling placement of furniture. 1. Machine Recognition and Inference Making in Computer Aids to Design. MIT, Architecture Machine Group, NSF Proposal, 1974. 2. Negroponte, Nicholas, The Architecture Machine, Computer Aided Design, Vol. 7. No. 3, 1975. 3. Finrow, Jerry, and Heilman, Robert, Toward a User Based Automated Architectural Design System: Theory, System Operation and Future Development, DMG-DRS Journal, Vol. 7, No. 2, 1973, p. 124. 4. Weinzapfel, Guy, IMAGE-A Computer Design Aid System, Proceedings of the Share-ACM-IEEE Design Automation Work­shop, June 28-30, 1971, Atlantic City, New Jersey. 5. Weinzapfel, Guy, The Falco Experiment, MIT, Architecture Machine Group, working paper, 1975. 6. Friedman, Yona, Toward a Scientific Architecture, Cambridge: MIT Press, 1975. 7. Touch Sensitive Displays, MIT, Architecture Machine Group, ARPA Proposal, 1978. 8. A simplistic brute force process is used at the present time. See John Hopcroft and Robert Tarjan, Efficient Planarity Testing, Journal of the Association for Computing Machinery. Vol. 21, No. 4, pp. 549-568, 1974, for a more efficient algorithm which may be implemented in the coming year if response times are too slow from our present routine. 9. Smith, Stephen Garland, A Graph Theoretic Approach to Interactive Layout Planning, MIT, M.S. Thesis, Management, Dewey Archives, 1971. Potential representation of floor plan with walls and thicknesses indicated and furniture placed. YONA presently makes no use of the Machine Group s rapidly devel­oping raster scan capabilities. The coming year s work, however, should see significant explorations of this technology for visualizations of designed environments. One can easily imagine a user painting the walls of his/her living room, not only with various colors but with textures as well (brick, panelling, et cetera). In summary, we see Architecture-by-Yourself as a worst-case exercise in man-machine interaction. The machine must be simultaneously understanding, helpful and not paternalistic. The user must deal with the soul-searching decisions of personal design. And, the partnership must yield a workable, cost-affective, one-of-a-kind solution. 78

article_rec.title: Automatic drafting systems
article_rec.subtitle: an effective person-machine interface

abstract.par: A primary advantage of computer graphics is that a comfortable environment can be created for an individual to communicate with a computer. A properly people-designed automatic drafting system is an excellent example of such an environment.

au.affiliation: Machover Associates Corporation, White Plains, N.Y.

fulltext.ft_body: AUTOMATIC DRAFTING SYSTEMS -AN EFFECTIVE PERSON-MACHINE INTERFACE Carl Machover Machover Associates Corporation White Plains, N.Y. 10601 A primary advantage of computer graphics is that a comfortable environment can be created for an individual to communicate with a computer. A properly people-designedautomatic drafting system is an excellent example of such an environment. 1. INTRODUCTION A person is smart, creative and slow.... while a computer is stupid, uncreative and very fast. A continuing problem is one of providing an environment in which the person and machine can work together as a productive problem solving team. Computer Graphics provides that environ­ment....and automatic drafting is an ideal application. To be successful in the commercial environment, automatic drafting systems must: .provide a comfortable, non­threatening environment to the draftsperson and designer. .increase the users productivity in order to justify the relatively high systems cost. The ability of the automatic drafting system to satisfy these key requirements depends in larger part on the human factors aspect of the system...hardware and software...design. 2. WHAT IS IN A TYPICAL AUTOMATIC DRAFTING SYSTEM A typical stand-alone automatic drafting system includes: .A computation facility with mini­computer and mass memory (for programs and drawing storage) with the drafting system software. Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania .Draftsmenwork stations, which may consist of a refresh cathode ray tube, light pen, function keyboard, and alphanumeric keyboard, or Digitizers combined with a storage tube, graphic tablet, function keyboard, and alphanumeric key­board. .A hard copy device (like a plotter or COM), or A storage medium (like magnetic tape), attached to the computation facility so that plotting tape can be produced and then taken to the hard copy device location. A system may have several kinds of mass storage (like disks, magnetic tape and cassettes), may support several work stations, and may have several hard copy units (like an electrostatic printer/ plotter, electromechanical plotter, and COM unit). In addition, the system may also be used for supplementary program­ming, and may therefore include a printer, card reader, and paper tape punch/reader. 3. USER ENVIRONMENT A typical draftsperson, using an auto­matic drafting system, is quite apprehensive about being "replaced by a computer". Therefore, great care must be taken that the user feels comfortable at the system's work station. 79 In my judgement, the station should be as "drafting-like", and as little as "computer-like" as possible. The user will want a reference table near-by... but will probably not want to be confrontedby a computer console. The draftsperson must be able to handle all the systems drawing functions without knowing anything about computers or programming. The tasks should all be accomplished expeditiously,with the system constantly prompting the operator about procedures, available functions and next steps. Each user must be able to communicate with the system in a natural way, by pointing and/or activating suitably labeled keys, for example. Typing should be kept to a minimum...basicallyto enter or change text, or to enter numeric dimensionsor position data, but not to enter drawing commands. The system should let the user know that an instructionhas been received.... and must respond to that instruction within a time interval consistent with the users expectation. Fundamentally, the system must provide a fatigue-free, sympathetic environment to the user. 4. INCREASING PRODUCTIVITY An automatic drafting system sells in the range of $150,000 and up. Depending on usage, number of stations, etc., the cost per work station hour is in the range of $10 to $50. Based on the "loaded" rate of a typical draftsperson, the system must increase the productivity of the user by about 3:1, just to break even. A well-designed system, used in an appropriate application,can often in­ crease productivity in the range of 6:1 or more. And, of course, it is this increase which accounts for the remarkable growth of automatic drafting systems in the last few years. To obtain this increase in productivity, an automatic drafting system should at least give the draftsperson all the facilities one needs to create or change any kind of drawing. These typically include ability to: .convert a drawing into computer­handleable form. .select (by title and/or number) a drawing already stored. .store (by title and/or number) any drawing created or changed. .combine portions of stored drawings with new information. .select from a large library of pre-stored symbols (or to create new symbols as needed). .define lines, arcs, curves, circles, and surfaces in 2D or 3D, graphi­cally or numerically,by a variety of geometric techniques. .add or change text. .automaticallyspline. .automaticallyfillet. .automaticallydimension. .automaticallysection (cross hatch). .manipulatea portion of a drawing by copying, scaling, deleting, moving, rotating, aligning, and windowing. .change several views by working on one view. .automaticallyinterchange measure­ ment units. .automaticallyproduce isometrics. .view only certain of classes (or levels) of data on a drawing. .producehard copy in any desired form...paper,microfilm, etc....at any desired scale. Drafting supervisors also expect auto­ matic drafting systems to provide several intangible benefits to which it is difficult to assign a dollar value. .Improved drawing quality...production of inked drawings in virtually the same time and at the same cost as conventional pencil drawings...and the drawings have consistent quality, from one to the other. .Improved compliance with standards... standard parts, standard symbols, standard notes, standard drafting practices can be all locked into the software. Finally, the process of creating a draw­ing can often also create a data base, and that data base can be used to produce additional output. .design analysis can be performed. .parts lists and bills of materials can be produced. .machine tool N/C tapes can be made. 80 There is strong evidence that these data base features can produce savings that potentially swamp the currently measurable savings reported for drawing production. Incidentally, the users of this additional output may be more computer-orientedand less intimidated if computer operator/ programmer-likeactions are needed to initiate these functions. 5. SUMMARY Computer Graphics provides the ideal environment for the drafting environment. While the draftsperson should be insulated from the computer, other users of the system can be asked to perform computer­ oriented tasks.

article_rec.title: Interactive simulation of network pumping policies on a computer-based graphics system

abstract.par: This paper is concerned with the development of a computer-based graphics system for interactive simulation of pumping policies on water supply networks. The method evaluates various strategies which are input to the computer via a light-pen graphics facility, and displays to the operator the cost of the input strategy based on a mathematical model of the pumping tariff which is developed. The method has been used for policy analysis on a pressure zone of a network in the United Kingdom, and the calculations implemented on a Fortran-based minicomputer graphics system.

fulltext.ft_body: Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Interactive Simulation of Network Pumping Policies on a Computer-BasedGraphics System P.F. Perry and J.D. Keenan Assistant Professors Department of Civil and Urban Engineering University of Pennsylvania ABSTRACT This paper is concerned with the development of a computer-basedgraphics system for interac­tive simulation of pumping policies on water sup­ply networks. The method evaluates various stra­tegies which are input to the computer via a light-pen graphics facility, and displays to the operator the cost of the input strategy based on a mathematical model of the pumping tariff which isdeveloped. The method has been used for policy analysis on a pressure zone of a network in the United Kingdom, and the calculations implemented on a Fortran-based minicomputer graphics system. 1. Introduction The field of computer control isgrowing ra­pidly and achieving widespread industrial recog­nition and acceptance1. Engineers inthe pro­cess industries and application engineers in the computer and instrumentation industries are being drawn into computer control projects in increasing numbers, and therefore require infor­mation about the concepts, equipment, and ap­plications of this new technology. Perhaps the most significant and profound development of this technological revolution has been the ad­vent of the high speed digital computer, whose vast potential lies in its character as an in­formation handling and information processing machine. Under man's guidance, computers can take diverse information in large quantities and transform itrapidly into usable form. This has made itpossible for data from complex industrial processes to be efficiently collec­ted and processed, and subsequently used as an aid for the optimum operation and management of the system. Inmany cases, the presentation of data ina more easily assimilated form has signi­ficantly improved manual operation of the process. Also, given an accurate dynamic model of the sys­tem and the ability to implement controls from the computer, the possibility arises of completely automatic optimal operation. The fundamental reason why industrial pro­cesses lend themselves to computer techniques is because of the computer's ability to handle infor­mation flow, which isthe essential ingredient of control, in an efficientmanner. Every process involves three kinds of flow: flow of materials, flow of energy, and flow of information, and be­ cause of this key role of information--whether in single-variablecontrol, multivariable process control, plant control or corporate control--the computer is the logical tool to use. Therefore, just as there have long been excellent devices de­signed to facilitatematerial handling and energy transmission, the modern process control computer takes its place as a device designed to facilitate information processing for control purposes in in­dustrial operations. Developments inmodern control theory and its applications are increasingly concerned with the on-line control of complex systems 2, 3, 4. These systems may in general be represented by large non-linear dynamic models, with high control and state dimensionality,and stochastic disturbances which corrupt the state measurements on the sy­stem. It is often appropriate to use an optimal control inwhich the control inputs are calculated to minimize a performance index subject to the constraints imposed by the plant. This is parti­cularly true for mass or energy distribution sys­tems, since in such cases it is often possible to accurately specify the cost of operation, and thus successful implementationof an optimal control will lead to operation of the system at minimum cost. The technical problems in implementing such a control are several. Considerablymore varia­bles have to be measured and made available cen­trally than inmore conventional non-optimal con­trol schemes, and thus a powerful centralized computer for data collection and system control is essential. Since optimization implies the mini­mization of a performance index over a period of time, e.g., one day's or a week's operation, it isnecessary to predict the behaviour of some va­riables over that time period.5 The computer al­gorithms used for optimization and other calcula­tions must be economical to run, capable of dea­ling with systems of high dimensionality,and com­putationally robust--in particular, they must be relatively insensitive to failures and noise in on-line data measurement. Inimplementing an op­timal control, a balance must be struck between the computer power needed for data measurement and system control, and that needed for the more complex optimization calculations. This paper is concerned with an application of computer based control inthe water supply in­ dustry, involving the use of computer graphics and interactive simulation as an alternative to com­ pletely automatic control. Specifically, the pro­ blem of optimum operation of pumping stations is examined and a solution developed within this framework. This problem of optimizing pumping costs in water supply networks is of great interest to wa­ter engineers and managers who are faced with e­ver increasing electrical pumping bills for sup­plying consumers with their daily water needs. This has led to a rapid increase in the level of technical sophistication in the industry, with many examples of water systems with centralized monitoring and control of important hydraulic parameters currently operational, leading to greatly reduced manpower and operating costs. This has led, in turn, to the possibility of building dynamic models of supply networks and ap­plying on-line computer-basedoptimal control. The analytical tools for carrying out such an im­plementation are available, but the major draw­back isthe lack of confidence that field engi­neers have in such methods, and their reluctance to turn the operation of the entire system over to the control of the computer. Inadditon, the computer requirements of such a scheme are some­ times prohibitive. Examining the literature on the subject of controlling water distribution systems reveals that there have been two basic approaches to the problem of optimizing pump operation: a heuris­ tic approach, where control actions are evolved from past operational experience, and a predic­ tive approach, where control actions are deter­mined by mathematical analysis of the water tribution system in response to anticipated con­ sumer demands. The first approach is suitable for implementation by human operator. Given adequate controls and on-line monitoring of plant status a skilled operator can evolve very credible control rules from experience of the system, even though uniformity of action can­ not be guaranteed, since different operators react to changing conditions indifferent ways. Nevertheless, the method iseasy to implement using hard-wired logic or computers. Selected telemetered variables are used for control pur­ poses, and as they exceed certain limits sup­plied by the operator as set points, control action at the pumping station iseffected in real-time. Such methods, since they are u­ niquely tailored for the particular system, have the significant advantage that they are designed by operators well experienced in the operation of the system, and hence are well trusted. A natural progression from the heuristic ap­ proach isto introduce closed-loop automatic con­trol, where the set-point controls of the pre­ vious method are calculated on-line to minimize operational costs and implemented on the plant via the telemetry scheme. This predictive ap­ proach has been used extensively inelectrical power networks 7, and gas distribution systems 8. The method reduces the experience factor of the heuristic approach by using a mathematical model to compute flow and pressure conditions for a pre­dicted consumption pattern inthe network. Con­trol rules can be worked out inadvance and the effects of various control policies evaluated. One method of reducing the computational problem for controlling water supply networks is to use a regression model9 ,which isbasically a reduced order model relating the key variables such as tank levels, pump pressures and flows, and some internal network variables. It has the advantage of being simple, easy to implement, and requires only minimal use of computer power. The coeffi­cients of the regression model may be generated from on-line telemetered data or from a validated network model. The simulation method described in this paper allows the engineer to retain the human supervi­sory element for control, while using an off-line minicomputerto guide his decision making. The operator inputs typical daily pump operating stra­tegies using a light-pen and graphics facility, and the algorithm computes the total pumping cost of that strategy subject to the network con­ straints. The cost calculation includes compo­ nents of unit electricity charge, peak hour maxi­mum demand charge, and cost of fuel adjustments. The computed cost isdisplayed, together with a plot of reservoir levels over the 24-hour period. The operator may then input an alternative stra­tegy and arrive at an optimum solution by contin­uous interaction with the computer. Among the main features of the method are its practical usefulness inthe water industry and the ease with which itmay be implemented. 2. Computer Control and Cost Evaluation of Pumping The optimal control of pumping inwater sup­ply networks isjust part of the overall real-time control problem involved inthe short term opera­tion of such systems. Fig. 1 illustrates the over­all computer control problem and the relationship between the controller, the process, and feedback information from the process to guide the control­ler. Among some of the problems of interest in the short-term operational mode are (i)pump scheduling to meet the demands on the system at minimum cost and without excessive pump cycling, (ii)waste de­tection to reduce both distributed leakage and deliberate wasteful usage, (iii) demand prediction to enable the pump scheduling to be achieved. In addition, several other activities such as network analysis and sensitivity studies are of interest in the planning phase of water operations. In this present paper, attention is focused on the particular problem of pump scheduling by evaluating various pumping strategies. The pump configuration inwhich we are interested isshown in Fig. 2,which shows borehole pumps delivering water into a contact tank, whence water is high­lifted into the distribution mains for consumption at the various nodes of the network. Inaddition to the contact tank, there may be additional floa­ting storage at various nodes of the network in the form of reservoirs which fill up during periods of low demand and discharge during periods of high demand, thus facilitating an equalization of source high-lift pumping rates. To evaluate the various policy options, it is necessary to develop a pumping cost model which gives the total dollar cost of a given pumping strategy, and this will now be developed. 2.1 Details of Pumping Charges The total electricity charge for pumping 10 consists essentially of three basic items, which are the unit energy (kWH) charge, the charge for maximum demand of kVA during any half-hour of the pumping interval, and the fuel adjustment charge whose rate is exogenously determined by the Elec­tricity Boards and is representativeof the market oil price. Although this isessentially a "con­stant" term inany index of performance, in the sense that it is not controllable and is relative­ly fixed, it is included in the cost model for completeness to provide a true representationof operating costs. Each of these charges will now be described insome detail. Unit Charges These are based on the total energy require­ments of a given pumping strategy over a monthly period. This energy isthe time integral of the instantaneous power at the ith pump as given by where ui, AHi and qi are respectively the instan­taneous flow rate, head increase and efficiency. Thus the energy units are given by where the summations are over the time interval (k)and pumps (i)involved. Defining uc, the unit charge, and w, the maximum demand charge as follows it can be seen that the total cost of units at the end of the interval may be expressed as where q is the unit tariff, which depends on both the number of units and the current maximum demand, rn is the night rebate on units, and K is the final increment of the pumping interval. Typical examples of q and rn are shown in Fig. 3. It is not difficult to show that The first term is the charge for each increase in uc, the second term represents the night rebate, and the third term represents a penalty for any increase inmaximum demand w. These integrals may be evaluated with reference to Fig. 3. Maximum Demand Charges This charge is usually based on the maximum kVA demand at a source station over the tariff period. Ingeneral the cost of these units is where the tariff S(w) isas indicated in Fig. 4. The integral on the right may be evaluated accor­ding to and the other terms may be simply derived from this. The actual tariff charge incurred iseither the maximum demand as evaluated above, or the maxi­mum demand evaluated during the preceding 11 months, whichever isthe larger. The detailed structure is illustrated in Fig. 4. Fuel Adjustment Charges This is a cost adjustment based on the varia­tion in fuel costs to the electricity authority. Ittakes the form of a fixed charge per energy unit used, where the charge depends on the amount by which the fuel costs per ton vary from a speci­fied amount. Itcan thus be convenientlywritten where f isa constant over the tariff period. While this component of total cost isof rapidly increasing importance to water authorities, its rate is exogenously determined and cannot be re­ duced by control of the network. It isof impor­ tance, however, in determining if it ispossible for the water utility to use diesel alternators for generating their own power rather than buying power from the grid. A schematic representation of the pumping station cost model isgiven in Fig. 5. In some cases the total maximum demand from all the sta­ tions is summated before application of the ap­ propriate tariff, rather than applying it to the maximum demand at each station. This variation will depend on the arrangement with the Electri­ city Board inquestion. 3. Use of Interactive Computer Graphics in Simulating Policy Alternatives. Based on the cost model of the previous sec­tion an interactive simulation program has been developed for implementation on a minicomputer graphics system. Fig. 6 illustrates the various steps in the calculation. The user inputs, using a light-pen, pump operating strategies over a cer­tain time period (totf) one for each of the n pumps on the network. Given these inputs, the program solves the net­ work equations for important pressures and re­ servoir heights. The cost model of section 2 is then used to evaluate the cost of the given strategy, and the cost together with the calcu­ lated reservoir heights are displayed graphi­cally. The operator can then adjust the inputs interactively until an acceptable control policy isformed. The model used for description of the net­work must be of the simple regression type re­lating only the major variables of the network if interactive computation isto be achieved, since the full network model involves the solu­tion of large sets of non-linear equations, a task which is not suitable for an interactive environment. The time horizon for controls is usually one month for short term operational strategies. Inthis case, inaddition to the control inputs, a variable must be set inthe pro­gram which indicates the maximum electricity de­ mand charge registered in either the maximum de­mand during the current month under simulation or that during the previous 11 months, whichever is larger. Of course, to realistically simulate such policies, an estimate of the consumer demand for water must be made. It isassumed inthis study that an estimate of this demand isavailable, and techniques have been developed elsewhere for this purpose The computer used for the implementation of this interactive program isa DEC GT44 Computer, shown in Fig. 7,which isa powerful Fortran based graphics system. Itconsists of a PDP 11/40 cen­ tral processor with 16k words of high speed core memory. 4. Results To illustrate the application of the method to a practical problem, a pressure zone of an actual network inthe United Kingdom was examined and interactive simulation was used to compare short term pumping policies and to solve a de­ sign problem involving a choice between on-off and variable speed pumping. The East Worcestershire Waterworks Company network supplies water to about 200,000 consumers over a 200 square mile area near the Bromsgrove and Redditch districts of Birmingham, England. The system is technologicallyadvanced, with a high degree of computer control from a central control computer (Kent K70) which is linked by radio and landline to all major parts of the net­work. The Bournheath pressure zone of this network is shown in Fig. 8(a), and the time variation of some of the principal parameters isshown in Fig. 8(b), as logged from actual telemetered data. Figs. 9 and 10 show the pump characteristic curves for the two main pumping stations, Wild­ moor and Bellington, for the currently installed variable speed pumps and possible fixed speed pumps. The advantage of variable speed pumping is that the control variable, which is the in­ stantaneous pump flow rate, may be set to any value between upper and lower bounds as demand conditions on the network vary. With fixed speed pumps, on the other hand, the degrees of control freedom are limited to the points of in­ tersection between the pump head-flow curve and the "system" curve, which effectively represents the effect of connection to the network as seen at the pumping station. Consequently, as demand conditions vary throughout the day on the net­ work, it is not possible to continuously adjust the flow rates to deliver only the demanded quan­ tity of water at the required head. From Figs. 9 and 10 itcan be seen that un­ der variable speed operation the Bellington sta­tion can deliver between 1 mgd and 2.5 mgd at al­most the peak efficiency of 83%, which clearly allows a considerable degree of freedom inchoo­ sing the control setting between these values. Similarly, the Wildmoor station can deliver be­tween 1 mgd and 1.5 mgd at about 82% efficiency. In both cases the variable speed action ensures that both the head-flow and efficiency-flow curves shift to give efficient operation. Thus the speed and head continuously vary with the de­mand over the 24 hour period to ensure intersec­tion of the system curve and the head-flow charac­teristic at the specified delivery rate, at which the efficiency is also maximum. The situation for the fixed-speed case isal­so illustrated for both of these stations. If fixed speed equipment using induction motor dri­ ven pumps with throttle control isinstalled, the degree of control freedom isconsiderably reduced. Inboth cases, the pumps only operate at peak ef­ficiency for conditions of average demand, and are consequently less efficient. For the Bellington station the efficiency drops to 75% for periods of low demand and to 80% for periods of high de­mand, with similar reduction for the Wildmoor station. Consider now the use of the interactive sim­ulation program described inthe previous section for comparing pumping strategies using the vari­ble speed pumps currently installed on the sy­stem. Fig. 11 illustrates the consumer water de­mand, inmillion gallons per day, on the Bourn­heath zone and the possible pump flow policies at Bellington and Wildmoor pumping stations. These policies are drawn on the graphics screen using a light-pen, and the minicomputer is programmed to read 48 half-hourly flow values per day. Once this information isprocessed, the cost is printed on the graphics screen and the integrated re­servoir heights associated with the flow policies are displayed. In Fig. 11, two possible manual policies shown by dashed lines are displayed, to­gether with the optimal policy which is arrived at by trying out several alternatives and choosing the least cost solution. The first manual policy halves the pumping rate at Bellington between 8 a.m. and 12 noon, and discharges the reservior during this period. The second manual policy keeps both Bellington and Wildmoor reasonably con­stant over the 24 hour period, with a slight re­duction inthe Bellington output to allow the re­servoir level to fall. After performing several iterations, the third policy isobtained. This keeps the Bellington output absolutely constant at 2.15 mgd, pumping at about 80% efficiency, and slightly increases the Wildmoor output between 6:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. from 1 mgd to 1.15 mgd. This produces the 10% amplitude reservoir cycle illustrated. The other method of implementing the opti­mal control strategy involves using fixed speed induction motor driven pumps with throttle con­trol, where the flow output is physically re­stricted to the values shown in Fig. 9. Now the Bellington station operates at constant output with both pumps on and the operation at near peak efficiency. The Wildmoor station operates with one pump on and the flow restricted to 1 mgd or 1.15 mgd. This involves the throttling of the head and operation at about 77% efficien­cy. Thus, it can be seen that the choice of variable speed as opposed to fixed speed on-off pumping may be examined using the interactive program. 5. Cost Savings To compare these modes of operation, it is necessary to evaluate the various control stra­tegies over a one month period to see what savings the optimization calculation will give over more conventional manual and on-off control. The stra­tegy of half-hourly flow set-points is input to the model ineach case, as illustrated in Fig. 11, and the total cost of that policy obtained. Table 1 summarizes the percentage savings in operating costs to be derived by using the optimal policy as opposed to the two manual policies and the case of on-off pumping. Itcan be seen that the main savings are on maximum demand charges ra­ther than unit costs. In the comparison of varia­ble speed optimal control with on-off control, it isclear that savings of about 5% can be made on both maximum demand and unit charges if variable speed equipment isused. Inaddition to the other practical benefits of such equipment, which have been well documented elsewhere 11, it is clear that percentage savings of this kind on rapidly increasing pumping costs in the water industry are very worthwhile. 6. Conclusions This paper has developed an algorithm which is suitable for comparing alternative pumping strate­gies inwater supply networks and is simple enough for implementation on a graphics based minicompu­ter system. As an illustration of the method, pumping strategies on a pressure zone of the East Worcestershirewater network in England are examined, using a DEC GT44 graphics system, and the results of the investigation demonstrate the use­fulness of interactive graphics in this applica­tion. article_rec.title: Interactive computer graphics for computer aided design in civil engineering

abstract.par: Interactive computer graphics can be an effective and efficient aid in the analysis/design cycle of engineering problems. The vistas of much engineering research and design can be expanded with the tools and methodology available with the introduction of an interactive computer graphics (ICG) system into an academic or industrial environment. Specific attention is given in this paper to new areas of application of ICG in civil engineering; guidelines for the planning of ICG systems; practical applications in bridge design and shipbuilding; and economic considerations involved in using ICG systems.
