fulltext.ft_body: Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania INTERACTIVE COMPUTER GRAPHICS FOR COMPUTER AIDED DESIGN INCIVIL ENGINEERING John L.Wilson Dept. of Civil and Urban Engineering University of Pennsylvania ABSTRACT Interactive computer graphics can be an effec­ tive and efficient aid in the analysis/design cycle of engineering problems. The vistas of much engineering research and design can be expanded with the tools and methodology available with the introduction of an interactive computer graphics (ICG) system into an academic or industrial envi­ ronment. Specific attention isgiven in this pa­ per to new areas of application of ICG in civil engineering; guidelines for the planning of ICG systems; practical applications in bridge design and shipbuilding; and economic considerations in­ volved inusing ICG systems. 1. INTRODUCTION This paper focuses on the principal factors in­volved in the successful implementation of an in­teractive computer graphics (ICG) system for compu­ter-aided design. The general purpose of this work is to provide a framework for discussing: sound interactive procedures; means of enriching the en­vironment for the users of graphics systems; and the economic feasibility of using these systems.The objective herein isnot to dwell on the speci­fic algorithms used incivil engineering design.Rather, some of the important considerations and methodologies are presented and assessed. Engineers and computers have attained a sophis­tication whereby methods are being developed to optimize their respective functions in the inte­grated man-machine system. Itis desirable to maximize the engineers' creativity and impromptu learning ability; likewise, itis desirable to maximize the computers' programmedability to process data. Interactive computer graphics, in particular, can present an engineer or decision-makerwith information regarding a proposed structure or re­sults of an analysis in a graphic, comprehensible form and at a much faster rate than achieved pre­viously. Italso permits an overall unification of the design process so that the designer will he able to examine alternative schemes ingreater depth and achieve a greater feeling for the response of a physical system. The following sections of the paper are oriented to members of the academic and industrial community Charles R.Lansberry Structural Analysis Group, Corporate Science and Technology, Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Co. to further a successful coupling of research acti­ vities with actual design. The thrust is to syn­ thesize some known concepts for system development which have been used in recent years plus certain methodologies used at the University of Pennsyl­ vania (1)and the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company (2,3). 2. NEEDS AND USES OF THE ICG SYSTEM IN CIVIL ENGINEERING The vistas of much engineering research and de­sign can either be "opened-up" or expanded with the tools and methodology available from the inser­tion of computer graphics hardware and software into an industrial or academic organization. The areas of application for computer graphics inimproving not only productivity but also in gaining further insights into the response of phy­sical man-made environments (structures, transpor­tation and water systems) are extensive. With the continued improvements in ICG systems itnow ap­pears as though they will have a significant impact on the education of students; the designs of prac­ticing engineers; and perhaps even more important­ly, on planning groups, public officials and deci­ sion-makers. To illustrate, a brief description is next given to some of the work that iseither in progress or has been completed at the University of Pennsyl­vania. First, an interactive modeling system for curved bridge analysis has been developed utilizing the method of finite elements (4). The interactive modeling system which communicates with the user through a problem-oriented language, permits the user to easily define the parameters which charac­terize the structure, such as radius of curvature, width, span length, etc.; modify an already exist­ing structure; and obtain graphical displays of various structural components and various results of analysis such as deflections and stress resul­tants. The results of this project have shown ob­vious savings in time in considerably reducing the error-prone process of manual input of finite ele­ment data and in reducing the debilitating process of interpretation of thousands oflines of tabular output. Also, of at least equal significance, de­signers of these complex bridge structures will be able to consider alternative designs ingreater 89 depth via parametric variations studies. Thus, there will be savings inall aspects of structural analysis/designcosts. Two very practical applications now under study at Penn involving planning and decision-makingare next discussed. Under the terms of the National Environmental Policy Act (1969) and subsequentguidelines, the Federal decision-makingprocess must consider ef­ fects on environmental amenities as well as techni­ cal feasibility and the cost/benefit analysis. The final decision ismade frequently on the basis of either extensive data tabulations or a single num­ ber index. The development of ICG methods for en­ vironmental analysis can provide the decision-maker with a visual representation of the data's signi­ ficance (5). Thus, with the aid of graphics as an interpretive tool, the decision-makingprocess will become facilitated and rationalized. As an example of the potential of ICG, consider the gamut of flood control options for a drainage basin. These range from land use restrictions to stream channelization to dam construction. A key environmental effect isthe impact on the land­ scape. The task of the decision-makerwould cer­ tainly be eased given an interactive computer­ based movie depicting the landscape changes as a function of project option. This approach can be extended to include an assessment of longer-term secondary impacts such as pictorialization of re­ creation development impacts. Also, in connectionwith decision-makingand interdisciplinary problem-solving,work is under­way on interactive simulation techniques for the response of communities to natural hazards (6,7)-­specifically earthquakes and floods. The comple­ tion of these programs will enable agencies and communities to compare the relative costs and benefits of different programs to homeowners, in­ stitutions, and governmental agencies. The in­ terested user groups will incorporate their own values and constraints into the framework provided by the modeling system to arrive at policies with respect to hazard mitigation and financial recov­ery. The modeling system will enable one to examine the effects of many factors (engineering,social and economic) on many interacting units (house­holds, institutions and government). Because of the vast amount of data and computations required, the modeling system will obviously be implemented on a digital computer. The interactive model will enable a user to compare a variety of policies and levels of disaster easily and rapidly. Unfortunately, however, the full potential of interactive graphics inmany areas has not been realized. Although there have been some reports in the technical literature of successful applica­tions of interactive graphics inthe design-analy­ sis cycle (1,2,3) acceptance by the industrial community has lagged far behind developments in the research and academic communities. Some im­portant aspects for the successful usage of ICG systems are discussed next. 3. PLANNING OF SYSTEMS The principal idea underlying an integrated system for computer-aided design is to provide a system of linked modules and segments inwhich in­ formation sets or blocks are repeatedly joined, pro­cessed and possibly distilled, and separated at in­terfaces. In these systems the required rate of information transfer is so high that a host of both technical and human factors must be considered in the planning of non-alienating ICG systems. In fact, there probably is no identifiable straightfor­ward or unique combination of hardware-software-en­vironment based on the variety of human factors considered. Therefore, any quantitative ranking of priorities must be viewed with some caution and flexibility in assessing the acceptability of pro­posed systems (8). This section of the paper attempts to relate the complex manner in which the human and technical factors are interwoven. The list isnot exhaustive but is rather intended to serve as a general guide­line of considerations for the planned usage of an ICG system. Brief consideration emphasizing the salient points follows. a. Determine if there is a need for an ICG system. Based on previous discussions it appears that ICG will have a significant role inallowing increased display of creativity and innovativeness of engineers inmany diverse areas. Inaddition there are areas which re­quire the use of ICG, e.g., investigationsor studies on the conceptualizationof mathemati­cal models. b. Identify the nature of this need. The sys­tems may take on a variety of functions to as­sist either in the learning or decision-making process. For example, increasing usage of ICG systems istaking place in the following areas: student education; consulting engineering; ar­chitectural work, interdisciplinary problem solving; and decision making. c. Establish functional, performance, and op­eration requirements of the system. These must permit some latitude inseveral areas such as interfaces and standardsfor the transfer of technology through computer programs. This will help to ensure that rigid and/or inferior constraints are not imposed that will inhibit effective applications. d. Consider both the type of input from the user and the flexibility of expression for ef­fective communicationwith the ICG system. The input may be classified as graphic, numeric or textual--each of which may impose different considerations in the design or selection of a system. Further, the flexibility of expression permitted to the user should allow for a natu­ral type of "conversation" and perhaps give the user the feeling that it is an attentive lis­ tener and responder. However, caution should be exercised in the sense that too much flexi­bility can create some chaos or confusion through ambiguity. e. Consider the image of the computer system and its environment to the user. Too often the user is presented with an alienating environ­ment. Generally, most initial fears or resis­tance have an exponential decay curve. However, 90 many times these concerns are supplanted by a series of continual frustrations of wait and down-time. In fact, at times some of our work may best be described as engineer-aidedcompu­ting rather tnan computer-aided-engineering. Another frequently neglected or ignored factor involves the all important consideration of system environment. Productivity could be greatly enhanced by more attention being given to the surroundings of the system such as size of room, color and furnishings. At many instal­lations tne atmosphere isquite unaesthetic and distracting. f. Consider alternative systems designs and perform comparative evaluations. This will ne­cessitate an examination of alternatives, trade­offs and economics afforded by networks vs. stand-alone systems, storage vs. refresh devi­ces and hardware vs. software. There has been considerable discussion on these trade-offs since several different types of systems confi­gurations are possible. It isbeyond the scope of this paper, however, to develop a compendium of positive and negative arguments for each case. It is suggested tnough that each poten­tial user group obtain this information from a variety of sources (manufacturers,distributors, and other users) to enable the "best-fit" within given needs and resources. g. Evaluate algorithms to be used in the ICG system. There are a number of factors to be considered such as: portability and modularity; user understanding and control over basic as­sumptions; reliability and validity of the al­gorithms; system efficiency; ease of use and in­terpretation of input/output; other user experi­ence and documentation. h. Consider the amount and rate of information transfer. Frequently, too much information is presented for tile user to draw conclusions about the validity af the model and learn the patterns of the responses. Itis recommended, especiallywith respect to graphic systems, that the amount andaccuracyof information be scaled down to avoid confusion. The user should be given the choice of obtaining selective output as well as acting as the filter indetermining the importance or utility of information in com­plex data. 1. Investigate economics of the proposed sys­ tem. How can one configure a system economical­ly? To successfully answer this question is be­yond the scope of this paper. However, brief mention ismade of some basic considerations such as: investment costs and savings. The "savings" amount isoften difficult to quantify and is only meaningful if the manpower replaced by the ICG system can be used productively elsewhere. Itshould also be noted that there is not always a direct translation or one-to­one correspondencebetween time and dollars. A few words should be mentioned about cost-ben­efit analysis of computer graphics systems. Although tne thought of such an analsis may be somewhat unpleasant to those who believe in in­teractive graphics, there must be some yardstick with which to measure the relative value of such a system. Unfortunately, few studies have been published relating economic principles to the design and implementation of computer graphics. Some concern inan economic evaluation isjusti­ fied, in the authors' opinion, not because gra­phics is not cost-effective; but rather, be­ cause the quantitative analysis of such systems is performed at a very crude level today. This lack of sophistication is due in part to the fact that such graphics systems necessarily in­volve interaction with humans, whose performance is always difficult to quantify. Nevertheless, if one accepts the hypothesis that the future of design and computer graphics are inexorably linked, interactive graphics repre­ sents the most likely medium for computer-aided design to be utilized at its highest level of effectiveness. As the number of applications of this technique to the solution of practical de­sign problems increases, so will the data base for assessing its effectiveness. Of further significance to an economic justification of in­teractive graphics is the fact that the cost of manpower is continuing to increase significantly year by year while the cost of computer services is still continuing to decrease. j. Obtain continued evaluation of feedback from users from the ICG system once it is in opera­tion. This will not only enhance further usageof the system but hopefully allow the incorpor­ation of modifications or customizing based on special requirements of users. Perhaps the best advice one can give the engineer designing an interactive graphics system, based on the authors' experience, is to allow for flexibili­ty. Demands on and requirements of the system will change with time as more interest is generated in­house. In addition, if past trends continue, one can reasonably expect new developments and cost re­ductions in the areas of hardware and software. It is the authors' careful intent not to impose rigid or inferior constraints on system design since the profession is essentially at an embryonic stage of understanding the full implications of interactive graphics in the design process. 4. Practical Applications 4.1 Why Graphics? The design and construction of super tankers, roll-on/roll-off vessels, liquid natural gas (LNG) carriers, and ecological tankers (complete double hull oil tankers) during the past few years has re­quired an accurate method of structural analysis. Many new structural problems are presented by these ships for which the designer, and in some instances the classification societies as well, have no past experience. The complex nature of these structures is such that the designer and/or structural engi­neer, armed only with 'classical solutions,' has sometimes been 'left in the dark' as to stress le­vels induced in parts of the ship. Faced with these new problems, the shipbuilding industry has turned to the computer and the finite element technique for their solution. For complex, highly redundant structures, such as ships, one of the biggest drawbacks to an efficient application of the finite element method is the effort required to generate and check input data and display the output in a meaningful format. The use of interactive gra­phics as an aid in model generation and debugging is significant. Its use following an execution as a method of display and data reduction enables one to further reduce errors, task time-spans, and computer and reporting costs. The generation of a structural model using in­ teractive graphics eliminates the need for manual creation of detailed drawings, the identification and coding of hundreds of node points and element incidences, the key punching and verification of several hundred (or thousand) cards. The debugging of a model using graphical play-back allows the user to quickly identify and correct model errors. Errors in input nodes and elements stand out clear­ ly on a plot of the structure displayed on a gra­ phics tube terminal, particularly when the ability to automaticallyrotate and view the model from any position is present. As a pre-processor, interac-' tive graphics saves time by allowing the user to quickly generate and thoroughly debug his model. In addition, costs are minimized by frequently e­ liminating the need for reruns to obtain correct results due to errors in the model. The output associated with a finite element analysis is voluminous. Graphics provides a means for reduction of output data into a visual format and can also be helpful ingenerating material to be used in a report. Such graphical tools as ele­ ment and nodal numbering displays, deflected fi­ gures, and iso-plots of principal stresses can save substantial amounts of time ininterpretation of results. For example, a deflected picture of the structure, by itself or superimposed over the undeflected figure, condenses all printed deflec­ tion output into a single visual display. This type of post-processing capability reduces the time required to generate a final report. Inter­ actively generated plots are compact, complete, and entirely machine generated. The interactive graphics software presentlyused at Sun Ship is FASTDRAW II, a McDonnell Douglas Automation Company proprietary time shar­ing system which interfaces with STRUDL, NASTRAN and several other application programs. Access to FASTDRAW isby means of a data phone. The graphic terminal hardware includes a Tektronix 4014 stor­age tube terminal, a Tektronix 4953 digitizing tab­ let and a Tektronix 4631 hard copy unit. The hard copy unit is particularly useful in reducing the amount of conventional plotting required in an analysis. The cost of leasing the equipment is less than $1000 per month. 4.2 Design and Analysis of Structural Details At Sun Ship, interactive graphics has been a powerful tool in the design and analysis of hull structural details for new classes of ships. Liquid Natural Gas carriers, ecological tankers, and largespecialized roll-on/roll-off container ships repre­ sent new types of ocean going hulls. The design of structural details for these ships represents, per­haps, one of the most important aspects associated with the development of the overall hull girder strength and integrity. Interactive graphics per­mits a fast and accurate change in the particulars of a detail to reflect the results of a recent analysis. Inaddition, various design alternatives can be quickly generated and analyzed from a 'stan­dard,' or basic, detail model. Results may then be compared to determine the 'best' alternative. Standard details such as transverse web frames, longitudinal girders, stringers, bulkheads and brackets can be stored in the graphics system for recall and modification at a later date to conform to a particular analysis. Figures 4.1, 4.2, 4.3 and 4.4 show four possi­ble structural configurations at the intersection of a deck transverse and vertical web at the side shell of a roll-on/roll-offcontainer ship. The finite element model for Design No. 1 (Figure 4.1) was generated first using ICG. Each of the three remaining design alternatives (Figures 4.2, 4.3 and 4.4) was created from the basic model in an inter­active mode by adding or deleting elements and members as necessary. Figures 4.5, 4.6 and 4.7 are finite element mo­dels of typical structural connections in an eco­logical tanker (adouble hulled oil tanker). A plane stress finite element analysis was performed for each of these details to determine the adequacy of the design. Generation of models for details such as these begins with a rough sketch of the fi­nite element mesh to be used in the analysis. The sketch is prepared by land and serves as a guide duringtheinteractive graphics session. The actual procedure followed during the interactive genera­tion phase is a function of the particulars of the detail, the capabilities of the graphics software and the ingenuity of the user. 4.3 Economic Considerations Specific figures for a time and cost comparison of manual versus ICG generation of the detail shown in Figure 4.7 have been reported elsewhere(2). In general, experience at Sun Ship has demonstrated that the number of man-hours required for model gen­eration and checking of details such as those shown in Figures 4.1 -4.7 has been reduced by 45 -80% with interactive graphics. This reduction is sig­nificant in that practical experience has shown that 60 -70% of the man-hours required for a typi­cal finite element application are involved with the generation of bulk data. Thus far, the advan­tages of ICG that have been realized at Sun Shipinclude an increase in the efficiency and produc­tivity of the engineer as well as a reduction in the cycle time for investigating new structural details. The cost of using ICG has been found to be ap­proximately the same as that associated with the manual approach (2). It is felt that the economic aspects are satisfactory at present, and will con­tinue to improve as increased competition is real­ized in the area of graphics in the computer net­work service industry. Furthermore, as engineering man-hour costs continue to rise, the use of graphics will become even more attractive as a pre­and post-processorof information. 4.4 Problems Encountered The problems encountered at Sun Ship with ICG are primarily related to the physical configuration of the system. These problems emphasize the impor­tance of some of the items to be considered in planning an ICG system; i.e., functional, perfor­mance and operational requirements, alternative system designs, and rate of information transfer. The system communication rate at present is a 92 relatively slow 30 characters per second. As the size and complexity of the structural model in,- creases, this slow line speed accounts for a large percentage of the graphics costs in the form of wasted man-hours while waiting for a redraw and increased system connect charges. Faster response time is needed for video graphic terminals in a time sharing environment. All or part of a file may be lost due to phone line problems. In addition, phone problems can re-sult in tne input of incarrect information to the system. Inconveniences caused by the inability to connect to the remote computer due to phone prob-lems can be discouraging, especially when the engi-neer has a "rush job." Computer down-times and/or "system full, try again later" messages can be just as disconcerting as phone problems.- Thus far, experience with ICG at Sun Ship has been favorable. Both phone and computer problems are within expected service levels. In planning our ICG system one of the most important consider- ations was flexibility. As demands on and re- quirements of tne system cnange with time, we an- ticipate modification of tne current configuration to satisfy these needs. 5. CONCLUSIONS Interactive graphics can be an effective and efficient aid in the analysis/design cycle. The vistas of much engineering research and design can be expanded with the tools and methodology avail-able with tne introduction of an interactive com-puter graphics system into an academic or indus-trial environment. With the advent of high-speed digital computers a generation ago, we were able to transcend tne analysis-bound environment. To-day, it appears possible we shall transcend the design-bound environment through ICG systems. Specific attention in this paper was given: to the planning of an ICG system; to practical applications; and to economic considerations in-volved in using these systems. Each of these topics are summarized in turn. First, tne guidelines developed for the plan-ning of an ICG system involve many complex tech-nical and human factors whicn are closely inter-woven. Therefore, any quantitative ranking of priorities must be viewed with some caution and flexibility in assessing the suitability of a proposed system. However, the framework deve-loped herein is useful to help ensure that ex-penditures of significant amounts of time, ef-fort and money are not wasted. Second, the practical applications involved in curved bridge analysis and shipbuilding demons-trate the ability of interactive graphics to sig-nificantly reduce the time required for bulk data generation and checking. The use of interactive graphics and the finite element method has been instrumental in realizing the designs of new classes of ships such as the ecological tanker. Une of the side benefits of interactive graphics and an important one from the engineer's stand-point in tnis application is its ability to make more interesting tne task of data generation and checking. No longer is tnis a boring and time-consuming job; but, ratner, it quickly becomes a challenge to the creativity of the engineer. Third, the economic justification is satisfac-tory and it is believed that the cost aspects asso-ciated with interactive graphics will continue to improve as increased competition is realized in the area of graphics in the computer network service industry. As engineering man-hour costs continue to rise, the use of graphics will become even more attractive as a means of data generation and model checking in connection with the finite element me-thod. In addition, the rapid developments taking place in the graphics hardware industry itself seem to indicate a continued reduction in the cost of graphics equipment and a simultaneous increase in capabilities. In conclusion, soom after an introduction to graphics, the engineer becomes keenly aware of the power of this tool in the analysis-design cycle. Productivity is increased with graphics by reducing the amount of time and drudgery required to complete an analysis. For the future. the full ootential of interactive graphics systems-appears lihited only the ingenuity and imaginatibn of the user. - REFERENCES 1. J.L. Wilson and S. article_rec.title: Graphical input through machine recognition of sketches

abstract.par: A family of programs has been developed to allow graphical input through continuous digitizing. Drawing data, sampled at a high and constant rate, is compressed and mapped into lines and splines, in two and three dimensions. This is achieved by inferring a particular user's intentions from measures of speed and pressure.Recent experiments have shown that even the most basic inference making cannot rely solely upon knowledge of the user's drawing style, but needs additional knowledge of the subject being drawn, the protocols of its domain, and the stage of development of the user's design. This requirement implies a higher level of machine intelligence than currently exists. An alternate approach is to increase the user's involvement in the recognition process.Contrary to previous efforts to move from sketch to mechanical drawing without human intervention, this paper reports on an interactive system for graphical input in which the user overtly partakes in training the machine and massaging the data at all levels of interpretation. The initial routines for data compression employ parallel functions for extracting such features as bentness, straightness, and endness. These are planned for implementation in microprocessors.Results offer a system for rapid (and enjoyable) graphical input with real-time interpretation, the beginnings of an intelligent tablet.

To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania GRAPHICAL INPUT THROUGH MACHINE RECOGNITION OF SKETCHES Christopher F. Herot Architecture Machine Group, Department of Architecture Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts A family of programs has been developed to allow graphical input through continuous digitizing. Drawing data, sampled at a high and constant rate, is compressed and mapped into lines and splines, in two and three dimensions. This is achieved by inferring a particular user's intentions from measures of speed and pressure. Recent experiments have shown that even the most basic inference making cannot rely solely upon knowledge of the user's drawing style, but needs additional knowledge of the subject being drawn, the protocols of its domain, and the stage of development of the user's design. This requirement implies a higher level of machine intelligence than currently exists. An alternate approach is to increase the user's involvement in the recognition process. Contrary to previous efforts to move from sketch to mechanical drawing without human intervention, this paper reports on an interactive system for graphical input in which the user overtly partakes in training the machine and massaging the data at all levels of interpretation. The initial routines for data compression employ parallel functions for extracting such features as bentness, straightness, and endness. These are planned for implementation in microprocessors. Results offer a system for rapid (and enjoyable) graphical input with real-time interpretation, the beginnings of an intelligent tablet. 1. INTRODUCTION There are many areas of human endeavor which could benefit from the use of computer aids if there existed an effective means of communicating about these tasks with a machine. While the field of computer graphics arose to fill that need, it has too often added a new level of complexity. In computer-aided design, for instance, the process of "digitizing" is suffi­ciently cumbersome to delay its application until a relatively complete design has been produced by the human designer. The result is usually more akin to computer-aided evaluation or manipulation than to computer-aided design. The research described here is motivated by the desire to involve the computer in the early stages of the design process, where the feedback generated by the machine can be most useful. The medium chosen is free­hand sketching, as done with pencil and paper, as could be done at a data tablet. A machine is postulated to be looking on while the user is sketching. It could make inferences not only about the meaning of the sketch but also about the user's attitudes toward, and uncertainties about, his design. This approach offers its own unique set of problems and solutions, since the data available to the machine are at once plentiful and incomplete. While the ultimate implementation assumes a near-human intelligence on the part of the machine, far off in time, there are many interesting things to be learned along the way. Our previous experiments[1, 2, 3, 4] have been directed toward the creation of a "passive" input system which would make fairly complete inferences about a sketch while requiring a minimum of intervention from the user. The programs we used in these projects involved many levels of interpretation. From the 100 pen positions sampled each second, the machine would have to find lines, curves, and corners, building a description of a two-dimensional object. This description could be interpreted further, possibly as a three-dimensional description. The following sections depict three experiments in computer processing of sketches. HUNCH, described in the next section, was directed toward answering the following question: Does there exist a syntax of sketching, something which could be processed independently of the embedding semantics? Could a machine make useful interpretations of a sketch without employing a knowledge of the subject domain? The mixed results of that experiment led to the investigation described in section 3, a rather ambi­tious effort to make use of architectural knowledge in recognizing a sketch. Finally, section 4 reports on current work which places more emphasis on user involvement in the input process. 2. THE HUNCH SYSTEM HUNCH is a name given to a set of FORTRAN programs which were de­signed to process freehand sketches drawn with a data tablet or light pen. Each program performs a different level of interpretation, storing its output in a file where it can be used as input by the other programs. Facilities exist to display and manipulate various stages of interpretation. The relationships among the programs are illustrated below. The system currently runs under the MAGIC[5] operating system on a 64K is possible to determine the speed as well as position at any point in the byte Interdata minicomputer. The MAGIC system allows a program to use sketch. any graphical input or output device in a device-independent manner, in­cluding a refresh display with light pen, a storage tube, a raster scan display, a large digitizer-plotter, and several varieties of data tablets. The user of the system typically sits down at a table and draws with a ballpoint pen on a piece of paper taped to the surface of a data tablet. Considerable effort was expended to provide an environment as close to sketching as possible. One of the tablets provided measures three feet by Fig. 2 -Large Data Tablet four feet so as to allow large drawings. A special pencil was constructed so that the user could work with the more customary graphite rather than a ballpoint pen.[6] The pencil was designed with the additional intention of Finding Curves, Corners, end Lines The original HUNCH system was conceived around a program called STRAIT, which found corners in a sketch as a function of speed, com­pressing the 100 points per second from the tablet into a much smaller list of endpoints of lines. The central assumption was that speed could be interpreted as a measure of intent-a quickly drawn line was intended less literally than a slowly drawn one. As a happy coincidence, it also turned out that as a result of the finite mass of the pen and hand, the speed necessarily decreased at corners. All that was necessary to find corners was to look for minima in the speed function. (Notice the bunching of raw data points at the corners in the previous figure.) Fig. 3 -Pencil making the record on paper correspond to the record in the machine. This is achieved by an eraser on the pencil which has its own sense coil, so that erasures on the paper can be recorded by the machine, in some sense, such as negative line. In the current configuration the computer samples the position of the pen at constant intervals, variable under program control from 16 to 200 points per second. The data (100 points per inch in X and Y and 3 levels of Z) is stored in a disk file or on magnetic tape. Since the sample rate is constant, it Fig. 5 -Speed Function for Figure 4 Curves were considered to be a special case of corners. With the assistance of Dr. Richard Riesenfeld we decided to fit them to B-splines[7]. When the curvature of a corner was too gradual, or the speed indicated that it was drawn too carefully, the output of the straightening program was flagged to cause subsequent invocation of the curve-fitting program. CURVIT would make one or more passes over the raw data at places pointed to by the output of STRAIT, producing its own output file. Fig. 6 -Output of STRAIN for Figure 4 98 When demonstrating STRAIT and CURVIT to visitors, it was somewhat disconcerting to find that it did not always make the same interpretation as the human observers. What was still more alarming, however, was that the program worked better for some people's sketches than for others. It appeared that the programmer had embedded a particular model of human sketching behavior that fit some users more closely than others. The ques­ tion that arose was whether this model could be changed simply by varying parameters, and if so, how the correct values of those parameters could be determined. Latching A cursory examination of the above figure will reveal that it contains per force five endpoints. It would be convenient for programs using this data, such as editors or "square-finders" if there were only four endpoints. The first version of STRAIT used a simple latching algorithm which joined to­gether any pair of endpoints falling within a fixed radius of each other. This simple "rote latching" often produced bizarre results where changes of scale were involved, as illustrated below. With the realization that the latching problem was more complex than originally expected, STRAIT was rewritten without latching, hence STRAIN.' Obviously some intelligent means of computing the latching radius is needed. In the next experiment, the latching radius is computed as a func­tion of speed, under the assumption that the speed provided by STRAIN for each line is also a measure of the user's certainty in positioning that line's endpoint. Fig. 7 - Rote Latching Fig. 8 - Latched Cube Fig. 8 -Latched Cube As can be seen from the above, speed is not always well correlated with intent. In part this is because the speed figure used is the average for the line and does not accurately reflect conditions at the endpoints. But there is a more serious difficulty at work here-one which illustrates the inter­dependence of the different levels of interpretation. The program errone­ously latched the front and back corners of the cube, since their two­dimensional projections happened to coincide. The only sure solution to this problem is to compare candidates for latching in three space instead of the (often ambiguous) two-dimensional projection. Paradoxically our current GUESS program requires latched data as input in order to determine the z-coordinates. The solution will require that some latching decisions be made, perhaps on such syntactical considerations as the number of bodies or the sequence of construction, with the provision to modify decisions if they prove untenable in the later stages of interpretation. Several approaches to this problem will be discussed in subsequent sections of this paper. Overtracing Although not handled at all by the original HUNCH system, overtracings present many of the same problems as latching. Once again the process is one of reducing the quantity of data by making inferences about the user's intentions, turning several lines into one line. The program must distinguish between two carefully drawn parallel lines and one wide, overtraced line. The amount and style of overtracing may serve as a measure of a particular user's attitude toward the design, with heavy overtracing indicating em­phasis or reinforcement of selected areas. Other Levels of Inference In addition to the processes already mentioned, there are many other pos­sible directions of interpretation. One of them involves inferring the third dimension of axonometric or perspective drawings. The currently imple­mented program makes use of some simple rules of projective geometry to map two-dimensional networks of lines into three-dimensional data structures. Fig. 9 - Overtracing While easily confused by lines drawn in other than the three primary axes, the algorithm has enabled experimentation with manipulation of three­dimensional structures and cast some light on the interdependencies of latching and finding the third dimension. Another type of interpretation is illustrated by a program which finds rooms and their connections in a floor plan. This program maps the raw data onto a two dimensional grid. Any point having a line pass through it is set to one. By mapping cells into an array at a suitable scale, any degree of detail may be chosen. The room-finding algorithm simply looks for areas of zeros completely surrounded by ones. Needless to say, the program works well for simple floor plans that conform to the programmer's original expec­tations. It works less well with odd-shaped rooms and doorways which might not be doorways, as in the upper right room in the above figure. In this case, the choice of the "correct" interpretation is not so easy. In fact, it probably varies not only with different users, but also with different contexts. In architectural applications, the concept of "room" is usually less important than the ways in which the space is perceived and used-a level of inference perhaps above or perhaps equivalent to that of finding rooms. A human observer resolves these ambiguities through the application of personal knowledge and years of learning how to look at pictures. Each line Fig. 11 - Room Finding takes on meaning only in the context of the drawing and its subject matter. Before a machine can effectively communicate with a human user about a sketch it must possess a similar body of knowledge and experience. 3. USE OF CONTEXT As suggested by the preceding descriptions, sketch recognition requires more than a simple hierarchical interpretation of the data. Although the programs described are usually run in sequence, the interpretations to be made are not independent. The bottom-up approach is hindered by the lack of any contextual information. In contrast to human vision, for example, where knowledge of what to expect in a sketch is involved in seeing things as detailed as individual lines, the HUNCH system operates solely on the basis of syntactic evidence. Its success can be attributed to its use of data not available to the human observer, such as speed and sequence. The answer to the question posed at the beginning-is there a syntax of sketching independent of the semantics?-is still unresolved. While there is room for considerable improvement in the low-level inference-making routines, latchers that look for closure, overtracing routines that consider sequence, etc., it seems that a truly successful system would have to make use of context at the lowest levels. Such a context would have to include not only what the person is sketching but also the stage of completion of the sketch and the design, the idiosyncracies of the person, and his or her attitudes toward the design. The knowledge of the sketching domain has to be structured in such a way that it can be used to direct the machine's analysis of the sketch, supplying goals to direct the low-level routines in their search for lines, curves, and corners and supplying enough information about what is plausible in the sketch to resolve ambiguities and fill in missing information. This knowledge also must be in a form that can be easily understood and modified by the machine so that a sketch-recognition system could be constructed which lends itself to diverse applications simply by changing the knowledge base. A scheme employing these principles was explored in [9] and is synopsized in the following paragraphs. The act of recognizing a sketch thus involves drawing a sketch for the machine and specifying the "context" to avoid the more difficult problem 100 of "context recognition". This context specification might be as specific as "suburban homes" or "machine screws," or it might be as general as "built form" or "tools." The context description is structured as a network con­taining general case descriptions, for example: This structure is matched against the context-free data structure generated by the low-level HUNCH routines to generate a composite structure where all of the syntactic entities of the sketch are assigned a meaning. The match- Fig. 14 -Instantiated Structure ing operation takes place in a top-down fashion. That is, the machine attempts to find an instance of the top-level general case node in the specific data structure. In the example structures, a search would be performed for a room. Since there is nothing labeled "ROOM" in the data structure, the program searches for components of a room, specifically walls, which find their match in the lines of the data structure. The process is, of course, more complicated than a simple recursive depth­first matcher, since the general case description will not match exactly, but only in part. If a required line does not exist in the data base, it may be necessary to reinvoke the line finder, which may have thrown away a line the first time. A yet more difficult problem is posed by erroneous or pre­ mature matches: the system is only as good as the matching machinery. Either some method must be provided for withdrawing incorrect matches, necessitating a control structure employing backup, or the matching process must be made more breadth-oriented, requiring a sophisticated pattern matcher which can look around and size up the situation before making a match. A preliminary system using the first approach was implemented in the CONNIVER[10] language, an artificial intelligence (Al) language which allows construction of complex control structures and provides facilities for maintaining and searching a data base. Unfortunately, the CONNIVER pro­ gram, while small in capability, consumed enormous amounts of computer time and memory. Any attempt to expand the capabilities of this modest program led directly into the same (vast) problems encountered by Al re­searchers working on machine vision or natural language. It appeared that the knowledge-based approach would require a rather large, permanent detour away from the initial problem of providing a graphical input facility. 4. TOWARD AN INTERACTIVE SYSTEM The most promising approach seems to be a much more interactive system, one involving the user to make decisions of which the machine is not capable, but still affording the unobtrusive input method of sketching. The program must take into consideration the interdependence of different levels of interpretation. The bottom-up flow of information operates as in the HUNCH system, except that the data base is more integrated than the disparate disk files of HUNCH. The top-down flow, which is one of the strong points of the context-based system, comes from the corrections and manipulations of the user, as well as from higher-level programs. These capabilities require a much more integrated and interactive facility than is provided by HUNCH. Such a system forms the basis of our current work and is described in this section. The new system consists of a data base and a set of programs to manipulate it. The data base is stored as PL/1-based structures, capable of being paged from a disk. Each time a new level of interpretation is encountered, a corresponding level is added to the data base. Pointers are maintained to show relationships between elements at different levels. For example, when two points are latched together, pointers are stored at the latched level to show which two STRAIN points make up the new single latched point. As in the HUNCH system, there are three kinds of programs which use the data base: Inference programs are improved versions of STRAIN, LATCH, OVER- TRACE, and GUESS. Each one employs tests of reasonableness to its output and can be controlled by means of a well-defined set of param­ eters. Display programs allow displaying any (or all) levels of the data base on selected output devices. Manipulation programs have been combined into a graphical editor which permits the user to modify the data base directly. Finding Lines and Curves If the new sketching system is to be truly interactive, STRAIN must operate in real time, finding lines and curves on the fly, while the user is drawing, instead of after the fact. The program must lend itself to "tuning" to the hand of the individual user. Accordingly, the new program is based on a set of functions, each of which measures some characteristic of the sketch over an inverval of variable but specified size and position. Two of the most useful functions are speed and "bentness," which are shown below for a square composed of 95 sample points. Speed measures the length of the interval divided by the number of points in that interval. Bentness measures the maximum of the distances from the points to the chord connecting the endpoints of the interval. By varying the number of points in an interval, the number of peaks in the output can be controlled. A large interval filters out peaks resulting from local, high­frequency variations, while a small interval will show up every tiny variation in the sketch. This interval length is one parameter which can be varied to get the closest fit between the machine's interpretation and the user's in­tentions. For example, if the program were told that the user has drawn a square, it could vary the size of the interval until the two functions pro-The latcher can attach a certainty factor to each of its local decisions, based duced exactly five peaks (remember that one corner, per force unlatched, is on parameters such as speed and line length. These decisions can then be both a beginning point and an endpoint). examined more globally in the light of the criteria mentioned above. Since Given these two functions, they can be combined so as to indicate intended lines and curves. The contributions of the different functions are deter­ mined by a set of coefficients which can be varied for individual users. Bentness is used to find the actual corners in a sketch, while speed is used to indicate whether they are really intended as corners. These functions will eventually be computed by microprocessors, so that the main program will see a tablet which produces not only X, Y and Z but also speed, bentness, corners, and curves. The raw data will still be saved, along with the function values, so that other programs can examine the data. The line/curve finder will be tunable both explicitly and implicitly. Explicit tuning is accomplished through a command which enables the user to modify the program's parameters to produce the most satisfactory result. It is envisioned that implicit tuning will be performed by means of the editor. If the user inserts points, creating corners in the data base, the system can change its parameters to generate more points. If the user deletes points, that serves as an indication that the corner-finding program is generating too many corners. 153 Words About Control Structure Unlike HUNCH, where the user explicitly invoked programs such as STRAIN and LATCH, the new sketching system runs its inference-making procedures in the background, so that they will not cause interruptions in the sketching and thinking processes of the user. Placing the pen on the tablet immediately starts the line/curve finder, adding the new lines and curves to the data base. Whenever the user is not drawing, the higher-level programs, such as OVERTRACE and LATCH, are run. These programs look for any changes or additions to the data base, such as would result from drawing, editing, or running other inference making programs. A program which modifies the input level of another program causes that program to be run. Conversely, any program may decide that its input data level is unsatisfactory and request the program which created that level to regene­rate it, perhaps using new parameters. Latching Revisited In view of the new data base and control structure, it may be useful to examine the metamorphosis of the latcher from a stand-alone program to part of an integrated system. Latching is an interesting problem from many viewpoints. While its ultimate solution requires a knowledge-based system, there are many clues available to the program which are independent of the subject matter being drawn. These include closure, changes in size or angle, and the number of lines latched to a point. those criteria tend to bias the interpretation in certain directions, their use will have to be controlled by a profile of the user created from a history of corrections he makes to the output of the latcher. On a more local level, these corrections can be used to control parameters such as the latching radius. By allowing profiles to be generated on an individual person/subject basis, some of the benefits of subject-area-based systems can be acquired. Another problem in latching is the determination of the scale at which the designer was working. This problem is exemplified by the drawing in Figure 7 where the windows were drawn at a smaller scale than the house. The program, assuming one scale, used two large a latching radius on the windows, latching too many points together. Scale will have to be deter­ mined by use of various clues, such as the "busy-ness" of a part of a sketch, as measured by the density of lines drawn nearby in soace and in time. The sequence of line input can be another useful clue since, for example, the two faces of a cube will probably form two separate clusters if divided by sequence. Once again this is a user-dependent property. CONCLUSION Progress in sketch recognition has in a sense come full circle from an insis­tence on machine recognition with no demands on the user, through knowledge-based systems, and back to a more modest interactive approach. It is our intention to involve the user in the way most meaningful to his design, through editing the machine's interpretation of his drawing to bring it into agreement with his own intentions. Our experiments have shown sketching to be a viable medium through which a person can communicate to a machine. The next question to be answered is. What balance can be struck between an intelligent but unwieldy system, and a tiresome but practical one? article_rec.title: Recognition of three-dimensional objects from orthographic views

abstract.par: This paper presents a program interpreting orthographic drawings input through a digitizing tablet into three-dimensional (3-D) objects. Ambiguity arises in such a task not only in the case of two views but also with three-view inputs, due to coinciding projections of vertices. The main effort consists in heuristically reducing this ambiguity. The general strategy is a bottom-up identification of the objects starting with the tablet-coordinates and aggregating them into vertices, then faces and finally polyhedra. The program does not contain any high level geometrical concepts or probable properties of 3-D objects but only some basic definitions of polyhedra (as expressed by Euler and Mobius). By applying these definitions to different parts of the scene to recognize, it defines local sets of alternatives and then chooses the right ones by running a mini theorem prover over these sets. A major issue in writing this program has been to limit the drawing constraints imposed on the user. In case that it gets blocked in the recognition process, however, the program can require the user's help.

To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania RECOGNITION OF THREE-DIMENSIONAL OBJECTS FROM ORTHOGRAPHIC VIEWS By Gilles Lafue Institute of Physical Planning School of Urban and Public Affairs and Department of Architecture. Carnegie-Mellon University Pittsburgh. Pa. ABSTRACT: This paper presents a program interpreting orthographic drawings input through a digitizing tablet into three­dimensional (3-D) objects. Ambiguity arises in such a task not only in the case of two views but also with three-view inputs, due to coinciding projections of vertices. The main effort consists in heuristically reducing this ambiguity. The general strategy is a bottom-up identification of the objects starting with the tablet-coordinates and aggregating them into vertices, then faces and finally polyhedra. The program does not contain any high level geometrical concepts or probable properties of 3-D objects but only some basic definitions of polyhedra (as expressed by Euler and Mobius). By applying these definitions to different parts of the scene to recognize, it defines local sets of alternatives and then chooses the right ones by running a mini theorem prover over these sets. A major issue in writing this program has been to limit the drawing constraints imposed on the user. In case that it gets blocked in the recognition process, however, the program can require the user's help. INTRODUCTION Investigations and at least one realization have been carried out in using orthographic projections to graphically input three-dimensional objects into a computer [8]. However, it has not been completely satisfactory from the user's standpoint because of the constraining rules that he has to observe in entering data. This paper presents a program translating orthographic projections of objects into a useful three-dimensional shape data structure. Like its predecessor it can not allow curves (they have to be approximated by planar faces) but we believe that it realizes some improvement in reducing other constraints imposed on the user. The program is an input module of a larger system, called BDS, aimed at storing and manipulating 3-D elements relevant to physical design [1], It decomposes the objects that it recognizes into topologies (i.e. sets of non-metric relationships between faces, edges and vertices) and geometries (i.e. sets of coordinates instantiating the topologies) to be transferred to BDS. [2] The input device is a digitizer tablet on which one draws the orthographic views. It records coordinates of points pointed to with a pressure higher than a certain threshold. Thus the user can draw on a sheet of paper put on the tablet with apressure moderate enough to avoid the coordinate recording, in order to keep track of what he is inputting, and press a little harder at vertices that he wants to enter. Two consecutive vertices are assumed to be linked by a straight edge. One of the main changes in input constraints, as compared with the previous program, is the use of the "single pointing" mode instead of the "double pointing" mode. The latter consists in pointing to two projections of a point at a time, so that extracting the 3-D coordinates from the pair of 2-D coordinates is immediate. Views are drawn simultaneously. With the single pointing mode, views are supposed to be independent from each other at input time. They can be entirely drawn one after the other or on different tablets. Associating projections is left to the program. The most obvious advantage of single pointing is its practicability. It is more natural and quicker to concentrate on one view and then deal with another one (note however that the user is still free to go back and forth between views). Another improvement felt by the user is that he does not have to draw every face in a certain direction (clockwise or counter-clockwise) depending on whether it is visible or not. The visible or invisible property of faces and edges is not specified to the program whatsoever. This, combined with the independence of views, frees the user from having in mind a 3-D internal image of objects in order to draw them in two dimensions. Note however that this freedom to "think" in two dimensions is a little impinged on by the fact that it remains firstly that views are to be drawn face-wise (i.e. a view is a collection of faces and not only of edges*), and secondly that all faces projected onto a view (i.e. not perpendicular to it) have to be drawn, whether they are seen or not. Finally, faces can be any closed polyhedron. There is no restriction on the number of vertices that a face can contain but the last vertex must be the same as the first one. This is used to delimitate faces at input time. The single pointing input mode is the source of most of the differences between the approach adopted here and in previous works. As it will become clear later on, associating projections often generates ambiguity, which may not sound surprising as long as two views are given but also remains true with three views (although to a lesser extent). Such ambiguity results in assuming more vertices (and consequently faces) than actually exist and therefore necessitates some device to depict and eliminate the surplus vertices. Our decision has been to supply the program with some means to cope with it rather than to oblige the user to avoid it. FIG. 1 Ambiguities of edge-wise input. (b) is the top view of (a). What vertices are linked: 1 and 2, 1and 3, 1 and 4, 2 and 3, 2 and 4 or 3 and 4 ? Because of these surplus vertices, object recognition is achieved through agenerate-and-test strategy. We often need information about what is possible before knowing what is true. On the other hand, in many cases, the difference between the number of possible faces and the number of true faces is small. The problem is not to select a small subset of a large set of alternatives with a simple evaluation function but rather to select a relatively large subset of a limited set of alternatives with a more complicated evaluation function. The input recognition is primarily bottom-up. Initially the system is only given a stream of tablet-coordinates, that is, atomic pieces of information. From coordinate pairs it has to recognize the particular polyhedra meant by the user as expressed in his drawing. The program does not contain a sophisticated network of high level geometrical concepts allowing recognition of objects of most common topologies on global properties and making good guesses in ambiguous situations such as in human recognition and some previous work in machine vision [3], [9]. It only knows a few basic properties of edges and vertices. The emphasis has been on generality. No decision is based on particularities of some shapes or topologies but on general laws. The objects to be interpreted are what we call Bodies, namely polyhedra that can be assigned avolume. A polyhedronis a system of polygons arranged in such a way that exactly two polygons meet (at an angle) at every edge and that it is possible to get from every polygon to every other polygon bycrossing edges of the polyhedron. Mobius has shown, however,that some closed polyhedra cannot be assigned any volume (e.g.,the heptahedron, the Mobius's strip, Klein's bottle) but, by considering line-segments, areas and volumes as relative magnitudes, as derived from analytic geometry, he also proved that, in order to have a volume, a polyhedron must be two-sided* (i.e.,every face has one external side and one internal side) and that if every face is followed in a given direction (clockwise or counterclockwise) on a given side (internal or external) then every edge is followed not only twice but also in oppposite directions [4],[5]. We shall call faces drawn by the user P-Faces (for Projected Face) in order to distinguish them from spatial faces (that we simply call Faces). A Face is projected onto two or three P-Faces. Similarly, we distinguish P-Edges and Edges as well as P-Vertices and Vertices. Holes in Faces are allowed under the condition that the user adds artificial P-Edges to the P-Faces containing them. A hole in a Face yields two disconnected rings of Vertices, which violates the Face definition. Therefore, in order to avoid interpreting such a Face as two different Faces, the two separate Vertices rings have to be artificially connected (cf. fig. 2). As one can see in fig. 2, holes are not the only features requiring P-Faces to be drawn with artificial Edges: every closed chain of Edges that does not separate the Body into two regions requires such an EdgeA. Of course, artificial Edges cannot be considered as other Edges, and in particular they are not analyzed (cf. 3.2). FIG. 2. Examples of input where artificial edges are needed to connect separate rings in a same face. -1-VERTICES IDENTIFICATION. 1.1.Initializations Before all else the user is asked to initialize a few basic variables: Firstly, he specifies his drawing tolerance. Most tablets have a resolution greater than hand precision, and for this reason a coordinate system with unit equal to the drawing tolerance is mapped onto the original tablet system. Coordinates of all points falling into a given coordinate zone of the drawing tolerance system will be standardized. This way, not only can the user define the precision desired but orthogonality to ground lines is also insured. Secondly, he defines ground lines. He does so by entering a point whose y-coordinate will define the horizontal ground line and then by entering apoint whose x-coordinate will define the vertical ground line. He can ignore one of the two if he wants to input only two views. Thirdly, he chooses the interpretation mode: single-body mode in which bodies are inputted and interpreted one by one or multiple-body mode in which sets of bodies are inputted and interpreted at a time. 1.2. Vertices Identification. Orthographic projection is considered here by itself and not as a subdomain of perspective. Transforming a set of two or three 2-D coordinates into a 3-D vertex is therefore straightforward and does not require an algorithm allowing for the general case of perspective (when the eye is not infinitely far away) such as the ingenious one developed by Parke [7] and Sutherland [8]. First, by comparing the tablet coordinates of the projections with those of the ground lines, projections of vertices are sorted into two or three views and tablet coordinate pairs are transformed into 3-D coordinate pairs. Then, in one view, say P1, each P-Vertex is associated with the set of P-Vertices of the view P2 sharing with it the same value of the coordinate common to P1 and P2. The same process is followed with the third view P3, if any. Then, each P-Vertex of the set from P2 is associated with the P-Vertex of the set from P3 sharing with it the same value of the coordinate common to P2 and P3, if any, and a 3-D vertex is identified by combining this pair of coordinates with that of the initial P-Vertex from P1. When all P-Vertices of P1 have thus been treated, all Vertices are identified and in the P-Faces, each P-Vertex is now associated with the set of Vertices projected onto it. Clearly, in the case of a two view input, more Vertices are likely to be generated than in athreeview one because the selection of P-Vertices from P2 through matching with those from P3 does not exist. Furthermore, even with three views, non-existing Vertices can be generated merely because there exists a triplet of P-Vertices on which they could be projected. This is the source of all troubles. (cf. fig. 3). -2-EDGES AND FACES IDENTIFICATION. We are now provided with two types of information: P-Faces and Vertices. Their combination should give Edges and Faces. A distinction must be introduced now between two types of Edges and Faces due to the orthographic representation mode. Side Faces are perpendicular to two projection planes. They are particularly troublesome in the case of two-view inputs since they are not projected anywhere and consequently not drawn. The definition of Side Face is limited to two-view inputs. Side Edges are Edges belonging to Side Faces. Drawn Faces are Faces that are not Side Faces. They have been drawn by the user on at least one view. FIG. 3. Example of non existing possible vertices. No vertex is projected on (1,1',1") and (2,2',2") although vertices 1 and 2 would be very possible. 2.1. Drawn Faces Identification. Identifying Drawn Faces consists in selecting for each P-Face all the sequences of Vertices projected onto it that can form a Face. A Face is a planar sequence of existing Edges. A Drawn Edge exists if and only if it is projected onto all the views to which it is not perpendicular. Several simple heuristics are used to reduce the searches involved in this process. 2.2 Side Faces Identification Since the information available on Side Faces is null we have to make assumptions about them. The basic assumption is that their edges are perpendicular to the views and consequently orthogonal to each other. Vertices belonging to a same Side plane are quickly identified by having a common coordinate and are gathered. Then, within a side plane, Edges are preselected, i.e.,their existence is declared either False or Possible before the Face identification process according to their perpendicularity to the views. Side Face identification is conceptually and computationnaly different from Drawn Face identification because the given information is no longer Vertices and P-Faces but Side Vertices, Side Edges and Drawn Faces. The lack of P-Faces makes it less rigorous than the general Face identification, but, on the other hand, it is performed after the identification of Drawn Faces and takes advantage of the information that these latter contain. The principle of Side Face Identification is to generate all Possible Side Faces containing a Possible Side Edge when this latter does not yet belong to any Side Face. In order to be Possible a Side Edge must belong to at least one Drawn Face (see B-Rule (3), 3.1). In addition, it is ensured that Side Faces do not contain Side Edges crossing each other, which is simple to do, due to orthogonality of Side Edges. -3- FACES SELECTION The Faces (Side or Drawn) generated during the Face Identification process are Possible. Our goal now is to sort True Faces and False Faces. The solution state of the object recognition at any of its stages is represented by the ambiguity measure consisting inthe number of Faces whose existence is Possible. This process is described here for single body objects. A later section deals with multiplebody objects Face selection. A Face is projected onto every view to which it is not perpendicular. Therefore, the way our Face identification process works, the same Face will appear in each of these projection planes. This is recognized and as soon as one of them is assigned an existential value True or False, this value is also assigned to the other ones and then only one instance of F1 is kept. Whenever a Face is declared True all its edges and vertices are also declared True. However, that an Edge is True does not necessarily mean that all the Faces containing it are True but only that two of them are. Similarly, that aVertex is declared True implies that at least three of the Faces containing it must be True. The general principle is to gather Faces having a common property into sets (called B-Sets). A property defining aB- Set, for example, can be to contain agiven Edge or a given Vertex. In addition, to each type of B-Set there corresponds a rule (called B-Rule) that determines the minimum and the maximum number of Possible Faces contained in the current B-Set which can be True. In other words, in a B-Set, the onlything known about the subset defined by the Possible Faces which happen to be True is the lower and upper bounds of its cardinal. Along the selection process, the difference between the cardinal of a B-Set and the cardinal of its subset of True Faces will hopefully decrease, until it becomes 0. At this point, the subset is fully defined; all the Faces of the B-Set (possibly zero) are declared True. When several B-Sets intersect each other, that is,when they contain at least one common Face, their intersection is analysed with the help of a mini theorem prover which will hopefully result in eliminating some Faces and keeping others. 3.1. B-Rules. There are four different B-Rules: (1) The number of Trues Faces containing agiven Edge is 2 if the Edge is True and 0 or 2 if it is only Possible (by definition). (2) The number of True Faces in which agiven Edge has a given direction equals the number of True Faces in which it has the opposite direction. This is the Mobius'complement to polyhedra definition. (3) There cannot be more than one True Face containing a given Edge and belonging to a given plane (Since we are dealing in this section with single objects, two adjacent coplanar Faces are in fact one single Face). (4) The number of True Faces containing agiven vertex is at least 3 if the Vertex is True and either 0or at least 3 if it is only Possible. 3.2.Edge Analysis To apply B-Rules (1), (2) or (3) to agiven Edge generatesthree B-Sets. It might happen that two of them, or even all of them, are identical. In this case, of course, only one B-Set is generated. Formally, this analysis is implemented as a set of productions whose conditions are instantiations of B-Rules into the current edge's context and whose actions are to generate the proper B-Sets. Since B-Sets contain only Possible Faces, the number of True Faces already containingthe given Edge is taken into account when fixing the minima and maxima defined by the B-Rules. Obviously, it is more rewarding to analyse True Edges than Possible Edges because the corresponding B-Rules are more constraining. 3.3. Vertices Analysis. Similarly, it is fruitful to analyse Vertices by applying B- Rule (4). It is certainly so to generate a B-Set for aTrue Vertex, but when a Vertex is only Possible, more than generating a B-Set by applying the B-Rule (4) which is rather "weak" for Possible Vertices, and waiting for it to be involved in a theorem-proving session, we would prefer to find out right away if it can be True. This is a relatively long process but it might significantly reduce the whole recognition time given that surplus Vertices are the source of all troubles. To estimate whether aPossible Vertex can be True or not is done as follows: Let S be the set of Possible Faces containing a Possible Vertex V. We want to determine the minimum and maximum number of Possible Faces of S that can be True from the knowledge we currently have about them, i.e.,the existing B-Sets containing them. If the minimum is equal to or greater than 3 then V is True and if the maximum is less than 3 then V is False. Also, if S is partitioned into disjoint sets,then the maximum number of its Faces that can be True is the sum of such maxima in each subset, and so is its minimum. Existing B-Sets containing subsets of Sare combined into disjoint subsets of S whose minima and maxima are computed from those B-Sets from which they are derived. If then the minimum is still less than 3 or the maximum more than 3, then V remains Possible. Finally, a Vertex can be eliminated in another type of situation, namely if it is situated between the Vertices of a True Edge. 3.4. Initializations. The first B-Sets. Some B-sets, the first ones chronologically defined, are not generated from B-rules but are derived from the problemstate such as at the end of the Faces identification processAll the Possible Faces projected on a given P-Face are identified at the same time and gathered in aset (cf. 2.1).If a P-Face has been drawn several times, it indicates that the user meant that several Faces are projected onto this P-Face (The user can draw a P-Face several times without doing so consecutively). To know the number of times a P-Face has been drawn is to know the number of Possible Faces projectedonto this P-Face that must be True*. To determine the number of True Faces in a set of Side faces is different. From the Sfde Face identification process and B-Rule (3), it follows than no more than one Side Face can contain a given Side Edge. 3.5.The Mini Theorem Prover If a Face belongs to several B-Sets it is possible, and even probable, that its existent@ will be determined. So, whenever a Face F is presenl in more than three B-Sets the theorem prover is run*. The B-sets become its axioms and the theorems to prove arc that ellher F IS True or F is False. The value True or False is given lo F end thir value prababfy implies values ol ofher Faces in fhe various fl-Sets. These values are carried over m other B-Sets and SO on until the theorem is either proved or refuted. A theorem is proved when no more Faces of the B-Sets constituting its domain can be assigned an existential value. In that case no concMon can be drawn because the fact that it is true in the context defined by the current B-sets does not imply its universality. On the other hand, if it is False in at least this context, it implies that it cannot be True. 4 theorem 1s refuted when the existential value assigned to a Face violates an axiom, namely when it brings the cardinal of a B-Set out of its range (see example on fig. 4).
