Example of a simple theorem proving. 0 The number three has been estimated to generally provide reasonable chances to lead the theorem prover to some result but there is nothing absolute &out it. 3.6.Face Direction. The interesting property Of the Faces composing B-Sets formed by applying B-Rule (2) is no longer their existence but their direction. B-Sets. thus built contain Faces of unknown direction and their bounded subsets contain Faces of a given direction (specified so as to ensure the equilibrium dictated in instantiating B-Rule (2)). If the cardinal of such a B-Set equals that of its subset, then all its Faces will have the specified directton. 11 a newly oriented Face is Possible, then it is given a * presumed direction. We do not know yet if it is True er not but we know that if it is, then its direction will be as just specilied. Therefore, if later on, during a similar process, it IS assigned d presumed direction opposed to this one, it can be killed. -4-BODY 1DENTIFICATION Because of the general principle that a good solution state is likely to lead to a better solution state (without proof of convergence in our case though), the different processes of the recognition are applied in the order of their strength. When a Face is declared True, then it IS put in a stack SO that its Edges will get enalyzed. I1 is put at the top of the slack if its directhan is defined and at the bottom if not To slarl, a djrecjion is gjueh lo Lhc TIUE FJC~ which is the most connected to other True Fates, so that its own Edges and many other anes will bet a dIrection, If there is no True Face at the beginning, then the first True Face is given a direction. When it occurs that there are no more True Faces to analyse on the stack, several things can happen. If there is no more Possible Faces, then Faces are combined into a body and the recognition is achieved. If there are still some Possible Vertices, then they are analyssd in the way described in 3.2. If there are still some posrhble Faces, then they are analysed. When no new True Faces can possibly be generated, r.e. when the program remains blocked, then it requires the user 5 help by questioning the existence of a Possible Vertex. rhis is usually a relatively easy question 10 answer, but the user is free to rgnore it. Finally, if none of these attempts produce any Improvement, then the program asks for a third view in the case that only two were given or else states its failure to recognize the input. -5-MULTIPLE BODY INPUTS Multiple body inputs are also recognized by the program, although with less certainty. Diflerences between the two modes appear in the two main phases: Face identification and selection and Body identification. ln the former, they are not really essential and just loosen a l~tlle the efficiency of Face selection (ch\efIy by enlarging the renge of B-Sets cardinals). In the laiter, they debne Ihe real sperifjrily of the multiple body mode. Unfortunately, they also constltute the weakest part of the multiple body object recognition. The number bf alternatives for the Face adjacent to a given Face in a particular Body can be quite large (not reduced to a single possibility like in the single body mode) and the heuristics to choose it are not very powerful [6]. 107 -6- IMPLEMENTATION ISSUES AND CONCLUSION. This program written in BLISS-10, is currently implemented on a PDP-10. It is in the process of being transferred to a PDP 11/20 and fully integrated into BDS. article_rec.title: Controlling user interaction

abstract.par: The user of an interactive application is in an anamolous position, especially if he is not one of the elite class known as "computer bums". This mythical user is at the end of a process totally controlled by a computer and a program. His communications with the program may suffer greatly because of this total dependence.Control of communication in the batch environment is much more a one-way street. Here the user supplies the program data, and the batch program informs him if something has gone wrong by evicting his run from the machine. The user then consults available documentation (if it exists) or a computer expert (if one exists) for help in solving the problem. The communication between program and user is not critical in this environment; the user is expected to know what to do before he starts the run and can seek assistance outside of the computer.The interactive environment, however, has the user totally at the mercy of the program for diagnostic and prompting information. Even sophisticated graphics-oriented applications, which provide large amounts of useful information through pictures, may not adequately control the user's interaction. The user needs direction imposed on him to successfully solve his problem. At the same time, the system must provide flexibility, i.e., he must not be constrained to a single path of action that may only suit the code's implementor. No user's manual can capture a flow of this nature because of the inherently static nature of words on paper. Furthermore, paging back and forth in a manual to decipher what is to be done next destroys the spontaneity implicit in a successful interactive system.The user must be the main concern of the interactive system for it to be successful. With this goal in mind, Battelle-Columbus has developed a structured approach to controlling user interaction. The approach benefits the implementor as well as the user. It places emphasis on design and checkout of interaction as the first, rather than the last, step in an interactive application.

fulltext.ft_body: CONTROLLING USER INTERACTION David J. Kasik Battelle Columbus Laboratories Columbus, Ohio 43201 1. INTRODUCTION The user of an interactiveapplication is inan anamolous position, especially if he isnot one of the elite class known as "computer bums". This mythical user isat the end of a process totally controlled by a computer and a program. His com­munications with the program may suffer greatly because of this total dependence. Control of communication in the batch environment ismuch more a one-way street. Here the user supplies the program data, and the batch program informs him if something has gone wrong by evict­ing his run from the machine. The user then con­sults available documentation (if it exists) or a computer expert (ifone exists) for help insolv­ing the problem. The communication between pro­gram and user is not critical in this environment; the user is expected to know what to do before he starts the run and can seek assistance outside of the computer. The interactive environment, however, has the user totally at the mercy of the program for diagnostic and prompting information. Even soph­isticated graphics-oriented applications,which provide large amounts of useful information through pictures, may not adequately control the user's interaction. The user needs direction imposed on him to successfully solve his problem. At the same time, the system must provide flexi­bility, i.e., he must not be constrained to a single path of action that may only suit the code's implementor. No user's manual can capture a flow of this nature because of the inherently static nature of words on paper. Furthermore, paging back and forth ina manual to decipher what is to be done next destroys the spontaneity implicit in a successful interactive system. The user must be the main concern of the interac­tive system for it to be successful. With this goal inmind, Battelle-Columbus has developed a structured approach to controlling user interac­tion. The approach benefits the implementor as well as the user. Itplaces emphasis on design and checkout of interaction as the first, rather than the last, step in an interactive application. Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. 109 Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 2. ALTERNATIVES Indesigning a large interactive application for the U.S. Air Force ),Battelle-Columbusbecame acutely aware of the lack of tools for controlling interaction. Although many successful interactive application from budget planningL to forging die designN ) are available at Battelle, no coher­ent mechanism was present to attack the problem. Most of the systems were keyboard oriented and ranged insophistication from excellent software string crackers to FORTRAN READ statements. One of the early decisions made in the project was to orient the task toward the Control Data CYBER Graphics alV"). Terminal, a large screen refresh termin­To avoid the need of long type-ins, the lightpen was chosen to be the general input mech­anism. The user can control the program by a series of picks from a menu of messages on the screen. Because of the breadth of the application, we decided to develop a tool for generating menus automaticallybefore attacking the actual problem. Three approaches were examined and discarded before the actual mechanism of a tree was chosen. The problem that needed to be overcome was one of se­mantic rather than syntactic validation because a lightpen strike easily detects the exact wish of the user. The first possibility was to adapt the finite state table(5) (Fig. 1) to the task. The state table isparticularly effective inparsing appli­cations. This approach proved to be unsatisfac­tory because the user would be constrained to one path. The detection of alternatives once a path is started is difficult without special case test­ing. The table isalso difficult to construct initially for the same reason. Finally, the table has no convenient mechanism for retreating to a previous node without going back to the start of the testing procedure. FIGURE 1. FINITE STATE TABLE (GRAPHICALPRESENTATION) The second possibility, a key-word table, has the same problems as the finite state table: difficult to detect alternatives, difficult in initial con­ struction, and no selective retreat. It is even less desirable because the one direction of con­ trol in the state table is not provided without special case testing. The third and least attractivemethod utilizes a series of IF tests that expand seemingly without bound. The interactive program controller may ultimately take more room than the working por­ tions of the program because the entire control­ ling mechanism has become a special case. All the previously described ills occur and are compounded. Changing one module may affect another module of the application, which may affect another, ad infinitum. The structure that overcomes all of these problems as well as offering some distinct advantages isa triply linked tree (Fig. 2). The tree explicitly links legal alternatives and offers a clear path back to the top, thus avoiding the main disadvan­tages of the state table. In implementing the "command tree", we have devised a generator and processor that are application free, thus making the tree usable by interactive application. 3. ADVANTAGES OF APPROACH The command tree concept offers distinctadvantages for both the interactive user and programmer. A large application can easily overwhelm an inter­ active user by being overflexible. The user may not know what direction to follow. Through the command tree, the user now receives: a knowledge of what he isexpected to do via prompting messages definitions of individual commands on request a historical record of prior choices FIGURE 2. TRIPLY LINKED TREE . ability to skip levels up and down .confidence inunified program responses. The command tree offers the user assistance in his decision making in two ways. On a large scale, the user isconfronted by a series of choices in a menu. He may be required to interactwith the picture in front of him before selecting again. Through the use of prompting messages, the user can be told what he isexpected to do next. While a prompting message can aid the user in his direction, he may need additional explanation about the actual meaning of a command. Through the use of the tree's help feature, the user can retrieve the definition of a command at any step. The tree thus aids the user inchoosing a path through the application and deciphering what particular commands mean. The user may also want to know how he reached a certain point inthe application. Because of the linkage in the tree, reconstructingthe path traced by the user is straightforward. The user can ask the system for an immediate playback of the actions he has taken. The above features aid a novice user. The exper­ienced user must also be considered in the design process for an interactiveapplication. He may know precisely what he wants to do without prompt­ ing messages or traversal of individual levels. The linkage in the tree and the setting of defaults within the application easily allows rapid tra­ versal. This tool isparticularly effective when the user has reached the end of a particular path and wishes to return to a much higher level. For example, he may have constructed a display and now wishes to zoom on the drawing. Through the skip feature, he can enter a picture modification section rapidly. Structuring a program's responses offers one final advantage for the user. As an application increases in size and complexity, numerous people will add sections of code. One continuing diffi­culty is that each individual programmer may impose his own "style" to interaction. By usino a single generator and driver, the same approach to interaction isprovided for all modules of the application. Both the novice and experienced user will know what to expect when new modules are added to the system. This helps the user imme­diately learn the features of a new module rather than anticipate a change in interaction mechanics. The programmer also benefits from the command tree. It simplifies his task by allowing the structuring of interaction before coding begins making the interaction steps easy to debug, update, and maintain calling the interaction service routines and traversing the tree automaticallythrough a small, general driver. Perhaps the most important single advantage of the command tree is to allow the programmerto con­struct interaction before programming begins. The programmer specifies each step in the interactive procedure explicitly, including prompting messages and help definition. This allows a top-down approach to the actual programming task. By using this approach, subtasks can be assigned without concern about the interactive flow. This approach makes the construction of interaction most impor­tant in the design rather than the construction of a particular subtask. Construction of the menus requires no more than preparation of a data file. The entire sequence can be set up and tested without the generation of application code. Inthis manner, the programmer can insure that the interaction works as designed before getting bogged down in code implementation. Similarly, pieces of large trees can be split out and exercized in parallel. Updates and changes to the menus can be made to the data file, avoiding costly recompilations and testing of newly developed code. Maintenance is also simpli­fied. The data file is in an easy to read format and contains enough information to be self­documenting. A program to traverse the resultant tree provides a rapid summary of the entire inter­action mechanism. In short, the interaction is totally centralized for an entire application. A general driver is provided to handle all types of lightpen picks and type-ins. After receiving a user input, the driver branches to the program­mer's processing subroutine. The programmer specifies the action to be taken next in travers­ing the command tree (go down n levels, go up n levels, stay on this level). If an error occurs, the processing subroutine can override the tra­verse action. For example, the user may make an error ina type-in. The processing subroutine can override the requested action, display an appropriate error message, and force the user to correct the bad values. The driver isalso com­pact, allowing more space for the programmer's own code. 4. IMPLEMENTATION The command tree is currently operational on Battelle's CDC 6400 computer system operating under SCOPE 3.4.x. It is a FORTRAN based system and consists of two modules. An overview of the system is given in Fig. 3. The generation phase isa stand-alone program. It communicates the programmer's command tree to the driver through a random-accessdisk file and an internally generated machine language program. The driver uses these two pieces to control the user's interaction and automatically branch to the programmer's processing subroutines. The command tree generator formats an interaction description for the driver. The programmerneed only supply the description as a free-format data file. The data file is structured only by a level specification for each command. As the level num­ber increases, the depth into the tree increases. An example of a user formatted data file isgiven in Fig. 4. FIGURE 3. COMMAND FLOW 15, N = "MODIFY PICTURE", A = 2, T = 5, 16, L = -1, P = "SELECT MODE BY WHICH PICTURE WILL BE CHANGED", 16, N = "LOCALLY", A = 2, T = 5, 17, L = -1, P = "CHANGE PICTURE OR RESTORE TO SAME AS WHEN ENTERED",17, N = "TRACK ON", A = 4, T = 6, 17, N = "TRACK OFF", A = 4, T = 6, 17, N = "COMPACT", A = 4, T = 6, 17, N = "ENLARGE", A = 4, T = 6, 17, N = "RECENTER", A = 4, T = 6, 17, N = "RESTORE", S = MOBOTH, A = 4, T = 5,17, N = "RETURN", A = -1, T = 5, 16, N = "SPLIT", S = MOSPLT, A = 2, T = 5,17, L = -1, P = "GENERATE LEFT SIDE OR RESTORE ONE SIDE TO FULL SCREEN",17, N = "SAVE ONE SIDE", S = ONPENA, A = 2, T = 5,P = "PICK AN ITEM ON THE SIDE TO BE SAVED, THEN RETURN", 18, N = "RETURN", S = MOSOS, D = -2, A = 1, T = 5,17, N = "FREEZE LEFT SIDE", S = MOFRZ, = -1, T A = 5,17, N = "FREE LEFT SIDE", S = MOFRE, A = -1, T = 5,17, N = "RETURN", A = -1, T= 5, 16, N = "SHRINK MEMBERS 80%", S = MOSSHK, A = 2, T = 5, 17, L = -1, P = "SELECT MEMBERS ON SCREEN OR ALL",17, N = "ALL", S = MOASHK, A = -1, T = 5, 17, N = "CHOOSE MEMBERS", S = ONPENS, A = 2, T = 5, P = "SELECT MEMBERS ON SCREEN TO BE SHRUNK, THEN RETURN",18, N = "RETURN", S = MOISHK, A = 1, T = 5, D = -1,17, N = "RETURN", S = MOUSHK, A = -1, T = 5,16, N = "CHANGE PLOT LIMITS", A = 2, T = 5,17, L = -1, P = "CHOOSE COORDINATE SYSTEM", 17, N = "RECTANGULAR", S = MOREC, A = 2, T = 5, FIGURE 4. SAMPLE DATA FILE 18, S = MODRW, A = -2, L = -1, P = "PICK EDIT, ENTER NEW VALUES, THEN ETX", 18, N = "EDIT", A = 4, T = 6, 18, N = "RETURN", A = -1, T = 6, 17, N = "POLAR", S = MOCYL, A = 2, T = 5, 18, S = MODRW, A = -2, L = -1, P = "PICK EDIT, ENTER NEW VALUE, THEN ETX", 18, N = "EDIT", A = 4, T = 6, 18, N = "RETURN", A = -1, T = 6, 17, N = "FILL SPACE", S = MOFILL, A = -1, T = 5, 17, N = "RETURN", A = -1, T = 5, 16, N = "RESTORE ORIGINAL PICTURE", S = MOZRS, A = 4, T = 5, 16, N = "RETURN", A = -1, T = 5, FIGURE 4. SAMPLE DATA FILE (continued) The flow contained in Fig. 4 will produce an ini- Ifthe user then picks "LOCALLY", all level 17's tial menu containing "MODIFY PICTURE" (i.e., all modifying "LOCALLY" will appear: promptingmes­ level 15's). After picking that word, the user sage "CHANGE PICTURE OR RESTORE TO SAME AS WHEN will see the prompting message "SELECT MODE BY ENTERED", and menu items WHICH PICTURE WILL BE CHANGED" and menu selection items of all level 16: TRACK ON LOCALLY TRACK OFF SPLIT SCREEN COMPACT SHRINK MEMBERS 80% ENLARGE CHANGE PLOT LIMITS RECENTER RESTORE ORIGINAL PICTURE RESTORE RETURN RETURN FIGURE 5. LINKAGES FOR FIGURE 4 Fig. 5 shows the system linkages involved for this number is encountered. The contents of each new example. level are described in Table 1. The tree is gen- erated as a random access disk file using the The generator decodes the file as each new level Research and Development Center's Data TABLE 1. LEVEL CONTENTS Field Meaning Number Integer descriptor of level number N [ame] Menu name to appear on screen for pick S [ubroutine] Subroutine to call upon picking the name L [ocation] Location (relative) name is to be placed in a screen A [ction] Action to be taken in tree after subroutine is complete T D [meI [efault] Type Default of pick values for to name be supplied by programmer. Up to 50 can be associated with any name. P [rompt] Prompting message H [elpl Definition of name. The generator produces the father, son, and level linkage needed to construct the tree. The scheme is a generalization of the method described by Knuth.(7) The level linkage is circular rather than one-way. The generator also provides one assembly language routine containing a linkage table to all of the subroutines specified in the data file. This routine is to be inserted with the programmer's own subroutines. The linked data file is then processed as the con-troller of the application's subprograms. The driver first places each name comprising the menu on the screen. Picks from another part of the screen can be queued before a menu item is picked. The menu name pick acts as the trigger for pro-cessing the queue and the driver calls the speci-fied subroutine. After returning from theroutine, the tree proceeds to the next specified level. The driver consumes less than 400 decimal words of core and centralizes all interaction processing in one routine. Core requirements are low because of use of the random disk file. 5. EVALUATION OF RESULTS The command tree is fully operational in both of its phases. It is currently the basis for a large application involving finite element model analy-sis being developed at Battelle. The net result of this effort has been excellent. The implement-ation time has been much less than expected be-cause of the top-down approach to programming. The command tree was structured and given to engineers for evaluation well before actual coding began. Although only the menus appeared on the screen, the engineers could grasp how the flow of the application would progress and their comments helped refine the menus greatly. The concept has been readily adopted and applied by others. Structuring a user's input through a tree gives implementors much more flexibility than the conventional approach. This is particularly true of non-computer oriented engineers, who most often code their interaction as a series of cum-bersome keyboard inputs even when working at a refresh-type terminal. The program for command tree generation is readily transferrable to other devices. The tree is gen-erated independently of the mode of user input. It could be adapted easily to a total keyboard in-put environment through a re-written driver. The checking of input commands is greatly simplified because legal commands are constrained to a subset automatically by the tree. Through another small modification, the experienced user could easily queue typed-in commands for automatic processing by the system. The concept of the command tree provides a useful tool in controlling user interaction. It has proved itself advantageous for both the user and implementor of interactive applications. article_rec.title: A computer-terminal, hardware/software system with enhanced user input capabilities
article_rec.subtitle: the enhanced-input terminal system (EITS)

abstract.par: The Enhanced-Input Terminal project is directed at providing major new degrees of freedom for touch-type computer input, especially for on-line use of interactive computer systems. The terminal comprises an integrated of hardware and software. While various choices are available for the actual input and output devices, the present prototype utilizes video display for both devices and a "cross-wire", touch-sensitive input panel. The EITS allows an "author" to define an essentially infinite set of symbols, and an infinite variety of "keyboard" formats. Chord inputs (i.e., simultaneous, multiple-"key" combinations) are also supported. Symbols can be defined in terms of dot matrices, generalized graphics, symbol strings, and functional operations. In spite of the complete generality afforded, the integrated system develops a standard-type of binary-bit-coded input stream, in which the individual symbols are uniquely and canonically represented, and which is amenable to all of the usual "text-file" operations, such as character manipulation, editing, transmission and re-display.

fulltext.ft_body: A COMPUTER-TERMINAL,HARDWARE/SOFTWARESYSTEM WITH ENHANCED USER INPUT CAPABILITIES: THE ENHANCED-INPUTTERMINAL SYSTEM (EITS)* Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Roy Kaplow and Michael Molnar Department of Materials Science and Engineering Massachusetts Institute of Technology Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139 The Enhanced-InputTerminal project isdirected at providing major new degrees of freedom for touch-type computer input, especially for on-line use of interactive computer systems. The terminal comprises an integrated system of hardware and software. While various choices are available for the actual input and output devices, the present prototype utilizes video display for both devices and a "cross-wire", touch-sensitive input panel. The EITS allows an "author" to define an essentially infinite set of symbols, and an infinite variety of "keyboard" formats. Chord inputs (i.e., simultaneous, multiple-"key" combinations) are also supported. Symbols can be defined interms of dot matrices, generalized graphics, symbol strings, and functional oper­ ations. Inspite of the complete generality afforded, the integrated system develops a standard­ type of binary-bit-coded input stream, in which the individual symbols are uniquely and canonically represented, and which is amenable to all of the usual "text-file" operations, such as character manipulation, editing, transmission and re-display. 1. GENERAL CONSIDERATIONSREGARDING USER INPUT TERMINALS Over the past decade, there has been a slow evo­ lution towards greater sophistication inmass­ produced computer terminals, yielding more favorable combinations of various benefits: * lower cost * higher speed * local editing * quieter operation * graphics display * limited choice of symbol sets Some of these, of course, have been achieved at the expense of local hard copy, by using a video­display, storage-CRT or plasma panel without a copy device. Nonetheless, significant limitations remain, particularly regarding user input. 2. THE MAJOR LIMITATIONS OF STANDARD INPUT TERMINALS 2.1 LIMITED SYMBOL SET The first and most noticeable limitation is in the small number of standard input symbols. The primary means of communication from the user to the computer is keyboard input of alphanumeric symbols. Unfortunately,that communication is often hampered by being forced within the con­fines of a limited number of symbols, usually a 116 subset of the USASCII 1968 standard set* of 95 printable characters. The limitation on the number of symbols available for a user task re­ sults from the nature of existing terminal/ keyboard devices and of their supporting input/ output software, both of which are based on the premise that a fixed and relatively small number of symbols will suffice. As terminal/keyboards have evolved from typewriters, this concept has no doubt seemed a reasonable one, with each sug­ gested deviation from standardness being subjected to its proper scrutiny.** Operationally, this limitation may not have seemed unduly restrictive inmany quarters. Indeed, the concept of defining the available symbols, or groups of symbols, to have special meanings under particular circumstances has allowed the standard symbol set to do more than double duty.Thus.+ and ** and .P.have all three been used to mean "raise to the power"; "0 backspace -" may mean arb f(x)"; and "A.SUB.i+j"may mean "Ai+j". In "the greek letter theta"; "INT(a,b,f,x)" may mean an environment inwhich much of the serious communica­tion from the user to the computer is still *ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstu = vwxyz 0123456789!"#$%&' ()*+,-./:; {}~ **It would appear, however, that even though type­writers were used as the base for design, in­adequate weight was given to the prevalence of special symbol and font-style devices, and to the skill with which most typists handle the carriage roll for off-line placement. referred to as "writing code" such conventions are readily accepted. And yet, there are signs that the situation is increasingly less satisfactory, particularly as the user group becomes less dom­ inated by computer professionals and demi­ professionals. Consider, for instance, a student of physics, using a computerized tutorial on the wave equation [1,2] and faced with a question that requires a mathematical response which would have the following appearance innormal notation: With a standard terminal, and following rules given in the tutorial referred to, he will have to type in something like: It isworth emphasizing that the notation exhib­ited isderived from a reasonably well-conceived scheme which tends to minimize the potential awk­ wardness. Moreover, it takes advantage of the fact that the response analyzer in the system being used [3] handles overstrike (multiple stroke) symbols; otherwise itwould have been necessary to spell out the Greek letters: These alternate forms are not desirable in in­structional applications because they require the student to learn extraneous codes and because they stress notational schemes different from those used in the published literature and in textbooks. They are also troublesome because the particular notational conventions are relatively arbitrary; the convention adopted by one author islikely to be different from his colleagues' and different from the conventions used inalgorithmic program­ming languages, such as Fortran, Cobol, MAD, etc. These languages, inturn, use conventions which differ from one to another. Thus, the use of a limited, standard symbol set (which does not in­clude the natural symbols (or positioning) of particular applications paradoxically tends to lead to a diversity rather than a uniformity notation. This isdistracting and confusing, particularly in an educational situation. Another interesting type of example, which stresses the differences between display and input capabilities, can be drawn from a report on a sophisticated,multi-charactercathode-ray­ type display terminal developed at the MIT Electronic Systems Laboratory, for use in libraries, as part of the Intrex project [4]. The partial line of text illustrated below (in quotes) represents a significant step beyond the display capability of run-of-the-mill terminals. The use of superscripts and subscripts and of non­ standard symbols allows the chemical formula in the line to be represented on the display in its standard form [5]: 117 The same report also explains how that information must be input: The augmented display capability illustrated above iscertainly valuable in its own right. However there is less advantage in its use if the user must train himself to use the different inputting code. It is perhaps surprising that the latter form isas readable as it is; for a person un­ familiar with chemistry itmight even be more readable than the correctly displayed form. As an input scheme for "chemists", however, spelling out the nonstandard symbols and format in English­like text is at best a tedious and error-prone option. Other schemes, deviating further and further from the standard symbol set, have been developed in response to the continuing pressure for more and different input symbols. One approach has been to replace the entire standard keyboard symbol set with another one, specially designed for a spe­ cific application. Perhaps the best known example of this is an APL terminal, for which the keyboard labels and type head are changed to provide a unique set of symbols, the symbol set of the APL programming language [6]. Taking this one step further, manufacturers now offer dual terminals of the cathode-ray or storage-tube-type,which the user may switch fairly conveniently between standard and APL, using one or the other at any time [7]. Another approach has been to add more keys to the keyboard. Some of the extra keys may be assigned high-level operational meaning, such as log x, ex or display, a scheme which provides a convenient shorthand in the limited context of a particular application [8]. Experimental terminals for engineering applications have been developed with as many as 250 "side" keys, alongside the standard keyboard [9]. For the extra keys, standard con­ventions are discarded; symbol codes, transmis­sion codes, and system input/output software routines. Nonetheless, such keyboards are still mainly limited to the fixed, though larger, symbol set which happens to be included. An additional disadvantage to this, as a general approach is simply the distraction that ispresented by so formidablean array of keys, only a fraction of which are likely to be used in any brief period of time. A related scheme has been to assign multiple sets of meanings to a fixed number of keys. This is an extension of the ordinary "shift" concept which allows each key to represent two different symbols, depending on whether the shift key is depressed or not. With multiple meanings, the user may be required to type a special code -­e.g., LEVEL III --to indicate that he desires to switch to a particularset of meanings for the keys. It is difficult to provide many readable labels per key, however, so the basic limitation remains. Thus, for example, inthe Culler-Fried "On-Line Computer System" for numerical analysis,the designers have used both the level-change scheme and a real enlargement of the keyboard to about twice the standard number of keys to satisfy the requirements of that application alone [10]. Also, in that particular system (among others) the user isallowed to assign personal meanings to particular keys at certain levels. This isa use­ful capability, but limited by the need for the user to memorize those assignments himself, since the key labels do not change. An interesting attempt to provide a multiplicity of key labels for a multi-"shift"-levelscheme has been made by the Philco Houston Operations of the Philco-Ford Corporation [11]. Their device con­sists of a "keyboard" comprising two 4 x 4 arrays of push bottons and an (exchangeable)ten page "book" of plastic sheet label overlays which have holes through which the buttons can protrude. The book spline locks into the center of the keyboard (between the two separate 4 x 4 button arrays). When the book isopen to a given pair of pages the overlays provide the key labels. Mechanical cams attached to the book spline and to the in­dividual pages actuate switches under the keyboard to identify the particular book pad pages select­ed. Ina related but more recent approach, K. Knowlton of the Bell Telephone Laboratories has assembled a device inwhich key labels are projected onto a mechanical-key keyboard, while the use of partially-silveredmirrors allows the user to see his hands, the keys, and the labels -all simul­taneously [12]. Although this sounds ghost-like in description, the device issaid to be easy to use. Another approach, used with CRT and other display terminals, has been to generate "soft-copy" input areas, in which special symbols or function names are displayed on a reserved section of the CRT screen and selected by pointing at them with a light-pen, or by moving a cursor controlled by a "joy-stick" or trackball, or by interrupting a light beam inan array, or by a similar tech­nique [13]. The previously mentioned MIT Project-Intrex BRISC terminal extended this idea by dis­playing variable labels to identify a set of extra push buttons mounted along the bottom of the CRT screen. "Soft-copy" input modes implemented on the display inthese various ways can provide an additional richness and flexibility in the input symbol set but are generally slower to work with than separate keyboards and are often not suitable for routine input. They are thus used incombina­tion with a standard keyboard, which results in the user having to transfer back and forth from one type of input device to the other --he must drop the light pen to type, for example, and vice versa. More importantly, information input in that fashion isoften handled ina manner that is not homogeneous with normal input. That is,with normal input-handlingsoftware a key push is sim­ply converted into a binary-bitcode, unique to the particular symbol selected, and appended --if appropriate --to a symbol string input-stream. Such a string is subsequently amenable to the usual range of "character-handling"operations and, of course, itcan be edited later or redis­played. In contrast, with input schemes like those referred to immediately above, the control­ling software routine is likely to be a specialized one, designed inconjunction with the specific picture then being displayed, and direct­ ly carrying out one action or another, depending on the numerical x and y values of the screen locations selected. Another type of effort towards achieving a larger input set is seen in the continuing work of com­mittees assigned the task of defining standard character codes [14]. In spite of serious initial attempts to standardize on a code requiring only 6 bits per symbol (64 characters in all) in the early 1960's, this was rejected as impossible by 1963. The first "standard" 7 bit code was ap­proved in1963 (ASCII; x3.4-1963). Of the 128 possible symbols, 32 were reserved for control functions and 28 were left unassigned; in partic­ular, the lower case alphabet was not specifically included. By 1968, however, the functions of all of the controls had been decided and the printable symbols were all specified; the latter included the lower case alphabet (ASCII; 3.4-1968). At the present time the standards arbiters seem poised to make another factor-of-two jump, to an 8-bit code. Infact, itmay be impossible to achieve universal acceptance at that level. For example, thirty-two additional control functions have been proposed for alphanumeric display terminals alone (of which 21 would be single-character controls). A group considering only library requirements has listed 55 new printable symbols that they would like in an expanded set. The Russians, with their Cyril­lic alphabet, and the Japanese, Koreans and Chinese, of course, have their individual require­ments for the extra symbols that might be associ­ated with the 8-th bit. We have already mentioned APL, a popular programming language, which re­quires thirty unusual symbols itself. Ifone con­siders the possibility of adding standard and common mathematical symbols, another list comes forth. There are also advocates for assigning mathematical operator status to single-key codes (e.g., ex, sin x); such features are now commonly available on inexpensive hand-calcula­tors, and therefore likely to be taken for granted by the incoming generation of users. Itdoes not appear, therefore, that extending the standard code to 8 bits will satisfy all of the obvious needs in this regard, let alone more exotic suggestions --such as musical notes, circuit element symbols and the like. 2.2 FIXED FORMAT A second basic type of flaw in the usual input de­vice is the lack of format flexibility. The user faces a fixed key layout, usually with fixed key labels; an instrument based on a design for put­ting English prose onto paper. As ithappens, the standard symbol layout used is not ideally suited even for that purpose, but that quantitative de­tail is almost irrelevant inthe present context. It is important, however, to consider the pos­sibility that touch-input communication to a com­puter may be qualitativelyenhanced through the use of formats more closely related to the specif­ic interactions underway. Two examples are dis­cussed below to illustrate the need. Often, experimenters who use the interactive capa­bility of computers in special ways (in such fields as cognition, psychology and computer science) 118 find itnecessary to constuct special input de­ vices. Often, however, their requirements could be satisfied by a more flexible touch-input "key­ board" device. We note, for instance, the recent reporting of computer-controlledexperiments on concept formation by E.A. Jerome of the National Institute of Mental Health [15]. The type of experiment being undertaken and the subject's input needs may be sensed from the following sample communications from the computer to the subject: Now please press all of the black buttons, one at a time. Then press the button marked SOLUTION. Fine! That was what we call a word. Itwas the word "black." A word consists of eight buttons all of which have some dimension in common. Now please send me the word "square". The keyboard constructed for these experiments appears to consist of about 19 buttons, arranged ina square array of 16, plus three which have special functions. In the array of sixteen, some of the keys have symbols printed on them, a square or a circle, large or small, solid or just out­ lined. One of the special buttons is printed "TELL ME", another "SOLUTION". Itseems clear that no degree of clever "code-convention defini­tion" will allow the usual keyboard to function in place of the special input device for this application. At the same time, given the sophis­tication of the computers now being used, it is unfortunate that readily-available input-output equipment isnot adequate for even such simple demands. As a second example of free-formattingadvantages, consider a keyboard image designed for use by children, consisting of figure outlines, as sche­matically illustrated in fig. 1.* A number of spots within each outline would be "live", and each would be indicated by a bright spot. All of the "points" within an outline would be assigned to the identical "symbol". That is,the points within the "fish" outline (the "fish" key) would all be assigned to one symbol and the points within the "man" outline (the "man" key) would be assigned to another symbol. The first symbol might have the visual representation: FISH, and the other the representation: MAN. Thus, if the student pressed any of the points within the fish outline, the symbol FISH would be echoed­back to the display screen, and the symbol MAN ifa point inside the other outline were pressed. Each of those two symbols would also be associated with a single binary bit code which would repre­sent it inany "text" file. That is, FISH might be coded and stored as 101101101 and MAN as 110011011. Within the set of keyboard images there might also be additional, but different keyboards from which the same symbols could be referenced. Thus, for example, there might be a keyboard with ordinary-looking key outlines, on which certain keys were associated with those same symbols (e.g., the visual representation FISH and the code 101101101) but labeled with the symbol itself (i.e., FISH). The latter keyboard might be used, for instance, by a teacher to write an in­ teractive program with which students would use the example "outline" pictorial keyboard, among others. Such a keyboard might also be used by the students themselves after they had learned to read the particularwords. 2.3 CONTEXT INDEPENDENCE As a third major flaw regarding standard, all­purpose keyboards, we suggest that they are det­rimental to the efficiency of human-computer interaction, especially inconsideration of errors and the fallibility of human memory. Inpartic­ular, we believe that it is not desirable to always present the user with a single keyboard through which he can send any communication which is,which has ever been, and which might ever be a valid statement. Such a keyboard does not pro­vide any clues as to what input ismeaningful at a given instant ina given process, although the computer software isoften very "knowledgeable" and sensitive about what is legitimateand what is not. At the same time, the very generality of the standard keyboard provides unlimited opportunity for error. It ismore desirable to present "current context keyboards" wherever the interaction affords the opportunity. That is,inmany instances the key­board presented at a given moment can be very specific, designed not simply for a given task, but even for a specific portion of that task. 119 This implies, of course, that keyboards need to be rapidly and dynamically variable, keeping pace with the user's activity; keeping pace with his path through the levels of the interaction. In this type of framework, the communication effi­ciency can be raised considerably, because: * each key press can have a relatively macroscopic effect, and * the error probability will be lower, due to the existence of a smaller choice of simultaneous options and the fact that the keyboards can be either self-explanatoryor include user instructions. Inaddition, dynamic keyboards can include user­defined key labels with the corresponding benefit that derives from the user being able to refer with a single key-push to objects of his own cre­ation, by names of his own choice. As an example of this type of keyboard utilization we consider possible modes of use for a set of programs designed for drawing crystal and molec­ular structure models on a terminal display in perspective or as stereo pairs [16]. Inusing the model-drawingprograms, the user can define models and viewing orientations (views) of his choice. The models are described interms of 1. three basic vectors, A1, A2, and A3, which specify the desired coordinate space and which are themselves defined interms of the orthogonal x, y, z coordinates. 2. any number of atoms, specified by: a) their location, interms of three relative distances, one along each of the basic vectors (relative distances called u, v, and w, respectively) b) their size, given either by a value for the atomic radius or by an atom-type identifier (which is tied to a radius value) c) an identification number, which can be included inthe drawing. 3. any number of "bond" lines, each drawn between any pair of atoms in the model. The views are specified in terms of 1. a point in the model which is to be the center of the view. 2. the viewer's eye point, specified in terms of one of the following: a) a point in space inAl, A2, A3 coordinates b) a point in space in r, 0, coordinates, or c) a point in space given by distance, r, from the view center and a direction, in terms of Miller index crystal notation (h, k, 1). 3. a choice of stereo or simple per­spective pictures. The individual models and views are automatically numbered and can optionally be assigned unique names when they are created. The user can request drawings of particular views of particular models. The display screen may be divided among one, two, or four perspective drawings, or among one or two stereo-pairs. To envision one possible form for a "dynamic key­ board" implementation,we consider an interaction comprising three different kinds of operations: * draw a particular view of a particular model * describe a model * describe a view We can define a special keyboard image for each stage of the interaction. The software (or the user) will select among the keyboards as required; then, the user will see keyboards that pertain to his immediate situation. The sketches infigs. 2 and 3 are schematic drawings for two keyboards in this scheme. The first isfor the "primary" level keyboard -used to request specific drawings on the display screen, or to initiate other actions, such as specifying a new type of view. The second is for the "describe a model" keyboard. Other keyboards for the process would no doubt include one to describe a view and one -with a simple set of alphanumeric characters -to name the models and views. Inthe two examples shown the following conventions have been used: FIGURE 2. STAGE ONE KEYBOARD: REQUEST A MODEL DRAWING OR START A DESCRIPTION. 120 * The live (touchable) points on the keyboards are usually marked by the * symbol, sometimes by the # symbol and, in the case of the digits, by the digit symbols themselves. Touching the indicated points is equivalent to depressing the associated "key". * Lines of input are held and can be edited until a "send" key is pushed. In the present example the relevant keys are labeled "INPUT LINE VERIFIED." * Dynamically created portions of the keyboard are shown in itallics. In the present example these are the "name" labels attached by the cur-rent user to the model and view keys numbered 1 to 3 and 1 to 4, respect-ively. (We can assume that the other available model and view numbers have not yet been used.) FOR A NEW MODEL, DEFINE THE THREE BASIC VECTORS FIRST. NUMERICAL VALUES, CALLED FOR BY W SIGNS g$QQs DRAW BOND LINE BETWEEN IATOMN~.=RJ [ LNO.=lll FIGURE 3. STAGE TWO KEYBOARD: OESCRISE A MODEL. There is no need to dwell here in further detail on the use of the model drawing programs. We think it is clear, however, that keyboards of the sort illustrated can be reasonably self-explanatory. We believe that a person with some knowledge of the explicit task (e.g., crys-tallography or molecular structure) can quickly become adept in the dynamic keyboard framework, with relatively little auxiliary information. By contrast, the manual accompanying the batch processing form of the programs runs to about 20 pages. 3. FEATURES DESIRED FOR A COMPUTER INPUT FACILITY In the foregoing discussion in section 2, we have argued foran input terminal with three major characteristics which are now rarely, if ever, found in COnjUnCtion. Here we specify those three more succinctly and concretely. 3.1 A symbol set which is author-definable and virtually unlimited in terms of the number of symbols or the visual aspect of the symbols. 3.2 Keyboards whose formats are essentially com- pletely arbitrary, allowing all possibilities ranging from the standard key layout of a type-writer, to drawings like those in fig. 1, to "templates" like those in figs. 2 and 3. 3.3 Keyboards which can be dynamically switched, keeping pace with the user's path through an in-teraction, being specifically relevant to the then current aspect of the task. Having listed these, it is important to stress that they should not be achieved at the expense of the most fundamental notion of all -that in-putting to a computer should generate a sensible input-stream. 3.4 The input actions should generate a binary-coded input stream which is explicitly meaningful in terms of the defined symbol set, and which has the attributes of an ordinary text file. Input should be amenable to the usual operations that one applies to text files (or symbol strings), such as: * character-handling operations (e.g., substring, length, concatenate) * string comparison (e.g., for response analysis and interpretation) * editing * outputting (including display format control) 3.5 Input should be canonicalized, so that a given symbol is always represented identically internally, regardless of the keyboard-image used to input it -of those keyboards associated with a given process.* These are the fundamental features. In addition, there are a number of other attributes for a terminal system that are necessary or desirable for effective and convenient use. First, regarding the general framework. 3.6 The system should include the concept of "working-sets" (comprising symbols and related keyboard-images) associated with specific types of processes. This feature means that a given process does not have to be "aware of" all the symbols which have ever been defined and allows more efficient internal operation, in terms of both time and storage. It does not follow, how-ever, that every end-user will have a personal working-set for every different job. On the contrary, a single relatively small symbol set * I.e., of those keyboards associated with a given "working-symbol-set". consisting of the ASCII characters, the Greek alphabet, mathematical symbols and vector nota­ tions may serve many applications in mathematics, physics and chemistry, for example. On the other hand, we do believe that as the value of context­ related keyboard-images becomes more widely per­ ceived, a close -even symbiotic -relationship will develop between the specific user-processes and the provided working-sets. Nonetheless, incertain environments itmay be desired that every author and every end-user use the same working-symbol-set,the accumulation of everything ever used. Therefore ..... 3.7 The system software should be designed so that it is capable of handling very large working sets. Second, there are a number of issues relating to the specification,the appearance and the function of symbols and keyboard-images. 3.8 There should be a convenient language for authors to define a working-set. This language must be defined such that it can be used through a standard terminal, but the most convenient mechanism will most likely be the enhanced-input terminal, itself. 3.9 Symbols should include, ingeneral, both visual aspects and local operational aspects. 3.10 The outlines of "keys" on a keyboard-image should be of any shape or size and should be able to encompass any number of live, touchable points. 3.11 The visual aspects of symbols, subsymbols, live-pointmarkers, key outlines, key labels, and keyboard legends should be definable in terms of dot matrices (of arbitrary size), symbol strings, subsymbols, and generalized graphics (including graphical "functions"). 3.12 The visual aspects of symbols should not necessarily be the same as the label on an associated key, so that one can be simply a "token" for the other. 3.13 The standard ASCII set should be part, and the same part, of all working-symbol-sets. This saves the trouble of specifically includ­ing iteach time and also makes itfeasible to exchange ASCII-only files with standard devices. 3.14 The coding scheme adopted for internal storage should be such that ASCII-only files can be handled by standard software or by the enhanced-terminal software -regardless of the source. 3.15 Itshould be possible to pre-define subsets of symbols (e.g., the Cyrillic alphabet, mathemat­ical symbols, musical notes, etc.) and include them inthe definition of various working-sets by simple file-reference. 3.16 When keyboard-imageschange, the switch needs to occur rapidly; certainly in less than a second. 3.17 The keyboard should have some pressure-feel to the fingers but an audible signal is probably more critical [17]. 3.18 The spatial resolution of the potentially live, touchable points should be sufficiently fine to allow freedom inthe design of keyboard­image formats. Something of the order of finger­width spacing seems adequate. 3.19 The keyboard electronics needs to be sensi­tive to "key bounce," of course. The system should also allow shift-key type of operation (with any "key" having the "shift" property), and it should permit finger-rolling,that is, "make­before-break" typing. 3.20 The system should include a chord mode, in which a number of keys can be touched simulta­neously and each particular combination repre­sents a specific symbol. 3.21 During input the system should "echo back" each symbol immediately, but -optionally -hold each line for correction, ifdesired, until it receives a terminator symbol. 3.22 In conjunction with the last point, the execution of "unerasable"operational aspects of symbols should be delayed during "echo-back" until after the line is verified and transmitted. 3.23 The visual and local operational aspects of symbols should be exactly the same when received by the terminal for output as when received on input. 3.24 It should be feasible to obtain local hard­copy when necessary, however non-standard the visual appearance of the symbols on the output displays might be. 3.25 Itshould be feasible to "roll" the displayed output backwards as well as forwards to allow re­call of previously displayed material as well as continuously scrolled output instead of "page­flipping." 4. IMPLEMENTATION We have, in fact, implemented a hardware/software terminal system embodying the features described in the foregoing section. It isan integrated system. Itcan serve as a remote terminal for a large time-sharing system, a stand-alone terminal/ computer combination, or as part of a distributed system with local input and processing as well as remote computation and data. 4.1 The hardware for the present prototype is comprised of three main components: 4.1.1 A Digital Equipment Corporation PDP 11/40 computer [18]. This device, which ismore power­ful than isneeded for the terminal-only applica­tion, provides the major portion of the needed processing for the terminal as well as the "library" storage media and the storage access mechanisms. The software to implement, i.e. to "compile", the terminal author language as well as many of the keyboard and output display 122 More detailed descriptions of the implementation computational and logical operations is handled and of the author language considerations will be by the 11/40 processor, programmed inassembly published later. language. 4.1.2 Two video monitors with solid-state, page­refresh memories and specialized circuitry for memory control and for video readout and signal generation [19]. One of these monitors serves the normal display function of a terminal; the other isthe basis for the dynamic keyboard. 4.1.3 A keyboard overlay with associated logic control circuitry and two-way interfacing to the 11/40. This overlay is essentially transparent and allows the displayed keyboard to be seen clearly beneath it. A matrix of crossed wires in the overlay inconjunction with scanning elec­tronics allows the surface to be "touch-sensitive" at a large number of points -approximately 600 in the present version. 4.1.4 Additional hardware factors As the system currently stands, it can be readily augmented with additional display and overlay hardware to serve as an eight-terminal complex, each with two "display" units. As regards each of the three main hardware compo­nents, itshould be noted that the system can in principle utilize a wide range of alternate de­vices. To use the displays as an example, we can mention that storage-type CRT's [20], disk-re­freshed video, plasma discharge panels [21] can serve (although some of these may restrain the keyboard switching rates), as can devices which use partially or fully coated mirrors to super­impose images, as well as devices which project keyboard images pre-recorded on film (although the latter scheme, of course, is limited to images which are not varied inthe course of an interaction). A schematic diagram of the hardware configura­tion is shown infig. 4. 4.2 The software can be thought of in terms of two main components. 4.2.1 The compiler for the author language ­which iscalled the Terminal Definition Language. Inthis language, the author writes a "terminal definition file" (TDF); the most direct means is via the standard on-line editor of the 11/40 operating system itself. The compiler converts the TDF into a set of highly-coded tables, con­taining the descriptions of the symbols and keyboard-images inthe working set. 4.2.2 The terminal operating system, that is, the driver. The driver programs implement the actuality of the terminal, accepting input from the overlay circuitry, echoing-back, drawing graphics, displaying images, retrieving and writing data to and from disk and display memories, converting input to coded streams for transmission, etc., etc. We note again, in this regard, that the functional behavior of the terminal isquite open­ended since any symbol can directly invoke any assembly language subroutinewhich can be handled by the local processor. 5. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS We are grateful for the support of the National Science Foundation, Division of Computer Activities. We especially appreciate the de­ tailed interest of Drs. Granger Morgan and Fred Weingarten, Jr. of the Foundation. We are pleased to acknowledge the help and collaboration of persons inthe MIT Artificial Intelligence group, particularly Mr. Ron Lebel, and of persons in the MIT ElectronicSystems Laboratory, particularly Mr. Joseph Boscoe, Dr. John Ward and Professor Frank Reintjes. article_rec.title: Graphics for social scientists

abstract.par: The social science computing environment and the implications of this for the developers of computer graphics is described. Graphic software developed for social scientists at the University of Michigan is illustrated. MULTIGROUP is used to generate displays in the process of data analysis. GRAPH is used to report results to others. A graphical editor is employed to customize displays.

ref.ref_text: MIDAS is a sophisticated statistical system which is capable of performing a wide range of analyses and data manipulations. The multigroup command within MIDAS performs analyses requested by the user and then invokes our graphics routines and the supporting IG routines (see note 3 below) for plotting. For a description of MIDAS see Daniel J. Fox and Kenneth E. Guire (1974) Documentation for MIDAS Michigan Interactive Data Analysis System, the Statistical Research Laboratory, The University of Michigan, Ann Arbor.
GRAPH will be described below. A user's writeup can be obtained from the Computer Support Group, Center for Political Studies, Institute for Social Research, P. O. Box 1248, Ann Arbor, Michigan 48106

The Integrated Graphics library was developed by the University of Michigan Computing Center. The library is described in a paper in these Proceedings by James Blynn and Andy Goodrich "The Internal Design of the IG Routines, an Interactive Graphics System for a Large Timesharing Environment."
Norman Nie (1975) et al Statistical Package for the Social Sciences 2nd edition, McGraw-Hill, N.Y.
Institute for Social Research (1973), OSIRIS III, Ann Arbor, Michigan.
W. J. Dixon (Ed.) (1973) BMD, Bomedical Computer Programs. University of California Press, Berkeley, California.

There is no universal graphics terminology for the types of pictures we will describe. Hopefully the referents of these terms will become obvious, if only after seeing the examples used later in this paper.

For a discussion of an interactive graphic system used for factor analysis and multidimensional scaling see Edward J. Schneider and David John Gow, (1975) "Extending the Information Transfer in Multidimensional Analysis through the Use of Interactive Graphics," Computer Graphics Vol. 9, pp. 191-200.
A standard text on regression analysis is Applied Regression Analysis by M. R. Draper and H. Smith (1966) Wiley, N.Y.
Perhaps the most innovative uses of graphics in statistics has been developed by John W. Tukey, Exploratory Data Analysis, Addison-Wesley, Reading Mass. (forthcoming).

For a description of an impressive set of Fortran callable subroutines see I. Hirschsohn, etal "Design and Implementation of the DISSPLA Graphics Language". pp. 31-44 in Douglas Lewin (Ed) Interactive Systems (1975), Online, Uxbridge, England.
The hierarchial data structure is a feature of the Integrated Graphics library.
MIDAS was used over 100,000 times in the last year alone.

L. Borman, W. D. Dominick, R. Hay Jr., P. Kron, and B. Mittman, "Personalized Management and Graphical Display of Data: An Extensible System Approach," Proceedings of the SIGDA/SIGNOD/SIGGRAPHWorkshop on Data Bases for Interactive Design," September 1975, pp. 36-44.

fulltext.ft_body: Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania GRAPHICS FOR SOCIAL SCIENTISTS* Edward J. Schneider Sylvia Barge, Gregory A. Marks Center for Political Studies Institute for Social Research The University of Michigan The social science computing environment and the implications of this for the developers of computer graphics is described. Graphic software developed for social scientists at the University of Michigan is illustrated. MULTIGROUP is used to generate displays in the process of data analysis. GRAPH is used to report results to others. A graphical editor is employed to customize displays. 1. INTRODUCTION Social scientists are a large group of potential users of computer graphics. They make heavy use of computers in both research and teaching. When they use computers they are accustomed to sophisticated software and unsophisticateddevices. They rarely write special purpose programs and only a small subset use special hardware. Instead, they rely on high quality, multipurpose-softwarepackages of canned programs. These and other characteristicshave implications for the design of graphics software and hardware. These potential users will expect graphic software to be easy to use, powerful, inexpensive and device independent. If computer graphics evolves in these directions social scientistswill become major consumers. Computer graphics can aid the social scientist who is involved in data analysis in two distinct ways. First, computer graphic displays can be used after the research process to communicate research results to others in publications, in presentations and in teaching. This use requires that graphs be clearly labelled and adjustable in format. Second, computer graphics can be used during the researchprocess to communicate results to the primary researcher. This can be accomplished by embedding the graphics within data analysis software. This use requires that the graphics be obtained easily in addition to the traditional printout of results; ease of use is more important than flexibility of format or elegance of labelling. *This research was funded in part through a grant by the National Science Foundation to the Institute for Social Research, NSFGI 29904. The software described in this paper was developed as a joint project by the Statistical Research Laboratory at the University of Michigan and the Computer Support Group at the Center for Political Studies. The people responsible for design and implementationwere Sylvia Barge, Daniel Fox, Richard Herstein, Tom Hibbs, Gregory Marks, Neal Oden and Edward Schneider. We have developed graphic software to satisfy the perceived basic needs and expectations of the social scientists and which have been well received and utilized at the University of Michigan. It is embedded in the interactive statistical system, MIDAS,[1] and appears as a stand alone interactive prompter, GRAPH.[2] In the future this software may be available more generally over a national computer network. Our graphic software includes a set of modules which correspond to the visual components of a display, such as an axis with tic marks and labels or a legend. This modularity provides extensibility of the set of available displays with minimal effort. Our software in turn employs the University of Michigan Integrated Graphics library [3] to define a visual component as a set of device-independent lines or text strings. The IntegratedGraphics routines handle all graphic device communicationsincluding that for storage tube terminals and the CalComp ploter. We are not attempting in this paper to describe the internal design of the software we have produced. Our purpose is to describe the social science com­ puting environment and the external form of the graphic software designed both to fit that environ­ment and to introduce social scientists to computer graphics. 2. THE SOCIAL SCIENCE COMPUTING ENVIRONMENT Our development work has focused on that group of social scientists involved in data analysis. We include in this group those who do primary and secondary research, as well as those who consume this research or utilize it in teaching. The data are usually individualopinion surveys or aggregate statistics such as census data. These are large data sets which often contain 1,500 to 2,000 cases with 10 to 15 card images per case. While consumers of data-analysis-orientedsocial science need have no knowledge of computers, pro­ ducers are of necessity users of computers. How­ ever, very few of these users know any programming language and instead of writing special purpose programs, they tend to use packages of canned programs. The most common packages are SPSS,[4] OSIRIS,[5] and BMD[6]. Local packages are often the most frequent choice at specific locations such as MIDAS at the University of Michigan. In general these systems provide subprograms for data manage­ment and analysis. These are invoked as needed using keyworded setups with the package minimizing the user's need to know about the operating system. The printout of a run using one of these packages can be anywhere from one page to several hundred. Often the output of the analysis is a series of numbers which could easily be summarized in a graphic form. This graphic form would be more quickly comprehended than the series of numbers in the printout. Most data analysis output falls under one of three general categories: a cross tabulation, a correlation matrix, or regression coefficients. Cross tabulation can easily be represented graphically by line graphs, bar charts, pie charts etc.[7] Correlation matrices can be represented graphically following further data reduction with techniques such as factor analysis.[8] Regressions can be represented by scatterplots with line(s) through them.[9] Virtually any set of statistics can be represented by a meaningful line graph.[10] Statistics which are normalized can be represented by normalized graph forms such as pie charts. Perhaps the distinguishing characteristicof social science data is that much of it is categorical or nominal. This has definite implications for graphical displays. It is rare that social scientists have a continous function or curve to plot. Rather it is usually a series of disjoint points. Even line graphs are more properly thought of as a series of broken line segments. Thus social scientists tend to use graphic forms which retain the disjoint nature of their data, such as histo­grams, bar charts, and pie charts. Another characteristicof social science data is that data are often incomplete or missing. This happens in various ways. A time point is missing because a survey could not be conducted that year, or a question was not asked on purpose or by mistake. Any computer program designed to process social science data should contain appropriate procedures for recognizing and handling missing data when it is encountered. The combination of the reliance on packages and the need for specific graphic forms leads us to believe that social scientists will use computer graphics when they can do so by invoking packaged software which will mask the technical complexity of generating the graphic displays and be able to produce the desired graphic forms. Such graphic packages should be more than Fortran callable sub­ routines[ll] which require the user to know technical details. Rather they should be the Fortran code which calls the graphic subroutine and takes care of the details for the user. One of the details with which the user should not be bothered is having to know the limitations of the hardware. Most social scientists are unfamiliar 126 with anything beyond the most elementary aspects of hardware. Often their research is unfunded and hence they tend to rely on public property provided by university computing centers. Some social science departments purchase their own terminals, but usually these are character rather than graphic devices. Thus the graphic packages must allow for character input from user terminals and be able to produce graphics on off-line plotters as well as on graphic terminals. We have produced software which takes the above considerations into account and attempts to meet the needs of social scientists. The two modes of this software are named GRAPH and MULTIGROUP. 3. GRAPH GRAPH is an interactive computer program which is capable of producing plots on a user's terminal and plot description files for off-line plotting. We assume that users have some mental image of what the plots should look like as they sit at the terminal. GRAPH prompts them to enter information which controls the plotting. The amount of prompt­ing is kept to a minimum. The user enters the type of the desired graph, which can be a line graph, a bar chart, a histogram, a pie chart or three other specialized graph forms: floating bar, boxes and profile graphs. Once the graph type is entered the program prompts become specific to the chosen graph type, although strict compar­ability between prompts for different types is maintained when there is an isomorphism. Users are supplying labelling for the graphs and the basic plot information such as the number of graphs in a picture, the number of points in a graph and the minimum, maximum, and interval for the Y-axis. For much of the graph we assume a standard set of parameters which were designed after considerable review of the needs of social scientists. We found that most social science graphs can be thought of as having two dimensions, only one of which is continuous. The continuous dimension is used to display the value of a statistic. The other dimension represents groups which are related nominally though sometimes they are ordered; in rare instances (such as time series) they are intervals. We use this knowledge to build assump­ tions which minimize the prompting. For instance we do not ask for a coordinate value, rather we evenly space entries along the X-axis in the order mentioned by the user. Perhaps the easiest way to describe how GRAPH works is with an example. In Figure 1, we have reproduced a GRAPH session where the lines in lower case are typed by the user and the lines in upper case come from GRAPH. The user is requesting a line graph with 2 lines, each having four data points. Most of the information is labelling. Once the user has completed answering the prompts the picture will be drawn on the terminal. See Figure 2. At this point the graphic editor will be invoked. We assume that most users will want to modify the basic picture in some unpredictable way.
