Rather we assume a graphic editor will handle these situations. The editor presents the user with a menu of options. These are listed in Figure 3. The user selects an editor option by pointing to the menu. The editor will then prompt the user to point to the item to be altered. We expect the user to want to edit parts of the picture rather than partial areas of the screen. We have therefore created the picture as data structure made up of sub-pictures, any one of which can be edited by the user.[12] This data structure gives the editor its power. The user can point to any item on the screen and edit it. Thus pointing to any part of the title is sufficient identication to have the whole title blownup, replaced, colored or even deleted or moved. A typical picture might be made up of thirty or more sub-pictures. Figure 4 is an example of a section of a pie graph being moved by use of the graphic editor. The additional label­ ling was added at a point indicated by cursor placement. The emphasis in the graphic editor is to allow users to particularize any of our graphic forms to their specific needs. We would like to believe that we are thus eliminating the need for a graphic artist to design displays for publication. We are sure some social scientists will need these artists anyway, but even these will find GRAPH useful for generating rough drafts of the desired displays. Those social scientists who draw their own displays will probably find GRAPH adequate for their needs. The range of displays which GRAPH can produce is indicated by examples of each of the basic graph types. See Figures 4 -10. With simple modifications using the editor this range can be extended. GRAPH was designed to handle the special problems of social scientists. It is usable by those who do not have graphics terminals it can handle missing data, and it is cheap enough to allow user 127 experimentationwith displays. In Figure 11 as an example of the character approximation of graphics produced by GRAPH on a character terminal. The user can preview plots on the terminal and then ask to have them run off on a plotter, probably off-line. Unfortunately graphic editing is not available when using character terminals. Missing data is most difficult to handle in line graphs: See Figure 12. The other graph types also handle missing data. Users often experiment with GRAPH by plotting the same values with a variety of graph types. We have facilitated this process by providing a default system. If a person would like to see a histogram and a line graph of the same data, that user goes through the prompt sequence for the histogram and then merely respecifies the graph type as line and defaults Fig. 11 - Character Histogram Fig. 12 - Missing Data in a Line Graph everything else. GRAPH will have stored the previous replies and will use them whenever the person sends an asterisk. We have made one assumption in GRAPH that may not be entirely obvious. We have assumed that the user has already generated the values to be plotted using some analysis program. GRAPH cannot produce the statistics, it can only plot numbers. The user will probably have generated a stack of output and chosen those results which best exemplify some point they would like to communicate to others. We feel that a much more exciting role for graphics exists in linking graphics capabilities directly into the analysis programs. We have built this mode of usage into the Multigroup command within the Michigan Interactive Data Analysis System. 4. MULTIGROUP The MULTIGROUP command in MIDAS provides the user with the ability to graphically display results in the process of doing data analysis. MULTI- GROUP users have data and would like statistics calculated on those data. We assume that the user would like a plot of that statistic over subsets of the data. Usually the user has labelled the variables and categories of the data and any plot MULTIGROUP generates will use these labels in the display. The statisticswhich the MULTIGROUP command is capable of producing are counts, marginal per­ centages, cummulative percentages, concordance coefficients, phi's tau's, lambda's, gamma's, rank tau's, correlations, and several others based on three-way cross-tabulations. Statistics are produced with confidence intervals when appropriate. We plot the statistic along the Y­ axis and the subsets along the X-axis, again using the X-axis as an ordinal axis. The graph types which MULTIGROUP can produce are lines, histograms, bars, pie, floating bars and variants of the line graph which handle cummulation. by MULTIGROUP. All the user had to tell MIDAS was: MULTIGROUP FUNCTION=MARG%VARIABLES=15 STRATA=V20 OPTION=FLOATBAR The parentheticalremark at the bottom of the plot was added by using the graphic editor which is also available with MULTIGROUP. The rest of the labelling is generated automaticallybecause the dataset contained that information.Because labelling is automatic,MULTIGROUP can be used to generate plots very quickly with less input from the user than GRAPH requires. We should also note that the floating bar graph in Figure 13 is an example of a graph type which is particularly useful for dichotomous data which is very common in the social sciences. MULTIGROUP should prove to be an important addition to MIDAS. It will make MIDAS an even more powerful teaching aid than it is already.[13] Under­ graduates use MIDAS even in freshmen social science courses. They need know only three commands: to read a dataset, to get a cross tabulation, and to exit the program. These commands prompt the user for the necessary information. The problem which faces social science instructors is getting across the concepts inherent in a cross tabulation. The students must be taught how to read a table. Our experience is that the concept of a relationship within a cross tabulation is most easily presented graphically. The concept of dependence seems to come across much quicker this way. With the MULTIGROUP command the student can get both the hands on experience inherent in interactive data analysis and the "aha" phe­ nomenon inherent in graphics. The skillful choice of data analysis assignments can drive the point home very quickly. For example, the cross tabulation of Congress­ man's party with their rating by The Americans for Democratic Action yields a 2x4 matrix of counts. In the row corresponding to Democrats the counts increase with increasingADA score; the row for Republicans decreases. Yet the inference that ADA score is dependent upon party is less obvious to students when confrontedwith the matrix than when they see the information presented graphically as in Figure 14. To drive the point home even quicker one might also have them look at the means for the two groups as in Figure 15. The benefits inherent in interaction combined with graphics leads us to believe that MULTIGROUP may pioneer a new mode of output display for canned analysis programs in general. We can imagine users demanding more and more of their output in graphical form rather than tabular form. THE FUTURE The software which we have described is only part of what we think social scientists will want in the way of computer graphics. We feel we have only touched the basic needs. However, we have done this in such a way as to provide building blocks for the future development. This develop­ ment will proceed in several different directions. One of the most interesting will be in the investi­gation of new ways of presenting information. An attempt to convey more information in a novel way is embodied in a graph form called "Boxes". See Figure 10. This graph form was created by Neal Oden. It is based on the notion that each cell in a cross tabulation has an expected frequency as well as an observed frequency. Each cell is represented by two concentric squares. The length of a side of the solid square is proportional to the cell's contributionto the observed frequency. The length of a side of the broken square is proportional to the expected frequency. Within each cell there are two lines forming an angle which is proportional to that cell's contribution to the total chi-square. article_rec.title: Specifying symbol instances

abstract.par: This paper reviews and compares the uses of dimensioning in the instance and dimensioning in the master to specify instances of symbol definitions in general-purpose graphics programming languages. The processing required to each case is described and compared. Dimensioning in the master is easier to implement, can allow faster display of images because of simpler processing, and semantically is a bit less powerful than dimensioning in the instance. When appropriate, both can gracefully coexist in a graphics language, but the great majority of graphics applications only need the semantic power of dimensioning in the master.

article_rec.title: BGRAF2
article_rec.subtitle: a real-time graphics language with modular objects and implicit dynamics

abstract.par: The BGRAF2 language for interactive real-time 2D graphics was designed as a user-oriented language emphasizing ease of use rather than of implementation. Procedural statements allow straightforward computation while classlike characteristics encourage modular graphics programming. The clock and event data types facilitate creation of parallel and synchronous procedures automatically acting on structures and display files. A graphic procedure, which includes procedural, drawing and event-driven statements, is a graphic prototype. Such procedures may be nested and iteratively or recursively called. An individual invocation of a procedure, called a graphic object, shares code while commanding its own data structures and images.

fulltext.ft_body: BGRAF2: A REAL-TIMEGRAPHICS LANGUAGEWITH MODULAR OBJECTS AND IMPLICIT DYNAMICS Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania S. Bergman A. Kaufman Ben-Gurion Universityof the Negev Beer-Sheva, Israel The BGRAF2 language for interactive real-time 2D graphics was designed as a user-oriented language emphasizing ease of use rather than of implementation. Procedural statements allow straightforwardcomputationwhile classlike characteristicsencourage modular graphics program­ming. The clock and event data types facilitate creation of parallel and synchronousprocedures automaticallyacting on structures and display files. A graphic procedure, which includes procedural, drawing and event-driven statements, is a graphic prototype. Such procedures may be nested and iteratively or recursivelycalled. An individual invocation of a procedure, called a graphic object, shares code while commanding its own data structures and images. 1. INTRODUCTION The BGRAF2 language is a higher level language es­pecially designed for interactive real-time two­dimensional graphics. The structured ALGOL-like procedural statements allow straightforward compu­tation, the class-like graphic procedures encour­age modular programming,and the implicit struc­tures lend autonomous dynamics to images. A graphic object is a time-, input-and computa­ tion-dependent instance of a graphic procedure. It is composed of explicitly drawn primitives (lines, points, characters), of sketches con­ structed from primitives, and of subobjectscreat­ ed by hierarchical "calls" to other graphic pro­cedures. A graphic object draws in its own co­ordinate system, defined in terms of the coordi­nate system of its parent. A call to a graphic procedure merely invokes a dynamic instance of that procedure, and thus, many such instances (objects) may be in effect simultaneously. Graphic recursion is permitted. The approach taken here to effect real-time chang­es on screen differs in principle from the stand­ard methods. According to traditional approaches the programmer either explicitly invokes system functions acting directlyon the display file (e.g., in GRIP [9]), or makes changes in a pseudo­ display file and recompiles the element which has been changed each time such a change is made (as in IMAGE [11]). The BGRAF2 language is based on neither of these approaches, but rather on what might be called "side effects". Graphic objects and primitives may be defined in terms of program variables, and the visual elements created may change automatically in real-time as these vari­ ables change their values. A graphic element, once defined, need not be referenced directly in order to change it. The side-effect approach is also employed in the real-time animation language ANIMA, mentioned by Csuri [5]. Explicit and implicit event-driven statements con­ trol the real-time processes in the language, while the procedural and graphic statements are used to initialize objects and data structures. Clocks and timers declared in the program synchronize the be­ havior of objects with the real-time (master) clock. Variables defined as functions of clocks act as "pseudo-clocks",changing in real-time according to any user-defined function. Graphic object defined in terms of these clocks or pseudo-clocks behave similarly. The BGRAF2 language, its use and implementation are presented informally in this paper. A complete definition of the syntax and semantics is given in [10]. 2. DRAWING The graphic primitives of BGRAF2 are point, vector, and string. These are data types in the language, together with integer, real, boolean, etc. A point constant is given by (a,b), where a and b are num­ bers. It denotes an absolute position of a point in the coordinate system of an object. A vector constant <a,b> signifies a relative translation of the drawing beam. The beam is moved in two dimen­ sions by a sequence of such statements, each of the form: commands. This sequence of statementsagain draws fig. la: Both sequences,when executed, create identical display files and images. However, the second se­ quence creates an additional structure and mecha­nism to alter the display file as variables I, J and K receive new values. For example, the sub­sequent execution of I:=I+1; repositions the rec­tangle at (2,3), J:=8; widens it keeping the dot at its center, and K:=J/2; changes the rectangle into a parallelogram,its nonvertical sides having slope of -1/2 as in fig. 1b. The thermometer drawing is dynamically linked to variable N, changing whenever it does. The prefix operator # gives the current value of a variable at the time the drawing code is executed. Thus, the addition of this code: adds a reference line to the thermometer represent­ ing the initial value of N. The initial image would be of the form given in fig. 2b, while later it might assume the form of fig. 2c. The basic utility in parameterizinga drawing is its conceptual simplicity, allowing the programmer to draw once and to control the image by "pulling the strings from beyond the view of the audience". This is emphasized by the following code which rubber-bandsa line segment from a fixed initium to an externally-controlled moving tracker. The system procedure track places the tracker at point P and alters P in accordance with the tracker mo­ tion. name and re-evaluatedwhenever its value changes. The definition statement is of the form: < variable> =< expression> ; and is non-procedural. A defined variable, being an abbreviationfor an expression, may be defined only once within a procedure and cannot receive values by assignment or input. In the previous ex­ ample, we might have written the definition M=0.9*N; transforming the range of N to the range of its graphic representation,or, if we are not interest­ed in viewing N out of range: M = max(O,min(90,0.9"N)); Then the first mercury line is drawn by <M,O>; and M is evaluated anew whenever N changes. Fig. 2 -ThermometerDrawing The third graphic primitive is string. Its con­ stants are defined by a character string delimited by single quotes. A string drawing statement con­ sists of a string constant or variable. The string is drawn from the current beam position, horizon­ tally in the current coordinate system, in standard character size. Thus, this code: ?(10,-30); 'VALUEOF N'; added to the thermometer code, labels the thermo­ meter as in fig. 2d. Graphic primitives may have properties such as intensity, type of line (solid, dotted, etc.), light-pen sensitivity, italics, blink, visibility, angle and size. Thes have either Boolean values or numeric values within certain ranges. Each property has a default value. Values may be as­ signed explicitly to graphic elements by appending a property and an expression giving the property value desired. For example: 'HELLO',intens:5,ital:true; draws italic string "HELLO" with intensity level 5, while: ((X,Y),blink:BVC,intens:J+l; intensifies a point at (X,Y)with intensity J+1. The point alters its intensity whenever J's value changes and blinks whenever Boolean BVC is true. Another graphic data type is the compound graphic element sketch, consisting of a parenthesized se­quence of graphic primitives and their properties. If S is of type sketch, then we may assign a fixed rectangle (6x3) whose base is light-pen sensitive (lps) and whose overall intensity is 5 by: ?#P; track(P); P; To simplify matters,a "defined" variable has been Sketch S may be displayed by a statement which introduced. It is actually a function, called by names it, i.e., S; . A sequence of five rectangles is drawn by the loop: The execution of a new assignment statement, e.g.: assigns a new sketch to S. If S had already been drawn a number of times, each rectangle now reap­ pears as a triangle. However, if S had been origi­ nally drawn with the statement #s; indicating the current value of S, assignment will not alter pre­ viously drawn display elements. 3. CLOCKS Timing mechanisms and time-dependent events and objects in real-time systems and languages are in­ dispensable, as stated by Frailey [7] and Cardman [3]. The clock and event data types in BGRAF2 facilitate the creation of parallel and synchronous actions and procedureswhich automaticallyact on the data structures, display files and the scena­ rio. Since a clock variable may be used as an or­ dinary numeric variable, real-time motion is trivi­ ally definable. The automatic incrementation of the clocks result in real-time dependent objects which dynamicallychange their shape, position, size, orientation, and other properties. A clock is an ordered 4-tuple [V,F,S,P] where: V is the clock value, an integer counter automat­ ically incrementing (decrementing)by one every F basic time units; this variable is also used as the reference name of the clock; F is the clock frequency in basic time units, an integer time interval that must lapse before the clock value is modified; S is the clock state, a Boolean variable indicating whether the clock is "running" or "suspended"; P is the clock period, an integer which is the maximal number of value changes before V returns to its starting value. A clock is locally declared in a type declaration statement such as clock V(F,S,P); . In defining time mechanisms, BGRAF2 assumes a hardware device signaling at a constant frequency according to an external "wall clock". A 50 Hertz wall clock is assumed in all examples given below. The master clock, time, which ticks according to the hardware device, is a real-time uninterruptableclock. It starts running when execution of the program com­ mences, with value zero. All the user-defined clocks are synchronizedwith and geared from the master clock as in [3]. A user-defined clock is a timer in the sense that it is bound to the graphic procedure in which it is declared. A procedure call creates an instance of a procedure including instances of all clocks de­clared in it. When the instance terminates, clocks are deallocatedwith the rest of its data structure. The default initial values of the clock parameters are [O,l,true,oo],following the master clock. Other values must be explicitly stated, e.g., a "second" clock which starts at 0 and ticks each second with a period of one minute is declared: 6 clock V=0(50,S=true,0); The clock value can be altered during execution by assigning it a new value, an action known as re­ setting the clock, e.g., V:=30;. Other clock para­ meters whose associated variables have been declar­ ed may be changed by assignment. In the previous example, the execution of S:=false; stops clock V while S:=true; causes it to resume running. A clock and its associated variables may appear in any expression as ordinary numeric and Boolean var­ iables, enabling the definition of clock-dependent variables, or "pseudo-clocks". These are variables of any type (e.g., real, point) and are functions of a declared clock running at arbitrary rates. Clock mappings allow definition of automatic change or motion, as for example this illuminated point moving diagonally across the screen: clock K; ...!(K,K); or this point tracing an exponentiallydecaying sinusoid from left to right: The following code draws a horizontal sequence of vertical strokes across the screen (assuminga 0-1000 screen). The strokes seem to appear at screen-left, move across the entire screen at uni­form velocity,and disappear at screen-right. Ac­tually, only 50 strokes assume periodic motion. Clocks, of course, have many other uses. In parti­cular, they are used in definingand controlling events. 4. EVENTS An event is an impulse function of time, defining a sequence of time-instants at which the event is said to "occur". It does not otherwise have a value per se in any finite time interval. In some ways it is like the timing signals called "events" in Brinch Hansen [2] used to synchronize concurrent processes that access common variables. In BGRAF2 an event expression or variable defines an event. An event variable can be declared (e.g., event E;) and explicitly triggered (e.g., signal E;). Boolean expressions (e.g., I>5) are event expressions. When so used, the event in question "occurs"at the instant that the expres­ sion value changes from false to true. An input expressionis an (external)event which occurs when certain actions take place on a peri­pheral unit and certain conditions are fulfilled, facilitating interaction between user and program. Input expressions are also event expressions,and thus, for example, the depression of the "Y" key on the keyboard, representedas key:'Y', or a light­pen hit on object OBJ, representedas lp:OBJ, are event expressions. A numeric, clock, or other variable also serves as an event expression, the event it represents occurring each time a value is (explicitly or implicitly)assigned to that vari­able. Various Boolean combinations of event ex­pressions and variables are also event expressions. where the do-block is a single statement or a se­quence terminated by end. The do-block is immedi­ately scheduled for execution upon occurrence of the event. Ideally, it is executed asynchro­nously and in parallel with other ongoing processes. Clocks gear events to real time. If K is a clock, then it serves as an event expression (onKdo ...) which occurs each time K ticks (changes). Clock­driven events can be partially masked by Boolean expressions (on KAB do ...). A periodic clock in­troduces another event, occurring at the end of each period, given by the event-valued system func­tion period(K). Another event-driven statement is the pick state­ment, syntacticallysimilar to the procedural case. It selects one of a sequence of code-blocks for im­mediate execution when the user makes one of a number of designatedchoices on an input device. The device may be physical (e.g., keyboard, light­pen) or logical (e.g., menu). For example: 5. THE GRAPHIC PROCEDURE An underlying principle of BGRAF2 is the modulari­zation of dynamic objects. An object is an invoked instance of a graphic procedure, in some ways simi­lar to the objects of SIMULA classes [6]. A graph­ ic procedure represents any dynamic scenario, from a simple static sketch extending to an entire time­ and input-dependentdynamically changing sequence. Objects may be built up in time and space from sim­pler objects. Each object is a self-containedunit controlling its own "actions" within its own co­ ordinate system, and controlled from "above" by its "parent". A parent node in this structural tree need not be concernedwiththe structure of its distant descendents, since each of its subtrees is totally controlled by its immediate descendent, the subtree root. Thus, for example, a graphic proce­ dure TRAFFICmay create a number of subtrees called CAR, each of which calls procedure WHEEL a number of times. WHEEL can be defined as a wheel whose angular velocity is determined from its size and speed, given as parameters. CAR may define a ve­ hicle of varying size and shape, determined by its parameters. It invokes WHEEL a number of times, and as it moves, the WHEELs also move with it, be­ing linked to the CAR coordinate system. TRAFFIC invokes a number of CAR instances of different size and shape, dynamically altering their velocities. It is not even "aware" of the existence of WHEEL. Syntactically,a graphic procedure consists of a body of statements such as declarations,defini­tions, procedural statements (including statements which create graphic elements) and event-driven statements. A procedure itself is merely a proto­type, each invocation of which produces an instance called a graphic object. Such an object has a sep­arate existence, and is in one of two states, ac­ tive or passive. It is active immediately after invocation,remaining so until all its procedural statements have been executed. In this state, events are inhibited and local clocks don't tick, permitting the completion of computations and the drawing of images before things start changing dynamically. When the object becomes passive, its event-driven statements are executed from time to time as events occur, and graphic images and data structureswhich are geared to clocks and pseudo­clocks change. The terminate statement terminates 136 a graphic object, deallocating its data structures and ending its existence. All its descendents are implicitly terminatedat that time. The geometric origin of an object is the current beam position when it is invoked. The mapping of its coordinate system to that of the screen is de­ clared in an optional screen statement preceding the declarations. Other properties of the object, including size and angle which affect the coordi­nate system, may be appended in the call, much the same as they are appended to graphic primitives and sketches: GEORGE(1,2,A+B),blink:BL,angle:ANG; If the properties are expressions (non-constant), they dynamically modify images produced by the in­ voked object, as well as those of its descendents. A graphic procedure need not draw anything itself. It may invoke other procedures to draw, while it manipulates their environments. Consider, for in­ stance, procedure DESCEND, which invokes an in­stance of procedure CHUTE and moves it down at con­stant velocity from its initial position on screen while rocking it back and forth in a pendulous mo­tion. These motions are accomplished by defining the angle and position of CHUTE relative to DESCEND's own coordinate system in terms of a clock of 200 ms. frequency. CHUTE's origin and angle are pseudo-clocks: Procedure CHUTE can be any procedure whatsoever. The following example of CHUTE draws a parachute, calling external routine ARC (not defined here) to draw an arc defined by three points. Eleven cords are attached to object PAYLOAD not defined here. The payload bounces up and down with respect to CHUTE, cords rubber-bandingaccordingly, as defined by pseudo-clockY: Top-down program design is facilitated by the graphic procedure structure. A procedure encom­passes not only the definition of graphic images, but also their time-, input-, and computation­ dependent behavior. This is again illustrated in the following program. The light-pen is used to draw a dotted curve, wherein the dots are about equally spaced. Each dot initially appears at maxi­mum intensity and eventually fades completelyand disappears, as if one were drawing with disappear­ ing ink. A procedure controlling the drawing need merely invoke procedure DOT at various times to draw a dot. DOT is independently defined as an in­tensified point whose intensity decreases with time and which eventually terminates itself without be­ing told to do so. Procedure DOT, essentiallyin­ dependent of DRAW, employs a backward ticking clock which ticks from 7 to zero, one tick each three seconds. Its intensity is defined in terms of this clock. An instance of DOT terminates itself upon completion of the clock's period. 6. COMMUNICATIONBETWEEN OBJECTS Graphic objects may receive and convey information or commands from other graphic objects in a variety of ways. One mechanism is the variable of type event whose scope of validity is the entire pro­gram. Events are used to transfer signals within an object and throughout the program. A variable of any other type may be declared global and thus be known beyond the boundaries of the procedure in which it is declared. Another standard method of communication is by def­inition of procedures with arguments (formal para­meters). In BGRAF2, all arguments are passed by reference. However, explicit reference to a parti­cular object may only be effected by use of refer­ence variables. Each reference variable points to an instance of a procedure currently in existence, either active or passive, or assumes the value null. If reference R points to an instance of A and the instance terminates, then R automatically assumes the null value. The operator assigns reference at procedure invocation; reference R1,R2; ...A R1; ...A@R2; An object can be referred to in order to check, change or terminate it. Reference variables are especially needed because the same graphic proce­dure may be invoked a number of times, and the pro­cedure name does not uniquely identify any parti­cular instance of it. A reference variable may also point to a graphic primitive or sketch. If V is a vector, the state­ment V; simply draws a line segment. That speci­ fic line can no longer be referred to individually and its (default) properties cannot be changed. If a reference variable R is assigned to it (at the time it is drawn), V@R; , it may be referred to by that name. Its propertiesare explicitly available by dotted concatenation: 7. RECURSION Recursion is not a concept one usually associates with graphic procedures. However, repetition can frequentlybe replaced by recursion, simplifying the program in the process. A procedure may sketch something and then (conditionally)invoke another instance of itself to draw another sketch of the same type, and so forth. The following example is inspired by Hoare's tree in [6]. It illustrates that the use of recursion implicitlycreates a linked data structure of arbi­ trary complexity. The program draws a binary tree on screen correspondingto a binary expression. Then, according to light-pen hits, existing sub­ trees can be replaced by new ones. Graphic proce­dure TREE reads from the keyboard, symbol by sym­bol, the binary expression in prefix form, and con­structs the correspondingbinary tree. The two symbols "+" and "*" are considered binary operators while all others are considered operands (leaves of the tree). Subtreesare positioned closer and closer together as one descends the tree. Graphic procedure NODE draws a node and recursivelycalls itself to draw subtrees if it is not a leaf. The event-driven statements exchange the corresponding subtree of NODE with a new one, again read from the keyboard. 8. IMPLEMENTATION BGRAF2 is a non-standard language, and its imple­mentation must deal with its unusual features such as timing mechanisms, parallelism, events, image manipulation, and user interaction, as well as or­dinary procedural structures. A BGRAF2 source pro­gram is compiled to an object module consisting of a sequence of pure code blocks and a set of data blocks. The run-time environment is comprised of the object module and five additional processors, the Scheduler, the Real-Time Processor, the Graph­ics Processor, the CommunicationsProcessor, and the Memory Manager. The Scheduler is responsible for scheduling code blocks for execution according to a hierarchical priority scheme. The procedural blocks correspond to the active states of objects, and are given low­est priority. Event-controlled,drawing, and definition code blocks are scheduled on queues representing "pseudo-now"--code blocks which must be executed "immediately". A still higher priority level is commanded by the Real-Time Processor which handles clocks and timing, and by the Communica­tions Processor, which is responsible for I/O and interaction. Slippage [8] is detected and handled by the Scheduler. In camera or debug mode, the line clock is disconnected from the system and the Scheduler empties its queues, signaling the comple­ tion of the current frame, and waits for an exter­nal signal before proceeding. This signal acts in place of a line clock tick. The Graphics Processor maintains the display files and an auxiliary tree, modeling the existing objects and their coordinate spaces and transformations. Each time a procedure is invoked, a new data area is allocated for the newly created object, but the same reentrant code is used. A variable in the data area is represented by two fields, the first of which contains its value. The second refers to a variable-lengthlinked list of pointers, each of which identifies a block of code to be executed "immediately" every time a value is assigned to the variable. BGRAF2 is operating in an experimental restricted form on a PDP 11/40 computer with a GT-42 graphics unit. A more complete implementation is currently being developed. A non-real-timeversion employing storage tube and plotter graphics is being imple­mented on a CDC Cyber 72. 9. CONCLUDING NOTES BGRAF2 is but an experimental language, an attempt to make real-time interactive graphics programming more natural, more modular. The language, associ­ ated processors, and the ideas behind them are a first attempt. The language is not as complete as we would have liked to see. The assumptions we made in designing the BGRAF2 language are: (1) The programmer does not need elaborate data structures representing his images outside those which he uses to draw with directly; (2) The language has sufficient versatility (or, more prosaically, system functions) to let the programmer monitor and control his images; (3) Drawings are two-dimensional in nature, not projections from three-dimensional data structures. The most basic assumption is the first, since the language possesses a dual-purpose data structure for images --as computations take place, images change autonomously. This is both a restriction of programmer freedom, and in the view of the authors, a powerful tool. REFERENCES [1] S. Bergman and A. Brinch Hansen, "Concurrent Programming Concepts", ACM Computing Surveys, vol. 5, no. 4, Dec., 1973, pp. 223-245. [3] S.J. Cardman, "Time Management in Real-Time Animation/Graphics Environment", Proc. SIGGRAPH '75, June, 1975, pp. 201-207. [4] C.A. Csuri, "Real-Time Computer Animation", Information Processing74, IFIP Congress Proc., 1974, pp. 707-711. [5] C.A. Csuri, "Computer Animation", Proc. SIGGRAPH '75, June, 1975, pp. 92-101. [6] O-J. Dahl, E.W. Dijkstra and C.A.R. Hoare, Structured Programming, Academic Press, 1972. [7] D.J. Frailey, "Timing Features for Systems Implementation Languages", Information Processing 74, IFIP Congress Proc., 1974, pp. 354-358. [8] R.P. Futrelle, "GALATEA: Interactive Graphics for Analysis of Moving Images", Information Processing 74, IFIP Congress Proc., 1974, pp. 712-716. [9] W.K. Giloi, "On High Level Programming Systems for StructuredDisplay Programming", Proc. SIGGRAPH '75, June, 1975, pp. 61-69. [10] A. Kaufman and S. article_rec.title: A developmental system for microcomputer based intelligent graphics terminals

abstract.par: A low cost intelligent graphics terminal for developmental work consisting of a Tektronix storage tube terminal and an ALTAIR 8800 microcomputer is described. The microcomputer system is used to develop and debug customized intelligent terminal configurations and features before a production model is finalized and fabricated. This allows flexibility in terminal design and allows changes to be tried easily before final versions are built. The customized terminal features that are described are the abilities to process a segmented display file, to provide refresh of up to 130 characters or vectors, to control accessory devices such as a flexible disk and a graphics tablet, to provide data compression of over 60% on large pictures, and to provide a local debugging utility.

Maas Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory Los Alamos, New Mexico 87545 ABSTRACT A low cost intelligent graphics terminal for developmental work consisting of a Tektronix storage tube terminal and an ALTAIR 8800 microcomputer is described. The microcomputer system is used to develop and debug customized intelligent terminal configurationsand features before a production model is finalized and fabricated. This allows flexibility in terminal design and allows changes to be tried easily before final versions are built. The customized terminal features that are described are the abilities to process a segmented display file, to provide refresh of up to 130 characters or vectors, to control accessory devices such as a flexible disk and a graphics tablet, to provide data compression of over 60% on large pictures, and to provide a local debugging utility. 1. In speeds involved, complex pictures take a this sense, two of the three bits mentioned relativelylarge amount of time to paint on the above are not redundant because they are used to indicate whether a character represents X or Y data, and low or high order bits. Thus, a stand-alone Tektronix graphics terminal has a certain amount of data compression built into it. However, for pictures that have the property mentioned above, it is desirable to be able to use relative coordinates for addressing points. If endpoints of successive vectors in a sequence have not changed much, it does not take many bits of information to represent the change; however, some information must also be present that tells how many bits of data correspond to a given point. There is more than one way to implement the above ideas. The amount of data compression attainable with a given scheme is picture dependent so that an adaptive scheme would seem desirable. However, a fixed scheme can be implemented that works well for a variety of pictures, yet still gives very good data compression for pictures composed mainly of very short vectors. The method operates on sequences of vectors such that in a given sequence, the endpoints of successive vectors do not change by more than a fixed amount n (which can vary from sequence to sequence) in absolute screen coordinates. The data is packed as n-bit relative coordinate information into 8-bit characters for transmission to a terminal. These sequences, with their corresponding n, are recognized by the terminal by means of certain control characters. For a given picture, n should be chosen as small as possible in a given sequence, otherwise a loss of data compression would result. Also, the number of sequences in a picture should be minimized because of the overhead of the control characters that must be sent to signify a sequence. These two conditions are not always compatible, so that a compromise must be reached. A fine mesh is an example of the type of picture for which the method works well. Meshes typically arise when partial differential equations are numerically solved by a finite element or a finite difference scheme. Usually we can take n = 5 or 6 for these pictures and obtain up to 60% data compression compared to the usual Tektronix data format. A disadvantage of the above data compression scheme is that if there is a transmission error in one of the compressed sequences, the picture can become greatly distorted. If one of the packed data characters is received incorrectly the portion of the picture represented by the rest of that sequence will be translated from the correct version. This does not happen with absolute coordinate data. If a control character is missed, the result is much worse. Thus, an error detection scheme might be a worthwhile addition to the data compression scheme, depending upon the quality of the data lines between the host computer and the microcomputer. 2.2 Selective Refresh A capability that is very desirable in certain applications is the ability to refresh selected information on the screen of the terminal. For example, there might be a large amount of stored picture information on the screen while only a menu is being refreshed. If the menu were stored and the screen erased every time the menu area filled up a large amount of time would be spent needlessly in repainting the picture information. In addition to storage capability, the 4015 has a limited refresh capability. For hardware characters, the refresh limit is 4000 characters per second, which is about 130 characters at a 30 Hertz refresh rate. Vector refresh is limited by the line rate between the microcomputer and the terminal, but cannot exceed 5000 inches per second. Tektronix sells a custom product "display buffer" that can be used for refresh purposes independentlyof a microcomputer [4]. This buffer can drive the terminal at the full refresh rate. However, the display buffer is almost as expensive as the complete microcomputer system. On the other hand, the display buffer plugs into the terminal s minibus, making a more compact arrangement. Therefore, depending upon the application involved, it might be desirable to use the display buffer alone, the microcomputer alone, or both the display buffer and the microcomputer. If the microcomputeris used alone for refresh, a high speed interface (TTY-port interface) must be used instead of a RS232 interface to take full advantage of the terminal s speed. The display buffer might be used alone for those applicationswhere the added capabilitiesof the microcomputer are not needed. The microcomputer might be used alone for those applications requiring several custom features. Both the display buffer and the microcomputermight be used when it is inconvenient to have a TTY interface on the Tektronix terminal or when the microcomputer would be overtaxed without the display buffer. 2.3 Device Control The microcomputer is well-suited to use as a controller for a graphics tablet or a flexible disc. Our time-sharing systems will accept input data strings only if they are less than a certain length and conform to a certain format. However, it is desirable to be able to send large amounts of data from a tablet or disk to the host computers. Consider the case where one wants to draw curves on the tablet and have the coordinates sent to a host machine. This is useful, for example in interactively solving boundary value problems for partial differential equations. A Tektronix tablet has a mode in which it continuously samples the pen position and generates coded coordinates. However, our time-sharing systems will not accept these continuous strings of data. But, by having the microcomputer store the data, block it into suitably sized and formatted blocks, and ship the data to the host one block at a time upon prompts by the host the continuous mode of the tablet becomes usable. Communication between the tablet and the microcomputer is accomplished by means of certain fixed control characters that the tablet is equipped to generate for these purposes. The Tektronix flexible disks are equipped to send data to a host in a prompted block mode if the data on the disk has previously been assembled into blocks of the appropriate size, separated by carriage return characters. Clearly, there are cases when the data will not have this format, and the microcomputer can then be used to send the data as outlined above. The microcomputer also makes feasible the use of a flexible disk or a graphics tablet of another manufacturer to obtain special features or lower cost in a specific application. The only requirement is that the microcomputer be equipped with an I/O port with the appropriate kind of interface to the disk or tablet. Much of the same software in the host computer that is used for the Tektronix disk or tablet can be used for another manufacturer'sdisk or tablet. The microcomputer handles the conversion between the various control sequences,block sizes, and, in the case of the tablet, coordinate codes. 2.4 Segmented Display File The ability to support a segmented display file [2] that is stored locally at the terminal can be useful in those applicationswhere only part of a picture changes between viewings. Only those segments of a picture that change between viewings are retransmitted from the host. In storage mode, the 4015 is capable of generating 1000 hardware characters per second. The vector writing rate is the same as in refresh mode. Therefore, great savings are possible in data communicationstime and in picture repaint time. The segmented display file can be stored on a flexible disk or in the microcomputer's memory. The Tektronix flexible disk interfaces directly to the terminal's minibus and can transmit data to the terminal at a rate of 6000 baud. If the memory of the microcomputer is used for storing the display file, then direct memory access (DMA) to the terminal would be a desirable feature. Segmentation is handled with a minimal amount of software in the host computer, in addition to the Tektronix software. These additions are in the form of a library of FORTRAN subroutines. These subroutines include open, close, append, delete, paint, display, and undisplay. "Open" and "close" are used in conjunction with each other to define a segment and to cause it to be stored. Segments are only stored in the memory of the microcomputer. "Append" is used to add to the contents of a segment and "delete" is used to delete a segment. A display flag is associated with each segment. When the "paint" subroutine is called, all segments that have their display flag set are drawn on the terminal. The display flags can be set and reset by the "display" and "undisplay" subroutines respectively. The memory of the microcomputer is managed by a linked list scheme. A related function is storing display subroutines or templates [2] locally at the terminal. This has obvious application to logicor electronic circuit design. The display subroutines could be descriptions of the commonly used circuit symbols in relative coordinates. A circuit design or analysis program in the host computer could display a symbol by transmitting to the terminal a symbol identifier and positioning data, not a detailed description of that symbol in absolute coordinates. Any vectors that lie partially or totally outside the viewing area after positioning are forced to the boundary. Better clipping will be provided in later versions. 2.5 Program Debugging The microcomputer can serve as a very useful debugging utility. For example, character sequences that produce very strange behavior may be sent to the terminal. When this happens because of some software or hardware error, it can be very difficult to locate. Such things have happened because of system errors on both time-sharing systems. The microcomputer can track down such problems by triggeringon specified character sequences and by storing the transmitted data bordering on the trigger points. The stored data can then be sent one character at a time to the terminal, thus trapping the offending character(s) without manually searching through and decoding a paper tape full of hundreds of characters. The microcomputer can also be used as a diagnostic tool to check out graphics terminals. A program written to sequentiallyexercise all of the various modes of the terminal can aid greatly in locating hardware problems. 3. Hardware and Software of the Developmental System The technology for implementing the functions we have described with a microprocessorhas existed for several years. However, it is only recently that hardware prices have dropped to the point where we could consider putting such a system on every Tektronix graphics terminal at the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory that could potentially benefit from it. Our philosophyhas been to purchase, rather than design, hardware whenever possible. Furthermore, we program in a high level language, PL/M [1], to keep software costs to a minimum, except when the executable code is too slow. Our developmental system consists of a MITS ALTAIR 8800 microcomputerand a Tektronix 4015 storage tube graphicsterminal. The ALTAIR microcomputer uses an INTEL 8080 8-bit microprocessor,which executes all instructions in 2-9 microseconds and can directly address up to 64K of memory. A bus structure is used on which the I/O lines, the memory address lines control signals, power supply voltages for TTL and MOS circuits, etc., are available. A large number of accessoryboards that plug into the bus are available from MITS and other manufacturers. We have 9K of 8-bit word volatile semiconductormemory, 4K of EROM nonvolatile memory, two I/O channels with RS232C interface, and two I/O channels that can interface to either RS232C, TTL levels, or TTY 20 milliampere current loop standards. The complete microcomputer costs under $1600. Both volatile and nonvolatile memory is available for less than 2/3 cent per bit on 4K memory boards. A real time clock vectored interrupt capability, and DMA would enhance our abilities to perform the functions that we have described, and these will be added to the system as they become commercially available. The I/O boards can accept any of the standard ASCII characters with or without a parity bit. However, the boards had to be modified to enable them to transmit and receive a "break" control signal, which is used by both of our time-sharing systems. Our Tektronix 4015 is equipped with a 4921 flexible disc, a 4953 graphics tablet and a Tektronix special product display buffer. The 4015 also has an enhanced graphicsmodule that provides features useful in some applications, such as 4096 x 4096 point addressabilityand hardware dashed and dotted lines. Source code for the microcomputer is written in the PL/M language. PL/M is similar to, but simpler and more systems-oriented than PL/1, and can be learned in several days by anyone who is familiar with a high-level programming language. We have a PL/M cross-compiler implemented on both the KRONOS and LTSS time-sharing systems. There is also an 8080 simulator that can be used, among other things, for timing measurements on portions of code. A cross-assembleris available that we use for optimizing code that is too slow from the compiler and for writing heavily used subroutines. All of the above software packagesare INTEL products that are written in FORTRAN. Once the executable code has been generated on one of the time-sharing systems, we "down line load" it via the data communication lines into the microcomputer by means of a loader permanently stored in EROM. The code can then be tested and changes can be made either by keying them in directly at the microcomputer or by changing the source code on the time-sharing system. When a code is completely debugged, it can be put in EROM for use in a dedicated microcomputer system. Control character sequences are used to switch between the various modes of the microcomputer system. The down-line loader has simple checksum error checking and handshaking with the software in the host computer. It requires about 600 eight-bit words of storage for the program itself. Programs for refresh segmentation, controlling peripherals,and debugging all require similar amounts of program storage. Programs for data compression and subroutining are longer, but the actual lengths can vary greatly depending upon the exact implementation. Conclusion An ALTAIR 8800 microcomputerconnected to a Tektronix graphics terminal provides a low cost intelligent graphics terminal that can handle the functions described in this paper. Software costs are minimal because the programming for the microcomputercan be done in a high-level language. Also, we have only implemented functions that involve a minimum of software changes in the host computer to the previously existing software. There are several functions that would be useful but would involve major software additions and changes in the host computer. For example, conic sections could be sent by the host computer in parametric form and decoded by the microcomputer. However, applications software would have to be written that would take advantage of this capability. This is a nontrivial task if general purpose codes are desired. A data compression scheme for text, such as described in [3], is another example. REFERENCES [1] INTEL -"A Guide to PL/M Programming" Rev. 1, Intel Corp., Santa Clara, Calif., September 1973. [2] W. Newman and R. Sproull -"Principles of Interactive Computer Graphics," McGraw Hill, 1973. [3] J. Sullivan -"Text and Data Compression," Union Carbide Corp., Report UCCND-CSD-INF-51 August 1975. article_rec.title: A mobile remote data collection and graphics display station

abstract.par: A low cost graphic and data collection facility consisting of a storage tube display, plotter, digital multimeter, floppy disc, calculator and BCD instrumentation interface has been built into a single, mobile unit. Laboratory data may be collected automatically by recording the output of the low speed digital multimeter or medium speed BCD DMA interface in calculator memory and then buffering the data to either floppy disc or tape cassette. The data can be summarized and displayed immediately on the CRT or plotter by the calculator using programs available on a floppy disc resident library. Alternatively, the data can be routed to one of two timesharing computer systems at speeds up to 9600 baud where 2-D and 3-D software packages and large application libraries can be used to construct more sophisticated displays for presentation interactively on the CRT. Various applications appropriate to a university environment are discussed. A similar facility at the Sacramento offices of the Army Corps of Engineers used for flood information reporting is also described.

fulltext.ft_body: A MOBILE REMOTE DATA COLLECTION AND GRAPHICS DISPLAY STATION* Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania John G. MILES Department of Computer Science California State University, Sacramento Sacramento, California 95819 A low cost graphic and data collection facility consisting of a storage tube display, plotter, digital multimeter, floppy disc, calculator and BCD instrumentationinterface has been built into a single, mobile unit. Laboratory data may be collected automaticallyby recording the output of the low speed digital multimeter or medium speed BCD DMA interface in calculator memory and then buffering the data to either floppy disc or tape cassette. The data can be summarizedand displayed immediately on the CRT or plotter by the calculatorusing programs available on a floppy disc resident library. Alternatively, the data can be routed to one of two timesharing computer systems at speeds up to 9600 baud where 2-D and 3-D software packages and large application libraries can be used to construct more sophisticated displays for presentation interactively on the CRT. Various applications appropriate to a university environment are dis­ cussed. A similar facility at the Sacramento offices of the Army Corps of Engineers used for flood information reporting is also described. 1. INTRODUCTION One year ago the California State University at Sacramento (CSUS) found itself in a situation familiar to a number of medium sized campuses. The computing resources available to the campus community were available in isolated pockets of processing power distributed over the campus. CSUS is one of 19 campuses in the Calfornia State University and Colleges (CSUC) system which main­ tains a large batch facility and a centralized 96 port timesharing system for use by all campuses. The Sacramento campus has a local batch computer with a communications link to the large machine and eight ports into the timesharing facility. In addition, CSUS has its own 32 port timesharing minicomputer system and a number of small, stand alone, limited capacity minicomputers. Sheer pro­cessing power seemed adequate but the campus lacked facilities for real time acquisition and storage of data in a form compatible with any of the larger processors, and had no graphics capability whatever. Lacking a comprehensive network linking available processors with on-site data acquisition and dis­play terminals, the University sought an affordable solution to the problem of servicing the data col­lection and display needs in the physical science laboratories. These laboratories are located in close proximity to one another in a large science building which also houses the computer center. It was decided that an effective, though interim, solution might be to develop an integrated, portable unit with the needed capabilities that could be shared among a number of disciplines. The component list had to include a CRT terminal with vector graphics, X-Y plotter, auxiliary storage, analog-to-digital converter and a pro­ grammable processor with sufficient interfacing and capability to control the flow of information between the components. The local mini timeshar­ing system has 16 hardwired and 16 dialup ports and since the eight ports to the large central facility are also dialup, it was necessary that the graphics terminal be able to communicate with either system over the switched telephone network at 110 to 300 baud and up to 9600 baud via the hardwired, RS232 ports on the mini. The central timesharing computer would provide 32K user parti­tions, virtually unlimited on-line file storage capacity and a good FORTRAN compiler for the type of applications anticipated. The terminal con­figurability capabilities of the local mini time­ sharing operating system--specificallythe baud rate select/option--wouldprovide a means for moving laboratory data into files on a system on which an extensive applications software library already exists. The requirements were met with the system which is described below. The cost of the hardware was about $22,000. A similar facility was acquired by the Sacramento District Army Corps of Engineers. Many common problems and applications have been broached through a cooperative arrangement between Corps of Engineers personnel and Computer Science department faculty and students. A discussion of the system and current and potential applications follows. 2. DISPLAY STATION CONFIGURATION A number of vendors supply stand alone data ac­quisition and or display systems that meet some or all the above requirements. Tektronix, Inc. components were chosen primarily because of the low cost, high resolution characteristics of the model 4010-1 graphics terminal [1,2]. The calcu­ lator was a political and fiscal compromise that has proven to be adequate at least for the short run. The diagram in Figure 1 illustrates the system as currently configured. Fig. 1 - Display Station Diagram All components including the terminal have been mounted on a specially designed cart three feet wide by three feet high by six feet long. The cart may be easily moved into any lab or classroom on campus from its usual location in the graphics laboratory in the computer center. Also located (permanently)in the graphics lab is an additional model 4010-1 and a hard copy unit connectable to either terminal. The floppy disc unit is an essential component in this configuration. Each disc has 64 tracks, 32 sectors per track and 128 bytes per sector. Any track can be addressed and read/write opera­ tions initiated manually by means of front panel controls. The terminal-to-discinterface allows complete control of the disc unit by means of control character sequences keyed in from the keyboard when off line, or computer generated sequences when on line. The calculator can address the disc, as well, through its own inter­ face as shown in Figure 1. The terminal and the disc can be disabled or enabled independently with appropriate control sequences. Consequently, users can view the disc drive as a separate on line peripheral, a calculator peripheral or as off line storage for displays on the 4010. The specifications and characteristics of the other components will be discussed as various modes of operation are described. 3. MODES OF OPERATION The overriding concern in the development of this facility was the ease of use by faculty and stu­ dents. It is not necessary for the user to reconfigure the system for any of the modes of operation described below. In only one case does he have to depress two otherwise unused switches located on the terminal and disc units. In all other modes the user need only be concerned with the operating characteristics of the devices he wishes to use in an application. He need not worry about the physical interconnections of the com­ponents on the cart--only the external devices in a data acquisition experiment. A discussion of five different modes of operation follows. 3.1 Low Speed Data Acquisition, Storage and Display Laboratory experiments involving AC or DC voltage, current, resistance or temperature measurements can be input to the digital multimeter and the digital output routed to the calculator display register. Experiments with small amountsof data may be sampled periodically in this manner and recorded in register memory and stored on a disc or tape cassette file for further analysis. A CRT or X-Y plotter display can be generated simultaneouslywith acquisition or upon conclusion of the experiment. Depending on the range of measurements taken, the step response of the digital multimeter ranges from less than a second to up to 10 seconds. For typical applications, a realistic sampling rate is two samples per second under calculatorprogram control. The digital counter may be used in conjunction with the multimeter if samples need be collected at precise intervals in real time. The counter can measure frequency, period, ratio and time intervals. A clock rate switch on the front panel of the counter can change the frequency of the number of pulses generated by an internal time base from one second to one microsecond. In other words, the counter can serve as an internal clock which can be interogated by the calculator to assure proper sequencing of activities in the acquisition and display of data in a real time experiment. 3.2 Stand Alone Plotting Facility A user with data to display as a point or continu­ous plot or histogram may do so on either the CRT or X-Y plotter using standard, calculator-based, plot software packages. Data is entered via the calculator keyboard or generated by user written subprograms and various keyword templates are used with the calculator's function keys to enable the user to easily invoke the desired subroutine. 3.3 Medium Speed Data Acquisition and Storage In this mode, the general purpose BCD interface may be connected to any one or all of six digits of any BCD device by means of a specially con­structed logic patch board available on the cart. With the use of this patch board, any type cable from the BCD device may be wired to the appropriate lines of the BCD interface (least significant digit to most significant digit, data ready sig­nals, etc.) Also, if the device is controllable, up to four triggers, addressable by the calculator through the interface, can be strapped into the proper cables on the device through the patch board. Up to eight, one bit lines can be moni­ tored through an array of light emitting diodes and an external clock pulse generator with select­ able rates can be patched into any input or output line on the board. The BCD interface utilizes the external bus (i.e., DMA) facility of the calculator to write a number of samples into a predetermined area of calculator memory. While the BCD interface can effect transfers directly into memory at rates up to 15K bytes per second, the addressable register memory capacity even in the largest calculators (1K bytes) severely limits the volume of data which can be acquired and stored even when buffered to disc. Since the single DMA channel must be shared by both disc and BCD inter­ face, high speed data bursts can be successfully recorded and sequentiallystored on a disc file if they are separated in time by at least one second. A double buffering scheme has been used in cases when the Nyquist sampling rate is low enough to route each sample to the display registers by the data bus and then to one of two rotating register memory buffers which is then dumped to a floppy disc file when full. 3.4 Disc-computer Data Transmission Data recorded on satellite disc in a real time experiment by any of the techniques above can be forwarded to a host disc file on either time­ sharing system by using essentially a "paper tape mode" of operation available on the 4010 terminal­to-disc interface. When the terminal is connected to a computer port through its communications facility, the data generated and stored on disc by the calculator can be transmitted 8 bits at a time to the computer where a conversion algo­ rithm reformats a 64 bit BCD number to its ASCII real equivalent and stores it on a user file. The user can then operate on this data with any number of large software packages available in­ cluding the graphics software mentioned below. If summary data is to be transmitted back to the satellite disc for further use by the calculator (such as to be displayed on the X-Y plotter) the inverse algorithm is used. These algorithms, trivial as they are even in a language like FORTRAN, are inefficient and cumbersome to implement in the calculator language primitives. 3.5 Conversational Graphics CSUS has implemented a considerable amount of graphics software on the large timesharing system in support of the CRT in a conversational mode. Fairly complete, though rather typical, two and three dimensional FORTRAN-based packages exist for constructing displays on the 4010 and for supporting the graphics input mode available on the terminal. The distinguishing feature of this mode of opera­tion is the inclusion of the floppy disc in the interlocution between graphics terminal and computer. An entire (or the important parts therein) on-line graphics session on a slow dialup port can be recorded on disc and played back in local mode at 6500 bps or greater. This facili­tates classroom demonstrations,picture formatting, report generation, hard copy production and even affords a limited opportunity to investigate computer animation. Satellite disc files can be created and managed with a small number of FORTRAN subroutines which can be considered a part of the graphics library although they can of course be used separately. It is appropriate then to consider meaningful and useful (pseudo)display file structures [9] which can be organized and located on the terminal disc. The logical structure of the display file must be managed by the timeshare user library routines until such time as the user is satisfied with the display. Then the display file can be reorganized sequentially on disc for later playback in local mode. 4. SUPPORT SOFTWARE The Terminal Control System [3,10], Advanced Graphics II [3] and Character Generation System [5] software have been implemented on the central timesharing facility as major components in a graphics user library. While these packages are large and consume more space and time than actu­ ally necessary for most user requirements, they have been used because of adequate and readily available documentation. For this reason also, these packages have been used as the foundation for the development of a reasonably complete 3D package with rotation, projection and three standard hidden line removal algorithms: 420 [6], 475 [7] and 483 [8]. In addition, two rudi­ mentary,2D display file constructors exist for experimental use, together with a primitive file management facility for the floppy disc. A simple CALCOMP-like language is under development for the timesharing library which will generate properly formatted data which can then be trans­ mitted to the satellite disc and then displayed by the calculator on the X-Y plotter. A large amount of calculator based software is available for the TEK 31 systems. This software is simply a collection of utilities and is not unlike most calculator software ranging from applications in most science disciplines to support programs for peripherals sold by the company. Unfortunately,it is all tape based but through a calculator file management package, a suitable floppy disc resident user library has been con­ structed which is easier and faster to use. 5. APPLICATIONS In this section some of the applications developed on this system are presented. Each example illustrates one or more modes of operation described above and emphasizes how the display station has proven effective in a troublesome situation in which many potential users of infor­mation display systems find themselves. Lacking a local facility with an adequate graphics support environment and/or faced with remote timesharing facilities with limited line speeds and possibly not inconsequentialconnect-time costs, users may use the disc in a manner analogous to the display processor memory in an interactive intelligent graphics satellite. A display file can be con­structed on the disc which represents the static information in any particular display and used to regenerate that information locally on demand, thereby saving costly and slow retransmissionof that data. To illustrate this, consider Figures 2 and 3. In Fig. 2 the legend and labeled grid for a month by month breakdown of campus computer utilization is produced one time with a relatively simple program in the FORTRAN-based graphics package and stored on disc. An annual utilization profile for each campus computer facility can be plotted on the same grid with only the actual data and appropriate labeling generated and transmitted over the lines. Fig. 3 illustrates an interactive curve fitting program employed by an introductory class in Engineering graphics. Here the student attempts to set parameters in one of a set of parameterized functions to fit a curve to data collected in an experiment. For each set of data and function type specification, the grid and menu sheet is generated once and stored on disc. By pressing two front panel disc controls the student can regenerate instantaneouslythe menu and grid for another trial. In a joint effort between the CSUS Computer Science Department and engineers at the Sacramento District Army Corps of Engineers, an analysis of the graph­ ics requirements in the periodic generation of reports on Californiawater projects revealed that seventy to eighty percent of the data required to generate the displays did not change from one report period to the next--primarilydue to the extensive display formats selected. The Corps is under contract for timesharing service and the cost to generate the two displays in Fig. 4 on a Tektronix model 4014 terminal was about $17 and took five minutes on a 300 baud line. By storing the templates for each of the reports on floppy disc either template can be put up on the CRT in less than 5 seconds and the actual data transmitted and overlaid on the display in about one minute. Two tracks on a floppy disc will hold the data for one template at a cost of less than $.30, based on an estimated $9 per disc. With the large number of reservoirs and other public works proj­ects currently being monitored, the eventual cost savings could be significant. Fig. 3 -Interactive Curve Fitting and Display Fig. 4 (b) -Reservoir Daily Report Tabulation A temperature monitoring and display experiment is shown in Figure 5. A calculator routine allows the user to preset the scaling factors, the CRT screen window and a simple grid is then dis­played. The program enters a wait state until the user initiates the counter by a front panel switch whereupon the output from a temperature probeconnected to the multimeter is simul­taneously recorded and plotted once every second over a 30 second interval. By changing the screen window between runs, multiple displays At a fixed wavelength, the absorbance of a reactant in a first order chemical reaction can be measured at precise time intervals by sampling the counter,recording and storing the output of the spectro­ photometer. In this case, the absorbance at 450 nanometers of bromine in the bromination of acetone was recorded and stored every one half second. Data was then scaled, plotted and labeled using the AGII and CGS software on the large timesharing system. It should be noted that in this experiment the rate at which data can be collected is limited by the chemical reaction and characteristicsof the spectrophotometer and does not demonstrate the full capabilities of the BCD interface. 6. CONCLUSIONS This system can be used to simultaneously acquire and display data, but it has been observed that most users prefer to wait for hard copy until suit­ ably labeled grids can be developed using the timesharedgraphics support software. The floppy disc drive will continue to play an important role in most applications simply because one floppy disc holds as much as forty tape cassettes but costs less than one cassette. Tapes are primarily used as the medium for trading cal­culator routines with other TEK 31 users. In summary, the display station and the similar facility at the Corps of Engineers are coming into heavy use in many different types of applications. As use and interest increases so will the demand for more advanced display systems. Currently, the availability of adequate software tools for program development on various microprocessor systems, coupled with their low cost, would suggest that the next logical step is to replace the calculator with a microsystem as the controller. There will be no attempt to rehost all the graphics support software on the microsystem--anunnecessary and costly duplication. But such a step would lead naturally to the development of a simple command language to facilitate the selection, use and control of the peripherals. At this point in time, however, it is felt that acquisition and applica­tion of the existing equipment was an important phase in the specification, development and appre­ciation of a fully interactive, intelligent graphicsand data acquisition sattelite.
