article_rec.title: Animation on a satellite graphics system

abstract.par: Although animation processing capability can be extremely valuable in certain graphics programs, its application is generally limited to users of stand alone, single user graphics systems. This paper describes an organization of software which enables a host program to define and control animations for an intelligent satellite graphics system. The discussion centers around the particular system on which it was implemented, but the technique should be general enough to have wide application. The results have significantly enhanced the operating characteristics of programs in the host-satellite environment.

au.affiliation: Air Force Institute of Technology, Ohio

ref.ref_text: Griffith Hamlin, Jr., James D. Foley, Configurable applications for graphics employing satellites (CAGES), Proc. of the second annual conference on computer graphics and interactive techniques-SIGGRAPH'75, vol 9, no. 1, July 1975, 9-19.
Richard M. Sowar, Interactive computer graphics on CREATE, unpublished technical report, SLTR 1-74, School of Systems and Logistics, Air Force Institute of Technology (AU), 1974.

fulltext.ft_body: Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania ANIMATION ON A SATELLITE GRAPHICS SYSTEM RichardM. Sowar Air Force Institute of Technology Wright-PattersonA. B. B., Ohio 45433 Although animation processing capability can be extremely valuable incertain graphics programs, its appli­cation is generally limited to users of stand alone, single user graphics systems. This paper describes an organization of software which enables a host program to define and control animations for an intelligent satellite graphics system. The discussion centers around the particular system on which it was implemented, but the technique should be general enough to have wide application. The results have significantly enhanced the operating characteristics of programs in the host-satellite environment. 1. INTRODUCTION The majority of satellite graphics systems in existence today carry the classificationof fixed function "black box" systems [1], i.e., the appli­ cation program can only access the satellite through subroutine calls inthe host system. A subroutine call results in the creation of one or more terminal commands, which when received at the satellite, cause the correspondingdisplay file modification. However, the ability to control exactly when a command arrives at the satellite is next to impossible because of several factors: the buffering technique for commands in the host, the speed of the communications interface, and the operating characteristicsof the host system. As a result, black box satellites are predominately used for the creation of "static" pictures. However, a logical grouping of terminal commands, processed with some semblance of time, can be used to perform certain types of animation. This is especially true if the satellite operates on a structured display file, because certain commands are then quite powerful. One such command may cause attribute changes (movement,blanking,...), or the addition and deletion of graphical picture structures. A list of terminal commands, processed in a timed sequence by the satellite, is the basic concept of animations inthis paper. To have applica­ tion, however, commands must be stored at the satellite with the definitionand control facili­ties in the host program. The following discus­sion deals with a particular environment and describes the changes to the satellite software to achieve animation. 2. HOST-SATELLITEENVIRONMENT The host computer is a Honeywell 635 operating under GCOS, with more than 130 remote devices con­nected to the system across the states. The satel­ lite system isa Sanders ADDS/900 with a Varian 620i minicomputer. The 620i has 12K of 16 bit word memory: 4K isrefresh memory and 8K houses the local system software. There isno auxilliary storage at the satellite system. Graphics programs are written in FORTRANusing a Graphics Subroutine Package (GSP) [2], which allows the creation of graphic data structures on a GROUP-ITEM basis. 3. HOST DEFINITION AND CONTROL OF ANIMATIONS An animation sequence, as defined inthis paper, is simply a "named" list of terminal commands. The commands can be any of those in the repertoire of the satellite, ranging from line drawing operations to the manipulation of the GROUPS and ITEMS of the display file. Normally, the terminal commands are processed as they are received at the satellite system. How­ever, several subprograms (Table 1), designed for the definition and control of animations, enable the host program to change this mode of operation. Animations are defined through the use of sub­routines ANMDEF and ANMEND. The body of an anima­tion, placed between them, ismerely a logical grouping of graphics subroutines. The result of ANMDEF isa special commandwhich switches the satellite from "processing"mode to "storage" mode. Subsequent commands are stored at the satellite until an "end of animation" command is received. The following example (Fig. 1) represents the host definition of an animation sequence named "SINE", which when activated,will move the graphical structure "CHAR" (the letter 'S') through the path of SIN(X),X=0,...,2r. Fig. 1 - An Example of a Simple Animation Once an animation isdefined, it can be activated at any time. It starts when the satellite pro­cesses an "invoke animation" command, which is generated in the host through subroutineANMINV. However, all commands of an animation sequence can not be processed at once, or only the end result will be seen. This isnaturally so, because of the the completion of one command until the start of the next. The time is a direct multiple of the DPC rate. For example, if the DPC rate is 60 cycles/sec., a time of 1 implies a 1/60 second wait between commands, and a time of 60 is a 1 second wait. The time is specified from the host program through subroutine ANMINV. An extremely valuable side effect, used for program defined function keys and normal system messages, is that a time of zero implies full speed processing(no wait between commands). The animation example (Fig. 1)consists of 101 "move" commands. The statement CALL ANMINVC'SINE",30) would activate the animation with a 1/2 second wait between commands, thus lasting for 50.5 seconds. Once defined, an animation can not be changed except by a complete redefinition originating in the host. However, the remaining subprograms (Table 1) offer the host program the control to cover a wide variety of applications. An anima­ tion can activate another (ANMINV), stop another CANMSTP), and resume another (ANMRSM). Itcan also stop itself (ANMWT) until another is com­pleted, at which time it will automaticallybe resumed. Finally, the inter-command time can be changed (ANMTIM) to show acceleration or decelera­ tion. 4. PROCESSING ANIMATIONSAT THE SATELLITE The animation implementationrequired the following of the terminal software: 1 -Local storage for animation definitions. 2 -A clocking mechanism. 3--Single command processing capability. 4--Animation control logic. 4.1 Local Storage Since there isno auxilliary storage at the satellite,commands consituting all animation definitions are stored in unused main memory. This amounts to about 2K in one version of the software and 4K in another. The most common commands used in animations require from 2 to 4 words of storage each. 4.2 Clocking Mechanism A 1/60 second clock was requiredsince the DPC at the satellite is 60 cycles/second. To support this, the real time clock of the minicomputeris used, although a count-down in the main control loop of the software has proven satisfactory. 4.3 Single Command Processing speed of the minicomputeras related to that of one display processor cycle (DPC) or refresh cycle. In fact, if more than one command isprocessedwithin one DPC, some information may be lost to the viewer. Therefore, to control the timing of animations, the host program specifies an inter­ command time that the satellite should wait from The only change to the original softwarewas in a message processingmodule. Here all commands were processed as they were received. The input module buffered commands in an internal form, and passed it to the message processor which stepped through each command by calling on the appropriate display file modules (Fig. 2). DISPLAY FILE MODULES Fig. 2 - Original Message Organization The previous organizationwas not suitable because animations require that commands be processed one at a time. However,normal system messages should be processedwithout any delay. The solution was to treat all messages as animations. To support this, the messageprocessor was changed to a command processor (handle one command and return), and it was given the task of storing commands during an animation definition (Fig. 3). An animation controller (explainedbelow)was written to process all animations, calling on the command processorwhen required. Finally, since all pro­cessing is designed for animations, the input module defines each input buffer as an animation. However, itimmediately activates itwith an inter­command time of zero which results in full speed message processing. 4.4 Animation Controller Every command to be processed at the satellite passes through this module. It is given controlfrom either the input module or the system clock. All decisions are made from an internal table (Fig. 4) in which each animation has a six word entry, indexed by the animation name. Animation is always reserved for normal messages (I/Obuffer) and has its values assigned by the input module. Entries in the table are made during ani­mation definition (START,END), and by the specialcommands used for controlling animations (Table 2). START - Pointerto start of animation END - Pointer to end of animation NEXT -Pointer to next command to be processed ICTIME -Inter-commandwait time while an animation in process TLEFT -Time remaining until next com­mand is processed. Decremented with each 1/60 sec. clock when active. WAIT -Animationon whose completion this animation iswaiting Fig. 4 -Animation Control Information The logic of the animation controller can be best described by the following flow diagram (Fig. 5). The terms used in the diagram are those which are defined in Figure 4. From this itcan be seen that an animationwith an inter-command time of zero has all commands processed in one pass through the module. Likewise,one with a time "n"requires "n"passes until the next command of that sequence isprocessed. Note also that animations activated in the same pass will be completely synchronized, since the system clock isnot reset until the end. 5. COMMENTS When motion isused to highlight a picture, it is sometimes advantageous to see it more than once, or even at different speeds. Since animation defi­nitions are stored at the satellite, they can be activated as many times as desired. However, if the command to activate an animation is processed directly from the communications line, the terminal user must be ready, because itmay start at any time. It turned out that program defined function keys fit very nicely into the animation framework. The host program can define a function key assignment just as an animation is defined. The only change was to disguise the subroutine names, i.e., FKYDEF and FKYEND rather than the corresponding animation names ANMDEF and ANMEND. The commands sent to the satellite are exactly those which are sent for animation definitions, except that a unique name is assigned. Inthe satellite software, a function key depress interrupt causes the corresponding animation, if defined, to be activated with an inter-command time of zero. If the statements were included in the host program, the terminal user could activate animation "SINE" as often as he desires by depressing the appropriate function key. This can be extremely valuable inmany educational applications, and it also reduces the Fig. 5 -Animation Controller Logic interaction design requirements of the host pro­gram. Function key assignments have a great value in non-animationprograms as well. 6. CONCLUSION A technique used for processing certain classes of animations in a host-satelliteenvironment has been discussed. While extending the capabilities of programs operating in this environment, the system has also maintained its original identity in support of on-going and non-animation applica­tion programs. In fact, the satellite has remained a black box system, since the only real change was in the satellites view of processing messages. The total implementationrequired only 200 additional words of logic in the satellite software. The primary limitation, as to the complexity and number of animations, is the amount of free memory available for their definitions. However, rather significant results have been achievedwith anima­tion applications in an educational environment. Certain applications include: viewing the flow of information through a mock computer, flow of infor­mation through a multiprogrammedcomputersystem, viewing a queueing model in action, and viewing several non-linearoptimization techniques via gradient search vectors. Not only have the appli­cations been valuable for hands-on use, but they have greatly simplified the creation of video tape presentationsfor classroom purposes. Foley, Configurable applications for graphics employing satellites (CAGES), Proc. of the second annual conference on computer graphics and interactive techniques- SIGGRAPH'75, vol 9,no. 1,July 1975, 9-19. [2] Richard M. Sowar, Interactive computer graphics on CREATE, unpublished technical report, SLTR 1-74, School of Systems and Logistics,Air Force Institute of Technology (AU), 1974.

fulltext.ft_body: A SYSTEM FOR INTERACTIVE ACQUISITION AND ADMINISTRATIONOF GEOMETRIC DATA FOR THEMATIC MAP PRODUCTION Klaus TUERKE Bundesforschungsanstaltfuer Landeskunde und Raumordnung, Bonn -Bad Godesberg, Federal Republic of Germany Most computer assisted information systems for planning purposes are designed to produce thematic maps as output. Graphic data processing, on the other hand, has not yet reached the degree of perfection already achieved in other fields of EDP, e.g. commercial and statistical applications. The author and his colle­ gues are integrating cartographic data and presentation techniques gradually into an information system. Within the system being described, the geometric data base is considered as a line network. The edges of the network are represented by strings of orthogonal coordinates (Segment definitions). A unique identifieris assigned to each coordi­nate string, and the areal units are defined by a sequence of edge identifiers (Polygon definitions). In order to obtain error-free files, strict rules have to be observed and a high degree of accuracy has to be achieved. For this purpose, an interactive system -DIGNET -has been developed to full­fill these objectives: (1) guide the operator through the digitizing session, (2) ask for the appropriate input, (3) create the reference tables, (4) react to erroneous input and operation, (5) detect digitizer malfunctions, (6) allow immediate graphic replay of the digitized data. In order to facilitate the manipulation of the boundary network files, a number of utility programs have been added to the DIGNET-System; among them (1) DIGEDI -to prepare maps for digitzing, (2) DIGLIST -to list all results from digitizing sessions,(3) DIGMERGE ­ to merge two or more submaps into one final map. 1. AUTOMATION IN THEMATIC MAP PRODUCTION The "Bundesforschungsanstaltfuer Landes­kunde und Raumordnung" (BfLR) is an insti­tution devoted to research and continu­ ous observation of spatial development in the Federal Republic of Germany. One of the most important activities of the BfLR is the development and maintenance if a spatially oriented information system (see Fig. 1). Thematic maps as output from this system play an important part in presenting facts and trends in spatial development. This paper will give a description of an application system for the inter­active acquisition and administration of area boundary networks. It might be interesting at this point to describe the special properties of thema­tic maps and the context within which they are required in a spatially oriented infor­ mation system. Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania There are many people who associate carto­ graphy exclusively with topographic map production. Topographic cartographers intend to store an almost complete inven­tory of all and everything that can be found on the earth's surface an a map ­be it on the analog paper map or in digi­tal form on electronic media. Maps in general can be used to serve one or more of the following three main func­tions: -Store information about phenomena in space (storage function); -Aide the researcher to enlarge his know­ledge and initiate new concepts about the spatial distribution of phenomena in space (analysis function); -Transmit facts and concepts about space in an easy to read medium to people interested in such information (transmissionfunction) (cf.Ganser [3]. 154 Reports, programs, information for parliament, government, public. Note: This is a rough outline of the elements involved; note escecially that acquisition, analysis and presentation interact with each other in a feedback process and thus cannot be separated so easily. Fig. 1: Elements in Elements in a Spatially Oriented Information System a Spatially Oriented Information System Thematic maps are primarily used as a transmission medium, being a powerful tool for presenting spatially distributed phenomena. The thematic cartographer is in a position to condense information and display it in such a way that the user can perceive the message intended by the author of the map within one or a few instants. The same information in written form whould require a lot of explanatory text and still suffer from the shortsomings of language as a sequential, one-dimensional medium describing two or moredimensional phenomena. Bertin in his brilliant book on the system of graphic semiology [1] has stressed the advantages of graphic media to offer human perception a 'direct access' to spatial relations. Consequently most computer assisted infor­mation systems for planning purporses are designed to produce cartographic output. Graphic data processing on the other hand has not yet reached the degree of perfec­tion already achieved in other fields of EDP, e.g. commercial and statistical appli­ cation fields. The implementation of computer aided tech­niques in automatic thematic map produc­tion has proven to be much more complica­ ted than optimists hoped -and some con­ventional cartographers might have feared -ten or twenty years ago. The vision of pusing a button at one end of a black box and obtaining a complete, ready-to-use map at the other has long vanished. We know today that the so called computer map in the near future will be a map interactively chosen under the visual control of cartographers, assisted by sophisticated graphic data processing equipment and software (Hessdorfer [5]). The problem at our agency has been to mix as much computer assistance as reasonable and economical while allowing a maximum of opportunities for the cartographer to intervene in the various steps of thematic map production in order to obtain optimal final results. Consequently in the last years we have gradually increased the computer assistance within the process of data acquisition, data management, analy­sis of numeric data and output of thematic maps. It is evident that a modular, semi­automatic system consisting of many fairly independent subsystem can only work with strict and well defined rules for the different data bases required for final output. 2. HARDWARE CONFIGURATION Currently the major parts of the BfLR hardware confuguration are -a PDP 11/45 master-computerwith 60 k Within the system being described,the geo­ words core, fixed -head and moving-head metrical data base defining areal units is disk, several tape devices and I/O ter­ considered as a boundary line network. The minals; edges of the network -the lines between -a PDP 11/20 slave processor driving di­tizier and plotter; -a table plotter CalComp 738 on line/off line; -graphic terminal Tektronix 4002 A with keyboard and joystick for graphic input; -digitizer d-mac pencil follower with CAMAC-interface also handling function buttons and acoustical/opticalindi­cators; and several smaller devices supporting the operator-machine dialog: -a 32-character alphanumeric display; -16 input function buttons; -8 indicator lamps; -8 acoustical alarms; -computer-controlledcassette recorder for acoustical output. 3. GEOMETRIC DATA BASE ORGANIZATION There are three different types of geo­ metric data relevant for thematic maps: p o i n t s representing the location of places; -i n e s that stand for communicat­ion links between places; and -closed p o l y g o n s defining areas. For a number of reasons, area oriented net­word are of special interest in computer­assisted cartography: -One of the most efficient presentation techniques in thematic cartography are choropleth maps expressing the magni­tude of a quantitative variable for each area by different shading and/or coloring. These provide for an easy to read image of the spatial distribut­ ion of the phenomena under observation. -Most people are able to identify locat­ions by the shape of their administra­tive area ) on a map. Even on maps using point or line symbols, area outlines are often used as a background. -Digitized area boundary networks allow for further geometrical computation like calculation of areas and centers of gravity, or Helmer transformations, or distortions of the surface according to variables other then spatial distances (time, accessibility). *)Gould and White [4,p.119ff]are more sceptical about the layman's ability to identify area boundaries.They still admit that "people confuse adjancent states sometimes, but they often know roughly where they are". two nodes -are represented by strings of orthogonal coordinates. A unique identifier is assigned to each of these coordinate strings, and the areal units are defined by a sequence of edge identifiers. The sign of these identifiersindicates the direction of the coordinate string relative to each areal unit. The boundary network data base consists of two types of files: -The neighboring lines between two areas (s e g m e n t s ) are digitized only once and stored as separate coordinates, in a "segment definition file" (SDF) -P o l y g o n s are defined by their identification code and stored in the "polygon definition file" (PDF) as a set of references to segment numbers. To clarify the data organization used )),we will take as simplified sample area con­ structed for demonstration (fig. 2) and an example from the County Boundaries of Germany (Kreisgrenzenkarte1970, fig. 3). In the demonstration map, Acounty (001) is defined by the segment 1, 2 and 3. The actual coordinates can be taken from the segment definition list (the unit is 0.1 mm). Acounty and Ceecounty (003) share segment 3. The sequence of the coordinates is clockwise for Acounty, counterclockwise for Ceecounty (note the opposite signs for the same segment in the two polygon defi­nitions). Likewise the Counties of Dith­ marschen and Nordfriesland in fig. 3 share segment 13. Some logical and geometrical problems of digitzing areal boundaires arise from the fact that boundaries in Central Europe habe grown historically rather than having been drafted on an engineer's desk as in many parts of the US and Canada. For example, one minor problem is the di­gitizing of several polygons belonging to one administrative area, e.g. islands like the one belonging to Acounty (fig. 2),or exclaveslike the city of Bremerhaven, which is part of the administration unit of Bre­men (cf. fig. 3). Enclaves, on the other hand, are rather complicated to define. Consider the situation of Beecity and Cee­county (fig. 2) or the city and the county of Luneburg (lower right part of fig. 3). The city is situated completely within the county boundaires. If these outer bounda­ries were to be used exclusively to define the county, errors whould occur in further **) See Peucker and Chrisman [6] for a systematic description of cartographic data structures used in geographic in­formation systems. SIGGRRPH DEMO Fig. 2: DIGNET example areas Fig. 3: Kreisgrenzenkarte 1970 (example areas) processing because they do not exclude the city boundaries. The solution is an auxiliary semgent (C), connecting the outer segments with the inner boundary, thus defining a ring shaped area linked at C. 4. DIGNET-A SYSTEM FOR DIGITIZING BOUNDARY NETWORKS In order to obtain network files with a minimum of errors, strict rules have to be observed and a high degree of accuracy must be achieved. With off-line digitizing procedures a considerable amount of post­processing and updating is necessary to correct the numerous errors possible: missing segments, faulty reference tables for areal units, missing coincidence of segment endpoints etc. The overcome these shortcomings an inter­active system*) has been developed to fullfill the following objectives: -initialize a specific map for digitizing, -ask for the appropriate input, -create the reference tables, -react to erroneous input and operations, -detect digitizer malfunctions, -allow immediate graphic replay of the digizited data, -do file handling and processing with minor operator intervention. Digitizing necessitates considerable concentration and visual stress on the operator. The system is designed to give the operator as many aids as possible, making his work comfortable and therefore error-minimizing.A short description of the digitizing procedure may give an im­pression of how this concept has been realized (cf. fig. 4). First, the DIGNET utility program is run. This map editor interactively creates an entry in a directory file for the map to be processed. It generates a file con­taining the area identifications, calcula­tes the number of disc blocks necessary for the several workfiles etc. Among other things the operator defines a code name for the map. Then the main program DIGNET is started. The operator only gives the code name of the map; the system handles all the files automatically. In the next step, DIGNET prompts the operator to input the coordi­nates of the map origin (map zero) and two reference points on the X-and Y-axes, *)A.R.Boyle,the leading worker in the field of both interactive and automatic digitizing, described an interactive digitizing system in a hydrographic charting context [2, p. 524 f] respectively. The rotation of the map is defined by the first of these points. In subsequent digitizing sessions, the system checks for coincidence of the reference points with the ones previously recorded. DIGNET then outputs the name of the first area to be digitized on the log device (teletype) and a small 32-character display mounted on the digitizer within the field of vision of the operator (RT 02). Whenever the input button is pushed, the current coordinates are recorded and echoed on the graphic display. Thus the operator can monitor the points already recorded. When the new coordinates refer to a point outside the portion of the map visible on the screen, the system automa­ tically places the new point into the center and replays all coordinates recor­ ded. At points where three or more areas meet, the NODE button is pushed to tell the system that one segment should be termina­ ted and a new one started. If the node is already recorded, a warning message is given in case the operator is trying to digitize a segment already recorded. The FOLLOW buttonmustbe pushedto copy one or more segments previously input into the polygon definition of the current area. The operator then only digitizes the coor­ dinates of the first and the last points in the sequence. Error messages occur when either an original node cannot be found within a certain tolerance radius of the point input, or when there is no path leading from the starting point to the final one. It is the operator's option to try again or return to the system state before the button was pushed. Closing the polygon is effected by pushing the END POLYGON button and re-digitizing either the initial coordinates of the poly­ gon or the beginning node of a sequence of already known segments leading to the be­ ginning. END POLYGON is used for all but the last polygon in a set of multiple polygons belonging to one administration area. The last (or only) polygon of an area is closed by END AREA. After storing the previous definitions, DIGNET moves on to the next area. Some special functions are included to: -replay all coordinates recorded on the screen, -Redefine origin and skewing whenever the position of the map on the digitizer has been changed on purpose or accidentially (or by digitizer malfunction), -remove the last coordinates recorded from the segment definition, -define another resolution tolerance for picking up nodes previously recorded, -terminate a DIGNET session. 158 Prepare a map for digitizing (define file names, allocate disc blocks, enter documentation) Digitizationof areas defined by DIGEDI List and plot the results of previous digi­tizing sessions, create sequential output Merge several digitized maps by deleting subsequent versions of neighboring segments, renumbering of segments an updating of the associated polygon file Fig. 4: DIGNET system components: A. Main program hardware environment B. Utilities Optical and acoustical channels keep the operator informed on system events. The output of the area identification and the graphical echo of the point recorded last have been mentioned above. Small lamps in the operator's field of vision and acou­ stical signals of different pitch, durat­ ion and quality respond to the operator's action or ask for special reactions. E.g. recording of a simple coordinate is ack­ nowledged by a low pitched acoustical signal; identification of node by a sonorous bell; error and warning messages are accompanied by several loud signals. The lamps are mainly used to show "system ready for input" and/or "special func­tion". A small example may clarify the inter­ action between operator and system. The operator wants to close a polygon follo­ wing a path over several segments previously recorded. He pushes function button "END AREA". DIGNET turns on the corresponding lamp plus the READY light to show it is waiting for input. When the coordinate input button is pushed, the READY light disappears and DIGNET is trying to solve the closing problem. If the search for the closing point of the polygon is succesful, the bell is rung, DIGNET closes the polygon definition, displays the identification of the next area and returns to the READY state. When the search fails, errors are flagged by loud acoustical signals and an error message (either "No node to follow/comple­te" or "No path to initial coordinates"); DIGNET returns to the state preceding the wrong input. The DIGNET main program uses a number of temporary direct access workfiles. To increase the portability of the geometric data base, the final system output should be sequential ASCII files. The DIGLST utility program can create a pair of sequential polygon/segment definition files, list the current state of any map in the directory file -directory entry, segment, polygon and node information in the workfiles -on the line printer and output the digitized segments on the plot­ter. Thus the operator can obtain a hard­copy of the work he has done that can be compared with the original map and searched for digitizing errors. Another valuable facility of the system is the merge program -DIGMRG -that combines two pairs of polygon/segment files by de­leting subsequent versions of neighboring segments, renumbering the segments and up­dating the output polygon file. Fig. 5 shows, how a submap of the areas Deeplace and Endtown can be merged with the example map on Fig. 2 to form a final pair of segment/polygon files. The merge option can be used for two purposes: -Experience has shown, that an operator is able to digitize for about 2 hours with a low error rate; after that the error rate goes up considerably. Therefore larger maps are segmented into submaps. of 30 -50 areas that are handled by the system as independent directory entries. We found out that operators prefer to know that previous submaps are secure againstall the possible hardships of EDP -system crashes, digitizer malfunc­tions, disc errors etc. -; the worst that can happen is another two hours digitizing session for the current map. The problem of updating the boundary files can be solved easely using the DIGMRG program. Polygons that have to be changed must simply be deleted out of the polygon definition file and pre­pared for digitizing in an independent submap. This new map containing the up­dated segments is then merged with the old map. 5. SOFTWARE CONSIDERATIONS The general concept for acquisition and development of software in the BfLR has been to gain as much independence from hardware configurationand operating systems as possible. In particular, FORTRAN IV has been chosen as a language usable on almost every computer to establish a high degree of system inde­pendence. Handling an "exotic" peripheral like the digitizer, on the other hand, necessitates programming on the assembler and/or system programming level. The basic program functions to monitor the digitizer are: LAMPON,LAMPOF control the acoustical and BEEPON,BEEPOF optical signals. These routines are FORTRAN callable and may be used by any FORTRAN program. In connection with the first major pro­duction, the digitizing of the Kreisgren­zenkarte 1970 (County Boundaries), ex­periences could be gathered to improve the data organization and human enginee­ring of the digitizing environment. The DIGNET system itself -known formerly as CADS (Computer Aided Digitizing System) -was first tested in several assembler versions under the DOS operating system. Most parts have been re-written in FORT- RAN IV and tested within in a new multi­ programming system (RSX-11M). 161 6. FIELDS OF APPLICATION OF BOUNDARY NETWORK FILES When several areas are added together to form new units we speak of graphical aggregation. For example, all the outward boundaries of communities belonging to one county form the county boundary; the district boundaries can be formed out of the county boundaries etc. Graphical aggregation of areas defined by polygon and segment references (as used in the DIGNET output) is comparatively easy. The new aggregates can be defined by explicit refrences ("area D is formed by areas A, B and C"). Aggregation of areas on the different levels of an administrat­ ive hierarchy can be much facilitated by the structure of area identificationnum­bers used. The official German identifi­ cation numbers consist of eight digits: two digits defining the federal state, one for the district, two for the county and three for the community. E.g. to find the areas belonging to one Regierungsbezirk (governmentaldistrict) of the Federal Republic, it is sufficient to look at the first three digits of the area identifi­ cation numbers. The graphical aggregation itself is per­ formed by searching the polygon definition file for those segment definitions that occur once for all members of the new aggregate; these segments are identical with the outer boundaries of the new area. There is one minor problem with graphical aggregation: High level aggregates like the boundaries of the federal states are generally used for small scale maps. Be­ cause they are based an a "base" map consisting of comparatively small units, the border lines of the aggregate contain too much detail. For this case we have developed programs to reduce the number of boundary coordinates in small scale maps, thus saving storage and processing/ output time. The value of the geometrical data base is dependent on how well it is integrated into the BfLR information system for spa­ tial analysis and how often it is used to present research results in thematic maps. The production of the Atlas of the Federal Republic of Germany (Part. II) can be regarded as a first test to integrating automatic methods into a process of designing and producing thematic maps. During the last years numerous maps have been plotted for this purpose. The main technical applications were: -automatic classification of data into groups, and plotting of the results using different shades and colors; -color separation and scribing of the area outlines for conventional repro­duction and printing techniques. A more integrated approach to computer aided design and execution of thematic maps is currently being realized at our agency in form of an interactive system that combines data analysis and automatic mapping techniques (Hessdorfer [5]). REFERENCES [1] Bertin, J.: Semiologie Graphique (Graphic Semiology) Paris 1967 (German translation: Graphische Semiologie. Berlin 1974). [2] Boyle, A.R.: Automation in Hydro­graphic Charting. In: Can. Surveyor, Vol. 24, 1970, 5. [3] Ganser, K.: Die Aufgabe der themati­schen Karte im Informationssystem Raumentwicklung. (The use of the Thematic Map in the Information System for Spatial Development) In: Kartographische Nachrichten 5/1974. [4] Gould, P. and R. White: Mental Maps. Harmondsworth: Penguin 1974. [5] Hessdorfer, R.: On CAMS, A Computer Augmented Mapping System for the Production of Thematic Maps. Paper presented to SIGGRAPH 1975. [6] Peucker, T.K. and N. Chrisman: Cartographic Data Structures. In: Am. Cart. Vol. 2, 1975, 1. [7] Rase, W.D.:Bereitstellung der geome­trischen Grundlagen fur die computer­unterstutzte Zeichnung thematischer Karten (Preparation of the geometri­ cal data base for the computer-aided drawing of thematic maps). article_rec.title: The application of the intercolor 8000 terminal to thematic cartography

abstract.par: The Intercolor 8000 color video terminal is used in conjunction with a timesharing computer system for applications in thematic cartography. The version of the terminal discussed can resolve the screen into a matrix of 25 rows by 80 columns with colored characters on colored backgrounds. Using the plot mode, the screen can be further resolved into single-color cells of 100 rows by 160 columns. The value and limitations of the terminal are discussed in terms of the selection and brightness of the eight colors, the dimensions of the cells and the ability to mix colors in small cells. The possibilities of using the terminal for dot, choropleth and isarithmic maps are explored. Acetate overlays can be used to add base lines such as boundaries and rivers and the composite images can be recorded on standard slide film.

fulltext.ft_body: THE APPLICATION OF THE INTERCOLOR 8000 TERMINAL TO THEMATIC CARTOGRAPHY James R. Carter Department of Geography and David J. Icove Department of Electrical Engineering University of Tennessee Knoxville, Tennessee 37916 The Intercolor 8000 color video terminal is used in conjunction with a timesharing computer system for applications in thematic cartography. The version of the terminal discussed can resolve the screen into a matrix of 25 rows by 80 columns with colored characters on colored backgrounds. Using the plot mode, the screen can be further resolved into single-color cells of 100 rows by 160 columns. The value and limitations of the terminal are discussed in terms of the selection and brightness of the eight colors, the dimensions of the cells and the ability to mix colors in small cells. The possibilities of using the terminal for dot, choropleth and isarithmic maps are explored. Acetate overlays can be used to add base lines such as boundaries and rivers and the composite images can be recorded on stand­ ard slide film. 1. INTRODUCTION The Intercolor 8000 is a microprocessor-based color CRT terminal developed by Intelligent Systems Corporation for use with timeshare and minicomputer systems. The terminal has limited graphics capa­bility and is able to present displays in combinat­ions of eight colors, including black and white. The terminal is available with either an Intel 8008 or 8080 microprocessorwhich is entirely dedicated to the maintenance of the color display. A large proportion of the displays can be initiated from the keyboard with the display assisted only by the microprocessor. The terminal was purchased by the Department of Geography, University of Tennessee, to serve as a timeshare terminal as well as to provide a new medium to develop interactive student teaching packages and applicationsin thematic cartography. The terminal is now linked to the University DEC System-10 through a RS-232-C interface and a Bell Telephone modem. 2. THE TERMINAL The basic terminal is available assembled or as a kit. A number of options are also available on the unit. See Table 1. The terminal uses a 19-inch color television screen and the illuminated image measures 12.0 inches by 8.5 inches (30.5 cm by 21.6 cm). There is no hard-copy unit available to complement the system,but the image is bright enough to allow photographs to be taken directly from the screen with standard slide films. Red and blue, however, are darker than the other colors. Exposures taken in darkness from the full screen swept in single colors revealed that the red and blue are two f-stops darker than the lighter colors. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior 163 specific permission and/or a fee. Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania The screen is refreshed at a rate of 60 times per second. Most photographs will be taken at speeds slower than 1/60 of a second so that more than one sweep will be recorded on the film. In almost all photographs taken from the screen at a variety of speeds, a light band can be seen extending horizon­ tally across the image. In most cases this band has not been so bright as to materially detract from the image. The standard display is made up of an 80 by 25 character matrix. With the background option any of the 8 colors may be selected for the background, and any color may be used to portray the foreground. At this level of resolution the terminal is no different than most CRT terminals, except for the ability to display a multitude of colors. In the standard display each character position or cell has a height to width ratio of 2.25:1 or 9:4. Any graphic pattern generated with these cells will have more than twice the resolution along the hori­zontal axis than along the vertical axis. The plot mode gives the basis of the limited graph­ ics capability of the terminal. This mode breaks the standard character into a 2 by 4 matrix of smaller cells. Thus, the 80 by 25 matrix is broken into a 160 by 100 matrix, as seen in Figure 1. Fig. 1 -Sketch showing the two levels of resolution on the Intercolor 8000. On the left, alphanumeric and density characters; on the right, the smallest addressable cells using the plot mode. Each of the smaller cells is nearly square, having a height to width ratio of 1.125:1 or 9:8. These smaller cells can only be saturated with a single color, for there are no characters that may be assigned to these smaller cells. Once the terminal is placed in the plot mode, a cell is illuminated with the foreground color upon receipt of the row­ column coordinates. The microprocessor continues to illuminate cells with each pair of row-column coordinates received. To change colors, the plot mode is exited, the colors changed, and the plot mode re-established. The ability to resolve a matrix of 160 by 100 with eight colors leads to a number of graphic possibili­ ties. However, the terminal is designed so that each small cell is treated as a member of its larger from the 80 by 25 matrix; and within each large cell it is possible to have only two colors--the back­ground and the foreground color. Thus 3, 4 or more colors cannot appear in juxtapositionin a 2 by 4 matrix making up a large cell. For if in the plot mode the background is set to white, the lower left cell of the larger cell is set to blue, and the foreground is then set to red and the upper right cell is called to be displayed in red, the lower left cell will also come up red although it was originally defined as blue. There is no way to increase the memory of the terminal so that both red and blue small cells could be displayed on a white background within the larger cell. This fact 164 imposes a severe limitation on the application of the terminal to cartography and all graphics. 3. CARTOGRAPHIC APPLICATIONS Thematic cartography is the branch of cartography that deals with mapping data on a particular theme. Items that may be mapped range from voting behavior water consumption, and crime statistics to levels of income and the type of vegetation. The thematic map may take many forms. This terminal provides a way to display thematic data processed by the computer in a manner unavailable with any other hardware at this price, although it is likely that similar color displays may become available in the near future [1]. As of this writing there are no computer programs available for this terminal--either mapping pro­grams or general purpose programs. We are develop­ing subroutines and programs to handle mapping situations. In the process we have been able to access the value of the terminal for mapping purposes and have developed some approaches to making the CRT displays more effective as thematic maps. The small cells can be joined to make lines, but these lines are so coarse that they still look like a string of small blocks. Because the cells are not square, simple diagonals are not at 45 ° to the cardinal orientations. In general, the crude lines that can be constructed on this terminal with this resolution appear to have no utility for carto­ graphy. But most thematic map applications need base lines to indicate boundaries, roads and streams to provide the reader with the redundancy necessary to give meaning to the information in the map. It has been found that this base data can be added to the CRT display by attaching acetate overlays to the screen. The brightness of the display allows the user to differentiate colors on an acetate overlay so that, if desired, streams could be shown in blue and boundaries in black. Given the ability to display cells at two levels of resolution, in a variety of colors for both foregroundand background, and viewed through an overlay which may be quite detailed and multicolor­ ed, three types of maps can be made on this terminal. 1. The dot map: This map type shows the occur­rence of an event or item at a point. The pattern shows a density in terms of dots per area. On this terminal the resolution of the dots is fixed by the 160 by 100 matrix. At this scale there are a maximum of 16,000 addressable locations on the screen, which should give a relatively decent representationof most data. 2. The choropleth map: This map type is based on a fixed areal unit of data collection, such as a county, state or census tract. The data class is portrayed by a symbol or color applied evenly over the areal unit. Most choropleth maps have the data aggregated into 3 to 8 class­es of generalizationbecause this is the maxi­ mum number of levels the eye can discern in gray tones given our ability to select patterns. Tobler [2] has shown how the plotter can construct patterns that are proportional to the actual values so that the data do not have to be aggregated into classes. Using the set of dens­ ity characters in the Intercolor 8000 it should be possible to display a large gradation of color combinations so that the choroplethmaps are essentially maps without classes. This could occur only when the maps are made with the 80 by 25 matrix. 3. The isarithmic map: This map type portrays a smooth, continuous surface formed by such variables as elevation, temperature and populat­ion density. Values are given at a few points, and the surface is derived by interpolation between the known points. There are many ways to perform the interpolation. On this terminal, the isarithmic surface can be shown with the large cells using the full range of characters to get a continuum of shadings. The purpose of the continuum is to have a range of color com­binations which give the impression of a smooth range of categories from high to low. This is the same continuum we would seek fro the class­less choroplethmaps. Many applications of thematic cartography are designed around a cell [3]. Such maps might be classed as dot and/or choroplethmaps. As dot maps they show an occurrence or non-occurrenceat a point--the point being the cell. As choropleth maps they show data by classes assigned to fixed areas--the areas being the cells. Baxter, et. al. [4] uses rectangular cells of two basic sizes to map environmentaldata for land use analysis. These cells are a function of the geographic grid. At the latitude where most of this work is done, a unit of longitude is 0.8 times the length of a unit of longitude. The cells for data collection have the same dimensions and are conveniently represented by a single character on the line printer. Carter [5] designed an urban map using square cells based on units 500 feet to the side. Icove [6] used cells in a hierarchy to map incidences of fire events. In the hierarchy the smaller cells were square, but larger cells were longer than they were wide. These examples were noted to illustrate that there are many thematic map applicationswhich use cells as the basic unit of data collection and display. However, almost all schemes use cells with a height to width ratio different from the dimensions obtained with this terminal. To apply any of these existing data sets to the terminal display will require compromise. Probably the easiest compromise can be achieved by stretching the base overlay along one axis. In all of the cases noted above, the distortion would be small and probably not recognizable by most users. For any new mapping situations, the dimensions of the cells for data aggregation might be selected to fit the terminal, if that were deemed important. If the cells of data collectionwere designed to coincide with the dimensions of the cells on the terminal, the cells of data collectionwould be distorted if ever displayed on a line printer. 4. MAPPING WITH THE 160 BY 100 MATRIX When small cells are used for the level of presen­ tation there are only two colors that may be contained within a larger cell. Using these small­er cells the cartographer is limited to a basic dot map showing the presence or absence of an attribute. More than one color of small cell can be used on the same map if the attributes displayed with the different colors do not exist near each other. There will be few instances where this situation can be guaranteed and for this reason we have not attempted to create a program to produce these maps. If the final product is a photograph of the CRT image, then it is possible to produce a map with the full range of colors applied at the finer resolution by taking multiple exposures of the image. This must be done in a dark room or under a hood so that the reflection off the screen is not recorded on each exposure. While it is a nuisance to shoot multiple exposures, as well as being tricky, it does give the opportunity to set the proper exposure as each color is displayed. A program has been designed to display each color separately against a black background. The major disadvantage is that the cartographer cannot see the final product until the film is developed. Along the same line, it should be possible to use the terminal and a 35 mm camera for the creation of "micro-graphic"separationplates for color print­ ing. This might prove to be a cheap way to imitate the micrographics work done by the U. S. Bureau of the Census [7]. No attempt has been made at this time to create plates and print a map using slides taken from this terminal. By combining the CRT display with a transparent overlay of base data and the multiple exposures of the camera a relatively fine resolution display can be produced in many colors. This approachmight have value to show something like false alarms, arson, and non-arson fires on a single map. The eight colors would allow for all possible combina­tions of these three variables, including the null set. The colors presented as solid cells do not form a series which gives the impressionof a continuum. This means that it is not possible to give a good image of intensity at the cell resolution of 160 by 100 cells. Thus, if arson is being mapped at this scale, white could be used to represent the area with the lowest incidence level, cyan the next level, then yellow, green, blue, magenta, and red respectively for the areas with the greatest incidence. Black may be reserved for the null area. The problem is that this combination of colors does not form a sequence such that everyone would realize that red is highest, blue is inter­mediate, and yellow is relatively low. No combination of the full set of colors forms a sequence. The small cell matrix has a respectable level of resolution but with the inability to juxtapose the full range of colors there are few ways the terminal can be used to generate thematic maps. Even if the juxtapositionproblem were solved, the lack of good color sequences would detract from the applicabilityof the terminal for mapping most items people want to map. 165 5. MAPPING WITH THE 80 BY 25 MATRIX The terminal does have some mapping applications at the coarser level of resolution. At this scale the cells are far from square but by displaying charac­ ters in one color on a background of another color, a fine gradation of patternscan be created and the stepped appearance minimized. A smooth gradation can be realized only when the data reflect a pattern with broad changes. When the spatial patterns of the data contain steep or abrupt changes, the angular character of the display will be emphasized. Perhaps the greatest advantage of this terminal is the ability to show on an output device areas above or below some central tendency. Quite often in the analysis of spatial data one wants to map the mean and departures from the mean. In black and white presentations there is no way to have an effective gray tone to represent positive departures and another gray tone to represent negative de­partures. On this terminal three colors can be combined to produce a graded series. The central tendency is indicated by an intermediate neutral color. Cuff [8] has shown that the choice and argangement of colors has considerable impact on the way the map reader assigns the colors to the data. From our experiences it would appear that the only three-color sequences that might be effective are: blue-yellow-red blue-white-red blue-green-yellow blue-magenta-red blue-cyan-white At this time no attempt has been made to test the relative value of these color sequences. It does appear to be impossible to find an effective four­color sequence from this combination of light colors. Using a three-color sequence, Carter is attempting to make a dynamic presentationof the patterns of moisture status conditions for the southeastern United States. Moisture status is an index of how wet or dry an area is. The index is based on a departure from a central tendency so it is appropriate to make this presentation with a three-color sequence. In this case, red is being used for-the driest situation, blue for the wettest, and yellow to represent the central tendency. The map pattern is generated by an interpolation subroutinewhich will find data for all cells based on the known values. The base data showing boundaries and coastlines will be recorded on an acetate overlay. The portion of the display extending out over the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico will be washed in cyan, while the continental area outside of the study area will be shown as a solid white. The dynamic aspect of the study will come about as month after month are displayed in sequence on the terminal. To record the transition from month to month, successive images will be photographedwith a movie camera using single frame exposures. 6. CONCLUSIONS The Intercolor 8000 does have some applicability to cartography. The terminal has only limited graphics capabilities so it should not be considered as a substitute for a full-graphics terminal. The color capability will prove advantageous in some mapping situations, but there does not seem to be any situation where all colors will be utilized on a single display. The coarseness of the cells on this model of the terminal makes it impractical to map linear features. The utility of the terminal can be extended by using acetate overlays to portray base data such as roads, rivers, and boundaries. Hard copy output is not available, but the image can be recorded on film. A range of photographic techniques can be employed to create a number of cartographic pro­ducts. A variety of subroutines and mapping programs are being written which make the terminal a functional, though limited, tool for cartographers. The attractive packaging and low price will probably result in many terminals being purchased for mapping activities. It is hoped that all potential users will realize the advantages and disadvantagesof employing this terminal or any similar terminal for the presentationand analysis of spatial data. ACKNOWLEDGEMENT The University of Tennessee Computer Center deserves special recognition for their assistance and advice on the purchase, installation and programming of this terminal. V, no. 3, July 1973, 262-265. [3] There are many references to map situations using cells. See for example: Coppock, J. T., "Maps by Line Printer" in Davis and McCullagh (eds.), Display and Analysis of Spatial Data. John Wiley and Sons, 1975, 137-154, and Baxter, F. P., T. L. Cox and R. P. Gregory, Land Analysis System, T.V.A. Technical Note No. B9, 1975. [4] Baxter, et. al., Op. Cit. [5] Carter, J. R., Gridded Map. T.V.A. Division of Tributary and Area Development, 1975. [6] Icove, D. J. and H. J. Crisman, "Application of Pattern Recognition in Arson Investigation," Fire Technology, Feb. 1975, 35-41. [7] Broome, R. F., "Micrographics: A New Approach to Cartography at the Census Bureau," ACSM, Proceedings of the Fall Convention,Washington, D. C. 1974, 1-14. [8] Cuff, D. J., "Perception of Color Sequences on Maps of Atmospheric Pressure", Professional Geographer, Vol XXVI, No. 2, May 1974, 166-171. 166

article_rec.title: Cartographic data structures
article_rec.subtitle: alternatives for geographic information systems

abstract.par: Means of capturing and encoding cartographic data for machine processing is a major issue in the design and the development of geographic information systems. The available and potential technology constitutes a bewildering array of choices for system designers from which to select formats and processing capabilities to meet user applications. Designers are not provided a very precise statement of data requirements (or fidelity requirements for the data capture and processing system); therefore, the tolerable distortion rates and tolerable information losses are not well expressed so as to assess coding efficiencies. Nor is there substantial agreement as to the appropriate breadth of comparative tests, as some systems can replicate coverages well for cartographic purposes, while other systems may provide stronger analytical capabilities for processing encoded geographic data.One of the major problems in encoding cartographic data is the lack of measures by which to assess the effectiveness of the coding. One set of effectiveness measures relates to the ability to replicate the source document in map form, while a second set of effectiveness measures relates to the use of the map or coverage data. There are a number of effectiveness measures that need developing in order to compare and test the effectiveness of alternative system approaches. A source document constructed to possess features that will test the effectiveness of alternative systems fairly and equitably needs development. This would result in the ability to establish benchmark tests by which systems could be compared.
