fulltext.ft_body: CARTOGRAPHIC DATA STRUCTURES: ALTERNATIVES FOR GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Kenneth J. Dueker Institute of Urban and Regional Research, University of Iowa Iowa City, Iowa 52242 Means of capturing and encoding cartographic data for machine processing is a major issue in the design and the development of geographic information systems. The available and potential technology constitutes a bewildering array of choices for system designers from which to select formats and processing capabilities to meet user applications. Designers are not provided a very precise statement of data requirements (or fidelity requirements for the data capture and processing system); therefore, the tolerable distortion rates and tolerable information losses are not well expressed so as to assess coding efficiencies. Nor is there substantial agreement as to the appropriate breadth of comparative tests, as some systems can replicate coverages well for cartographic purposes, while other systems may provide stronger analytical capabilities for processing encoded geographic data. One of the major problems in encoding cartographic data is the lack of measures by which to assess the effectivenessof the coding. One set of effectiveness measures relates to the ability to replicate the source document in map form, while a second set of effective­ness measures relates to the use of the map or coverage data. There are a number of effectivenessmeasures that need developing in order to compare and test the effectiveness of alternative system approaches. A source document constructed to possess features that will test the effectiveness of alternative systems fairly and equitably needs development. This would result in the ability to establish benchmark tests by which systems could be compared. 1. INTRODUCTION Capture and encoding of cartographic data for machine processing is a major issue in the design and development of geographic information systems. Data capture technology --manual coding, digi­tizing, scanning --and formats --pixels, cells, grid units, points, line segments, or polygons -­constitute a bewildering array of choices for system designers. The system designer is faced with selecting data capture technology, a format that provides a capability to meet user appli­ cations, and a data processing system that is commensurate with the choice of data format and volume of data. Cartographic applications require data formats that more closely capture the fidelity of source data. Yet, some degree of spatial aggregation is necessary for inclusion in geographic information systems. Dr. Dueker is Director of the Institute of Urban and Regional Research and Professor of Urban and Regional Planning and Geography, University of Iowa. Support of the Energy and Environmental Systems Division, Argonne National Laboratory (ANL) is gratefully acknowledged. ANL work performed under the auspices of the Office of Land Use and Water Planning, U.S. Department of the Interior under InteragencyAgreement P7434A. There is no easy choice with respect to fidelity requirements for data capture or the appropriate level of aggregation of data. Too little is known as to the data requirements for planning and cartographic applications and the data capture and manipulation technology for large­scale applications. A region consists of spatially varying sets of characteristics. In this paper, each set is considered a coverage, say soils, and each coverage is categorized, say into soil classes. In other words, geographic data is considered to consist of various areas of like character­istics separated by networks of lines. A single such partitioning of a region into non-over­ lapping zones will be referred to as a coverage (1). For example, there may be coverages showing soil characteristics, land uses, vegetation cover type, political division, or combinations of these. Linear data, such as streams, roadways, railroads, can also be con­sidered a coverage, but with the emphasis on the network of lines rather than the bounded areas. This paper is concerned only with coverages as two dimensional objects, thus excluding pictorial representationof the three spatial dimensions as well as time-varyingpictorial information, e.g., on-line character recognition. This restriction also rules out picture processing, computer gen­erated movies, and computer typography. Finally this paper treats the subject of coverages from a primarily problem oriented rather than tech­nique oriented standpoint, in that the emphasis is on the relationship between encoding coverages and applications, rather than hardware/software techniques for encoding coverages. With grid data it is a simple matter to compare the characteristics of a point on two coverages. The most troublesome characteristicof grid encoding is its approximation of coverages. Accuracy is directly linked to the size of the grid cell and precise replication of a coverage requires a large number of infinitesimally small cells. The first section of this paper discusses geo­ coding options for encoding coverages. Then the data capture, formatting, storage and output of coverages is related by analogy to information theory for purposes of illuminating parallels between encoding spatial data and encoding messages for transmission, receiving and use. This analogy proves useful in that it identifies the dilemma of system designers, in that fidelity requirements for the spatial processing have not been developed and consequently effectiveness measures for the encoding of coverage data cannot be specified. Next, the paper attempts to identify the potential for error in data capture so that system designers can be alert to situa­ tions that can occur and make allowances for remedying these errors, and the development of effectiveness measures and means to compare different systems. Finally, the paper calls for the development of comparative benchmark tests that agencies could employ to evaluate vendor systems. 2. OVERLAYING COVERAGES A coverage can be encoded as a one-dimensional representationin which the basic record is a single contiguous homogeneous tract or "polygon" coded by locating the boundary as a series of connecting points and by indicating the char­ acter or descriptor of the enclosed territory.* Ignoring any error in the drawing of boundaries or in ascribing characteristics, the accuracy of polygon encoding is limited only by the pre­cision with which boundaries can be coded as series of connective points. One disadvantage of the polygon method occurs when two coverages have to be compared. With polygon data it is time consuming to identify the polygon in which a certain point lies, and thus its characteris­ tics, and to compare the same point on another coverage. The advantages of organizing the data so that the character of any location can be retrieved quickly, often leads to gridding polygon data prior to overlaying or the initial adoption of a grid data structure. In a grid structure the coverage is encoded by recording the nature of each of a series of cells ordered in some conventional sequence. Compression of grid data structure is possible to eliminate a data set containing a separate entry for each cell by means of using some form of multiplier convention for sequences of repetitious cells. Both polygon and grid cell encoding are widely used. The polygon form is adopted by systems whose major concern is data storage and accurate cartographic retrieval, and the measurement of area. The grid system is more widely used in various forms of planning, but where accuracy is less important and the ability to overlay cover­ ages is essential, and where the range of likely demands on the system is perhaps much better defined. (1) 3. DATA AGGREGATION A system designermust select an appropriate level of abstraction in converting a map to a coverage, and then again in converting a coverage to digital form, both as a means of reducing the sheer data volume. Level of data aggregation and geocoding options should be determined by the intended applications. Developing these inter­ relationships is crucial to the design of systems having multiple uses, but at the same time it is difficult to relate the designers' options to abstract data use/applicationcategories. Yet, systems must be designed for classes of problems, not specific applications. Data aggregation has two components, aggregation of phenomena to categories and spatial aggrega­tion. The level of detail for coverage categories and spatial units should be compatible. A large number of categories, for say cover or soils, generates a complex coverage, which if encoded to large spatial units, such as LUNR's (2) one kilometer grid imposes a high degree of spatial aggregation. Similarly a coarser coverage class­ification such as MLMIS (3) utilized finer spatial units (40 acre) for predominant use assignment. Consistency of coverage categories with spatial units is crucial to selecting a geocoding option which meets intended data uses/applications. It is essential to recognize that comparison of systems is made difficult if they have been designed for different applications. For example, a system designed principally for cartographic uses may more exactly replicate coverages, but may be incapable of extended applications, while a system less capable of replicating coverages may have more flexible geocoding structures that enable more powerful analytical processing, such as overlaying or generating slope maps. 4. A COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM FOR GEOGRAPHIC DATA A generalized communication system is comprised of elements: a data source from which a message is encoded, a transmitter from which a signal is emitted, a channel for communicating the signal, a receiver for receiving the signal and converting it back to a message to the final destination. This problem of sending and receiving messages through the use of the system which is constrained by channel capacity and the presence of perturb­ances (noise and distortion) is the general case from which this discussion of encoding geographic data is an application. A geographic information system also has elements of a sender, receiver, message, signal and channel. The problems of channel capacity and transmission cost may be considered as analogous to computer storage size and machine processing cost. Of par­ ticular interest in this paper is the encoding problem. In the generalized communicationsystem, information theory is used to measure the amount of information (in units called "bits") that is contained in the data being processed, and this theory aids in the evaluation of alternative encoding schemes to eliminate redundancy through efficient coding. Information theory is employed here to consider means of reducing redundancy in the storage and processing of geographic data. The adaptation of the generalized communication system model to geographic data demonstrates that the terminology or organizationconcepts for information theory is useful in the analysis of geographic data handling problems, particularly in assessing the efficiency of encoding data. In applying information theory, a digital cover­ age consisting of a quantized arbitrarymatrix is considered a set of messages. The gray level of intensity for each cell is a "message." If there are m gray levels or intensity categories, the total amount of information in an n-by-n digital coverage (which is average amount per element times the number of elements) can be as high as n2log2m bits. The actual information content depends upon the probabilitieswith which the gray levels occur. Physical pictorial media can be used to store information at extremely high densities. However, pictures encountered in practice (television images, line drawings, printed pages, etc.) have information content that fall appreciably short of their potential capacities, often by a factor of two or more. The difference between potential and actual information content is called redun­ dancy. (4) Efficient encoding of pictures or coverages is possible if redundancy is minimized, and there has been considerable effort made in devising coding schemes to represent a picture or coverage as compactly as possible. This process of approximating the picture acceptably (where the standards of acceptability may be either objective or subjective) by another picture that has lower information con­ tent has been directed largely toward the goal of televisionbandwidth compression. However, the manual abstraction of coverages from pic­ tures and other sources provides an initial ab­ straction of the information from which further approximationis possible. The object is to reduce redundancy and not content. The process of creating coverages from images or pictures is the first step in efficient coding of pictorial information. Cells within a single map segment of a coverage by definition have the same message or value. Hence, within a map seg­ ment a message of the next cell is a predeter­ mined value rather than a probability of that element being the same as the preceding element message. Thus, the source document is an abstraction of reality,which when encoded enables the reduction of redundancy. Consequently, encoding of coverages reduces to a case of coding long "runs" of repeated message. Therefore, it is then economical to encode the first message of each run and then the length of the run rather than encoding each message or cell in a sequence, and all of the detail that appears in a picture is replaced by a simpler coverage that looks like the original but that has a lower redundancy. The degree of "compression" that can be obtained by approximationmethods for generating coverages is generally greater than that obtainableby encoding techniques alone. There are two basic methods used to approximate pictures; these are sampling and quantization. Sampling consists of taking values at a finite set of points, and approximates the surface by interpolating analytically simple functions through these values. In quantization,one allows the function or picture to take on only a finite set of values or quantization levels, (replacing the actual value at each point by the quantization level closest to it). In approximating a function or surface from sampling methods one can sample from equally spaced points or a rectangular array, though it is sometimes desirable or necessary to use unequally spaced points. Contouring routines such as SYMAP or trend surface analysis, using polynomial interpolation, can be used to approxi­ mate the value at any point in an n-by-n matrix representing an n-by-n digital picture.* Figure 1 represents efficiencies in coding geo­ graphic data. Figure 1(a) represents an n-by-n matrix of fine cells or pixels with m gray tone levels. With no predictable pattern the infor­ mation content is n2log2m bits. A complex urban land use scene would have a lower level of randomness or entropy and a rural land use scene would even be more orderly or less complex a pattern. Regular sampling to approximate the image implies a larger cell size (see Figure l(b) where n > n') and quantization (wherem > m'), imposes a further ordering to the image. Figure 1(c) suggests boundaries are drawn around contiguous sample cells of like category, thereby creating the coverage. Figure l(d) consists of n'1 columns of m'1,n'2 columns of represents one type of encoding where row i m'2, and n'3columns of m'3. In the case of (b) the information loss can be estimated and in (d) the coding efficiency can be estimated. (Run length coding, as this row record with a multiple for sequences of repetitious cells is called, is only one type of encoding. Polygon or line segment encodings are often used. The run length coding illustrates best for the pur­pose of this discussion the potential for compression or efficiency of encoding.) Figure 1 Information Content and Efficiency of Coding The utility of information theory is that it forces system designers to ask important ques­ tions about information loss, redundancy, and coding efficiencies. 5. ERRORS IN CAPTURE AND ENCODING The capture, encoding and processing of coverages provides considerable "opportunity" for the intro duction of error. Although source document errors are not within the scope of this discus­ sion several of the more basic source document errors will be identified. Most attention is given to the encoding errors that occur in the capture of coverages. Finally, some attention is given to logical errors associated with the processing of data, particularlythat processing associated with editing the file to insure com­pleteness and error detection. Source document errors that should be removed prior to data capture, but which if not, should be detected for correction during or following digitizing. Source document errors usually con­sist of missing line segments, missing center identifiers, redundant center identifiers, or redundant line segments. Although it would be desirable to assume error free source documents, it is unlikely that error free source documents can be achieved. Conse­quently, the data capture and processing system must be capable of detecting and identifying the errors for subsequent remedy. Figure 2 identifies various kinds of encoding errors which can occur because of or in spite of error free source documents. Encoding error type one is a failure to encode a line segment; type two, a failure to encode a center; type three, a failure to end a line segment; and type four, a redundant encoding of a center or a segment. (1) Failure to encode a line segment, (2) A center, (3) Failure to end line segment (4) Redundant encoding of center or segment (5) Overshoot, (6) Undershoot at junction points (7) Digitizer error (8) Inability to maintain a narrow isthmus (9) Failure to identify contained and containing polygons Figure 2. Encoding Errors Source: Goodchild (5) (modified) Encoding errors types five and six consist of the overshoot and undershoot problem resulting from difficulties of digitizing line segments to meet at a common junction point. Encoding errors specificallywith digitizing are represented by encoding errors seven, eight and nine. Error type seven is a pure digitizer error caused by the movement to another point than in­ tended; type eight is where a narrow isthmus was not maintained and the digitizer created two polygons where one was intended, and error type nine consists of failure to identify contained and containing polygons. Source document errors and/or encoding errors that escape detection show up as logical errors in machine processing. These must be detected and corrected. Two types of edits are employed to purge files of errors. One type are those which compare points which should coincide but which do not because they were digitized sepa­rately; similarly, separatelyencoded lines and areas may be compared for reconciliation. In this way undershoots, overshoots, and slivers are removed. These edits can contribute to error if the threshold for closing gaps elimi­ nates an intended isthmus or short line segment. Graph Theory edits to purge files of missing or superfluous line segments and center identifiers are often employed. These consist of chaining around polygons and junctions to ensure polygons have a single identifier and that line segments leading to junctions close correctly. Although this discussion of capture and encoding error pertains directly to digitizers, a scanner which detects the presence of cells that are part of a line segment and converts these line segments to polygon records must deal with the same problem, as well as the additional problem of converting cells that indicate the presence of a line segment to polygon records. Alter­ natively, scanning the coverage to create grid data is a problem of filling the cells with the appropriate polygon center identifiers. Assuming a clean source document, scanning for the presence and absence of line segments con­sists of smoothing small scan cells into line segments, identifying junctions, and describing polygons and associating the correct center identifiers with each polygon. Such is done in the CGIS system. (6) Direct scan to grid units is an aggregation problem; one of combining small scan cells into grid units for storage and use. ORRMIS (7) performed separate scans for each category or classificationof a coverage. For coverages consisting of land use or soil type, a manage­ able number of scans enabled encoding a coverage, whereas a large number of uniquely identified areas requires an inordinate number of scans to encode a coverage for say census tract identi­fiers. Scanning or automatic line following technology is more likely to encounter difficultywith source document errors, whereas a digitizer oper­ ator can recognize and correct many source docu­ ment errors. Consequently, line gaps, uneven line widths, intensity variations of patterns on source documents, may cause considerable problems with fully automated data capture systems. In addition, the logic of creating line segments and polygons from scan cells may create error situations. Whether data capture is accomplished by wholly manual methods, such as overlaying a grid on a map; by man-machine interaction, such as digi­tizing; or completelyby machine as in scanning, the potential for error must be anticipated and procedures developed to insure an adequate level of quality of the encoded data to meet the pur­poses of the intended application. In digitizing, the degree to which interactive editing is employed may be a function of the level of digitizer operators. High level opera­tors may be capable of judgments to interactively edit data; whereas if lower level digitizer operators are employed, post edit of their work may be more advisable. 6. EFFECTIVENESSMEASURES AND BENCHMARK TESTS One of the major problems in encoding geographic data is the lack of measures by which to assess the effectiveness of the encoding. This section of the paper attempts to identify possible effec­tiveness measures that would allow comparison of data capture technology and encoding methods. On one hand, there are a set of effectivenessmeas­ ures that relate to the ability to replicate the source documents in map form and there is a second set of effectiveness measures that are more user oriented. These latter measures relate to the marginal utility of additional precision of data with respect to decision making, which at this time can only be approached by setting standards or requirements related to the degree of aggregation necessary for different classes of problems or applications. With respect to the former problem, that of replicating coverages or overlays of coverages, several effectiveness measures are suggested. If a coverage is assumed to consist of a large num­ber of pixels or scan cells, an effectiveness measure would be the proportion of pixels that are correctly classified through the polygon and grid coding. Similarly, an overlay of two or more coverages could also be assessed by calcu­lating the number or percent of pixels correctly classified. With respect to area measurement, the area estimates from polygon and grid coding could be compared to the pixel count, to estimate the percent error in area measurement. Similarly, although beyond the scope of this investigation, effectiveness measures are generated from carto­graphic or map standards for cartographic applications of the coded data. In addition, there need to be comparative meas­ures developed with respect to quality control that encompass the error rate from the source document to the capture to the editing. What is needed here are per record, per cell, per polygon, per frame, per hour error rates for different system types by coverage type. One such measure would be to regress digitized points for a line of a known function. Finally, there need to be effectiveness measures that relate to the appli­cations of updating, edge matching and retrieving data. Benchmark tests enable comparison of alternative systems. With respect to geographic data encod­ ing, one objective is to compare the accuracy of the final product with the original input. This kind of benchmark test checks the efficiency of the hardware system in the functioning of the software programs. Another objective is to com­ pare the accuracy of area measurement, especially after overlaying coverages. This requires use of standardized input in the comparison of the out­ puts utilizing statistical tests. Yet, several questions remain: 1. How broad or how narrow should all encoding tests be? Should it only test the cartographic replication of source documents? Should it include overlay analysis? Should it include other analysis, e.g., generating slope maps? 2. Can one general benchmark test be constructed for both digitizers and scanners? 3. Should there be separate benchmark tests for evaluating source documents? For encoding errors? For logical errors? 7. IN CONCLUSION This paper has identified a series of issues in encoding coverages which will require attention within the next few years. The major unresolved issue is the breadth of the tests to compare encoding processes. Geographic data handling for statewide land use applications requires addressing the issues raised in this paper. Although systems will have to be designed before these issues are resolved fully, the issue iden­tification process alerts system designers to potential problem areas. Until some of these issues are resolved, system designers should caution designers of geo­ graphic information systems of the potential for errors and delays and cost overruns when attempting to encode and replicate a large num­ ber of complex coverages. Presently a coarser statewide system is more appropriate, while at the same time undertaking prototype developments in smaller study areas to test more sophisti­ cated encoding techniques and to develop staff capabilities. Durfee, ORRMIS Oak Ridge regional modeling information systems, Oak Ridge, Tennessee: Oak Ridge National Laboratory, ORNL-NSF-EP-73, 1974.

article_rec.title: On the semantics of the assignment statement of high-level graphical languages

abstract.par: Based on the concept of treating graphical data as a data type in its own right with associated language parts and constructs such as graphical constants, graphical variables and graphical expressions, the semantics of the assignment statement of a high-level graphical programming language are investigated in some detail.It is assumed that the graphical data are defined by the areal external representation model. In addition, the semantics of binary operators, the superposition and the deletion operators, are considered.

fulltext.ft_body: on the Semantics of the Assignment Statement of High-level Graphical Languages Guenther Schrack The University of British Columbia Departments of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Vancouver, B.C. V6T lW5 Canada Abstract Based on the concept of treating gra­phical data as a data type in its own right with associated language parts and constructs such as graphical constants, graphical variables and graphical express­ions, the semantics of the assignment statement of a high-level graphical pro­gramming language are investigated in some detail. It is assumed that the graphical data are defined by the areal external repre­sentation model. In addition, the seman­tics of binary operators, the superposi­tion and the deletion operators, are con­ sidered. 1. Introduction Much effort has gone into the design and implementation of graphical program­ming languages and graphical language extensions [1,3,4,5,6,7,8]. From initial attempts with ad hoc solutions, sophisti­cated and powerful high-level programming languages have been developed. However, a unified treatment of the language objects of concern, viz. graphical data, has not emerged. A study of the literature on pro­gramming languages leads to the conclusion that graphical data should in fact be treated formally as a data type. An inves­tigation has shown the concept to be feasible [5]. This paper is a report on an inquiry into the semantics of the graphical assignment statement and of two graphical binary operators, the superposition and the deletion operator. 2. General Concepts Pictorial (or two-dimensional) data are considered to constitute a single data class. Members of that class are data types such as RASTER, COLOUR, GRAPHICAL etc. The data type GRAPHICAL, the only data type to be discussed in this paper, represents line drawings. A unit of gra­phical information which is considered logically as a single unit is called a Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania graphical object. Graphical data are re­ presentatives of graphical information; the value of a graphical datum is a gra­ phical object. The set of all graphical objects representable internally in a ma­ chine is called the domain of the data type GRAPHICAL. When dealing with graphical data, an important aspect is the model employed for the external representation of a graphical object. The model governs the kind, beha­viour and number of the graphical oper­ators required to process graphical data. For the data type GRAPHICAL, two basically different models can be distinguished. One, called the lineal external represen­tation model, is based on the vector (line segment). Each graphical object has a head and a tail [4]. The other, called the areal external representation model, is based on the plane (surface patch). Each graphical object is considered as a finite surface of sufficient but undetermined size and shape. One particular point on the surface is called the reference point of the graphical object and is required in connection with graphical operators. Only graphical data employing the areal exter­nal representationwill be considered in the sequel. In graphical data processing, graphi­cal data appear in different language con­texts. Any language construct or datum which possesses as value a graphical ob­ject is called a data form. Graphical con­stants, graphical primitives (the atomic graphical constants from which data forms with more complex graphical objects are built from), graphical variables (subs­cripted or not), graphical input and output data, and graphical expressions are examples of graphical data forms. Associated with each graphical object are data named attributes. In particular, the coordinates of the reference point, the scale factors and the angle of rota­tion with respect to the reference point are called attributes. A graphical object can be transformed (translated,changed in scale, rotated, etc.) by unary graphical operators called modification operators. They simply change the attributes of the graphical object in question. These oper­ators are considered unary because they operate on a single graphical object, even though they require numerical arguments, thus have several arguments. For example, consider the graphical assignment state­ment This statement defines the graphical var­iable P with the aid of a graphical var­iable Q which is being modified by the three modification operators AT, SCALE and ANGLE. The modification operators have as arguments variable Q and a single or a pair of arithmetic expressions. Although the syntax used here is that of LIG [5], no attempt is made to plead in favour or against this notation. A set of modifica­tion operators and their numerical argu­ments is called a modification. Modifica­tions are defined by default and are therefore optional. Modification operators are considered to be on the same level of operator hierarchy; if several appear in a modification, they are assumed to be exe­cuted from left to right. Their hierarchial level is below that of arith­metic operators in order to force an evaluation of the arithmetic arguments first. The exact semantics of the modifi­ cation operators are not of interest here; for more details, see [5]. The meta-notation which will be emp­ loyed below for assignments and expressions is the following. A graphical constant, graphical primitive or graphical variable is denoted by one of the capital letters P, Q, R, and S. The symbols <a>, <b>,... are used to denote a modification which need not necessarily be distinct. 3. Graphical Expressions, Graphical Assignment Statements, the Superposition Operator If a graphical variable, say P, has not been defined previously in a program and appears in an assignment statement of the form P := Q <a>; the right-hand side will be called a simple graphical expression, the statement itself a simple graphical assignment statement and the operator denoted by the symbol ":=" the assignment operator. (Refer to the Appendix for a syntax of the graphical assignment statement.) Evidently, in order to allow the de­finition of graphical objects based on previously defined graphical objects, operators in addition to modification operators are required. Two will be consi­dered in detail, the superposition and the deletion operators, jointly to be referred to as the manipulation operators. Both are treated as binary infix operators, and their symbols will be the plus ("+") and the minus ("-") sign respectively. Howe­ver, the syntax and symbolism of these operators are not of primary importance in this discussion. The superposition operator combines two modified or unmodified graphical ob­jects by superimposing them in such a way that their reference points conincide. Each of the graphical objects of the operands becomes a part of the new graphi­cal object without opaquing or oblitera­ting any part of the other. The superposi­tion operator is commutative, i.e., the values of the graphical variables P and S in the statements are identical. Additionally, superposition is associative, i.e., the graphical super­ positions in the statement P := 0 <a> + R <b> + S <c>; may be grouped from the left or from the right. In order to insure that superposi­ tion is invoked only after all modifica­ tions have been carried out, the superpo­ sition operator must be lower in the oper­ ator hierarchy than the modification oper­ ators. Two or more simple graphical express­ ions which are concatenated by manipula­ tion operators will be called a complex graphical expression, and an assignment statement with a complex graphical ex­ pression as its right-hand side, a complex graphical assignment statement. 4. Assignment, Reassignment, and Redefinition Statements Two assumptions will be made regar­ding graphical assignment statements: (a) Only one language construct can define the value of a graphical variable; it is the graphical assignment statement. (b) A deferred assignment is not allowable, i.e., each graphical constant or graphical variable appearing in a gra­ phical expression must have been assigned a value by a statement executed previous­ly. For the implementationof a program­ming language, a distinction needs to be made whether a given variable name, ap­pearing on the left-hand side of an assignment statement, appears in the pro­gram for the first time or whether it had appeared in some language construct pre­viously. Therefore, to take into account the "past" of a graphical variable, a dis­tinction is made between an assignment, a reassignment and a redefinition statement. By an assignment statement the value of a hitherto undefined graphical variable is defined. By a reassignment statement a graphical object is assigned to a graphi­ cal variable which is unrelated to the value which had been defined previously on another occasion. For example, consider the two statements (assumed to appear in the same program): P := Q <a>; ... (1) The first is an assignment statement pro­vided the variable name P appears in the program for the first time; the second is a reassignment statement since the right­hand side of the two statements are for­mally unrelated to each other. The effect of the reassignment statement should be natural, i.e., one that a programmer would expect according to the "Law of Least Surprise". Thus, in above example, the previous value Q <a> of P is lost and P is assigned the new value S <c>. These seman­ tics must hold for more complicated assignment statements, as for example in A reassignment statement, then, discards the present value of a graphical variable and assigns it a new one. So far, not all possibilities of de­finition have been exhausted: the defini­tion of a graphical object in terms of itself is an admissable and often de­sirable situation. Such an assignment statement is called a redefinition state­ ment. As an example, consider the state­ments where statement (6) is a redefinition statement. The modification <b> in state­ment (6) may, of course, be missing. The semantics of this type of state­ ment requires further discussion. First, again according to the "Law of Least Surprise", the redefinition statement should be equivalent to statement (6), due to the commutativityof the superposition operator. Second, a substitution of state­ment (5) into (6) shows that (6) is equi­valent, in effect, to the statement where the sequence of execution of the mo­difications is assumed to be, as men­tioned, from left to right. Seen in this light, a redefinition is in effect just a reassignment with the exception that a repeated modification takes place. For a further example, consider The redefinition statement may be mistaken as a recursion statement, which is, however, not the intention here. At least one graphical language (GROAN [8]) allows the recursive definition of a gra­ phical object. The effect of such a state­ment is equivalent to what can be accomp­lished by the following sequence of state­ments involving a redefinition statement within a loop: where the numerical arguments of the modi­ fication operators in <b> depend on the iteration counter K in some fashion. Whether a recursion statement is of value for a graphical language depends entirely on the application intended for programs written in that language. GROAN is an interactive or dialogue language, and its recursion ability might well be desirable, e.g. in aiding an artist for producing graphical art work. The graphical data which the suppor­ ting subprogram system of an implemented graphical programming language creates during the course of execution of an app­lication program is called the data base. It consists in a substantial part of data blocks storing interrelated data of dif­ferent data types as well as pointers connecting the data blocks. To allow wri­ting efficient algorithms for setting and resetting the pointers, and for a garbage collection scheme to be effective, a fur­ther distinction must be made among the reassignment and redefinition statements. Thus, statement (4) is called a reassign­ment statement of type complex-simple, since the assignment statement (3) de­fining P is complex and (4) itself is simple. The other types are, of course, simple-simple, simple-complex and complex­complex. Statement (8), then, is a rede­finition statement of type complex-comp­ lex. 5. The Deletion Operator In contrast to the syntax and seman­tics of the superposition operator, which are quite straight-forward and where the "addition" of two graphical objects to form a new one is suggested by the symbol "+", both syntax and semantics of the de­letion operator are severely restricted. The difficulties arise from the fact that the deletion operator is an operator which cannot have any two objects from the domain of its data type as its operands, as is the case for the superposition oper­ator and, e.g., for numerical subtraction. A graphical object named "door" cannot be deleted from the graphical object "house" unless the latter had been defined to inc­lude, by superposition, the former. Futhermore, the definition of the graphi­cal object "house" from that named "door" is an entirely different matter: obvious­ly, the deletion operator is not commutative. Purpose and semantics of the deletion operator must be closely tied to the superposition operator; it is, in fact, an operator the sole purpose of which is to reverse a previously executed operation of the superpositionoperator. Thus assuming that the right operand of the deletion operator is the graphical object to be deleted from the value of the left operand, the graphical assignment statement cannot be correct semantically since its left operand is a modified operand. (Inverse modifications are assumed to be unavailable or undefined: given modifica­tions <a> and <b>, if <a><b> = <default modification>, then <b> is called the in­verse modification of <a> and vice versa.) These considerations point out that quite severe restrictions need to be imposed on the use of the deletion operator. Consider the example Statement (10) employs the deletion oper­ator legally since it reverses the action of the superposition operator in statement (9). By direct substitution, (10) becomes Note that in statement (10), the left operand of the deletion operator is an unmodified graphical variable and that the right operand is a graphical variable or constant modified by a modification iden­ tical to that in statement (9). Generally, neither graphical constants, modified or not, nor modified graphical variables may be used as a left operand of the deletion operator. In the example above, statement (9) could have been replaced by P := R <b> + Q <a>; since the superpositionoperator is commu­tative, and statement (10) would still be legal. No restriction needs to be introduced for the case where the left operand of the deletion operator and the variable on the left-hand side of the assignment statement are identical: On the contrary, for interactive graphical programming such a statement is a particu­larly important one. This construction will appear in a program which allows the user to reverse an incorrect or unsatisfa­ctory superposition. The special case P := P -P; or its equivalent should reassign P to the graphical primitive BLANK. Attempts to use the deletion operator illegally should result in a compiler error if the illegal use can be detected at the syntax level, else in a run-time error. Examples would be the appearance of a graphical constant on the left of the deletion operator, and an attempt to delete a graphical object from a graphical variable which is not part of that graphi­ cal variable. Multiple appearances of the deletion operator in a single graphical expression can be admissable, provided it is legal semantically, i.e., the graphical objects to be deleted must all be part of the value of the left-most operand. As the de­letion operator is not associative, execu­tion proceeds from left to right. Thus, the complex graphical expression When using parentheses, care must be taken to insure that all graphical ex­ pressions involving the deletion operator are still legal. The expression P -(Q -R <b>) is legal as is but may not have a modifi­ cation following the graphical variable Q. As to the hierarchy of this operator, the "Law of Least Surprise" suggests that the deletion operator should be executed first if it appears in an expression where both manipulation operators occur. This will insure that only the graphical var­iable immediately to the left of the dele­tion symbol is taken as its operand. 6. Assignment by Name and Assignment by Value Flon [2] distinguishes among two kinds of data, depending on their nature and mode of storage. A scalar datum is a datum which is referred to and stored as a single unit; a complex datum is normally accessed as a single unit but stored in more than one storage cell. For complex data, occasions may arise where it is de­sirable to access any one of its parts, and language constructs must exist to allow this. Single and double precision floating point numbers are examples for scalar data; data of type COMPLEX and CHARACTER STRING are complex data, the former having two parts (a real and an imaginary part), the latter having many parts (substringsof one or more charac­ters in a given position of the string). Depending on the complexity of the data base, i.e. on the data structure re­quired to store a complex datum, an assignment statement can be implemented in two different ways, called assignment by name or assignment by value. An assignment by value executes the operations occurring on the right-hand side of the assignment statement, and copies the result into the location assigned to the variable of its left-hand side. An assignment by name does not necessarily carry out the required operations but manipulates the data base in such a manner that the desired complex datum can be referred to whenever re­quired. If for a given programming language, the assignment statement is implemented as an assignment by name, effects may arise which may not be desirable. Two such ef­ fects will be discussed specifically in the context of a graphical language: de­ferred assignment and the effect on the deletion operator. A graphical datum is a complex datum since quite an elaborate and extensive data structure is required in order to store a graphical object and since it may become desirable, on occasion, to inspect or change one of the attributes of a gra­ phical object. Since graphical data are complex data, it will be more efficient both in respect to storage as well as to execution time to implement a graphical assignment statement as an assignment by name. Consider an assignment statement such as (1) or (3). Even if the graphical var­iable Q had not been assigned a value pre­vious to the execution of the statement, an assignment by name of Q to P can still be made because no actual operations beyond setting pointers and storing attri­ butes are carried out at this point. Such an assignment is known as a deferred assi­ gnment of Q. Of course, before P is being displayed, it will be necessary to assign a graphical object to the variable 0. Depending on the expected sophistica­tion of the programmer using the graphical language, it may be desirable not to allow such assignments. If deferred assignments are to be illegal, the compiler or prepro­ cessor would still need to accomodate programs where the first physical ap­ pearance of a graphical variable is on the right-hand side of an assignment state­ment, even though logically the sequence is in correct order: Similar examples can be given invol­ving the deletion operator. Such examples show that it might be desirable to include in a graphical language an assignment-by­ value statement which should be used only if necessary. In fact, the language TUNA [1] does have the two assignment state­ments, they are distinguished by two dif­ferent assignment operators. 7. Conclusion This paper discusses various aspects of the semantics of the graphical assign­ ment statement of a higher-level graphical programming language, for which the gra­phical data are based on the areal exter­ nal representationmodel. In particular, the semantics of the manipulation oper­ators are investigated. Although a pro­grammer using such a language need not be aware of most details and distinctions pointed out, these considerations become important for the implementation of the language, i.e. for the construction of a compiler or preprocessor and the suppor­ting software system. Some of the characteristicsof these assignments and operators have been imple­ mented and tested for the Language for Interactive Graphics (LIG), a graphics extension of Fortran [5]. That language has been used and evaluated by a number of programmers and found to be sound, al­ though more experience and a refinement of the language and of the system is de­sirable. It may be noted finally that most problems considered above are not unique for the data type GRAPHICAL but arise for any data type which is implemented as com­plex data, i.e. with a data base containing pointers within its structure. 8. Newman, "Display Procedures", Communications of the ACM, 14(October 1971), p. 651-660. [4] John E. Rieber and Alan C. [5] Guenther Schrack, "Design, imple­mentation and experiences with a higher­level graphics language for interactive computer-aided design purposes", Computer Graphics (SIGGRAPH-ACM), 10 (Spring 1976), p. 10-17. [6] David N. Smith, "GPL/I -A PL/I extension for computer graphics", AFIPS Conference Proceedings (SJCC), 38 (1971), p. 511-528. [7] T.R. Stack and S.T. Wyvill, "GROAN: An intro­duction to a general purpose graphics language", The University of Bradford, U.K., Internal Report (revised June 1974), 28pp. Appendix This Appendix lists a formal syntax (in Backus-Naur form notation) for the graphical assignment statement. <graphical assignment statement> ::= <simple graphical assignment statement> I <complex graphical assignment statement> <simple graphical assignment statement> ::= <graphical variable> <assignment operator> <simple graphical expression> <complex graphical assignment statement> ::= <graphical variable> <assignment operator> <complex graphical expression> <assignment operator> ::= := <simple graphical expression> ::= <graphical entity> I <graphical entity> <modification> <graphical entity> ::= <graphical primitive> I <graphical constant> I <graphical variable> function> <modification> ::= <modification operator> <numerical arguments> <modification operator> ::= AT I SCALE I ANGLE I ... <complex graphical expression> ::= <simple graphical expression> <manipulation operator> <simple graphical expression> I <complex graphical expression> <manipulation operator> <simple graphical expression> <manipulationoperator> ::= <superpositionoperator> I <deletion operator> <superpositionoperator> ::= + <deletion operator> ::=­<numerical arguments> ::= <numerical expression> I <numerical arguments> , <numerical expression> <numerical expression> ::= ... <graphical function> ::= ... <graphical variable> := <identifier> <graphical constant> ::= <keyword> <graphical primitive> ::= <keyword>

article_rec.title: Enhanced graphics performance with user controlled segment files

abstract.par: This paper describes a simple idea for extending the use of display segment files in computer display systems. The extension is to provide manual control of segment files in a display terminal as well as program control from a host computer. The use of display segments local to the display makes it possible to speed up the rate at which pictures are displayed when the communications line to the host computer is slow or when the host machine is time-shared and heavily loaded. The manual control of segments are terminal functions that work for any program including old programs that knew nothing about display segments.

fulltext.ft_body: ENHANCED GRAPHICS PERFORMANCEWITH USER CONTROLLED SEGMENT FILES W. D. Little* and R. Williams IBM Research Laboratory San Jose, California 95193 This paper describes a simple idea for extending the use of display segment files in computer display systems. The extension is to provide manual control of segment files in a display terminal as well as program control from a host computer. The use of display segments local to the display makes it possible to speed up the rate at which pictures are displayed when the communicationsline to the host computer is slow or when the host machine is time-shared and heavily loaded. The manual control of segments are terminal functions that work for any program including old programs that knew nothing about display segments. Keywords: Computer Graphics, Interactive Systems, Data Structures, Display Files CR Categories: 4.34, 4.4, 8.2 Fig. 1 The Graphics System Architecture 1. INTRODUCTION Many graphics systems use a host computer and a second small computer with data paths similar to that shown in Fig. 1. Our architectural philosophy has been to develop a terminal with memory rather than a satellite computer system. No application code and no application data reside in the terminal Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior 179 specific permission and/or a fee. Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania and our application runs equally well on a storage-tube terminal as on the terminal shown in Fig. 1. In our system, the host machine supports the application data base and executes the application program whereas the terminal interacts with the user, services the communications line and controls the display hardware. With many such systems, the bandwidth of the communicationsline between the host and terminal and the service from the host limit the rate at which pictures can be displayed. This paper discusses the implementation and use of manually controlled segment files to speed up the rate at which pictures can be displayed and to reduce the computation required at the host. Manually created segments do not exist as segments in the host; the application code need have no notion of segments, and segments created manually are not modified or returned to the host. However, segments can also be created by host application programs. Segments created either way are compatible. 2. SEGMENT FILES We define a segment as a sequence of commands, each of which maps into a command to the display system (see Fig. 1). Segment files can be created at the terminal, and stored on a disc, so that they can be redisplayed in the future. The management of segment files can be directed from the applications program by appropriate calls to the display package, or alternately, the files can be managed by user inputs at the terminal. We refer to the former segment file management as "programmed controlled" and the latter form as "user controlled." Program controlled segment files have been used widely with refresh displays, where in essence the segment files are an extension of the display files [1]. For non-refresh displays, display files are not required and segment files are rarely used, so that each picture displayed must be generated by the applications program. One reason that segment files are rarely used with non-refresh systems to reduce host processing and to decrease communicationsdelays is because application programmers cannot predict which segments the user may want filed. With the user controlled segment files that we have implemented, the user has complete control of segment storage at run time and the applications programmer need not be concerned with segments at all. The user stores segments as he (she) sees fit during a session at the display in order to improve response and reduce host processing. Even existing application programs that were written without knowledge of segment files can benefit from user controlled segment files, because no extra programming is required in an application program to use segments manually. Because the reviewers of our paper did not fully appreciate the general discussion, it is worthwhile to illustrate the manual control of segments with specific example scenarios. Example one: A local government employee is using a graphics terminal to view data on a map in order to investigate a proposed change in zoning in the town. He accesses data in a data base and displays it on a map in various ways [2]. The map is a section of a large map and this section is used repeatedly with different data displayed on it. The map can be shaded according to income distribution or population distribution, or traffic flow, or land slope, or water drainage, etc. The user would like to make a display segment of his map and store it locally so that it can be redisplayed more quickly for each display of data on the map. This is important when the communication line to the host is slow or the time-shared host response is slow. Example performance calculations are shown below. Example two: An investment counselor is querying a very large data base about the performance of stocks in order to decide how to invest pension funds. Searching and retrieval of data involves lengthy calculations and finally graphs and charts are displayed. Each graph (or several overlayed graphs) can be manually "saved" at the terminal so that redisplaying a graph for comparisonwith another graph will be much faster and cheaper than reaccessing and extracting the data from the database. In the first example, the segment data was used to redisplay a "background" to the main display and saved communicationtime. In the second case, the segments were used as a "soft" copy and saved computation and communication time. In both cases it was not possible to predict ahead of time how to organize the data into segments, only the user knew while executing programs. No extra code had to be written in either case once the function had been provided in the terminal. The terminal function works for any application and basically provides "soft" copy capability with the ability to add to the copy or mix copies or compose nested copies. The application program can also invoke all the functions as well and segments created by a host program in the terminal are completely compatible with manually created segments. 3. PERFORMANCE The improvement in response time for local segments is dependent upon the amount of data in a segment, the communication line bandwidth, the host response time, the data extraction or computation time, etc., and is impossible to predict in general, but easily calculated in specific cases. For example consider a map of 2 000 vectors, a fairly simple map, for which each vector is two points x,y and each coordinate value is 16 bits. The map is defined by 2 000x2x2x16 bits = 128 000 bits. If the vectors are connected, this reduces to about 64 000 bits to be transmitted to the terminal. Consider a disc storage in the terminal with an access time of 100 msec average and 5 Mbit read rate. Then the data can be accessed and read in 100 + 64 000/5 000) msec = 113 msec. If the host time sharing system response time is th and the computation time is tc, then the following results: 180 consider the delay to update a refresh memory or to draw 2 000 vectors, which is different for different types of displays and can range from about 100 msec to a few seconds. Whenever a lengthy calculation tc or a poor response time th is encountered, the performance gain is also considerable. In our implementationthere are several independent files, each containing up to 150 segments. A brief description of the segment management within a file and the management of files is given next. 4. SEGMENT MANAGEMENT Segment management, whether program or user controlled, is performed by four terminal functions: These functions can be invoked in three ways: 1. by control words inserted into the host/satellitecommand stream by calls to display package subroutines in the case of programmed controlledsegments. 2. by control words generated by a user activating functions with an input device such as a keyboard in the case of user controlled segments. 3. by control words read from a previously stored segment that is being displayed. The control words are generated automaticallywhen the terminal functions are initiated. The OPEN-SEG function sets segment number, SEG-NO, to the OPEN and ACTIVE state and places SEG-NO in the directory of a linked-list segment file (if it is not already in the directory). While the segment is OPEN all segment data and control words are inserted in the file as they are received. The VIS parameter sets the VISIBILITY status of the terminal (if visible, the incoming segment is sent to be displayed and is stored in the file but if invisible, the segment is stored but not displayed). By this means, it is possible to build a file of many segments, perhaps rather slowly if transmission line or host limited, and display the stored segments rapidly at a later time as required. The CLOSE-SEG function terminates the ACTIVE and OPEN states of a segment. The DISPLAY-SEG (SEG-NO) function puts SEG-NO in the ACTIVE state and displays the specified segment provided the VISIBILITY status is set ot visible. DELETE-SEG removes the specified segment from the directory file. Segment nesting is supported by these four functions also. Each use of OPEN-SEG or DISPLAY-SEG stacks the ACTIVE, OPEN, and VISIBILITY status while CLOSE-SEG unstacks the status variables. An example application program containing host application code to generate segments is shown in Fig. 2. Fig. 2 Application Program Defining Nested Segments Three segments would be created. Segment 1 would contain graphic display commands to display streets, an OPEN command to invoke segment 2, and a CLOSE command. Segment 2 would contain highway graphic commands, an OPEN command to invoke segment 3, and a CLOSE command. Segment 3 would contain a map outline and a CLOSE command. These files would be created at the terminal but not displayed while being created because of the 0 visibility parameter in the OPEN calls. Once created the segment can be displayed by program or user initiated control words. Display of segment 3 would draw only the map outline, display of 2 would draw highways and the outline, while display of 1 would give the streets, the highways, and the outline. Note that without any application code the same effect at the screen can be created by manually generating each segment. However, the segments would then be "unknown" to the application program but available as "soft-copy." Both methods have their uses and power. 5. FILE MANAGEMENT In order to allow several users to have their own independent files, there are three file commands. These are: A user may first initialize a file (erase all previously stored segments), and then create and store segments using the segment commands and the PUT-WORD routine. At the end of a session he can save a file, i.e., "CLOSE" it. To actually fetch data from or write data into segments, the following two routines, which are self-explanatory, are needed: GET-WORD (WORD,ENDFLAG) PUT-WORD (WORD) 6. COMMENTS The picture segment file system has been implemented at the IBM, San Jose, ResearchLab on a System/7 computer which drives a color refresh display. It has been used to speed up the redisplay of shaded maps in the GADS system [2] and for storage and manipulation of segments produced by ROBART, an interactive drawing system used for producing color slides. It will also be used with the Picture Building System which is being developed [3,4]. 181 7. CONCLUSION Manual control, as well as program control, of picture segments at a display terminal is a most useful function. This function can be used by programs that have picture segment handling in the application code. The local storage and redisplay of picture segments can reduce communications delays and thereby speed-up the execution of application programs. This is particularly important on slow-speed telecommunicationlines with a speed of 110 bits/sec but less so on lines at 9 600 bits/sec. In addition, there is also the advantage of reducing the load on the host machine and an effective speed-up of execution when the host machine is very heavily loaded. REFERENCES [1] W. M. Newman and R. F. Sproull, Principles of Interactive Computer Graphics, New York, McGraw-Hill, 1973. [2] E. D. Carlson, J. L. Bennett, G. M. Giddings, and P. E. Mantey, the Design and Evaluation of an Interactive Geo-Data Analysis and Display System, IFIP Congress 1974, North Holland Publishing Co., Amsterdam, 1974, pp. 1057-1061. [3] R. Williams, G. M. Giddings, W. D. Little, W. G. Moorhead, and D. L. Weller, "Data Structures in Computer Graphics," Proc. of Workshop on Data Bases for Interactive Design, Waterloo, Canada, Sept. 1975. Available from ACM Hq. New York. [4] R. Williams and G. M. Giddings, "A Picture Building System," Proc. of Computer Graphics, Pattern Recognnition and Data Structure, Los Angeles, May 1975, pp. 304-307. Available from IEEE, Hq. New York. Also in IEEE Trans. on Software, Vol. SE. 2, No. 1, 1976, pp. 62-66.

article_rec.title: Graphic and relational data base support for problem solving

abstract.par: This paper describes a general purpose 'picture building system'. The main purpose of the system is to provide an environment wherein an application programmer can interactively create and modify applications. In addition to a graphics software package the picture building system provides high-level application building tools and a relational data base as integral parts of the system. An interpreter is provided to draw pictures from data stored in relations. A correlation handler is provided to allow a user to identify and manipulate displayed items. A relations editor is provided to interactively create, edit, and display relations. The picture building system works on a variety of graphic and nongraphic terminals.
