fulltext.ft_body: GRAPHIC AND RELATIONAL DATA BASE SUPPORT FOR PROBLEM SOLVING Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Dan Weller and Robin Williams IBM Research San Jose, California 95193 This paper describes a general purpose 'picturebuilding system'. The main purpose of the system is to provide an environment wherein an application programmer can interactivelycreate and modify applications. In addition to a graphics software package the picture building system provides high-level application building tools and a relational data base as integral parts of the system. An interpreter is provided to draw pictures from data stored in relations. A correlation handler is provided to allow a user to identify and manipulate displayed items. A relations editor is provided to interactively create, edit, and display relations. The picture building system works on a variety of graphic and nongraphic terminals. CR Categories 4.3, 4.4, 8.2 KEYWORDS: Relational Data Base, Computer Graphics, Programming INTRODUCTION This paper describes the design and implementation of a general purpose 'picturebuilding system'. The main purpose of the system is to simplify the task of creating and using application programs. The use of a graphics terminal can greatly simplify both application programming and the end use of a program. However a central problem in programming is that of structuring the data, and this problem is particularly acute for graphical applications. Frequently graphics software packages provide for little or no data structuring. In addition to a graphics software package the picture building system provides high-level application building tools and a relational data base[1] as integral parts. Data is stored in relations which can be nested so that an arbitrary hierarchical data structure can be formed. If a system using graphics has some data base support, generally only the nongraphical data is stored in the data base. Even in cases where graphical data is stored in the data base it is not directly usable for input and output to a graphics terminal. For, example, if an inventory of parts is kept in a data base, a picture of each part is not kept in the data base, althougha separate microfilm library may contain such pictures. Our data base does allow graphical and nongraphical data to be stored together. This capability is made possibleby allowingdata to have graphical 'meaning'; thus graphical data can be said to be self-describing. Having unified data base support for graphical as well as nongraphical data can simplify programming. Also, because the graphical data is self-describing, programs and data can be made essentially independent. Thus one program may work for many different sets of data and one data base may be used by many programs. The picture building system provides high level Interactive Systems, Data Structures, Application commands for easy use of the data base and of graphics terminals. Commands are included to facilitate graphical input to the data base and graphical output from the data base. BACKGROUND The Picture Building System consists of a number of component parts as shown in the system diagram(fig. 1)[2][3][4]. The data base is a relational data base called XRM[5]. A relational data base is a data base that allows a user to view his data as a collection of relations. A relation is a table or flat file in which the columns may have certain attributes[l]. A row or record of a relation shall be referred to as a tuple and a column or field of a relation shall be referred to as a domain. Fig. 2 shows a sample relation with the domain values listed under the domain names. The symbolic interface to the relational data base is GXRAM[6], which allows relations and domains to be referenced by mnemonic name. A comprehensive set of commands for all the usual data base operations is provided. GXRAM supports relations as definded by Codd[l]. In addition, it supports relationswith the following features: 1) ordered tuples, and 2) duplicate tuples (no key[l]). We have found both of these features to be very useful when storing graphical data in relations[2]. The interpreter traces through any hierarchy of relations, converting the graphical data to calls to a low level display package (DISPLIB[see acknowledgements]). Thus the interpreter draws pictures from data stored in relations. DISPLIB is a graphics subroutine package with routines such as move the beam, draw a line, draw characters, etc. DISPLIB works for a variety of display terminals and thus allows device independence for routines which call it. This paper will not discuss DISPLIB in detail. Correlation refers to the process of Fig. 1 -System Diagram for the Picture Building System identifying an item displayed on a graphics terminal. The correlationhandler allows a user to identify and manipulate displayed items. GRAPHICAL MEANING In order for data to be used by a program it must have a syntax or structure as it is usually called, and some semantic content. Clearly one must know how the data is stored and accessed(syntax), and how it is to be used(semantics) before it can be processed. Traditionallydata bases provide syntax support for data but do not provide semantic support. Consequently semantic information must be stored in the program accessing the data base, and thus the programs and data are no longer independent. Associated with the data in the data base there is certain semantic information. Also, unless the data base supports only one fixed structure, there is certain syntactic information describing the data structure and access paths. If semantic information and a description of the syntax is stored along with data in a data base, then that data is said to be self-describing. All the graphical data in our data base is self-describing. Together with each relation a description of the structure of the relations and each of the domains is stored. The description of each domain contains certain semantic information which is called the graphical meaning of the domain. Storing a graphical meaning for each domain in a relation allows pictures to be drawn directly from data in the data base and independently of the program which created that graphical data. Table 1 has a list of the allowable graphical meanings. The list is intended to be comprehensive,but other graphical meanings could be added with no effect on previous application programs. The graphical meanings and the interpreter have been designed to handle three dimensional data, but so far only two dimensional capabilities have been implemented. Each domain in a relation can have a graphical meaning associated with it. Thus a tuple in a relation may have different graphical meanings associated with each field in that tuple. Fig. 3 shows an example of a relation that draws some lines and second a relation with calls to the first relation. The domain names used in that figure are meant to be indicative of the graphical meanings. An application using the picture building system consists of two parts: 1) an application program, and 2) a set of applicationrelations. A relations editor is provided to interactively create, edit, and display relations. Thus an applicationwhich only displays pictures or makes queries of the data base requires no application program. For example, if the data base contains data for an inventory of parts, then the parts could be drawn and the inventory data could be examined interactively from the relations editor. The picture building system works on a variety of graphic and nongraphic terminals. In particular it works on IBM 2250 refresh terminals, Tektronic storage tube terminals, and RAINBOW, a color raster T.V. system[3]. Fig. 3 -Example Relations for Drawing Lines A domain can have a graphical meaning RELATION, thus a tuple can contain a 'call' to another relation. The relation called can be another standard tabular relation in the data base or it may be a procedural relation that is, a normal program. A relation may be called with parameters. These parameters can be implicit ones such as color, shift, rotation, etc. or they may be explicit parameters(P1,P2,...,P10). Rotation, scaling, and shifting specified in a tuple apply to that tuple and to any relations called by that tuple. If there are several levels of relations called, then the transformationsare compounded and stacked appropriately by the interpreter when it is displaying the relation. A domain with a graphical meaning of CORRELATION (light pen sensitivity) may take on three values: 1) make this tuple and all relations called by it correlatable, 2) make this tuple and all relations called by it not correlatable, 3) do not change correlatablility; that is, disregard this domain. A tuple may specify a color, in which case that color applies to that tuple and all relations called by that tuple. A null value for color will cause the domain to be ignored. A domain with graphical meaning of XYZOPERATION specifies an operation on the domains which specify X, Y, Z position, TEXTSTRING, and RASTERSTRING. A raster string is a bit string which specifies whether consecutive points on a display line should be on or off. The XYZOPERATION can indicate that the X, Y, Z point(s) are the end-points of a line, the corner points of a rectangle, the starting point of a text string, etc. Table 2 lists the possible XYZOPERATIONS. Some of the XYZOPERATIONS require two points whereas others require only one point. The window and viewport specify a mapping from the user data space to a logical screen space. All or part of the data space may be mapped into all or part of the display screen. WINDOW AND VIEWPORT Before the interpreter can display a relation a mapping from the data space to the logical screen space must exist. If the default mapping is acceptable then no user action is necessary. To set a mapping different from the default mapping a program must be called with a relation name and tuple number as input. The program will extract information from the specified tuple to set the desired mapping. Positional data in a relation refers to positions in some implicit coordinate space. This coordinate space shall be referred to as the data space. A rectangular area in the data space is called a window. A display screen is considered to have its lower lefthand and upper righthand corners at (0,0) and (1,1) (standard x, y axes) in the logical screen space. Thus mapping a window to the rectangle (0,0) to (1,1) in the logical screen space would map the window onto the full screen. A rectangular area in the logical screen space (or just display space for short) is called a viewport. A mapping from the data space to the display space is specified by choosing a window and a viewport. This use of window and viewport is similar to Newman and Sproul[7]. A relation which contains window and viewport information shall be refered to as a view relation. Table 1 -GRAPHICAL MEANINGS INTERPRETER The interpreter is the major source of graphical output for the picture building system. Unlike other interpreters for graphical data[8][9], this interpreter does not work on a fixed data structure. The interpreter determines the syntax(structure) and semantics(graphicalmeaning) of the data from syntactic and semantic information stored in the data base. The interpreter can be invoked to display a relation on a graphics terminal. Since any tuple in a relation may have one or many calls to other relations, the relation displayed may be an arbitrary network of relations. The interpreter traces through the data in the relation producing calls to DISPLIB to draw a picture on the current display device. As the interpreter traces through a relation it also creates a correlation table (through calls to DISPLIB). Correlation will be explained in detail in the next section. The interpreter may display an entire relation or just a single tuple. Fig. 4 is a flow chart of the interpreter. The following is a description of the action performed by the interpreter when displaying a relation. The action when displaying a single tuple is similar. The interpreter gets a description of the domains of the relation and fetches the first tuple. If any transformations(rotation, scaling, shifting) or parameters are specified they are recorded. If an XYZOPERATION is specifed, then calls to DISPLIB are made to perform the proper operation with the proper transform, parameters, and correlation vector(see next section). Then the tuple is checked for calls to other relations. If a procedural relation is called then that procedure is executed and control returned to the interpreter. If there are calls to tabular relations then certain variables are stacked and the interpreter is called recursively. When control returns to the first tuple, the transformationand parameters are restored and the next tuple is fetched. The rest of the tuples in the original relation are processed in a similar fashion CORRELATION Correlation is the identificationof an item in the data base by pointing at its representation on a display terminal. The correlation process involves two steps: 1) identifying the item on the display screen and 2) linking the displayed item to the data base. The correlation mechanism also returns the x,y coordinates of the position pointed to, in user coordinates; that is, data space coordinates. If a vector refresh terminal like an IBM 2250 is used, then a displayed item can be identified directly from the display file[7]. For a raster T.V. terminal or a storage tube terminal, with no hardware display file, identifying a displayed item must be handled differently. As the interpreter displays relations entries are created in a correlation table. The correlation table contains one entry for each line, area, or text string displayed which is correlatable (light pen detectable). An entry in the correlation table consists of positional information specifying the extent of the item, and a vector identifying the item in the data base. A vector is needed due to the hierarchical structure of the data. Invoking Fig. 4 -Flow Chart of the Interpreter the correlation mechanism causes the following actions to take place: 1) an x,y position is read in from a light pen or a cursor, 2) the correlation table is searched for an item that intersects or nearly intersects the returned x,y position, 3) the vector of identifying information for the 'hit' item is returned, and 4) the x,y coordinates are converted to data space coordinates and returned. The basic item in the data base that can be correlated is a tuple. A tuple may represent, among other things, a line, a text string, or a call to another relation. A displayed relation may be represented by a tree as in fig. 5b. The internal nodes represent relations, the branches represent tuples, and the leaves represent displayed items. The purpose of correlation (aside from returning a postion) is to choose, from graphical input, a node in the tree; that is, a tuple in the data base. Consider the relation SHAPE (fig.3) drawn as a tree in fig. 5. Suppose one wished to choose the first line in relation TRIANGLE (as called from the first tuple of SHAPE. The term pointer shall be used to mean a unique identifier for a tuple. Returning a single pointer to the first tuple in TRIANGLE is not sufficient since TRIANGLE is called twice from SHAPE. In general a vector of pointers (called a correlation vector) for an entire path down the tree is necessary to uniquely determine how a tuple fits into the structure of the data base. The correlated item can be anyone of the tuples referenced by the returned correlation vector. The correlation handler is a collection of commands that allow correlation and manipulation of the correlated item. The correlated item may be deleted or redisplayed (possibly in a different color). Thus it is simple to provide visual feedback for identifying displayed items. Also, any domain value in the correlated tuple can be read or changed. This ability allows many high level graphic functions to be easily implemented. For example, the graphic operation 'move a displayed object' is carried out by 1) correlating to identify the object being moved, 2) correlating to read in an x,y position, 3) recomputing the domain values which specify position (graphical meaning SHIFTX, SHIFTY, SHIFTZ) in the tuple calling the item to be moved, and 4) redisplaying the tuple (or erasing and redisplaying entire relation). Note that the same steps and programs are used, but with different relationalstructures, whether the moved item is an atom, a bolt, a chair, or a map symbol. Thus this operation and many others become general-purpose high-level tools for building application programs. RELATIONS EDITOR The picture building system provides a relations editor to interactively create, edit, and display relations. The relations editor works on both graphic and nongraphic terminals. Naturally a relation cannot be displayed graphically on a nongraphic terminal, but a list of the commands (line,text,area,etc.) that would be issued during display of a relation can be listed. A person using the relations editor will normally choose an editing function, then the relations editor will query the user for any information needed to carry out the function. One of the main functions of the relations editor is the production of relations for an application. The production of a relation consists of two steps: 1) defining the structure of the relation, and 2) adding tuples to the relation. The structure of a relation consists of some data describing the relation such as its name, number of domains, ordering, etc.; and a description of each domain. Fig. 5 - Correlation Example The domain descriptions consist of a name, a graphical meaning, a data type, and other similar information. The structure of a relation may be defined automatically,based on the type of data it is to hold, or domain by domain. If a relation is being defined domain by domain, then the relations editor will query the user for a description of each of the domains. Relations that can be defined automatically fall into one of the following three classes: 1) relations with basic graphical data, 2) relations that have calls to other relations, and 3) view relations. Relations with basic graphical data include relations to display lines, text, solid areas, etc. Relations that call other relations may have domains for specifying transformations, color, correlatability, etc. View relations have domains with graphical meanings that specify a mapping from the user space to the logical screen space. When defining a relationautomatically a user chooses one of the three classes of relations listed above, and then the relations editor queries the user further for specific information. Once the structure of a relationhas been defined, then tuples may be added to that relation. Tuples may be typed in or added graphically to a relation. For example, to add a line to a relation, one could type in the tuple or just point to the desired end points on the display screen. The graphical editing of relations will be described in detail in a future paper. The relations editor also allows a user to read or write a number of relations or the entire data base from and to a disk file in human readable text format. This capability allows offline production and editing of relations by any standard text editor. Also, in order to provide a backup capability, machine independence, and protection against a data base whose internal structure may change, this capabilitywas found to be most useful and even necessary. SAMPLE APPLICATIONS As stated before an application using the picture building system consists of two parts: application relations and application programs. Normally graphical information is stored in relations which can be created interactively by the relations editor and displayed by the interpreter. Alternatively, graphical information can be displayed directly through calls to DISPLIB. This section examines the relations and application programs for two simple applications. The first example application is a parts inventory system. Suppose one wished to computerize the information from a PIC parts catalog[10]. There are on the order of 10,000 parts in such a catalog. There are about 500 classes of parts such as a precision grooved pulley each of which consists of 20 (on the average) different parts. In the catalog there is one picture for each class of parts, which have several dimensions that are parameterized (each different part having different values for the parameters). For example, a picture of a gear wheel may be shown with parameters for radius and number of gear teeth. Along with each picture there is a table with a row for each part in that class. The table shows the part number, the price, and the drawing parameters for the part. An application is desired that would take as input the part number and would both output data on the part and would draw the part (and not just a generic parameterized drawing of that part as in the catalog). For most graphic data or base systems this would be difficult or impossible. With the picture building system one could store 500 parameterized relations to draw the pictures of the parts. One would also need a relation, with one tuple per part, listing the part number, the price, the parameters for drawing the part, and a call to the relation that draws that part(one of the 500 parameterized relations). This relation could be broken down, if desired, into one such relation for each class of part. An example class of parts is the swivel stud. A relation for the different swivel studs is shown in fig. 2b. The relation swivel stud1 is the parameterized relationwhich draws the swivel stud with parameters a,b,c,d. This relation could be produced, along with the relations for any other class of parts, using the relations editor. Once this was done one could examine the data for any part or actually draw that part directly from the relations editor. these were If parts to be referenced often, then one might wish to write a simple application program to take input as the part number and display the part and information regarding that part. The output of such a program (about 20 statements in PL/I) is shown in fig. 6. Clearly the picture building system has simplified the writing of the application program, in fact it has all but eliminated the need to write an application program in this case. Another example application is a graphic chess moving program. At present the program allows two people to play chess using a color terminal. In the future it will allow a person to play against the computer. Fig. 7 shows the chess board but, since the actual board is red, white and blue, much information is lost with a black and white hard copy. There is one relation for each type of chess piece (pawn, king, etc.). An entirely different set of chess pieces could be created without effecting any application programs that use the chess board. Pieces are moved by pointing to squares on the screen. The chess moving program is less than 100 statements in PL/I. It is clear that having the graphic information stored in relations simplifies the task of application programming in the above cases. Also, since programs and data are independent, creating and managing the proper data and data structures is much simpler. CONCLUSIONS Two dimensional graphics terminals are closer to the three dimensional world than one dimensional punched cards or printers, so it is obvious that graphic input and output can simplify almost any type of problem solving. The question is how to make effective use of graphics and how to avoid starting from scratch for each application. The picture building system provides general-purpose high-level graphics and data base support for programming. It allows data to be stored 188 Fig. 6 -Swivel Studs Fig. 7 -A Black and White Copy of a Red, White, and Blue Chess Board separately from programs in powerful but conceptually simple relations. Because the data is self-describing and independent of the accessing program, it is possible to supply application-independent programs that perform standard functions, thus greatly simplifying the creation of new applications. It is expected that any loss of machine efficiency due to generality will be more than compensated for by increased programming efficiency. The picture building system is now working on a number of different computers, each supporting a variety of graphic and nongraphic terminals with a wide range of possible transmission-line speeds. article_rec.title: Experience with distributed processing on a host/satellite graphics system

abstract.par: The problem cf distributing an application between two processorshas been investigated by studying an interactive graphicsapplication that is divided between a time-shared host computer anda dedicated satellite system. The division of labor in theapplication is determined by a network flow assignment algorithm.The effect of variation in availability of the host computer on thedistribution of the application is also studied. In particular,host availability is an important factor in determining the taskdistribution. As host availability decreased, procedures miqratefrom the host to the satellite.

fulltext.ft_body: EXPERIENCE WITH DISTRIBUTED PRCOESSING CN A HOST/SATELLITE GRAPHICS SYSTEM Janet Michel Andries van Dam Division of Applied Mathematics Erown University Providence, Rhode Island 02912 The prcblem cf distributing an application between two processors has been investigated by studying an interactive graphics application that isdivided between a time-shared host computer and a dedicated satellite system. The division of labor in the application is determined bya network flow assignment alqcrithm. The effect ofvariaticn in availability of the host computer on the distribution of the application is also studied. In particular, host availability is an important factor in determining the task distribution. As host availability decreased, procedures miqrate from the host to the satellite. 1 INTRODUCTIONANE BACKGRCUND This paper describes actual experience with the problem of distributing an application system between a time shared host computer and a graphics satellite system as the CPU availability of the host processor varies. As a test case, statistics were gathered ona graphics application that is distributed between an IBM S/36C-67 runninq the CP-67/CMS virtual machine time shairg system and the Brcn University Graphics System satellite [4]. These statistics were ther analyzed with a network flow assignment algorithm that produces the optimal assignment of the procedures in the application to either the host or the satellite. The effect of variation in host availability on the distributicn of procedures is also studied. The term host availability is used tc mean the computational power presented by the time-shared host ccmputer to ar individual application program. The optimal distrituticn ofprocedures in a application distrituted between a host and satellite balances ccmmuricaticnlink cost and processing cost. As host availability decreases, the optimal distribution chanqes, and procedures migrate from the host to the satellite. This work was supported in part by the National Science Foundation, Grants GJ-41539, and the Cffice of Naval Research, Contract NOOC14-75-C-0427. Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania The first section of this paper summarizes basic informationon the Erown University Graphics System (BUGS), the Interconnected Processor System (ICCPS) that performs the distributions, and the test case graphics application, HUGS. The next section describes the statistics gathering facilities in ICCPS. Secticn 3 provides a general description of the network flow assignment alqcrithB and its implementation. The results of the test case experimentation are qiver in Section 4, and conclusions and suqqestions for further research are in Section 5. 1.1 The Erown University Graphics System The major components of BUGS are twc Digital Scientific Meta-4 micrcprcgrammed processors, called the Meta-4A and the Meta-4E, and a Vector General display. The Meta-4A is the main satellite processor (CEU) and the Meta-4E is a display processor (DPU) with graphic instructions and a general purpose instruction set. Using a third micrcprcqrammed processor for real time transformaticns, windowing,and clipping, the DPU refreshes the Vector General from structured display files stored in shared core. The BUGS system is connected to the S/360-67 via a hiqh speed multiplexcr channel interface. The Meta-4A has a home grown S/360-like instructior set and a multitaskinq operatinq system. [ 1], [11] 1.2 The ICCPS Environment The Interconnected Prccessor System (ICCPS) [15], [91 is a tccl for simplifyirg the implemertaticn cf an applicaticn that is distributed over a sat cf interconnected computers. The chief characteristic of the ICCPS approach is that the systems over which an application is distributed are merqed into an apparert single system cn which user programs are written. The motivation for the design of ICCPS was qenerated during several years experience with satellite qraphics.The ICCPS envircrment alleviates the fcllowing problems that freguently slow the implemertaticn of graphics application software: multiple languaqes, interprccesscrccmmunicaticns, and the assignment cf prcqram procedures tc processors. The languaqe problem is solved byhaving a single source languaqe for all user proqrams and qeneratinq equivalent object ccde for both the host ccmputer and the satellite for any source prccedure. For this purpose, the Alqol W compiler [8] has been modified at Brcwn to qenerate code for the Meta-4A. Communication and procedure lccaticn are handled by the ICCPS run-time monitor. This monitor traps all interprccesscr procedure calls and handles all communication of parameters.1 The ICCPS mcnitcr alsc provides for run-time activation of procedures on either processor; the smallest unit of code which may execute on either processor is the procedure. Thus the actual prccess of allocating the procedures in the application between the two processors may be postponed from design and implementation time to application prcqramexecution time. Currently, the applicaticnprcqram user gives ccmmands to the ICCPS monitcr indicating which procedures are to be activated on which processor. However, this leaves the choice of determinirq the optimal distribution to the user. The task of findinq the optimal distributicr of procedures between the two processors is now being automated. The irtertion is to remove the burden of decision from the proorammer and allow to better distribution decisions to be made. 1.3 The ApplicaticnSystem The qraphics application system, HUGS [91, [71, is a simple, two dimensional drafting packaqe that is distributed between a host processor and a satellite graphics processor. The application data structure resides onthe host's secondary storaqe, and the qraphics display is available thrcugh the resources of the macro assemler languaqez commcn tc both satellite. HUGS was implemented in a the hcst and satellite. A conscious attempt was made to avcid makirq any unwarranted assumption as to the best distribution of the HUGS procedures. HUGS was designed to be erccncmic; it has unlimited subpicturinq, windowing, levels of detail associated with each item in a picture, rejecticn options on all changes made to a picture, and constrained drawing using a variable size grid. The individual procedures of the HUGS application prcqram were classified into seven subsystems. The Mairline subsystem consists of three routines that are free to reside cn either prccessor. It interprets commands issued by the user and passes control tc the appropriate routine s). Mainline is called by the Attention Handler. The Atterticr Hardler is fixed on the satellite and decodes raw interruptsfrcm the various qraphic inputdevices. The Generatior subsystemconsists cf ten procedures that get items from the application data structure,perform clipping and viewpcrtinq, and generate display orders for the graphicsdata structure. Generation proceduresare free to reside cn either processor and are called by Mainline. The Updatesubsystem's procedures are also called byMainline: they implement adding lines, text, or subpictures, and movinq and deleting items, ir both the applicaticn data structure and the graphic data structure. There are seven Update procedures that are free to reside on either processor. All access to the application data structure stored cr the host is made through the Applicaticn Data Structure subsystem. These procedures are fixed on the host. All access tc the araphic display data structure is made through the Graphic Data Structure subsystem procedures. These prccedures, which add, delete, and attach graphic input devices to items in the picture, are fixed on the satellite. The final subsystem, the Calccmp Plottinq procedures, is fixed on the host. The fcllcwinq digram shows the subsystems in the HUGS applicaticn with lines representing the interactions between the prccedures in the subsystems.The procedures that are indicated as fixed on either the host or the satellite are fixed bynecessity because they contain peripheral device or operatinq system deperdert code. 2 DATA GATHERING After observing users how drafted pictures with BUGS,some scenarios typical of user activity were developed. Data was gathered by the ICCPS statistics package during repetiticr cf these scenarios and then analyzed. This statistical data is oriented toards resource requirements, including: time cf day, CEU clock time, commurication link start I/C's (i.e., the number of input or output initiations) and number of bytes transferred. In additicn, records of the cost charged to the user's account by the computer center and virtual machine paqing activity are gathered for the host. The ICCPS run-time monitor includes commands to specify the desired statistics and the names of the procedures tc be measured. The statistics specification is typed directly to the monitor by the user or can be read from a disk file. The statistics package also measures the resources used whenever the mcnitcr changes the distribution of the applicationprccedures. The statistics packaqe in ICCPS was designed with the qcals of source language independence and simplicity. ICCES provides a natural procedure-level breakpoint system that is invisible tc the prcgrammer at the source-lanquaqe level. Its run-time monitor, which can trap all procedure calls, gathers informationon the resource requirements of any procedure. The run-time statistics are recorded as simply as possible sc that distortion cf the data introduced by the act ofmeasurement is mirimized. For every call and return, a statistics record ccntainirq data supplied by the operating systems is added to a trace file. A separate prcgram, Clcthc3, collects static data frcm the cbject code libraries containinq the application. Static data includes size, arameter descripticn, and the external prccedure references made by each procedure. After the applicaticn prcqram has run, dyramic trace file data and static data are summed and averaged by Iachesis tc prcduce the fcllcwinq information about the application fcr the entire qathering period: response time and "user think time" data, a descripticn ofprocedure interacticn, and input for more ccmplex analysis as described ir the next section. 3 DATA ANALYSIS Static data from Clcthc and dynamic data from the trace file are combined into a procedure interaction data structure by a separate prcgram, Laches-s. Different subroutines examine this data structure and prepare formatted input for analysis prcgrams that find the best distributicr of rocedures between the two processors. Cne subroutine provides data in the form of a modified commodity network graph for analysis by a network flcw assignment algorithm. Another formats data for Eestdist, a subfunction of Foley's qeneral purpose graphics modelinq system [41. The Eestdist analysis generates a set of possible distributions and then evalvates the performance of each distribution with a queuing network model. It uses a backtrack algorithm that solves the more difficult problem by allcing for memory constraints as well as variable computation and communication time costs. The approach taken in the Erown experiments has been tc verify results of the flow analysis method byrunning the correspcndinq data thrcugh Bestdist. 3.1 The Network Flow Assiqnment Analysis A modular application system that is distributed betweentwc prccessors can be modelled as a modified commodity network graph. The problem of finding an assignment of procedures to processors that minimizes the cost of both computation and interprocessor ccmmunicaticn is then solved by applying a maximum flow-minimum cut alqorithm [31. The theory tehird the model and a complete description of the alqcrithm are in [121. Basically, the maximum flow-minimum cut alqcrithm determines a maximum flow throuqh a network qraph from one point tc another when the branches of the graph are subject to capacity limitations. Acutset of the graph is a partiticr that severs the scurce mode frcm the destination node; the capacity of the cutset is the sum cf the capacities cf the individual cut branches. The maximum flow-minimum cut alqcrithm finds the cutset of the graph that has the minimum capacity. That minimum capacity represents the bottleneck that bcunds the maximal flcw of the entire network. One distribution of procedures between the twc processors is fine fcr the session measured, but what happens tc the distriuticn as host CEU availability changes? How stable is a distribution, that is. will a slight change in the host performance cause the distributicr tc change? By extrapolating from the measured data, the range of host CPU availability within which a distribution is optimal can be determined. Ic dc this, the measured host execution time must be The main advantage cf retwork flow analysis is that it is easy to change the basis for optimization. For example, by replacing the ccmputaticn data with monetary cost data, a distribution can be found that talances ccmnunicaticn link charges, charges for host usage, and any charges for satellite usage. In additicn, the weight cf the cutset prcduced by the maximum flow alqcrithm is useful as a prediction of the respcnse time or cost of the distributicn. Acccrdinq to a theorem by Stone, "The weight of a cutset of the mcdified craph is equal to the cost of the ccrrespcndinq module assignment." [121 The main prcblem with the ccmmcdity flcw graph model is allcwinq for constraints on satellite memory. If the cptimal distribution does not fit in the satellite's memory, then the next best distribution must be found. If the satellite operating system allcws dynamic loading cf prccedures, then a factor must be added tc the satellite execution time of procedures that must beloaded into core. An alqcrithm for findirq the next best soluticn has recently been devised but has not yet been tested [131. Another possible problem is that the model assumes that the communication cost between the twc prccesscrs is symmetric. For the Erown confiquration, the cost cf transferrinq data from the host processor to the satellite is the same as the cost of transferrinq data from the satellite to the host. 3.2 Implementaticn cf the Assignment Analysis Atropos is a program that prepares a modified commodity network graph from the qathered data and analyzes it with the network flow assiqnment alqcrithm. For response time optimization, data on the branches from a procedure node to the two processor nodes is the total executicr time for the procedure on each processor. Data on the branches between procedure nodes (A and B) is a function of the fcllowing: the speed of the communication link, the total length of the parameter list, the number of times A called B, and overhead for link input/cutput initiations. normalized to represent a dedicated CPU. The measured host execution time data for each procedure is multiplied by the ratic of the calculated execution time to the measured execution time fcr a special benchmark procedure. Next the ncrmalized executicn time data is multiplied by an arbitrary host CPU deqradaticn factor, F. For F equal tc one, the host is dedicated: for F equal to 1.5, the host availability is degraded by fifty percent. The critical values of this factor, that is, the pcints at which a change in host availabilitynecessitates a redistributicr, are determined by performing a bisection search on the set of possible rccedure distributions obtained by varyinq F. The result of this search is a library cf distributicns where each distribution is associated with a ranqe cf host deqradaticn factors within which a distribution is optimal. This range is a measure cf the stability of the distribution. 4 SUMMARY CF RESUITS Data from a general sceneric that exercised all the procedures in the application was analyzed both by the network flow assignment method, Atrcpcs, and tv Eestdist. The results frcm the Atropos analysis agreed with the results from the Bestdist analysis on the same data with the same communication link speed. In addition, data from several different scendrios was analyzed by Atrcpcs. The resulting distributions cf prccedures between the satellite and the host, and the corresponding ranqes of host execution speeds within which the distributicn is optimal, were studied. The average response time predictions produced by the aralysis were verified by the measured average response time from the scenario data. The averaqe measured response time is the average clock time starting on a call to the mainline procedure by the interrupt handler and ending cn the return of the mainline procedure. With a dedicated host the optimal distritution assigns all free procedures except one tc the 4 . As host availability decreases, prccecures miqrate to the satellite. In qerral, prccedures tend to cluster and move as grcups. These grcups are lccal regicns cf high interaction activity. This tendency was alsc noticed by [5]. It is not surprisinq to note that these qroups ccrrespond tc the subsystems that were created during the design of EUGS. In an application with a wider ranqe cf procedure interaction and less clustering, prccedures wculd prcbably tend to move individually. The order in which qroups cf procedures moved to the satellite was consistert for all the scenaries. Prccedures in the Update subsystem that were used during the scenaric moved before the Generation procedures since Update prccedures make heavy use of fixed satellite routines. The ranqe cf hcst executicr speeds within which a distributicn is optimal varies with the scenario. For example, in a scenario that emphasizes picture drawing and rarely regenerates the picture, more host degradation is needed before the generaticn procedures will move off the host. Since the user can assign procedures to processors with the ICCES mcnitor commands, it is pcssible to attempt to find an optimal distributicn of procedures by hard, without an analysis routine. This involves trying different configurations during a relatively constant pericd cf host availabilityand then examinind the measured response time data. Befcre the assignment algorithm was implemeented, a distributicr cf prccedures identical tc one of the theoretical distributicns was derived in this way; however, the effect of host availability on the distribution cannot be determined by hand and is not cbvicus frcm the measured data. An optimization fcr cost was also done by using ccst functions fcr hcst and ccmmunicaticn link usage with no charge for satellite usaqe. The results vacillated between a distribution with all procedures on the satellite and a distribution with all except Generation procedures on the satellite. There is a delicate balance between link charges and host charges. The effect cf different ccmmunication link speeds on the distributicn of prccedures could alsc be studied by hclding execution time data ccnstant, varying the link speed by a factor and searchinq for critical values of the factor. This kind of optimizaticn is necessary for designing a new host/satellite system rather than for distributing applicaticns cc an existing satellite system. General purpose modelling cf satellite qraphics configurations is done more thoroughly by [4]. 5 CCNCIUSICNS A fixed library cf prccedure distributions associated with typical host load factors is prcbablysufficient fcr use in periodically shifting procedures tc achieve cptimal response time for the average user. Before automatic redistribution usinq such libraries is implemented, further study is needed to determine sufficiently accurate run-time measures cf host CPU availability for use in the analysis algorithm. In addition, the balance between the ccst of reccnfigurationwith the benefits cf better response time must be considered. Currently, better methcds are being developed tc measure and predict host availability in the Erown CP-67/CMS virtual machine ervironment. [21 In contrast tc the use cf fixed libraries, it be would desirable to custom fit the distributicn cf procedures to the user activity at run-time. This would entail the gatherirq cf data, computing the best distribution of procedures, and then changing the distributions cf procedures at run-time. Further study is reeded tc determine the feasibility, computational expense and optimal frequency cf run-time redistribution.[10] The network flow assignment algorithm has proved tc be an excellent method for assigninq procedures to two prccessors and studying the effect of hcst availability on the migration of procedures. Even if run time data is not available, the network flow assignment algorithm could be useful for distributing an application between two processors. A qccd estimate cf parameter length information and the execution time of procedures cr each prccesscr wculd produce a near optimal distribution. [12] Moreover, an automated analysis methcdolcqv is essential fcr choosing distributions since the ad bcc judqements of users and designers are notoriously poor and time ccrsuming. For example, in a hypothetical distributed graphics application system frcm an earlier paper [151, it was predicted that display code generaticn prccedures wculd be the first tc move tc the satellite. Fcr the HUG applicaticn system, it turned cut that the cppcsite is true. Since there is less ccmmunication link usage transferring a compact display tuffer than transferring items frcm the data structure in the HUGS applicaticn, display code qeneraticr prccedures are the last qrcup tc move tc the satellite. insure the best Ic distributicn of prccedures, it is essential tc autcmate the prccess cf determininq optimal distributicns of procedures between processcrs. article_rec.title: Configurable applications for satellite graphics

abstract.par: This paper advocates a configurable approach to software for satellite graphics in which the division of labor between the host and satellite computers can be easily changed after an application program has been written. A software system, CAGES (Configurable Applications for Graphics Employing Satellites), implements this approach. CAGES can substantially simplify the application programmer's task of programming a host and satellite computer by making the intercomputer interface relatively invisible to him, while at the same time allowing him the efficiency and flexibility that can result from direct application programming of the satellite computer.Proper design of configurable programs is facilitated by a mathematical model defining a pairwise measure of program module inter-dependence. Experience with this model has resulted in a set of programming guidelines that further aid the application programmer in producing a suitable program structure.
