To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania CONFIGURABLE APPLICATIONS FOR SATELLITE GRAPHICS Griffith HAMLIN, Jr. Institute for Computer Applications in Science and Engineering Hampton, Virginia 23665 This paper advocates a configurable approach to software for satellite graphics in which the division of labor between the host and satellite computers can be easily changed after an application program has been written. A software system, CAGES (ConfigurableApplications for Graphics Employing Satellites), im­plements this approach. CAGES can substantially simplify the applicationprogrammer's task of programming a host and satellite computer by making the intercomputer interface relatively invisible to him, while at the same time allowing him the efficiency and flexibility that can result from direct application program­ ming of the satellite computer. Proper design of configurable programs is facilitated by a mathematical model defining a pairwise meas­ure of program module inter-dependence. Experience with this model has resulted in a set of programming guidelines that further aid the application programmer in producing a suitable program structure. 1. INTRODUCTION Computer graphics installations often employ a two-computer complex,consistings of a smaller satellite computer connected to a larger host com­puter. The intercomputer link can range from a low speed telephone line (300-9600 baud) to a very fast I/O channel connection (greater than 300,000 baud). Two basic categories of software designs for such satellite graphics installationsare dis­cernible: "fixed-function"and "programmable­ satellite" systems. In fixed-functionsystems the satellite computer and intercomputer channel appear to the applica­ tion programmer as a "black box" that is accessed by subroutine calls from the host computer. All application-specificcode is host-resident. Only a fixed set of general purpose functions, chosen by the graphics installation's software developer, is satellite-resident. This approach relieves the application programmer of many of the burdens of programming two computers and is quite suitable for certain classes of application. Programmable-satellitesystems allow the applica­tion programmer to directly program the satellite computer. Existing examples [1,2] of such sys­tems allow the programmer flexibility in choosing a division of labor optimized for his particular application. They do not relieve him of the burdens of consciously programmingtwo computers although they do reduce these burdens considerably. The advantages and disadvantages of these two gen­eral classes of satellite graphics software are discussed in [3,4,10] and will not be repeated here. 2. THE CONFIGURABLEPROGRAM APPROACH We desire an approach that eliminates from the application code all explicit references to the two computers, and yet, at the same time, allows the application programmer to directly program the satellite. This paper advocates such an approach to software for satellite graphics, known as the configurable program approach [3]. The fundamen­ tal notion of the configurable program approach is that the application programmer may choose the di­vision of labor between the host and satellite computers after the application is coded. Thus all application source program modules must be executable on either computer. If this is not achieved, the programmer's choice of divisions of labor is reduced. The actual binding-time of this division of labor depends upon the implementation of this approach, but the division of labor is easily changed, even after it has been initially bound. Such a change may require recompiling the application, or it may only require requesting the change to an on-line monitor during execution. It never requires the programmer to change any of the application, except, of course, for re-specifying the desired division of labor. The configurable program approach alleviatesmany of the complications introduced by direct applica­tion programming of the satellite. First, the di­vision of labor between the two computers need not be completely determined at design time. This is 196 desirable because the amounts of CPU time and other resources required by each application com­ ponent are difficult to determine during the design process. Second, the configurable program approach relies inherentlyon one programming language, since the same source program is required to run on either computer. Thus the bilingual requirement on the programmer, often present in other programmable satellite approaches [1,2], is necessarily elima­ted. Third, the application programmer does not explicitly program intercomputercommunications. They are automatically provided by the system upon references to procedures or data elements which are not resident on the referencing computer. The programmer continues to use the familiar sub­routine call and data reference to implicity initiate the communications. 3. CAGES OVERVIEW To demonstrate the effectiveness of the configur­ able approach in simplifying the programmer's task and to better understand the design decision alternatives involved in a implementation of the approach, the CAGES Systemwas implemented at the University of North Carolina. It is fully des­ cribed elsewhere by Hamlin and Foley [4]. Briefly, CAGES was implemented on the U.N.C. satellite graphics system consisting of an IBM 360/75 host computer, a PDP-11/45 satellite computer with 28K words of main memory and a fixed head disk, a Vector General 3-D interactive display, and a high speed selector channel interface. Application programs are written in a modular fashion, as if all modules were going to be resident on one computer. The application programmer then specifies to CAGES which modules are to be host­ resident and which are to be satellite-resident. All modules that are potentially satellite­resident may use only a subset of PL/I known as PLCD [5,6]. CAGES arranges for the modules to execute according to the specified configuration, and provides the program with a virtual single computer with dual CPUs. To maintain this virtual machine, CAGES provides three types of services: 1. Calls from one computer may be made to subroutines resident in the other computer. The execution of such a remote subroutine call triggers intercomputer communicationsby the system to cause program control and parameter values to be transmitted between computers. If the call so specifies, the calling program can continue execu­ting, allowing simultaneous execution of the sub­routines. Such multiprocessingis severely limited in the current implementation of CAGES. Due to the use of a uni-programmingsatellite operating system, no sequence of calls is allowed which implies the simultaneous execution of more than one satellite-residentsubroutine. Also, subroutines executing simultaneouslyon different computers may not change the values of shared data. These limitations are only a function of the current implementationand not inherent in the configurable programming approach. 2. An asynchronous interrupt (e.g. a PL/I CONDITION)may occur on one computer for which the associated interrupt handling subroutine (e.g. PL/I ON-BLOCK) is resident on the other computer. 3. Data with EXTERNAL scope may be referenced from program modules on both computers. If this occurs, the data is known as GLOBAL data. At the left of FIGURE 1 are shown CAGES applica­tion programs written as if they were going to be resident on only one computer. The programmer also supplies extended declarations specifying a particular configurationof the application. These declarations and the source code are input to a pre-processor written for CAGES. The pre­processor changes some of the source code slightly, generates some PL/I source procedures itself, and produces three files. One contains procedures destined for the host, one contains procedures destined for the satellite, and one contains symbol table entries for GLOBAL variables. The (modified) source procedures are then compiled by either the PL/I-F compiler (host procedures) or the PLCD compiler (satellite procedures). Finally, the loaders of each computer combine the CAGES run-time system with the object modules produced by the compile steps to produce two executable load modules. In the course of maintaining a single virtual computer for the application program, the CAGES run-time system initiates and controls all intercomputer communications. Another implementation of the configurable program approach, by van Dam, Harrington, and Stabler [7,8], is known as ICOPS. It uses differ­ ent criteria and techniques. ICOPS programs are limited to subroutine calls and parameter passing for inter-computercommunications, but the division of labor can be changed dynamically at run-time, and ICOPS is not tied to any specified language. CAGES programs have richer inter­ computer communicationcapabilities and are written in PL/I, but actually changing a program's division of labor requires at least a partial recompilation. Because CAGES does not assume anything about the applications it supports, except that they are written in a subset of PL/I, the system's ideas are equally applicable to non-graphics programs which must for some reason execute in the memories of a two-computer network. One network distributed processing system is the Resource Sharing Executive (RSEXEC) [9], described by Thomas in 1973. It is a distributed executive system which runs on the TENEX operating system of PDP-10 host computers on the ARPANET. Its goal is to facili­ tate the sharing of resources among the host of the ARPANET by making invisible to the user the distinction between a local TENEX virtual machine and remotely located one. CAGES has a similar goal of trying to make the host-satellite configuration appear to the application program as one computer with one main memory. RSEXEC allows a program on one host to access files and I/O devices anywhere in the network in such a way that inter-host boundaries are invisible. CAGES applies this same notion to GLOBAL data and remotely located subroutines by allowing access to them from either computer in a manner making the actual location of these objects transparent to the applicationprogram. 4. GRAPH MODEL Some program structures are well suited for distributed execution and some are not. To aid in understanding what types of structures are best suited for configurable programs, a graph model of a distributed application has been defined, and is fully described by Hamlin [10]. Briefly, each applicationmodule is represented by a node of the graph. An edge exists between node i and node j if module i may call module j during execution. This model tries to measure a property of the structure of the program relating to its suit­ability for distributed execution among two or more computer memories. It does not measure the performance of the program. Hence it has no input parameters describingmodule execution times on different computers. It does measure the amount of interaction that exists between each pair of modules by measuring the execution over­head that would be caused if the modules in each pair were placed on separate computers. This overhead due to a program's distribution is assumed to be composed of: (a) the cost to send parameters and other needed data between computers, incurred each time a module is called or returns across the computer boundary; (b) the cost to fetch from the remote computer any GLOBAL data items needed by a module, incurred each time a module references a GLOBAL data item which is resident on a remote computer. To calculate this overhead the model's parameters include the following: (a) A description of the program's flow of control among the nodes. (b) A cost associated with each pair of nodes. The cost is incurred each time one node transfers control to the other. (c) A cost associated with each GLOBAL data item. This cost is incurred upon each access to the GLOBAL data item when the preceeding access to that GLOBAL data item was made from the opposite computer. (d) The probability that each node will access each GLOBAL data item. The application programmermay estimate these parameters or he may execute the application with any configuration and allow CAGES to collect execution data from which they may be calculated. The particular cost function used to determine the cost parameters is left to the programmer. He may, for example, choose the cost associated with a GLOBAL data item to equal the time required to transfer that GLOBAL data item between computers, or he may choose its cost to be the number or words of intercomputer communicationsgenerated by a transfer of the GLOBAL data item. From this information a "nearness measure" between every pair of modules is calculated, inde­pendent of any particular module distribution. The resulting nearness matrix represesnts, for each pair of program modules, the execution over­head cost which would be incurred if the two modules were placed on separate computers. For any configuration,the sum of the nearness measures between all pairs of separated modules is the predicted execution-timeoverhead cost caused by the distributed processing. An algorithm, such as that described by Ford and Fulkerson [11] in 1962, could be used with this model to find the configuration causing the least overhead expenditure, given that two particular nodes must be separated. However, the Ford- Fulkerson algorithm allows no module placement constraints, such as satellite memory limitations, which limit the number of nodes that can be placed in one of the partitions. Dealing with such satellite memory limitations and other constraints is part of the problem of choosing a suitable configuration. Recent work by Stone [12] may prove useful in automatically configuring an application,although his approach also ignores constraints on memory sizes. When designing a distributedapplication, the programmer should consider any proposed applica­tion structure in terms of its expected inter­computer overhead. To aid in this task, several commonly occurring structure-relatedsituations in satellite graphics programs have been identifiedand analyzed with the model. The result is a set of structuring guidelines which is fully described by Hamlin [10]. The guidelines are not unexpected. They verify one's intuition. More importantly, they give a quantitative measure of the relative advantage of one technique over another in a given programming situation. As an example of such a situation analyzed by the model, suppose a certain program module, A, has a large nearness measure with most of the other modules, causing considerable run-time overhead no matter in which computer it resides. A lower­level service routine might exhibit this charac­teristic. It may be advantageous to duplicate module A on both computers. This eliminates all intercomputer transfer of control which would have occurred when modules remotely called A. However, module A may itself call other modules. Duplica­ting module A causes one copy of module A to be remotely located from all modules it calls. Also, module A may use some STATIC data (PL/I termology) which must be transferred between computers each time a different copy of module A is activated. These two considerationsmay add to the execution overhead if module A is duplicated. Hence it is not always advantageous to duplicatemodule A. Suppose we know the following parameters: P = fraction of the invocations of module A which are satellite-resident. F = (program model path costs for all execu­tion paths which end with module A and whose beginning module and next-to-last module are on opposite computers) divided by (costs of all paths which end with module A). I = fraction of the invocations of A which are not on the same computer as was the previous invocation of A. H1 = sum of nearness measures between A and all host-residentmodules which call A (directly or indirectly). S14= sum of nearness measures between A and all satellite-resident modules which call A. N = nearness measure of A with itself. A relatively straightforward analysis given in [10] concludes that duplication of module A is advantageous if: That is, if this condition is met, the model's prediction of overhead cost will be less if module A is duplicated than if module A is placed on either the host or satellite computers (assum­ ing all other modules remain fixed). 5. EXPERIMENTALUSE OF CAGES Results of two interactive application programs run under CAGES are presented here. These appli­ cations were run to test: 1. The ease of using the system and of reconfiguring a program. 2. The accuracy of the model in predicting system overhead. 3. The effect on performance of different distributions of an application. 4. The effect on performance of different program structures for an application. 5. The usefulness of the model's nearness measures in suggesting suitable program structures A particular set of input data and user responses was selected for each application. Each set was designed to exercise the various modules of the applicationin a manner similar to the applica­ tion's "typical" use. This same set of data was always used with each run of teh application. Sixteen runs were made with the first applica­ tion, MEDICS. Fifteen runs were made with BLOCKS, the second application. These runs were approxi­mately equally divided among the various configu­ rations tested for each application. During each run, response times and intercomputer channel usage data were collected by the CAGES run-time system. The data items collected were: (a) "Average response time" -the average real time measured from the time the user inputs a response (pushes a PFK key, etc.) until the next display is shown to him and all activity in the entire system is suspended, awaiting his next response. (b) "Host CPU-time" -the average amount of CPU-time per user interaction used by the host computer. (c) "CAGES host CPU-time" -the average portion of the host CPU-time which was spent in CAGES run-time modules. (d) "Percent of CAGES overhead" -the CAGES host CPU-time divided by host CPU-time. (e) "Message words" -the average number of 16-bit words of intercomputer traffic per inter­action. (f) "Predictedwords" -the number of message words predicted by the model. (g) "Host elapsed time" -the amount of real time per interaction during which control was resident in the host computer. It does not include the time when the host was only waiting for the satellite computer to perform some tasks and return. (h) "Elapsed time" -the average real time per interaction, not counting time the entire system was idle, waiting for the user's next input The several computer runs were made at various times of the day and night throughout a fall semester at U.N.C. The maximum variation in per­formance data obtained between any two of these runs was only 10%. This includes two runs made in "stand-alone"mode with no other users on the host computer. We attribute this low variation to the U.N.C. computer center's policy which gives graphics jobs extremely high priority. The performancedata given in this section are median values of all runs. FIRST APPLICATION: MEDICS MEDICS is an interactive curve fitting application designed to fit a function to a given set of exponentially decaying input data points. Written in 1970 to run on a single computer, MEDICS does not, in its original version, possess a structure designed for distributed execution. The basic modular structure of MEDICS is shown in FIGURE 2. After each step in the solution process, results are displayed to the user, usually in the form of a graph. After analyzing the graph, the user inputs parameters to the next step. Each of the main-line modules of MEDICS contains both calculations required by one solution step and calls to a set of graphical subroutines written especially for MEDICS, to create a display of the results of the step. The only changes made to MEDICS to run it under CAGES were to replace calls to the IBM subroutinepackage designed for the 2250 display (in use at U.N.C. when MEDICS was written) by calls to a locally written subroutine package for the current Vector General display unit. This required changes only in the display modules and the addition of some code in module ATTN to perform functions originally provided by the 2250 hardware. An existing application was selected to measure the improvement (if any) in performance resulting from changes made to its structure as a result of applicationof the model. Applicationof the model to the original MEDICS structure shows large nearness measures among the graphics subroutines, making it unreasonable to place any of these modules on separate computers. Also, each of the 14 main-line modules contains large floating point calculations which makes it unreasonable to place these modules on the U.N.C. satellite computer. Due to the foregoing considerations,a configura­ tion that placed all the graphics modules on the satellite and all other modules on the host appeared to be the best configuration of the original MEDICS modular structure implementable at the U.N.C. installation. A configurationwhich placed all application dependent code on the host appeared to be the only other reasonable imple­mentable configurationof this original MEDICS structure. In this configuration,only module ATTN was satellite-resident. ATTN only inter­ cepts low level graphics inputs and refreshes the display (formerly done in IBM 2250 hardware). ATTN must be satellite-residentto accomplish these functions. The data from these two con­figurations are shown in the first two columns of Table 1. The column labeled Host represents the configura­tion which placed all modules but ATTN on the host computer. The column labeled Distributed repre­sents the other configuration. For the "Host" configuration,the relevant near­ness measures (between ATTN and everything else) predicted the amount of CPU-time overhead and intercomputer traffic correctly within 8.6%. The average user response time with this configuration was 3.3 seconds. In the "distributed" configurationthe display program is built on the satellite. Therefore small display program changes made as a result of user inputs do not necessitate its transfer from the host computer as in the "host" configuration. This was expected to decrease response time for minor inputs. It did in fact decrease the amount of data transferred between computers by approximately 30%. However, due to the extremely fast data rate of the U.N.C. host-satellite communications link (selector channel speed), this reduction made little differ­ence in response times. Increased CPU overhead by CAGES to format a large number of short messages compensated for the reduction in data. The resulting response time was 3.32 seconds, approxi­ mately the same as in the "host" configuration. With data gathered by CAGES it is possible to calculate the response times that would be incurred with any given transmission speed. At 2400 baud, for example, the MEDICS response time would have been 7.15 seconds for the "host" configuration and 6 seconds for the "distributed" configuration,a 19% improvement due to reduced intercomputer traffic. The nearness matrix indicates that the original structure of MEDICS is not well suited to distri­buted execution. Indeed, the "distributed" configurationhad considerableoverhead. This is basically because MEDICS was designed for one computer. Most notably, 12 of the 14 main line modules contain both large calculations and graphic input/output. The nearness matrix shows that several main-line modules are much nearer the graphics modules than to each other. Therefore they should have been placed on the satellite computer, perhaps replacing several graphical modules with smallest nearness measure. Since this was precluded by the large floating point Table 1 MEDICS PERFORMANCE 200 calculations performed in these modules, they were rewritten. Blocks of source code in each module which contained only calculations, and blocks which contained only graphics related code, were identified. Each module was restructuredinto two modules, one containing the calculations and the other containing the graphics related code. Essentially the same set of source statements was reused, but the statementswere combined into modules differently. The nearness measures from this new MEDICS struc­ture indicate that five of the newly created graphics modules have a much larger total near­ness measure to the graphics subroutines than to their associated calculation modules. However, due to memory requirements, not all five can be accommodated in the satellite. It was necessary to place 2 of these modules on the host. A smaller module was moved to the satellite in their place The resulting configurationhas 4 of the newly created modules and the graphical subroutine on the satellite. Its performance is given in the "restructured"column of Table 1. The average response time per user interaction was 1.69 seconds with this configuration,about twice as fast as the two configuration of the original MEDICS structure. This restructuring of the MEDICS application produced a much larger change in performance than between the two diffe­rent configurations of the same original struc­ture, even for a 2400 baud intercomputer link. It forcefully illustrates the importance of giving careful thought to the program structure at design time to accommodate likely configura­tions. SECOND APPLICATION: BLOCKS BLOCKS [14] is an applicationprogram designed for the purpose of creating and manipulating block diagrams such as electronic schematics and program flowcharts. FIGURE 3 represents the basic modular structure of BLOCKS. EDIT supervises control among the various editing functions. Each of 5 function modules controls one of the 5 basic capabilities supportedby BLOCKS. Module ADD adds a block to a diagram, DELETE deletes a block, CONECT connects two blocks with a straight line, MTEXT adds or changes text labeling a block, and CPAGE changes among pages of large diagrams. Each function module calls upon LSMOD, TSMOD, and PSMOD to access and modify the three data structures describing the diagram being built. In addition, the function modules call upon module DPMAIN and its subordinate modules (GETEXT,MOVEIN,TEMPLT) to generage Vector General display programs to draw pictures of diagrams being built. Finally, all modules call upon module INTACT when they wish some input from the user at the CRT display. INTACT also provides low level feedback to the user. From the BLOCKS nearness matrix, it was discovered that 56% of the total value in the entire matrix was contained in nearness measures among the three modules DPMAIN, MOVEIN, and CONECT. There­fore these three should always be placed on the same computer. However, two factors make this impossible. First, some of the modules can reside on only one computer. Modules INTACT, MOVEIN, and VRESET must be satellite-residentto access the CRT display hardware and its program buffer in satellite memory. Second, the transferrable modules of interest (EDIT, DPMAIN, ADD, DELETE, CONECT, MTEXT, CPAGE) are all rather large. After accommodatingmodules required to be satellite­resident, satellite memory constraints allow only one transferable module to be made satellite­resident. Thus we are not able to place both DPMAIN and CONECT on the satellite with MOVEIN. There are four configurationsof BLOCKS that appeared to be reasonable and implementable. Modules DPMAIN and CONECT were each placed separately on the satellite in two of these configurations. Performance data for these four configurationsare given in Table 2. The first configuration (configuration1, Table 2) placed on the satellite only the three modules that must be satellite-resident. It produced a 1.5 second average response time. When DPMAIN was made satellite-resident,while leaving EDIT host­resident (configuration 2, Table 2), the response time improved by 10%. Placing EDIT on the satellitewithout DPMAIN (configuration 3, Table 2) increased response time 30%. When CONECT was placed on the satellite alone (configuration 4, Table 2) its separation from DPMAIN negated an improvement that might have come from placing OPMAIN and INTACT together. Response time did not change significantly from the third configuration. 6. CONCLUSIONS Several conclusions are drawn from the two experi­mental applications. First, analyzing the applica­tion structure and modifying it accordingly at design time to accommodate likely configurations is very useful. When this was done to MEDICS, a decrease in overhead and a 49% improvement in response time resulted. Data from the model helped to produce an efficient structure and configuration. Table 2 BLOCKS PERFORMANCE The configuration of BLOCKS predicted as optimal by the model was slightly too large (10%) for the available satellite memory, so it could not be tried. However, the time savings of a predicted 383 words of intercomputer communicationsin this configuration should give an advantage of 2.14 seconds of response at 2400 baud when compared to the first configurationof BLOCKS. Based on comments from the BLOCKS programmers and from the author's experience in restructuring MEDICS, the configurable programming approach is almost as simple to program as a fixed function satellite approach. Except for efficiency consid­erations, the two-computer network is hidden from the applicationprogrammer. Therefore the coding tasks are of approximately the same complexity in both approaches. However, with the configurable approach, the applicationprogrammer must design the modular structure of the application care­fully and he must choose a configuration of the modules. Hence, there is marginally more work involved in writing a configurable application than in writing an application for a fixed func­tion satellite. The opinion of the BLOCKS programmers was that the elimination of direct application programmer coding of the intercomputer communications is a major advantage of the con­figurable program approach, especially for appli­ cations in which remotely called modules in turn call other remotely located modules. The associa­ted communications, if written directly by the application programmer, would be quite tedious. The BLOCKS programmers noted an unexpected debug­ging aid in the configurable programming approach Due to the availabilityof satellite on-line debugging aids and procedures at the University of North Carolina graphics installation, it is easier to debug a module if it is satellite­resident. The easy reconfigurability of CAGES programs allows a module being debugged to be placed by itself on the satellite. There it can be interactively debugged. After debugging, the module may be placed on the host or satellite according to other criteria. The major cause of errors and delays when recon­figuring BLOCKS and MEDICS was slight differences in the syntax of the two versions of PL/I in use on the host and satellite computers. Use of a single compiler with two sets of code generators 202 for the host and satellite would eliminate this problem. Also any object code generated to handle configuragle system functions, such as message formatting and data translation, would surely be more efficient than the source code generated for that purpose by the CAGES pre­ processor approach. 7. SUMMARY In summary, the use of CAGES suggests that con­ figurable applications show much better perfor­ mance when their structure is designed with distributed execution in mind. Changing among different configurations of a given structure in an effort to tailor the division of labor to the individual application can increase performance. Thirty percent variation among the configurations of BLOCKS was observed. Furthermore, the config­ urable program approach to software for satellite graphics can provide a simplification to the application programmer's task of programming two computers that approaches the simplification obtained with the fixed-function satellite approach. Data from the CAGES implementation indicate that the configurableprogram approach is a viable approach to software support for interactive satellite graphics applications. The configurable program approach can be extended to more general networks of N computers. Also, more general multiprocessingshould be possible using this approach than is found in the CAGES implementation. REFERENCES [1] I. W. article_rec.title: Remote programmability of graphic interactions in a host/satellite configuration

abstract.par: This paper describes the remote programmability of graphic-oriented interactions in a large, time-shared host/multiple-satellite configuration. The philosophy and architecture of a pseudo machine -- the Programmable Graphics Processor (PGP) -- is presented along with a description of the higher-level language used in the host to specify programs for execution in the satellite. These programs are first compiled into PGP machine language in the host and then transmitted to the satellite where they are executed in response to asynchronous interrupts (attentions) originating from various types of interactive graphic input devices. In this manner, fairly complex and tailored interactions such as multiple line rubberbanding and limited area tracking are specified conveniently by applications programs in the host computer.

To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania REMOTE PROGRAMMABILITYOF GRAPHIC INTERACTIONS IN A HOST/SATELLITECONFIGURATION Samuel D. Moulton Philip J. Corman Digital Equipment Corporation Maynard, Mass. This paper describes the remote programmabilityof graphic-oriented interactions in a large, time­shared host/multiple-satelliteconfiguration. The philosophy and architecture of a pseudo machine the Programmable Graphics Processor (PGP) --is presented along with a description of the higher­level language used in the host to specify programs for execution in the satellite. These programs are first compiled into PGP machine language in the host and then transmitted to the satellite where they are executed in response to asynchronous interrupts (attentions) originating from various types of interactive graphic input devices. In this manner, fairly complex and tailored interactions such as multiple line rubberbanding and limited area tracking are specified convenientlyby applications programs in the host computer. 1. INTRODUCTION For the past several years, the concept of interfac­ ing graphic satellite computers to a large time­ shared host computer has gained popularity. The ad­ vantages of such configurationshave been described in a number of other papers [1-5]. The graphic satellite computer, typically a mini-computer, serves to unburden the host computer of trivial but time-consumingsupport work while providing a real­ time response to users interacting with refresh graphic display terminals. Resources of the large time-shared host computer can then be concentrated more effectively on providing adequate processing and data base functions for application programs. A number of host/satelliteimplementationshave been described having capabilities that range from relatively simple "fixed-function" satellites to very complex programmable satellites. The program­ mable satellitesprovide superior facilities by which the applicationprogram running in the host computercan control user interactions in the remote satellite environment. Systems of this type, how­ ever, still exhibit their own peculiar set of prob­ lems. The "division of labor" problem has often been commented upon and significant research in this area has been reported by Hamlin and Foley [6] at U.N.C. and by Van Dam and Stabler [7] at Brown. Both of these efforts have been aimed at achieving a balanced division of processing tasks between (at least) two processors. This distributed processing ideal, while an admirable goal for a general purpose host-satelliteconfiguration,is not realized with­out paying a price in operating system size, com­plexity, and perhaps run-time efficiency. This price may prove unacceptablein configurationsthat have multiple satellites because the per-stationcost of each satellite becomes an important criteria. There is considerable economic motivation to base such systems on relatively small satellite processors with slightlymore than sufficient power to handle the most demanding application anticipated. For example, the presence of rotating memory can in­ crease the overall system cost dramatically when re­ quired on each satellite in a system, and therefore becomes undesirable unless the need truly justifies the expense. If one views the satellite computers in a multiple satellite configurationas having a special rather than general purpose (i.e., each is to serve as a remote displayprocessor or graphic support cpu) then the need for a large degree of flexibility in dis­ tributing processing tasks between the two computers is minimized. In general, decisions along these lines then become fairly clear. It is desirable to offload the main cpu and decrease communicationtraf­fic as much as possible. As much of the graphics work as is practicable and reasonable should be done in the graphic support cpu. To this end, the appli­cation programmer'sawareness of the dual cpu con­figuration can influence the structure of his de­sign to take advantage of the configurationin cer­tain cases (e.g., where parallel processing is pos­sible or where "fine tuning" is required). The major problem then becomes one of providing a natural and convenientmeans for the application program running in the host to specify and control interaction processing in the satellite. A very time consuming aspect of developing interactive graphic applications programs involves optimal in­ terfacing of the system with highly-interactiveend users in differing applicationareas. This requires that much attention be given to human engineering and results in frequent modification and revision of programs. While subroutine packages have tradition­ally provided a means for specifyingpictures, not much work has been devoted to providing an adequate and reasonably general means for specifying and con­trolling user interactions at a remote graphics station. The Interactive Control Tables described by Cotton [8] provide a language facility whereby an application program running in the host processor can specify complex interactionprograms to be exe­cuted in the satellite. With the exception of this noteworthy work and that described by Christenson and Pinson [4] and by Kilgour [9, 10], little re­search has been done (or at least published) regard­ing improved methods for specifying and accomplish­ ing remote user interactions. The state of the art still seems to be at the macro or subroutine level, with such packages commonlybeing furnished as inter­ active graphics system software. Packages of this type are grossly inadequate from the viewpoint of the application programmer; furthermore, they often do not make effective use of system resources. Large host/graphic satellite systems are becoming increasingly complex in order to meet specific end­user requirements and to provide for even greater system capabilities and throughput. End users are continually imposing additional requirements for complex interaction and concurrent retrieval and processing of associated information in diverse forms. As applications become more demanding and in­ volved, the need for better application independent programming tools tailored for this environment be­comes more acute. Successful implementation of a wide range of varied application projects requires a comprehensive and efficient set of development eff tools. To provide an effectiveprogramming tool and opera­ tional environment for execution of programs in a highly interactive host/satelliteconfiguration, the graphics system software should possess the follow­ing attributes: o A single, complete operating environ­ ment extending across both processors. The remote satellite software should provide for efficient execution of in­teraction programs through effective management of available resources. The host processor software should present a comfortable and natural in­terface to the application programmer. o A graphics-orientedinteraction lan­guage facility. Semantics of the lan­guage should be fairly primitive (e.g., like an implementationlanguage) to enable custom tailoring of interaction programs to be executed in the satel­lite. The language should be powerful in its ability to specify remote in­ teractions, but it should also be easy to learn and to use. No attempt will be made here to defend the validity of these contentions. The purpose of this paper is to describe how these attributes have been realized in a specific implementation,and in particular how various elements of the operating environment and language complement each other. Critical parameters that influence performance and must be considered in the design of the system soft­ware include efficient use of local satellite memory, response time for end users at a variety of remote graphic stations, and the speed with which informa­tion can be accessed and manipulated. In systems that are usually bound by operator interaction and access to data bases, these parameters are often considered far more important than central process­ ing speed. While this may seem obvious, it is stated explicitly to confirm the underlyingphilo­ sophy upon which the design of the system software is based. Effectivemanagementof system resources requires numerous tradeoffs of one resource for an­ other in an attempt to achieve an optimum balance. Without such a guiding philosophy it is almost im­ possible to correct an imbalance once the interior architectureof an operating environment has been designed. 2. BACKGROUND The graphic interaction facilities described in this paper are an integral part of a unique host/satel­ lite architecture developed at Digital Equipment Corporation and previously described by Bruce [11]. This architecture has been derived to fulfill the graphics needs of a large computer-aideddesign system [12]. Briefly, this CAD system is based on a network of DECsystem-10'ssupportinga distributed engineering data base using a general-purposedata base management system, DBMS-10, in a time-shared environment. Each DECsystem-10 (host) computer is required to support eight to twelve graphic satel­ lite processors. The variety of graphics hardware to be supported by the satellites demands that more than one type of cpu be used as a satellite process­ or. Furthermore, many satellite processors are re­quired to support multiple (up to four) graphics de­vices concurrently. Plotters and storage tubes are driven via this architecture as well as full-function refresh displays. Two environmental considerations that influenced the satellite software system design included: 1. The satellites must not require rotat­ing memory for economic reasons. 2. Most satellites will be relatively near (less than 3 miles) to the host and can be hardwired using high-speed (100 kb) communication links. The remainder of this paper describes the host/sat­ ellite operating environment with particular empha­ sis on the methods used to specify and accomplish graphic-oriented interactions. 3. THE SATELLITE ARCHITECTURE The satellite architecture resembles that of a special-purposecomputer closely coupled to a power­ful display processor. It is programmed in a man­ner oriented towards graphics, and it contains only graphic-orienteddata. Interaction between a user and an application data structure is via specific graphic constructs. The resulting machine has been named the Programmable Graphics Processor or PGP. Like a general-purposecomputer, the PGP has memory, an interrupt structure, and a control element. PGP memory, however, consists of program space and reg­ ister space only (i.e., there is no random access memory). The interrupt structure enables devices attached to the PGP to asynchronouslysignal the processor about some external event such as a light pen detection or a keyboard strike. Such interrupts are viewed on a logical rather than physical level and are termed "attentions". Attention handler programs residing in the PGP program space are exe­cuted as a result of an attention. The control ele­ment provides for decoding and execution of PGP in­ structions as well as the sequencing of program logic. The display processor portion of the PGP machine accepts and processes a structured picture definition that has been sent to the PGP in a common interface format. This portion of the PGP inter­faces to a comprehensive set of interactive display­oriented registers that can be accessed directly by attention programs. The displayportion of the PGP alone is sufficient for certain passive (i.e., out­put only) graphic devices such as plotters. In this case the PGP really is not programmed at all, but merely interprets a picture definition and pre­sents the picture on a particular device. The programmabilityof the PGP machine is in the area of user interactions. Therefore, the dual na­ture of the PGP machine is resolved by viewing it as two processors: a picture processor and an interac­tion processor. The interaction processor communi­cates with the picture processor, in the case of in­teractive display devices, via the previouslymen­ tioned device registers and a set of graphic chan­nels. Once initialized, graphic channels provide high-speed access to both coordinate and parametric information in portions of the picture that are to be manipulatedor modified in real time. Although the PGP architecture described above re­ sembles that of a hardwired processor, it is cur­rently implemented by emulation in software. It was originally written in the BLISS-11 implementa­ tion language for the PDP-11 with a GT40 display, and subsequently translated to assembler language for the PDP-15 computer driving a VT15 display. The picture processor and interaction processor have been implemented as two independent but closely re­lated interpreters. These interpreters are re­entrant and draw upon the facilitiesof an under­ lying, stand-alone operating system. The operat­ing system is core resident and provides for a sophisticatedlevel of multi-programmingsuch that up to four PGP machines can be emulated concurrently on the same satellite processor. A keyboard device can be associatedwith each of the logical PGP ma­chines, and each keyboard can operate either as an interactive PGP device or as an independent time­sharing terminal connected to the host computer. 3.1 The Picture Processor The picture processor is implemented in the form of a Pseudo Display File Interpreter. The PGP builds structuredpictures from data and transformations supplied by host computer applicationprograms in the form of a pseudo display file (PDF). The PDF is a device independent representationof the picture and includes window boundary, view center or view­port, and scaling information such that any portion of a picture can be presented at any desired size or location. The PDF is segmented [13] and is built from calls to a set of graphic subroutines in the host computer. When received by the PGP, the PDF is interpreted, transformed, and clipped to generate an actual display file or sequence of drawing com­mands. For interactive devices, the logical struc­ture of the picture is maintained in an ordered seg­ment table which provides access to addressable con­trol points (segments)within the real display file. As implied, segments constitute the basic picture building elements. The applicationprogram assigns segment names (numbers) when building a picture and can form an arbitrarilycomplex hierarchical tree structure if desired. The only reason for including a structure with the picture is to provide a means for dynamic identificationand modificationof dis­crete portions of the picture. Segments are actu­ally nodes of a tree and, hence, follow a tree dis­ cipline (i.e., each segment has only one heritage). The picture can be manipulated or modified at any level in the hierarchy as required by the applica­tion. Segment names need not be unique since a given node in the tree is identified by a path (list of segment names) through the tree. There are two types of segments: structural and primitive. Structural segments correspond to the in­ternal nodes of a tree, and primitive segments corre­spond to endnodes or leaves. Structural segments serve only to logically group a set of other seg­ments which, in turn, may be either structural or primitive. Primitive segments describe the visible portion of a picture (i.e., lines, text, circles, etc.). A primitive segment is defined as a type­dependent algorithm that operates on a supplied set of data points. For example, a line segment consists of a set of points that are to be connected by straight lines, and a circle segment consists of a set of points specifying where each instance of a defined circle is to appear. It is possible to build a picture with only primitive segments. In fact, this might well be the case for passive graphic devices where dynamic interaction is not required. Segment parameters including reference point, scale, rotation, and mirroring can be specified for each segment whether structuralor primitive. The refer­ence point of a segment is distinct from the data points of a primitive. It is essentially an offset from the next higher-level segment,and defines a lo­cal origin for all coordinateswithin the segment with which it is associated. Thus, the position of a group of primitives having a common ancestor can be altered by changing only the ancestor's reference point. Graphic parameters (including intensity,line texture, blink, etc.) can be associated with a struc­tural segment, a primitive segment, or data points within a primitive segment. These parameters apply to the entire heritage of a node unless redefined at a lower level in a sub-tree beginning at that node. At the lowest level, graphic parameters related to a point in a primitive segment affect only the graphics associated with that specific point. 3.2 The Interaction Processor Man-machine communicationusing interactivegraphics is made possible by using a human operator to "close the loop" between a displayed picture and various in­ put devices associated with the display medium. In the PGP, control of operator interaction with such devices is accomplished by means of (PGP)machine­level programs that are executed upon the asynchron­ ous occurrence of attentions (logical interrupts) from these devices. Each interaction device poten­tially has a corresponding attention handling pro­gram. Drawing on a very rich instruction set, these programs can read and change the contents of various registers in the Interaction Processor, make compari­sons and alter program flow, and perform a broad repertoire of arithmetic, logical, and string operations. The programs also are capable of provid­ ing control functions such as dynamically enabling or disabling attention sources, invoking subroutines, initiating transmissionof information to the host computer, and terminating program execution. PGP attention programsmonitor and control graphic in­put devices by reading and writing a comprehensive set of interactivedevice registers. They also can manipulate portions of the displayed picture by modi­ fying or deleting specific graphic constructs and by adding, modifying, or deleting coordinate points or graphic parameters in a primitive. In this way, PGP attention programs couple graphic input devices (and hence the user) with the picture. Attention sources that are currently defined for the PGP machine are summarizedbelow. Not all of these attention sources, however, are based on manual in­ teraction. Host computerandinterval timer atten­ tions signal asynchronous events that may occur completely independent of operator actions. Even though there may be separate attention pro­grams for each possible attention source, all of the facilities of the interaction processor (i.e., registers, etc.) may be used by any attention pro­gram. In general, the PGP machine code in which attentionprograms are defined consists of a set of instructions directedtowards the PGP register set and graphic channels. The PGP register set includes the processor registers and graphic device interac­ tion registers summarizedbelow. PGP processor registers include eight general regis­ ters, four text string accumulators, a general­purpose pushdown stack, and an Interval Timer reg­ ister. Any general register can be loaded with data from other general registers, the device reg­ isters, or with immediate data from attention pro­ grams. These registers can then be manipulated arithmeticallyor logicallyand can be compared with other registers or immediate data for condi­ tional branching. The general text string accumu­ lators can be loaded with immediate text strings from attention programs, displayed text strings, or text strings from other string accumulators. They can be employed to perform conversions of decimal character strings into binary values in general reg­ isters (or vice versa), to compare text strings, to accomplish text string concatenations,and to form messages that are to be displayed locally or returned to the host computer. The general purpose stack and related PGP instructions provide for pushing and popping of word data, allocation or deallocation of stack space, and indexed access to entries on the stack. In addition, the entire latest light pen de­tected segment hierarchy can be loaded onto the stack with a single instruction,and subsequently used to open a graphic channel or for other purposes. The Interval Timer register may be loaded with a value that representsa period of time in increments of 1/60 of a second. When this period of time has ex­pired, the Interval Timer attention is generated and the associated attention program is executed. All interactivedevices interface to the PGP by means of device registers. The loading of an input device register results from a physical interrupt and usu­ally generates a logical attention for the PGP. The appropriate attention program is then executed which, in turn, can interrogate the device register(s). The attention program may manipulate this device-related data, if required, and use it to control program flow, to modify displayed graphics, to return infor­mation to the host processor, or to provide many other control functions. Output devices other than the actual display device are interfaced to the PGP. These include lights, printing or other message de­vices, and the pseudo-devicetracking symbol. The PGP controlsthese devices by means of associated device registers. Loading these registers produces an appropriate action in the output device as a side effect. For example, loading coordinate data into the tracking symbol position register(s) causes the tracking symbol to appear at that point on the dis­play device. Positioning device delta registers hold the incremental distances by which the position­ ing device was last moved. Data in these registers is not cumulative, but rather set to new values on each movement of the device. The delta registers can be used to update the position of graphic con­ structs that are "attached" to a tracking device and are to be moved when the tracking device is moved. In addition to processor and device registers,the PGP architecture includes several read-only regis­ ters that indicate specific device characteristics. These registers are included because the PGP is ca­ pable of supportinga wide variety of graphic devices. The device characteristics registers may be trans­ mitted to the host computerto allow the application program to make intelligent decisions regarding the capabilities of the particular PGP with which it is associated. The interaction processor includes a large set of (64) graphic channels that are defined to allow di­ rect access to a specific portion of the displayed picture that typically is to be modified by real­time operator interaction. Channels are addressed by number and are opened by specifying a list of segment names (i.e., a path through the hierarchy) that uniquely identifies the segment that is to be accessed. Once opened, a channel may be positioned sequentiallyto any subsegment within a structural segment or to any point within a primitive segment. Associated coordinate and parametric information can then be read, inserted, or changed very rapidly un­ der attention program control. Instructions are specificallyprovided in the PGP to accomplish channel-orientedoperations dynamic­ally and locally without host processor interven­tion. Perhaps one of the most significant of these is an instruction to open a channel with a segment hierarchy supplied on the pushdown stack. This hier­archy may have resulted from a light pen detection or practically any other application-sensiblemeans. Also, instructions are provided to add positioning device delta registers to either or both coordinates on an opened channel. This operation causes a dis­ played entity to appear to move in unison with the positioning device. The real power of this facil­ ity, however, is realized in an instruction that applies this operation to all open channels. Com­plex interactions involving simultaneous rubber­banding of numerous lines can thus be simply speci­ fied and efficiently accomplished. Channel-oriented instructionsare also provided to close a channel (or all channels), to delete a subsegment (or point in a primitive) to which a channel is positioned, and to read, insert, or modify a specific coordi­ nate or parameter via an open channel. Channeldata that is accessible to attention programs is summar­ized below. The concept of graphic channels is one of the key elements in the design of the PGP architecture. High-speed access to portions of the displayed pic­ture that are to be modified in real time is an ab­solute necessity. The degree to which this facility is highly programmable is also quite important. The graphic channels as implemented have far ex­ceeded the minimum performance goals originally es­tablished. Very complex manual interactions re­lated to multi-layer printed circuit board design are accomplished with ease and entirely within the satellite. 4. THE INTERACTION LANGUAGE The interactionprocessor in the PGP is supported by an interaction program compiler in the host com­puter. The interaction language is designed to pro­ vide the applicationprogrammer access to all of the programmable facilities of the PGP machine. High-level constructs are provided within the frame­work of a block-structured implementationlanguage for specifying interaction tasks. An interaction task consists of a set of attention handlers that are precompiled and referred to by a common task name. The applicationprogram invokes named inter­action tasks by calling a small run-time support package that simply supplies any specified run-time parameters and then transmits the generated PGP machine-levelcode to the satellite. Each of the attention handlers that comprise an interaction task consists of an ordered set of interaction language statements. An ON statement indicates the particu­lar attention source with which a given attention handler is to be associated. Subsequent program statements are enclosed in BEGIN-END pairs or paren­ theses, which are completely interchangeable. For example, the general form used to specify an atten­tion handler to be executed upon occurrence of a light pen detection is as follows: Each of the interaction language statementsthat form the body of an attention handler is terminated with a semicolon. These statements may be one of several types that include assignment statements, program control statements, and various directives. 4.1 Assignment Statements An assignment statement consists of any writeable identifier followed by an equal sign, which is fol­lowed by a general expression. A writeable identi­fier is the symbology for expressing either a write­able PGP register or a graphic parameter associated with an active channel. The language makes no pro­vision for user-defined variables since there is no random access memory in the PGP. However, PGP reg­isters as well as graphic parameters are referenced symbolicallyby means of keyword mnemonics that have been defined above. For example, TSX is the identi­fier for the tracking symbol X register, and GO is the identifier for general register 0. Graphic parameters associated with an active channel are referenced by preceding a channel designator with an appropriate mnemonic. Thus I[3] refers to the intensity parameter associated with the graphic en­tity on channel 3. The generalexpressionsused in assignment statements are formed by combining readable identifiers with available operators. Readable identifiers include designators for registers that can be read, numeric constants, string literals, and run-time arguments. Thus, the assignment statement GO=LPX+100; adds the decimal constant 100 to the value of the latest light pen detected X coordinate and places the result in general register 0. String literals are expressed as a string of characters enclosed within quotation marks. Thus, the assignment state­ ment S[3]="HELLO"; changes the displayed text string on channel 3 to the characters HELLO. Both constants and string literals can also be passed as run-time arguments. Run-time arguments are referenced positionally with the notation $n, where n is associatedwith the se­quential position of the referenced argument. This facility to pass run-time arguments allows standard interaction programs to be written and subsequently tailored for a particular use at applicationpro­gram execution time. Mixed mode (i.e., both numeric and string) opera­tions are explicitly permitted in general expres­sions, and the compiler generates the PGP code to perform appropriate conversions where required. The destinationregister ultimately determines the mode of any expression in an assignment statement. Thus, the statements specified in a tracking symbol attention program would display a continuous numeric indication of the tracking symbol position providing channels 1 and 2 were opened to text primitive segments. Note that this operation implies a conversion from the binary values held in the tracking symbol registers to two corresponding character strings. General expressions are parsed from left to right without operator precedence and without parentheses to force precedence. The following operators may be used in forming general expressions: + Addition (or unary minus) * Multiplication / Division :Text string concatenation & Logical AND ! Inclusive OR Logical NOT (unary) 4.2 Control Statements Interaction program control statements, which di­ rect program flow, fall into one of the categories listed below. Each of these constructs is dis­ cussed in the following paragraphs. compares the X coordinate value of the latest light pen detection with the value resulting from multiply­ing the contents of general register 0 by the con­stant 10. Multiple relational expressions separated by Boolean AND and OR connectors may be specified in a single conditional expression. For example, the above relational expression could be expanded to to express a more complex Boolean condition. This conditional expression, in turn, could be included with an IF/THEN statement such as to conditionallyposition the tracking symbol within a variable-sizedarea in the lower right hand corner of the display. Program looping constructs are made available in the interaction language in the following general forms. The only difference between the two constructs is the point where the conditional test is made. Also, WHILE specifies execution of the action clause as long as the condition is TRUE, and UNTIL specifies execution of the action clause as long as the condi­tion is FALSE. The CASE statement provides a structured multiple branch with only one entry point and one exit. This construct has the following general form. IF/THEN/ELSE statements have the following general forms: The action clause following a THEN or an ELSE can consist of one or more program statements of any type enclosed in a BEGIN-END pair or parentheses. In fact, additional IF/THEN/ELSE statements may be specified within an action clause to effect nest­ ing of program control logic. Conditional expressions are comprised of one or more relational expressions, which are formed by separa­ting two general expressions with a relational op­erator. Relational operators include the usual GTR, LSS, EQL, GEQ, LEQ, and NEQ. For example, the relational expression The CASE statement specifies the execution of one of the action clauses that follow the keyword SET. The value of the readable identifier provides an index to determine which action clause is to be executed. Routines are invoked from attention handlers or other routines via the general construct CALL n where n identifies the routine that is to be exe­cuted. Terminationof execution within a routine is simply specified by RETURN. 4.3 Directives The interaction language includes directives that provide certain control functions,perform limited picture modifications,and return information to the host computer. These include both channel-oriented and non-channel oriented directives. Channel­orienteddirectives provide for program control of PGP graphic channels and include OPEN, POSITION, CLOSE, LOCK, and UNLOCK. The OPEN and POSITION di­rectives are provided to establish a channel to point to a portion of the picture that is to be read or modified in real time. These directives have the following general form: Opening a channel establishes a link to a particu­ lar segment with the designated heritage. Having opened a channel, POSITION can be used to orient the channel to a particular sub-element of the segment to which the channel has been opened. If the chan­ nel has been opened to a structural segment, it may be positioned to a subsegment; if the channel has been opened to a primitive segment, it may be posi­ tioned to a specific point within that primitive. When achannel link is no longer needed, it may be broken by means of the CLOSE directive. LOCK and UNLOCK directives are included to provide control in exempting specified channels from certain all­ channel operations. Non-channel oriented directives include SEND, BLANK, UNBLANK, ENABLE, and DISABLE. The SEND directive returns information specified by an argument list to the host computer along with an indication of the type of information being sent. The BLANK and UNBLANK directives are followed by a segment list to indicate a picture segment that is to be made to appear or disappear from view. The ENABLE and DISABLE directives provide for program control over attention sources. In additionto the directives mentioned above, a DELETE directive is also included. This directive may be either channel-orientedor non-channel oriented depending on which of the following gen­ eral forms is used. 4.4 Example A special syntax is included in the interaction language to enable an applicationprogrammer to specify an operation that is to be performed on all open channels. To illustrate, the assignment state­ment specifies changing the intensityof graphic en­tities on all open channels to intensity level 4. Similarly,the construct specifies adding the values of the tracking symbol delta registers to the coordinate values on each open channel. This particular assignment statement can be employed to accomplish multiple line rubber­banding. In fact, assuming that appropriate chan­nel control has been established and that tracking 210 symbol attentions have been enabled, the attention handler provides for multiple line rubberbandingwhile con­ straining tracking symbol movement to some portion of the left hand side of the screen which has been de­ fined at applicationprogram run-time. This example as well as others in this section is in­ tended to illustrated specific features and capabili­ ties of the interaction language. In the interest of brevity,many language features have not been de­ scribed. Although the material presented is neces­ sarily brief, it is hoped that it still conveys the "flavor" of the language as well as the naturalness and ease with which more complex interaction tasks might be specified. 5. CONCLUSION The PGP architectureand interaction language de­ scribed herein are a unique combination of general concepts that togetherprovide a powerful, device independent operating environment. The PGP archi­ tecture provides for efficient execution of interac­ tion programs in the highly interactive satellite environment. Simultaneousrubberbanding of 25 separ­ ate lines is routinely handled with little speed degradation. The authors feel that emulation of the PGP architecture in software makes very efficient use of core memory. Complex interaction tasks can often be specified in only a few words, with the re­ sponsibility for carrying out such tasks being dele­ gated to the system software. The overhead of in­ terpretationhas not proven to be a limiting factor at any time. The satellite system software current­ ly resides in 12-14K words of 16-or 18-bit memory and uses an additional8-12K words for display file and tables. Practical experience with the interac­ tion language has shown it to be natural and easy to learn, while enabling a high degree of custom tailor­ing in specifying remotely executed interaction pro­grams. The language encourages the application pro­grammer to think of interaction requirements algo­rithmically. The fact that the applicationprogram­mer must be bilingual has not proven to be a problem, possibly because the language resembles the BLISS implementationlanguage used for the CAD applica­tions. The decisionto implement a special purpose language was made only after considering alternatives that included a subroutine package, a set of high­level macros, and extensions to the host implementa­tion language. Each of these alternatives was found lacking. On the application level, since the language is in­dependent of actual hardware subtleties and machine­level code, interaction tasks are easy to modify and maintain. Applications have been developed on one processor while intended to run on a completely dif­ ferent type of processor. On the system level, new instructionsand facilities have been added to the PGP architectureand subsequently reflected in the language with relative ease. Continuing work is be­ing done, however, to enhance both the language and the satellite architecture. The tree structured graphicdata in the PGP presents an inherent prob­ 4. article_rec.title: Affordability of computer graphics for planning networks in DOD program management

abstract.par: This report represents data relative to the alternative consideration involved in selecting a configuration for the Interactive Graphics Networking System, (IGNS). The IGNS permits a user to interactively view a network, modify it, if needed, analyze various management options and view their impact upon the data contained in the network, and, finally receive network plots and management reports.A prototype of this system was developed and tested for feasibility. Having proven the feasibility, the purpose of this report is to provide the data necessary for a user to decide the individual optimum system configuration which may be used to facilitate an interactive networking reporting capability.
