To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania QUANTITATIVE IMAGING OF DYNAMIC STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION OF THE HEART, LUNGS AND CIRCULATION BY COMPUTERIZEDRECONSTRUCTIONAND SUBTRACTION TECHNIQUES* Richard A. ROBB, Erik L. RITMAN, James F. GREENLEAF, Ralph E. STURM, Gabor T. HERMAN, Peter A. CHEVALIER, Hsun K. LIU, and Earl H. WOOD Biophysical Sciences Unit, Department of Physiology and Biophysics, Mayo Graduate School of Medicine, Rochester, Minnesota 55901 Conventional radiographic imaging techniques are not adequate for determination of the true, dynamic changes in shape and dimensions of the intact working heart, lungs and circulation which are required for accurate quantitativedetermination of the structure and function of these organ systems. This paper describes a com­puterized method for obtaining images of the dynamic spatial distribution of x-ray attenuation throughout multiple parallel cross-sectional planes bisecting the intact thorax, with 1-mm spatial resolution and 60-per-second temporal resolution, and for generating time delay video and cine displays of the spatial and temporal sequences of these cross-sectional images. Operator-interactivecomputer programs facilitate the dynamic display of reconstructedcross sections of the heart and lungs, with or without dynamic background subtraction, and permit calculation and display of any desired single or spatially related set of coronal, sagittal or obliquely oriented sections. Such displays permit viewing of the temporal and spatial distribution of contraction, expansion, and perfusion of these organs over their full anatomic extent in various orientations and in variable time-base modes ranging from stop-action to real-time. The results achieved with this computerized system for three-dimensionalreconstructionand display of moving organs, partic­ularly the heart, lungs, and circulation,demonstrate the potential for providing greatly improved techniques for investigationof the relationships of the dynamic three-dimensionalanatomy and blood-tissue exchange properties of moving organ systems to their regional and integrated function, and ultimately for providing powerful new clinical diagnostic methods for elucidation of abnormalitiesof the heart, lungs and circulation in man. 1. INTRODUCTION It is of fundamental importance in stud­ ies of cardiovascularand pulmonary physiology and for obtaining more accu­rate clinical assessments of regional heart, lung, and circulatory function to measure and analyze the dynamic regional changes in geometry, perfusion and ten­ sion of these organ systems. The func­ tion and performance of the heart, lungs and circulation are inseparably linked to their motion in three dimensions (1,2). However, satisfactory noninvasive methods have not as yet been established for determinationof the true, dynamic *This work was supported by Grants HL­ 04664, HL18968 and RR-7 from the National Heart and Lung Institute, U. S. Public Health Service; N01-CB-53857 and N01-CB­53860 from the National Cancer Institute; NGR 24-003-001 from the National Aero­nautics and Space Administration; F44620-71 -0069 from the U.S. Air Force, MES 75-22347 from the National Science Fdn.; and AHA CI 10 from the American Heart Association. changes in shape and dimensions of the intact heart and lungs or for accurate three-dimensionalmeasurement of the dis­ tribution of blood flow to, from, and within these and other organ systems of the body. Such measurementsare required for accurate quantitative studies of the structure and function of these organ systems to be carried out. Although current computerizedx-ray tomo­graphic systems, such as the ACTA (3), DELTA (4), and EMI (5) whole-body scan­ners, produce remarkably accurate anatomic images of any single cross section of the body, they cannot provide, due to their limited axial scan range and relatively long scan times (20 seconds or longer), high spatial and temporal resolution transaxial images over the entire anatomic extent of moving organs such as the heart, lungs and circulation. X-ray video imaging techniques, coupled with precise computer synchronizationof physiological events, provide the capa­bility of noninvasivelyrecording multiplanar images of the entire chest and its contents with high spatial and temporal resolution from which dynamic complete three-dimensionalreconstructions of intrathoracic organs can be determined (6,7). 2. METHODS Fig. 1 diagramaticallyillustrates the system developed in our laboratory for generation and collection of two-dimen­sional multiangular x-ray projection images using a computer-controlledsingle­source single-detector x-ray fluoroscopic system. The x-ray imaging chain, shown at the bottom of the figure, is a new high performance state-of-the-artvideo­fluoroscopic system, unique in its design and construction,which we call the SSDSR for single source dynamic spatial recon­structor (8). Fig. 1 -Diagram of computer­controlled single-sourcesingle­detector x-ray video system (SSDSR) for collection of multiplanar roentgen video projections for dynamic spatial reconstructionsof the intact thorax and its contents. The object to be reconstructed is posi­tioned in the x-ray field of the SSDSR and rotated under computer-controlabout an axis perpendicular to the central plane of x-ray beams. The fluoroscopic image at each successive angle of view is scanned by the video camera, producing an electronic video signal representation of the image, which is made up of approxi­mately 500 horizontal scan lines. Each line in the video image represents the projections of an approximately1-mm thick section of the object scanned. Measurements of the transmitted x-ray in­tensities on each video line are made by the video digitizer (9) and are repeated on the same lines for each successive view of the object as it is rotated in arc of 180 to 360 . Typically two minutes are required to complete digiti­ equi-angular increments through a total ° ° zation of all lines in all recorded angles of view. These x-ray transmission measurements provide the data required for determinationof up to 500 parallel adjacent cross sections of the object, or, in other words, its complete three­dimensional reconstruction. Reconstructionof a moving object, such as a beating heart within the thorax of a live animal, requires maintenance of exact temporal relationshipsbetween physiologicalevents and x-ray projection image recording. This is accomplished by slaving all components of the system, including the computer, to the master oscillator, labeled SYNC in the slide, which controls the video sweep circuits of the video camera. The rate and phase of the cardiac and respiratory cycles are kept constant and synchronizedwith the rotation, x-ray pulses, video re­cording and digitizing process by computer-controlledventilation of the lungs and pacing of the atria and ventri­cles, all in exact temporal relationship with the 60-per-secondoscillator pulses. The ECG and other hemodynamic variables are simultaneouslyrecorded with the video images on a videotape or video disc (10) so that sets of images, recorded at the same phase of successive respiratory and cardiac cycles at each incremental angle of view can be selected for each point in time throughout the respiratory and cardiac cycles to obtain complete dynamic spatial reconstructions of the thorax and its contents. Fig. 2 schematicallyillustrates how a single transverse cross section of an Fig. 2 -Schematic diagram of geometric considerationsfor re­ construction of a cross section of the heart (see ref. 11). object (in this case the heart) is deter-mined using an algebraic reconstruction technique (12). The transaxial planetraversed by the x-ray beam which contains the desired cross section of the object to be reconstructed is mathematicallydivided into a set of small squares of arbitrary size (typically 64 x 64 up to 128 x 128) and the intensity of the x-raybeam transmitted through that plane is measured at several points (up to 1 000 along the detector for each rotational position of the x-ray source and detector with respect to the object. The geometricconsiderations are the same if the source and detector are rotated about the object or if the object is rotated with respect to a fixed source and detector. The transmitted x-ray beam measurements from the detector are related to measurements of the incident x-ray beam (obtained by removing the object from the system) for all angles of view by a system of linear equations in which the unknowns are the x-ray beam attenuation coefficients in each small square of the grid. The alge-braic solution of this system of equationsprovides an array of numbers which can be displayed as a matrix of picture elements with individual brightness levels pro-portional to the attenuation coefficients in each small square. Such a display re-sults in an image of the cross-sectional structure of the object scanned. More recently we have implemented a fan-beam convolution reconstruction algorithm (13) which operates on multiplanar pro-jection data recorded in this same waybut which is faster and produces somewhat better cross-sectional images of the thorax than are obtained with the alge-braic technique. The left-hand panel in fig. 3 is a photo-graph of a video monitor upon which is displayed the thorax of an intact dog,supported in the head-up position, which was recorded with the SSDSR system. The white area on either side of the dog re-presents the unattenuated x-ray beam impinging on the fluorescent screen and demonstrates the superior dynamic rangeof this system, by comparison to conven-tional fluoroscopic equipment, in as much as the spine can be seen through the heart shadow, and other intrathoracic structures, including the radiopaque 2-mm diameter catheters, are simultaneously imaged with the unattenuated x-ray. No x-ray contrast material has been injected into the dog to produce this image. The brightenedhorizontal line superimposed upon the thoracic image represents the projectionof the central fan of x-ray beams onto the fluorescent screen, and depicts the ana-tomic level selected for the cross-sec-tional reconstruction of the dog's thorax shown in the right-hand panel of fig. 3. This reconstruction, produced in one mi-nute by a fan-beam convolution algorithm, is typical of the best reconstructions we have been able to achieve to date. Note the spinal vertebra and spinal chord, ribs, pleural surfaces of the lungs, the esophagus, bifurcated trachea, epicardialsurfaces of the heart, and the two cath-eters in the heart. Some trapped air which leaked through the catheters can be seen in the chambers of the heart. The spatial and contrast resolution achieved in this reconstruction is very encour-aging, considering fluoroscopic x-ray levels and video recording techniques were used. Fig. 3 -Photograph of thorax (left panel) of an intact dog supported in the head-position in SSDSR system and reconstructed cross section (right panel) of thorax at level indicated by brightened horizontal line in left panel. Reconstructions of this type can be ob-sections. No x-ray contrast material was tained from one scan for up to 500 cross-used for these reconstructions. sectional levels. l-mm apart, over the entire anatomic extent of the thorax, and successive sets of these cross sections can be reconstructed at a temporal re- solution of 60-per-second throughout suc- cessive cardiac and/or respirators cycles. That is, the SSDSR scans can produce- dynamic, high axial spatial resolution and large axial range cross-sectional images whrch cannot be achieved by other current- ly operational CT scanners; and which are required for detailed quantitative anal- ysis of the dynamic regional and syner- gistic function of the heart, lungs and circulation. Fig. 4 depicts 64 brightened l-mm thick video lines, each 3-mm apart, covering the anatomic extent of the thorax of an intact dog, which were selected from one rotational scan for reconstruction of 64 cross sections of the dog's chest. The two lines between each level were also digitized and averaged with each Fig. 5 -Sixteen parallel 3-mm thick preceding line to produce cross sections transverse sections reconstructed at effectively 3-mm thick. 12-mm intervals extending from the apex of the lungs (upper left) to the base of the lungs (lower right). A very useful advantage of full spatial anatomic reconstructions of the thorax such as these is that multiple parallel sections oriented at any desired angle in relation to the x, y and z axes of the thorax can be computed from the.re- constructed transverse images, and dis- played for viewing of the thorax from any aspect. Fig. 6 is a computer-generated displayof 16 parallel 3-mm thick coronal sections, Fig. 4 -Photograph of thorax of intact dog with superimposed brightened horizontal lines at 64 levels selected for cross section reconstruction. Fig. 5 shows 16 of these reconstructed cross sections (every fourth line in fig. 4, hence 12-mm apart) from the apex of the lungs, at the upper left of the figure, extending cephalo-caudally to the diaphragmatic margin at the base of the lungs, at the lower right of the figure, in left-to-right, top-to-bottom order. The spinal vertebra, ribs as they Fig. 6 -Sixteen parallel 3-mm thick course through the plane of the cross coronal sections of dead dog thorax section, the bifurcated airway, the In 12-mm increments extend& from epicardial surfaces of the heart, and the sternum (upper left) to backbone pleural surfaces of the lungs can all be (lower right) determined from "stack" visualized. Some trapped air in the bowel of 64 parallel transverse sections, can be seen in the lower row of cross of which 16 are shown in fig. 5. 12-mm apart through the thorax, extendingin 4 rows, left-to-right and top-to-bot­tom, from the sternum at the upper leftto the backbone at the lower right. These 3-mm thick coronal sections were computedfrom 64 reconstructed transverse sections of the chest of which 16 are shown in fig. 5. Note the ribs in the chest wall,the catheters in the heart (in row 2),the trachea and esophagus (in row 3) andthe detail of the backbone (in row 4). Fig. 7 is a similar display of sagittalsections extending from the left side ofthe thorax (at the upper left) to theright side of the thorax (at the bottomright) computed from the same set of 64reconstructed transverse sections. Fig. 8 illustrates a sequence of thoraciccross-sectional reconstructions of a living dog's chest, with no x-ray con­ trast material injected, obtained fromtemporally correlating sets of digitizedmultiplanar x-ray images of the thoraxrecorded during rotation of the dog inangular increments on successive res­piratory cycles. Each row of sec­ tions represents three different anatomiclevels of the chest; the top, center, andbottom rows corresponding respectively tothe apical, mid, and basal levels of the thorax; and each column of cross sections represent three different phases of therespiratory cycle, the left, center, andright columns corresponding, respectively, to the end-expiratory, mid-inspiratory,and end-inspiratory phases of the respi­ratory cycle. Hence, this montage of images illustrates both dynamic (in thehorizontal direction) and spatial (in thevertical direction) reconstructions made from a single rotational scan. Fig. 8 -Reconstructed thoracic cross sections of the intact lungs andheart-of a living dog reconstructedat three different anatomic levels (rows) and at three different pointsin the respiratory cycle (columns). Fig. 9 shows a single cross-sectionallevel near the mid-plane between thebase and apex of an intact, beating heartwithin the thorax of a living dog recon­structed at 12 successive points through­out the cardiac cycle, with each successivepoint in time being 33 msec apart. Duringthe rotation period of approximately 25seconds, respiration was suspended andx-ray contrast material was continuously infused into the left ventricular chamber to achieve constant beat-to-beat opac­ ification of the chamber during therotational scan period. The left ventricular chamber and epicardialsurfaces of the heart can be seen in each successive image in the first two rowsduring the isovolumic and contractilephases of the systolic period, followedby the subsequent diastolic filling periodshown in the bottom row. The upper left­hand image corresponds to end-diastole,and is coincident in time with the com­puter pacing pulse (or "R" wave) whichinitiates the contraction. These cross sections demonstrate the here­tofore unobtainable capability for deter­mination of the dynamic cross-sectionalshape and dimensions of both the epi- andendocardial surfaces of the intact work­ing heart in living animals over theentire anatomic and temporal extents ofthe myocardial walls and cardiac cycle,respectively. Display of the three-dimensional image information obtained by these techniques is an important factor in establishing the usefulness of these capabilities inbasic research and clinical practice. Time delay video and cine recordings of the temporal and spatial sequences of the computer-generated cross section recon­ structions illustrated in these figureshave been made. These sequences of cross sections reconstructed over the full anatomical extent of the beating heartand breathing lungs throughout successivecardiac and respiratory cycles, respec­ tively, in isolated preparations and in intact dogs can be viewed in variable time base modes ranging from stop-action to real-time. Such dynamic displaysprovide the capability for studying the spatial relationships and instant-to instant changes in geometry of theseorgans and permits evaluation of theirregional and integrated overall function in the intact thorax. An example of how three-dimensionalimages can be displayed to permit anal­ysis of the spatial relationships and re­gional detail of image structures isillustrated in figs. 10 and 11. Fig. 10shows a sequence of 4 reconstructed crosssections from base-to-apex of an isolated,dead canine heart whose chambers and coronary arteries were filled with cottonand barium paste, respectively, prior torotation and digitization of a total of48 video lines selected for cross-sec­tional reconstruction. The characteristic cross-sectional shapesof the epi-and endocardial surfaces of both the left and right ventricles at eachof 4 selected levels are accurately recon­structed. In.addition, the cross Fig. 11 -Computer-generated per­spective line display of coronaryartery system at four differentangles of view computed from 48parallel transverse cross sectionsreconstructed over the anatomic extent of heart (see ref. 14). sections of the coronary arteries as theytraverse the myocardial walls can be seenas bright spots (more x-ray dense) at eachcross-sectional level. These arteries are approximately 2-mm in diameter near thebase of the heart (upper-left crosssection) and 0.5 mm in diameter near theapex of the heart (lower-right crosssection). Fig. 11 shows four three-dimensionalperspective line displays of the coronary tree of the heart at successive 50" angles of view determined from the co­ ordinate positions of the coronary arteries, which were entered into the computer using an operator-interactivedisplay and light pen assembly, in eachof the 48 parallel cross sections of the heart reconstructed from its base to apex. By performing rotational matrix operations on these sets of x,y, z coordinates, line representations of the coronary tree can be viewed from any orientation in stop­ action or during continuous rotation to facilitate studies of the geometric re­ lationships of the coronary artery system. Similar three-dimensional displays of the complete coronary vessels, obtained by entering into the computer the entire cross section of each artery at each re­ constructed level, permit regional struc­ tural details (i.e., narrowing) to be examined as well. Fig. 12 is a computer-generated gray level plot of two cross sections of an isolated beating left ventricle recon­ structed near the base (left) and apex (right) of the ventricle during the same instant in the cardiac cycle. The myocardium is depicted by points with different gray levels which are propor­tional to the degree of stress at eachpoint location in a direction perpendicularto the plane of the reconstructed crosssection. These values are determined bymathematically dividing the cross-sec­tional image of the myocardium into alinked set of several hundred triangularelements and, by using finite elementanalysis techniques (15), computing thestresses at each node of each triangleon the basis of the cross-sectional shapeof the myocardium and the simultaneouslymeasured transmural cardiac pressures.This type of display in which measured or calculated physiological variables are superposed upon the reconstructed cross­ sectional anatomy permits simultaneous analysis of structure and function of the object being studied. By using three-dimensional boundary surface detection and three-dimensional computer graphics techniques (namely,hidden surface removal and shading), the three-dimensional reconstruction of ob­ jects can be presented in the form of three-dimensional displays. The left-hand panel in fig. 13 is acomputer-generated three-dimensional surface display of a whole isolatedcanine heart which was determined byautomatic three-dimensional boundarydetection of 30 reconstructed cross­sectional levels of the heart. The right-hand panel in fig. 13 is a three­dimensional gray-level surface displayof the same heart but mathematicallyopened into halves to permit viewing ofthe structural detail of the intra-chamber surfaces. Fig.. 14 is a computer-generated graylevel surface display of the leftventricular chamber of a dog upon whichiso-stress contour lines have been super­imposed (16). This type of multi­dimensional display is useful for quanti­tative evaluation and study of the inter­relationship between structure andfunction of the heart. The usefulness of these kinds of displaysdepends a great deal on the display for­mat. The illusion of three-dimensionalitycan be enhanced with stereo pairs gener­ated by mathematically rotating theoriginal surface through a small angleand displaying the original and rotated chamber detail. Fig. 14 -Computer-generatedsurface display of the leftventricular chamber of an intact dog upon which is superimposediso-contour lines representingtangential stress. L axis re­presents spatial coordinatesfrom base-to-apex (i.e., structure),8 axis represents coordinates ofcircumferential stress contours (i.e., function) (see ref. 17). surface side-by-side for stereoptic view­ing. Another method for viewing suchstereo pairs is to display images alter­nately field-by-field on a televisionmonitor and view the image throughglasses which become alternately opaqueto each eye synchronously with the dis­play of the image fields. The capability provided by the videoimage digitizing system for obtaininghigh spatial (up to 2 000 samples on eachof 250 lines per video field) and hightemporal (60 video fields per second) re­solution measurements for cross-sectional reconstruction of moving organs alsopermits the study of the appearance, meantransit and clearance of x-ray contrast substances through, for example, the myo­cardium with a degree of anatomical andtemporal precision not possible by currentradioisotope techniques. This capabilityis indicated in fig. 15 which illustrates the quantitative determination by dynamicbackground subtraction of the spatial dis­tribution of the coronary circulationwithin the myocardium of a patient under­going selective coronary arteriography. Fig. 15 -Comparison of actualx-ray video images (left column)of human heart recorded duringselective coronary arteriographywith digitized, computer-generatedsubtraction images (right column)computed at same point in threesuccessive cardiac cycles (seeref. 18). 253 Each computer-generateddifference image (right-handpanels, 1-3) of contrast dis­tribution at the same specific phase of three successive heart beats following the injection of contrast material is obtained by subtraction, sample for sample, of the digitized arrays of the video images recorded during and following the injection (left panel) from the digitized arrays of the video images re­ corded just prior to the injection. Simultaneous ECG recording on the video­tape allows precise temporal and phasic registration between the pre-injection video images and the post-injectionvideo images which are subtracted to produce difference pictures at each point in the cardiac cycle throughout successive post­injection cycles. By combining dynamic three-dimensionalre­construction techniques with dynamic sub­ traction techniques, the instant-to-instant regional changes in shape and dimensions and transmural perfusion of the myocardium (and other organ systems) can be accurate­ly and completely studied. 3. DISCUSSION Cross sections over the entire anatomic extent of the intact, working heart and lungs at different instants during the cardiac and respiratory cycles have been successfully reconstructed in our labo­ratory from images obtained by rotating live, anesthetized dogs in the x-ray field of a single x-ray source, single image detector system while controlling respiration and pacing the heart in exact synchrony with the video scan rate and pulsing of the x-ray source. Although the margins of the lungs and epicardial surfaces of the heart can be readily recognized in such cross sections, intracardiac detail is limited due to beat-to-beat variations in cardiac geo­metry and to insufficient roentgen opacity gradients between the myocardium and the circulating volumes of blood during the 20-to-120-secondperiod of time re­quired for rotation and recording. En­ hanced blood-to-musclex-ray density gradients achieved by intravenous in­fusion of conventional radiopaque con­trast materials cannot be uniformly maintained without physiologicalpertur­ bations for this period of time. This difficulty in producing anatomical and circulatory stationarity, which would be impractical to impose upon patients if it could be achieved, and which most cer­tainly does not occur naturally during normal spontaneous activity, and most particularly does not occur in patients with cardiac or pulmonary disease, makes very improbable the effective use of electrocardiographicgating of any me­ chanical scanning procedure for obtaining 254 accurate reconstructions of moving organs such as the heart and lungs. These con­ siderations indicate that dynamic three­ dimensional reconstructionof the heart within the intact thorax of a living dog or human requires development of an all electronic device which can record ap­ proximately30 multiplanar x-ray images of the total heart practically instan­ taneously, and at frequent enough inter­ vals of time and with sufficient density and spatial resolution to capture and re­ solve the most rapid changes in cardiac structural detail and circulation over the entire anatomic extent of the heart throughout each cardiac cycle. Our pre­ liminary results with a single-source, single-detector prototype unit of such an imaging system indicate that such a de­ vice, which would be equally suitable for use in a clinical diagnostic setting as well as in a research environment for determinationand display in real-time modes of cross sections of the function­ ing thorax and its contents of unanes­ thetized living animals and man, is technologicallyand practically feasible (19). Fig. 16 is a diagram of such a complete dynamic spatial reconstruction (DSR)sys­ tem. The twenty-eight sets of image­ intensifiers and image isocon video cameras are arranged behind the curved fluorescent screen to produce twenty-eight video images of the 30 cm x 30 cm over­lapping roentgen projection images pro­duced on the screen. One complete scan is accomplished in 0.01 second by pulsing each of the x-ray sources in succession for 0.34 milliseconds. Total incident dose for successive 60-per-second scans lasting for two seconds (i.e., about two heart beats) would be approximately 2 r. The video images are multiplexed onto four video discs for immediate storage. Following transfer of these recorded data to the computer, up to sixty adjacent cross sections can be reconstructedfrom these data for every 1/60th second of operation of the DSR. ponents and data flow path associated with dynamic spatial reconstructor (DSR). High-speed parallel processing recon­struction techniques (i.e., convolution implemented in special purpose hardware) will permit computation speeds of about 1/60th a second per cross section, that is, two minutes for the entire scan pro­cedure. Such rapid processingwill be essential for effective clinical use of the full potentialities of the DSR. 2. 3. E. H. Wood, E. L. Ritman, R. E. Sturm, S. Johnson, P. Spivak, B. K. Gilbert, and H. C. article_rec.title: Characteristics of neuroscience computer graphics displays and a proposed system to generate those displays

abstract.par: Computer graphics displays in the neurosciences are classified into three categories: anatomical structures, physiological waveforms, and statistical summaries. The capabilities required in a line drawing system to present neuroscience displays are smooth rotation and translation of 3D structures, simple line rejection, orthographic projection, and flexible interactive hard copy capable of drawing dots. The general purpose computer is available to refresh the CRT. A simple graphics processor with the necessary capabilities is defined and its unique features are discussed.

To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania CHARACTERISTICSOF NEUROSCIENCECOMPUTER GRAPHICS DISPLAYS AND A PROPOSED SYSTEM TO GENERATETHOSE DISPLAYS* Joseph J. CAPOWSKI Department of Physiology, University of North Carolina Chapel Hill, North Carolina 27514 Computer graphics displays in the neurosciences are classified into three categories: ana­ tomical structures, physiologicalwaveforms, and statistical summaries. The capabilities required in a line drawing system to present neuroscience displays are smooth rotation and translation of 3D structures, simple line rejection, orthographic projection, and flexible interactivehard copy capable of drawing dots. The general purpose computer is available to refresh the CRT. A simple graphics processor with the necessary capabilities is defined and its unique features are discussed. 1. INTRODUCTION For several years I have been the director of a computer center used to collect and analyze neuro­physiologicaland neuroanatomicaldata. The center is based around a DEC PDP-11/45 general purpose computer and Evans and Sutherland LDS-2 line drawing graphics system. The role of the graphics system must be emphasized; experience has shown that the primary output form from the com­puter to the neuroscientistis the CRT display and its hard copy. The graphics form is easily understood by the scientist and allows him to feel comfortable in an unfamiliar environment. Much work has been done by graphic display man­ ufacturers and by university researchers in de­ fining new display algorithms, new display tech­ nologies, and new display hardware. Much less thought has been given to what the user really needs. I have been unable to find in the liter­ ature a presentation of the needs of computer graphics users in the neurosciences. This paper is an attempt to fill that void. From my ex­ perience, I shall try to define what graphic displays neuroscientists generate and then pro­ pose a simple graphics system which allows easy generation of those displays. 2. CHARACTERISTICSOF NEUROSCIENCEGRAPHIC DISPLAYS Neuroscience graphic displays attempt to convey information about a neuroanatomicalor neuro­ physiological system to a scientist. This in­ formation almost always takes one of three forms. The first form, two examples of which are shown in fig. 1, is a display of structural information about neuroanatomical tissue features. The dis-Fig. 1 -Three dimensional neuroanatom­ play is formed of many short lines. The structure ical structures. (a) the axon tree of a neuron. This display is composed of about *Work on this project was supported by the Alfred 450 short lines stored in a binary tree. P. Sloan Foundation and by Grant No. 5-PO1-NS (b) A 3D perspective projection of fifteen 11132-02 of the National Institutes of Health. planar sections of a hagfish brain. The sections were traced with a data tablet into a general purpose modeling program [1]. This display is composed of about 1600 short lines. It is taken from [4]. might be two or three dimensional. The two dimen­sional case may be considered a subset of the three dimensional case. The three dimensional case oc­curs so often in neuroanatomy that it must be con­ sidered. The second form of information,an example of which is shown in fig. 2, is a presentation of e­ lectrical waveforms recorded from an animal. The X axis in these displays is usually time, but could be some other parameter which varies with time. Fig. 2 -Action potential waveforms re­corded from the peripheral nervous system of a rabbit. Each waveform is composed of 70 short lines. This figure is taken from [2]. The third form of information,two examples of which are shown in fig. 3, is a display of graphs, usually statistical distributions of neuroanatom­ical features or neurophysiologicalevents. The examples show the need to easily display both lines and dots. Fig. 3 -Statistical summaries of neuro­ anatomical features and neurophysiological events. (a) An interpoint distancehis­ togram of all terminals of a neuron axon tree. (b)A graph of instantaneous fre­ quency and stimulus temperature versus time for action potentials of the type displayed in fig. 2. This figure is taken from [2]. In all of the above cases the information conveyed is not realistic. The display is not a copy of a real object which a person could hold in his hand or see through a window. Because of the lack of realism, many of the computer graphics techniques designed to generate a realistic display from a computer-storedmathematical model are of little value. The remainder of this section discusses which techniques are necessary for neuroscience displays. Most of the features to be discussed apply to hard copy as well as to CRT displays. Structure data for the three dimensional displays are stored in a computer memory display file of three dimensional coordinates. The ability to smoothly rotate and translate the picture in real time is necessary for the scientist to understand the structure. Since the number of lines in a display may be fairly high (greater than 2000), the real time rotation calculation must be per­formed in special purpose hardware, probably as a matrix multiplication. For the waveform and graph displays, no real time rotation is required. Translation, or a relative drawing capability can easily be performed in matrix multiplicationhard­ware. Because the display file stored in the computer is not updated in rotation and transla­ tion, the remaining transformationsapplied to the rotated figure must also be performed in special hardware. After the picture has been rotated and trans­ lated, some parts of the picturemay not be in the scientist's view according to some definition of his viewing limits. Since the structure is composed entirely of short lines, a simple line rejection scheme which rejects a line if either end of the line is out of view can be used with­out degrading the picture appreciably. The simple rejection scheme is ideally suited for waveform displays. In the case of graphs, the problem does not arise as it is assumed that graphs are drawn entirely in view. Once it has been determinedwhich parts of the three dimensional structure are to be shown, the projection onto a two dimensional display sur­ face occurs. Two projections, orthographic and one point perspective, are in general use. Fig. 4 shows an anatomical structure in both projections. For the structuresdisplayed in neuroscience work, the orthographic projectionis much more natural. Also, the apparent distortion caused by the per­ spective projection is greatly enhanced during smooth rotation. Our experience has shown that a smoothly rotating orthographic projectionprovides a most pleasant and effective way to study a three dimensional structure. The simplicity of the or­ thographic projection,ignoring Z after rotation, adds to its appeal. la. It has been rotated 300 degrees about the X axis. (a) Orthographic projection. (b) Perspective projection. The tree is apparently distorted by the perspectiveprojection. Depth cueing by varying the CRT beam intensity with Z has proven to be of little value. Possibly this is because a scientist wishes to examine a struc­ture as if it were a cube two feet on a side held at arms length. In such an examination, light transmitted to the scientist's eyes from distance points in the cube would not be noticeably more attenuated than light transmitted from near points. For two dimensional displays, of course, depth cueing does not apply. Various line types, for example dashed, blinking, dotted, have been attempted for some applications. Our experience has shown that the extra amount of informationwhich can be passed to the scientist through the use of various line types is not great enough to justify the effort to build line type capabilitiesinto the display hardware. The data tablet is a good tracing device. Un­ fortunately the data tablet requires scientist preparation time for its use. Our experience has shown that the use of the data tablet for pointing applications, for example menu selection, is an­noying. The hardcopy device should be able to make a copy of the CRT display at any time. Flexibility in the use of the device is quite important. It must be possible to draw a plot and then, say, draw another plot in a new color superimposed on the first one. The type of flexibility cannot be de­ fined in a program. It must be possible for the scientist to manipulate the plotter to achieve the desired effects. The use of different symbols to indicate different data types is quite messy when the amount of data is high. Different colors indicate different data types much more clearly. The hardcopy device must have the ability to draw dots. Ball point pen plotters cannot perform this task. A complete list of plotting needs is pre­ sented in [3]. Once a neurosciencedisplay has been started, the computer system waits for a scientist's command from some interactive device. The command could be to modify the display or to stop the display, possibly to generate another display. During the display the computer is either executing a polling loop of interactive devices or is idle awaiting an interrupt from an interactive device. During the neuroscience displays, no time consuming computer calculations are necessary. Therefore the computer could be used to refresh the display. 3. A PROPOSED SYSTEM FOR COMPUTER GRAPHICS DISPLAY IN THE NEUROSCIENCES A simple, low cost display processor, capable of generating the displays described in the previous section has been built and is now being debugged. This neuroscience display processor (NDP) re­ quired about 6 man-months to design and build and contains approximately $2000 worth of parts. A brief description of the NDP system is now given. 3.1 Assumptions It is assumed that the graphics display system is a peripheral device of a general purpose computer processor. The general purpose processor will handle all mass storage functions, input-output functions, and will refresh the graphic display. The general purpose CPU will also monitor the usual interactive devices such as a joystick and pot box, data tablet, and keyboard. Light pens are not considered as our use has never shown a need for one which could not be handled by a data tablet. The interactive devices are attached to the general purpose processor rather than to the graphics system for two reasons. First, interfaces of these devices to common processors are com-mercially available. Second, these devices oper-ate at slow human rates and therefore can be pro- grammed in a high level language supported by the general purpose processor. It is assumed that the CRT-plotter system is used in.an interactive mode. That is the user manipu- lates the CRT display until he is satisfied with it. He then indicates to the computer system through some device that he would like a hard copy. A copy of the CRT display is then plotted. 3.2 The Proposed System within its Environment A block diagram of the NDP in its computing en-vironment is shown in fig. 5. Pig. 5 -A block diagram of the NDP in its environment. The NDP is connected to the PDP-11/45 by a DEC DRllC general purpose parallel digital inter-face. The PUP-11 sends a 16 bit command through the command cable. Only three commands exist: load register, move, draw. A load register com-mand instructs the NDP to capture 12 bits of data from the command into one of its internal registers (eg. an element of the rotation matrix). A move or draw instruction causes the NDP to fetch a co-ordinate triple of drawing data, multiply it times the rotation and translation matrix, check the result for rejection, and pass the result to the NDP line generator. If the instruction is a move, the line generator updates the CRT beam position without turning on the CRT beam. If the instruc- tion is a draw, the line generator updates the CRT beam position with the CRT beam on. When the com-mand is complete, the NDP so indicates to the PDP-11 through the "done" line. PDP-11 software may sense this condition and issue a new NDP command. Thus the PDP-11 is actively involved in refreshing the picture. The NDP shares PDP-11 core memory. The PDP-11 can write into or read from the memory; the NDP can only read from the memory. 64K, 16 bit words of Cambridge dual port memory is presently in use. The memory need not necessarily be dual port. If only single port memory were available, both the NDP and the PDP-11 could share the port through the PDP-11 unibus. Both processors would be some- what slower however, and the number of lines which could be displayed without flicker on the CRT would be reduced. The NDP supplies a 16 bit word address to memory. Thus, 64K words of drawing data can be accessed by the NDP. No attempt is made to access only bytes of data. A 12 bit data word is returned from memory to the NDP. There- fore the NDP's initial resolution before any data mapping is one part in 4096. Output from the NDP can be sent to a Hewlett-Packard 17" CRT or to a Hewlett-Packard 7210 digital plotter. The NDP must supply analog de-flection voltages to the CRT. The plotter and its line generator interface expect digital line end-point coordinates. The plotter contains its own line generator to move its pen in straight lines between the line endpoints. 3.3 Interesting Characteristics of the NDP In order to keep the NDP as simple as possible, all drawing is performed in three dimensions, i.e. three words of data are fetched from core memory for each coordinate. Then, after rotation and translation, the Z value is discarded. Thus an orthographic projection of a 3D image is always being computed. An alternative, at the cost of more complexity in the NDP algorithm, would be to have a 2D or 3D mode of NDP operation. The constant 3D drawing was selected for two reasons. First, the 50% increase in the display file size of a 2D drawing should not be excessive as computer memory costs continue downward. Second-, the increased complexity of the programming of a 2D display required by the insertion of an extra word in each display coordinate should be tolerable as it only has to be done once. The display of usual 2D images, graphs and waveforms, should be handled by a subroutine call from a user's high level language application program. The application programmer need not be concerned that the NDP always operates in 3D. Further simplicity in the NDP results from definingit as a first quadrant display. The range of coordinates which can be displayed is 0,O through 2047,2047. It is assumed that this is the range of the drawing data coordinates which are fetched by the NDP from core memory. The elements of the rotation and translation matrix may be negative,however. The first quadrant assumption allows simplification of the multiplier, the line re-jection logic, the line generator digital logic, the D/A converters for the CRT, and the power supply. In addition, since the H-P plotter expects first quadrant coordinates, no quadrant mapping need be done before the data are sent to the plotter. The loss of resolution to one part in 2048 in the NDP shouldnotbe noticeable in the display for two reasons. First, matrix multipli­cation error is not cumulative. Each matrix ele­ment is computed, independent of all previous elements, to 16 bits of accuracyby the PDP-11. Second, the D/A converters and the remaininganalog circuitry in the CRT and the plotter do not yield accuracy greater than one part in 1000. The Evans and Sutherland concept of multiple or repeat or table drawing was seriously considered. The table draw instruction,a hardware instruction allowing a series of moves or draws using data fetched from a table in memory, is most powerful and some implementationof it should be included in the NDP. The table draw instruction is de­ scribed in detail in [5]. One possibility is to define efficient assembler languagemacros to re­ duce the table draw to a series of move and draw commands issued by the PDP-11 to the NDP. Another possibility is to implement the instruction in NDP hardware. This would require the additionof a counter register, more complicated instruction de­coding, and further algorithm states. An estimated time savings of 17% in the execution of a long table draw could be had with the hardware imple­mentation. The macro implementationwas selected. Because the NDP ignores the Z after rotation of a coordinate triple, no need exists to perform that part of the matrix multiplicationwhich computes the rotated Z. The rotation and translation com­ where [X Y Z] is the coordinate triple from memory, M is the rotation matrix, [TX Ty] are the trans­ lation terms, and [XRT YRT] is the rotated, trans­ lated, and orthographically projected coordinate. Actually the translation terms are stored in the bottom row of the matrix. Thus a 4x2 rotation and translation matrix is required. It is assumed that the six rotation elements of the matrix are stored in 12 bit fractional form, that is, have a value between -1 and 1. It is also assumed that the coordinate triple is composed of positive integers of the range 0 through 2047. The multiplier requires that one of its inputs is an integer and the other is a fraction. The pro­duct is an integer. The PDP-11 can easily cal­culate the fractional form rotationmatrix ele­ments and pass them to the NDP. A discussion of fractional notation in matrix algebra using a PDP­ 11 programmed in Fortran to generate matrix ele­ments is available in [1]. One NDP assumption is that any display which might be partially off screen due to rotationor trans­lation is composed entirely of short lines. Thus, if either endpoint of a line is off screen and the entire line is not drawn, the picture quality is not degraded appreciably. The logic to check for these conditions is quite simple, though it is necessary to insure that the NDP algorithm accom­ modates the line rejection structure so that no spurious lines are generated for all combinations of moves, draws, line endpoints on screen, and line endpoints off screen. Because the NDP is a first quadrant processor which uses two's com­ plement arithmetic, if a line endpoint is on the screen, the most significantbit from the final translation calculations in X and Y must be zero. If the most significant bit is one, either an overflow or a negative result has occurred. An overflow indicates that an endpoint is off screen to the right or to the top. A negative result indicates that an endpoint is off screen to the left or to the bottom. Since the entire line is to be rejected, it is not necessary to distinguish in which direction the endpoint is off screen. A line is rejected if either the present coordinate or the previous coordinate is off screen. If a line is rejected, the savepoint, storing the CRT beam position, is still updated from the present coordinate in order that, in the case of a line being rejected because only the previous point was off screen, the next line will be drawn from the proper starting point. article_rec.title: A parametric algorithm for drawing pictures of solid objects bounded by quadric surfaces

abstract.par: An algorithm for drawing pictures of three-dimensional objects, with surfaces made up of patches of quadric surfaces, is described.The emphasis of this algorithm is calculating the intersections of quadric surfaces. A parameterization scheme is used. Each quadric surface intersection curve (QSIC) is represented as a set of coefficients and parameter limits. Each value of the parameter represents at most two points, and these may easily be distinguished. This scheme can find the co-ordinates of points of even quartic (fourth-order) intersection curves, using equations of no more than second order.Methods of parameterization for each type of QSIC are discussed, as well as surface bounding and hidden surface removal.

article_rec.title: Texture and reflection in computer generated images

abstract.par: In 1974 Ed Catmull developed a new algorithm for rendering images of bivariate surface patches. This paper describes extensions of this algorithm in the areas of texture simulation and lighting models.The parametrization of a patch defines a coordinate system which is used as a key for mapping patterns onto the surface. The parametric values within each picture element are input to a pattern definition function. A weighted average of the values of this function over the picture element scales the intensity of that picture element. By suitably defining the pattern function, various surfaces textures can be simulated. The shape and size of this weighting function is chosen using digital signal processing theory.The other problem addressed here concerns lighting models. The patch rendering algorithm allows accurate computation of the surface.

article_rec.title: Hierarchical geometric models for visible-surface algorithms

abstract.par: The research described in this paper addresses the problems associated with the design of systems for efficiently producing computer-generated pictures and picture sequences of very complex, three-dimensional environments. The thesis of the research is that the geometric structure inherent in the definition of the shapes of three-dimensional objects and environments must be used not just to define their relative motion and placement but also to assist in solving many other problems of systems for producing pictures by computer.The implications are that by using an extension of traditional structure information, or a geometric hierarchy, five significant improvements to current techniques are possible. First, the range of complexity of an environment is greatly increased while the visible complexity of any given scene is kept within a fixed upper limit. Second, a meaningful way is provided to vary the amount of detail presented in a scene both according to the screen area occupied by the objects in the scene and according to camera and object motions. Third, by using the geometric hierarchy, "clipping" becomes a very fast logarithmic search for the resolvable parts of the environment within the field-of-view. Fourth, by using this positional hierarchy in conjunction with a storage hierarchy of the sort used in virtual memory computing systems, frame-to-frame coherence and clipping define a graphical "working set", or fraction of the total structure that should be present in primary store for immediate access by the visible-surface algorithms. Finally, the proposed structural framework suggests a new recursive descent visible-surface algorithm in which the computation time grows almost linearly with a scene's visible complexity rather than as a worse than linear function of its object-space complexity.

article_rec.title: ARTES
article_rec.subtitle: an interactive highway design program

abstract.par: The geometrical definition of a highway alignment is the result of a compromise between two conflicting objectives: keeping within budget limits and providing the user with optimum safety, operating and aesthetic conditions. The interactive graphic console when used as a large computer system peripheral unit is a particularly well-adapted instrument, when properly programmed, to assist the designer in resolving this conflict. It presents him with the appropriate graphical displays representing his design choices and offers him the possibility of modifying these choices as the computer processing progresses. ARTES is such an interactive program. It displays the geometrical elements composing a highway alignment (horizontal alignment, vertical alignment, natural ground and highway cross sections), and displays composed elements such as perspective views and visibility diagrams. It prints out earthworks quantities, plots all graphical elements and enables the program user to modify the geometrical elements composing the alignment thus enabling him to study multiple alternatives affecting construction costs and user conditions.

The first version of ARTES became operational in 1972 and has now been used in the design of thousands of kilometers of highways and expressways throughout the world. ARTES displays directly on the screen of the interactive unit the graphic components of the: -horizontal alignment, see fig. 1, - vertical alignment and natural ground align­ment, see fig. 2, - roadway cross-section, see fig. 3, -perspective views in any direction and from any position above or on the roadway, see figs. 4 and 5, and calculates the corresponding earthworks quan­tities. Using the light pen and keyboards, modifi­cations can be made directly on the screen, for example, to the horizontal or vertical alignments. The effects of these modifications are available for display immediately including perspectives and corrections in earthworks quantities. Fig. 1 ---This is a display of a typical horizontal alignment. An area was selected directly on the screen, where this horizontal alignment could be modified. Passage corridors were also identified on the display unit. The program then attempts to identify the most smoothed alternative possible, while respecting the imposed geometric con­ straints and the passage corridors. Fig. 2 -This is a typical vertical alignment. The functional keys control the displacement, modifi­cations in scale and supervision of geometric con­straints of slope and curve. The basic points of the vertical alignment can be seen. These points can be detected by the light pen and displaced by feeding into the typewriter the differences of curvi­linear abscissa and of the DX and DY coordinates. Fig. 3 -This is a typical cross-section. The dif­ ferent factors of the cross-sections can be modi­ fied, either directly (the scale, for example) or on a similar picture, such as creating complicated embankments with walls. By displacing the center line of the alignment, difficult construction prob-. lems (cliffs, railway tracks, etc. ) can be exam­ined on the screen. 269 Fig. 4 -A perspective is shown on the screen. An option can be made (such as continuing to the next perspective) by using the light pen. On the right can be seen the typewriter keyboard and on the left the functional key panel. computation data, visibility distances and align­ment loss. Calculation options can also be di­rectly modified by the light pen and by feeding new values into the typewriter. A particular option enables the perspective to be drawn directly. An explanation is called for here: the initial cen­ter lines and vertical alignments may possibly have been calculated by the traditional geometric components method and it is exceedingly difficult to make modifications which directly use such geometric components. ARTES, therefore, per­mits the designer to directly modify certain align­ment points, also called base points, which are all connected by polynomial curves, in order to provide the necessary continuity and verify the geometrical constraints [6]. This procedure is applicable to vertical alignments without restric­tion and the line thus obtained can be considered as final. The same does not hold true for hori­zontal alignments. Even though the resulting curve verifies the necessary geometrical condi­tions, it cannot always be directly used for the final location if the roadway is for high design speeds. However, in this case, since the geo­metrical conditions are met, calculating a conven­tional alignment with only a slight deviation (a few decimeters) is straightforward. The earthworks quantities calculated and the visibility conditions developed may be considered as valid, however, in view of the high degree of accuracy in the data and calculated results encountered at this point. 3. PROGRAM DATA Input data concerning the center line and vertical alignment may be the result of direct definition by basic points, or on the other hand, by the conven­tional calculation method. In this latter case, it is possible to arrive at an actual integration of the center line and vertical alignment as previously computed. Natural ground data can also be obtained in vari­ous ways from either a complete cross-section or from a simplified cross-section (one point and two transversal slopes, or in some cases, by a single point on the center line). Basic cross-section data are supplied as standard cross-sections in the library along with standard transitional zone options. This flexibility allowed in the manner the input data can be prepared and the resulting compati­bility this provides with other design programs is important. The ARTES program is, for example, entirely compatible with the French SETRA Sys­tem and indications are that it could and should be made compatible with other systems of this type such as the Federal Highway Administration s Road Design System. The various features of the ARTES program and its great flexibility make it a convenient and useful instrument in a wide var­iety of fields. Examples are given below. 4. CHECKING THE VISIBILITY OF A PRELIMINARY DESIGN A preliminary design based only on the following graphic elements: -horizontal alignment, - vertical alignment and natural ground alignment, and -standard cross section can be visualized completely within a very short time. Within only ten days, the Northern France Agency of SETRA was able to thoroughly check the visibility conditions of the entire 110 km of a given section of the A 26 expressway, to determine the main disadvantages of the alignment as well as indi­cate desirable improvements and their correspond­ing costs, all for a total machine cost of $2,000. 5. DIRECT STUDY OF CERTAIN ALIGNMENTS When only brief studies of short alignments are needed, such as computing earthworks quantities depending on the type of crossing structures used, the horizontal and vertical alignments can then be directlyinput and shown on the screen, along with the natural ground definition. Numerous different alternatives can then be analyzed in sequence within a relatively short time. For example, figs. 6 through 8 demonstrate such a sequence. Fig. 6 displays a poor visibility condition bordering on sight discontinuity. Fig. 7 shows a first attempt to correct the condition and some improvement. Fig. 8 shows a fully corrected alignment with near perfect visibility. Fig. 7 -A first attempt to correct the condition showing some improvement. Fig. 6 -A poor visibility condition bordering on sight discontinuity. Fig. 8 -A fully corrected alignment with near 271 perfect visibility. 6. CONNECTION WITH AN OPTIMIZATION STUDY As implied above, this was the main objective in developing ARTES. The vertical alignment gene- rated by the optimization program can now be checked from a visibility standpoint and can be corrected directly on the screen. This almost inevitably results in a compromise choice being made by the designer between the extent that driver visibility can be improved versus the quantities of earthworks affected. The object, of course, is to provide the maximum of driver safety for a minimum of Cost. This was preciselywhat was done in the study of the RN 4 highwaydetour in easternFrance referred to as the deviation de Stainville. The cost of the initial un-optimized solution amounted to $3. 1 million. By using the APPOLON computer optimization pro-gram, the cost was reduced to $2.6million, but a considerable visual loss of alignment occurred and slight other imperfections were noticed. These both were detected and corrected in a highly satisfactory manner directlyon the graphic console using ARTES. In SO doing the cost increased to $2.8 million. This, of course, reduced the optimized savings by about $200,000 to improve the visibility situation to a satisfactory level and left a $300,000 saving over the originalunoptimized alignment. A series of console displays generated by ARTES for the design team during this project is shown in figs. 9 through 17. Fig. 10 -The display produced as a result of a request for a cross-sectional view of the vertical alignment. Fig. 9 -The initial display setting parameters for the redesign of route RN 4 at Stainville in eastern France. Fig. 1 f -A request for cross section calculations. Fig. 14 - the same view (as fig. 13) except at 1700 meters. Fig. 15 - The same view (as figs. 13 and 14) local- izing the problem at 1800 meters and clearly indi- cating a very poor and dangerous visibility condition. The computer and other costs involved amounted to $1,200 or about 1/250 of the anticipated invest­ments benefit. In making an overall estimate of the advantages presented by ARTES, considera­tion must also be given to the costs and time that would have been involved in correcting the visi­bility deficiencies in the normal manner. 7. CONCLUSION The above brief description of ARTES has focused attention to the possibilities offered by being able to visualize and modify the results of optimization. ARTES has been operational, in a production sense, since 1972 and has since been further re­fined. The advantages have considerably out­weighed the expenses involved, but it must be kept in mind that ARTES is a tool and a tool only, and must remain under the control of the designer re­sponsible for analysis, options and trade-offs making up the final configuration of the roadway. As a matter of fact, having ARTES available to him increases his responsibility because he is relieved from a number of tedious tasks and to a certain extent from time pressures. Thus, he can and therefore must examine more attentively all the factors involved and carefully review the con­sequences of his choices before making his final decisions. REFERENCES [1] P. article_rec.title: Computer aided integrated circuit design
article_rec.subtitle: a distributed integrated approach

abstract.par: The design of silicon integrated circuits requires a broad spectrum of computer aids for simulation, physical design, and testing. A CAD approach is described which is both integrated and distributed in nature. The various functions required by circuit designers for simulation, layout, and testing are integrated into a single system, based on a minicomputer (HP21MX) with a storage scope (Tektronix 4014) display. These systems are distributed to provide the design aids in close proximity to users. Approximately forty systems are now employed for the various steps in the design process.

au.affiliation: Bell Telephone Laboratories, Incorporated, Allentown, Pa.

fulltext.ft_body: Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania COMPUTER AIDED INTEGRATED CIRCUIT DESIGN - A DISTRIBUTED INTEGRATED APPROACH E. B. Kozemchak Bell Telephone Laboratories, Incorporated Allentown, Pa. 18103 The design of silicon integrated circuits requires a broad spectrum of computer aids for simulation, physical design, and testing. A CAD approach is described which is both integrated and distributed in nature. The various functions required by circuit designers for simulation, layout, and testing are integrated into a single system, based on a minicomputer (HP21MX) with a storage scope (Tektronix4014) display. These systems are distributed to provide the design aids in close proximity to users. Approximatelyforty systems are now employed for the various steps in the design process. 1. INTRODUCTION The design process for integrated circuits (ICs) is complex. It requires many talents-includingunderstanding of semi­ conductor devices, circuit design, logic design, circuit simulation, layout of complex mask sets, generation of test programs, testing, test data reduction, specification of the design for manu­ facture, and troubleshootingdesign and manufacturingproblems. The most impor­ tant asset in successfully accomplishing this design function is a group of indi­ viduals with the design experience and engineering judgment to make good deci­ sions at each step in this process. While this human resource is a necessary condition, the complexity of integrated circuit design has rendered the human resource alone insufficient. The integrated circuit designer must rely heavily on computer aids to deal with the sheer magnitude of the problem at each step. While reliance on computer aids is essential, we are still far from the point where the computer, devoid of real human engineering judgment, can design an inte­grated circuit. We are at the point where the proper use of computer aids in basically an interactivemode at each step in the process can lead to significant reductions in design time, cost, and probability of error. A simplified overview of the steps in­volved in the design of an IC is shown in fig. 1. Each box represents a major function to be performed, a major soft­ware system to aid in that step, and an interface between the designer and the computer. The chart is simplified not so much because it leaves out steps, but because it fails to show the heavy inter­action that goes on between the various steps. For example, the way in which a circuit is to be tested may affect how it is physically designed, or the physical design of the circuit may introduce changes in the DC or transient behavior. This paper will attempt to take the design environment just described and present an approach to computer-aideddesign which has worked well within that environment. The design system will be described by attempting to answer the following questions: 1. What are the key elements of a costeffective CAD system? 2. What are the key elements of this system from the user s vantage point? 3. What are the key elements of the system from the software developer s point of view? 4. How can the user s and developer s needs best be met in an environment of continually evolving and changingneeds? 2. COST EFFECTIVE SYSTEM The key to cost effectiveness is matchingthe computer system used to the need athand, A computer that is too powerful or not powerful enough for the task involved will lead to ineffective utilization of both people and machines. In consideringthe needs of an IC design system, thefollowing attributes were considered mostimportant: 1. IC design involves the processing of many designs which can generally betreated independently of each other. 2. IC design is typically organizedaround several product lines, e.g. memory,bipolar logic, MOS logic, etc.The need for common project libraries is, therefore, important, but there isno need for sharing of these librariesbetween project groups by establishing one central data base. 3. Various project groups should remain compatible with others where this compatibility does not needlessly compromise their effectiveness.Design aids in support of specificproduct lines should be undertaken, bysoftware development teams working closely with those product lines when a sufficient design volume is antici­pated to offset software development costs. 4. The core of general purpose design aids should be technology independent and should be adaptable to increasingcomplexity. Integrated circuits haveprogressed from simple gates to 16K memories on a single silicon chip inless than a decade. These considerations led to the choice of a minicomputer-based interactive design system. The independence between designsled to the conclusion that no one central data base for a large number of designs had to be maintained. This recognition made possible the establishment of many indepen­dently operated design systems, with no ties between them other than a magnetic tape interface. The need for common libraries within product lines has been handled by project libraries, stored onmagnetic tape. A specific design is then initiated by extracting the necessaryinformation from the library tape onto a job tape and proceeding. The key to main­taining compatibility between project groups has been standardization on a single minicomputer hardware configuration and standardization at key interfaces, such as a standard graphic description languageand a standard logical connectivitylanguage. The minicomputer chosen was an HP21MX with 16K of memory, a SM-byte disk, and a 9­track magnetic tape drive. This system,together with an optional digitizerplotter! is shown in fig. 2. User inter­action is via a Tektronix 4014 storage scope display, alphanumeric and command Distributed Approach keyboards, and thumbwheel-controlled crosshairs. The basic system can be purchased for approximately $50K and yields an on-line usage charge of approxi­mately $6 per hour over standard working hours. The evolution of minicomputer computing power and cost has been well matched to the evolving needs of IC design. A typical graphical data base for an LSI chip is 600K bytes-still well within the minicomputer mass storage range. 3. USER NEEDS Integrated Approach The steps in fig. 1 give some indication of the number of different functions for which a CAD system is used. At the present time, all functions shown in fig. 1 that are amenable to computer aids have been used effectively on the mini­computer. It is, therefore, possible to provide these functions in one integrated design system, resident on the mini­ computer. This approach eliminates the need for multiple computer systems to perform different parts of the job. All frequently-used designtools are made available on the HP21MX standard hardware configuration. These tools include inter­active graphics, automatic layout aids, design rule checking, tape output for plotters and mask making equipment, circuit analysis, logic simulation, test program preparation aids, and data analysis programs. The uniqueness of this approach is due largely to the breadth of functions that have been integrated into one minicomputer system. Users need interact with only this system. A typical silicon integrated circuit designed with this system is shown in fig. 3. To make effective use of this integrated system, it must be distributed among users. Forty systems are presently in use in Bell Laboratories and Western Electric at four locations. At each location, these systems are dispersed geographicallyin order to provide the distributed processing power in close proximity to those using it. If one system is down, others can pick up the load. Priorities can be established by those close to the work needs. 4. SOFTWARE DEVELOPMENT NEEDS From the diversity of aids available on the minicomputer design system, it is clear that software development must proceed with well established ground rules. While interactive graphics is usually given a large amount of attention in computer-aideddesign literature, it accounts for less than 50% of the total design aids software. Development of this software centers around several major sub­systems. Each subsystem has a separate data base. Portions of the data base are shared between subsystems. Interfacing between subsystems when required is done in standardized interface languages. The major subsystems and their related data bases are: (1) Layout Graphic file (2) Logic simula. Gate connectivity (3) Circuit anal. Transistor connectivity (4) Test program Tester instructions preparation (5) Test data anal.Tester output (6) Text editing Text file While some overlap exists between data bases, they can be treated independently for the most part. Thus, the software development effort for each subsystem can proceed in a reasonably independent way from the other subsystems. The interaction between graphics-related software and test data reduction is virtually nonexistent. On the other hand, where functions proceed from a common circuit schematic or circuit description language, these functions share circuit connectivity descriptions. Thus, for example, the same data base is used to execute a logic simulator and to prompt the graphics system user with connectivity information. The real key in maintaining a workable integrated system is to have well-defined interfaces between various subsystems and between the subsystems and the user. Some examples of these include the standardized graphic description language, the logical connectivity description, an expanded vector file for interfacing the graphics system to various plotters and other post layout functions, a standard test language format, or a standard tester output description. 277 Having separated the job into the develop­ment of several independent subsystems, software for each subsystem can proceed to best meet the particular need. Options available to the software developer include use of standard vendor-supplied operating systems or special-purpose, low­overhead operating systems tailored to the specific job. Source code may be written in assembly language or higher-level languages such as FORTRAN. Both approaches have been taken in the IC design system in terms of operating systems and programming languages. Thus, a system user may perform a layout using software with a tailored operating system and assembly language code. Having completed a layout session, he dumps his output onto magnetic tape. At this point, a user of the logic simulator or text editor may load a magnetic tape and begin his work. These systems are available under the same tailored operating system. Having completed a logic simulation and dumped the results onto magnetic tape, that user might leave and a third user of the data analysis or circuit analysis programs may access the system. Since these programs are written in FORTRAN and operate under a standard disk operating system, a 30-second change of disk platters is required to access the new software. For most applications, the minicomputer has proved to be well matched to the needs of IC design. In terms of processor speed, the only significant limitationhas been in tasks requiring large amounts of floating point arithmetic computation, such as circuit analysis. Here the com­parative slowness of minicomputer floating point hardware has limited circuit size for interactively executed jobs. In terms of mass storage, data analysis programs have been the only area to really push the 5 megabyte capacity. Here it is possible for test data from a single IC wafer to fill up the entire disk. With these few exceptions, the minicomputer has provided the necessary computational power. There are roughly 40 man-years invested in the software system. Of this, approximate­ly 20 man-years involve layout (graphics) related software, 5 involve simulation aids, and 15 involve testing aids. This software has been developed by approximate­ly 10 people over a four-year period. 5. INTERFACE BETWEEN SOFTWARE DEVELOPMENT AND USER COMMUNITIES No system of this magnitude could be effectively built without an extremely close working relationship between the developers and users of the software. Major new programs are instituted only after a careful evaluation of where design time, manpower, and cost are spent, and an estimate of what the impact of computer aids in that function might be. At this point, input from users is solicited for two reasons. First, it provides a good measure of what the real needs are-some­thing that software development people cannot otherwise determine. Secondly, it gives the users a sense of contributing to the design aids system. This joint commitment is extremely beneficial in the early stages of system use. Most of the software involved is technology independent. Various product lines, however, impose unique needs on the system, and these needs invariably change with time. To keep pace with evolving needs and to provide a long term user-developer dialogue, user groups have been estab­lished. These groups meet at specified intervals to review new requirements and shape software development by rank order­ing the importance of suggested new features. 6. SUMMARY An interactive, minicomputer-basedsystem with-wide ranging capabilities for integrated circuit design has been described. The uniqueness of the system is the breadth of functions it makes available in an integrated way. While many minicomputer-basedsystems provide sohpisticated interactive graphics, few, if any, provide the broad scope of aids necessary for integrated circuit design. 278

article_rec.title: Making graphics work

abstract.par: This paper describes some of the operational considerations of a large data processing installation involved in support of an interactive computer system in heavy production use. Application and operating system software has varied over the continued growth and expansion of this system. Mechanisms for user input and feedback, vital aspects to its successful operation, are discussed. The application specifically cited is MCDONNELL DOUGLAS' CAD/CAM (Computer-Aided-Design/Computer-Aided-Manufacturing) System and highlighted are daily operations of its computer graphics terminals. This system is configured to provide 95% availability with backup switchability features. Typical response, varying with the nature of the user application, ranges from 0.1 to 60 seconds.
