To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. 279 Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania FIGURE 1 MCAUTO POLYPLEX CONFIGURATION St. Louis, May 1976 COMPUTER GRAPHICS HISTORY: Graphics capability and utilization at MDC have been evolu­tionary, commencing with the first in-house CG configuration implementation using an IBM 2250 CRT and 360/40 computer in May 1966. Figure (2) briefly summarizes system software evolution milestone changes along with console growth. Graphics accomplishments, a subset of total CAD/CAM System develop­ments as denoted in Figure (3), goes back much beyond the in­stallation of our first in-house console in 1966. It is also apparent from analysis of these time graphs that operating system and hardware (Figure 2) and application software (Figure 3) devel­opment and capability has progressed through the years. The May 1976 graphics configuration, illustrated in Figure (4), highlights specific console designations, different remoting tech­niques employed, use of three distinct host computers for com­plete CG operations and central graphics data base activities. As previously mentioned, the remainder of this paper will not dwell on specific applications of computer graphics, but will highlight the day-to-day activities involved in the successful operation of "making graphics work". The reader, if interested in further application discussion of MDC's graphics programs, is referred to [ 1, 2, 3] publications. Also, details of typical mathematics employed by these applications are well covered in the [4, 5] literature. OPERATIONAL GROWTH/STABILITY: As previously indicated, MCAUTO configurations are in heavy production usage by a variety of applications. Managing this large and complex installation demands technical know how and extensive managerial talent on the part of various levels of data processing executives. There are many ways to measure the re­sults obtained from implementing a set of policies and techniques for improving installation management methods. One particular­ly significant test of success is whether operational stability can be maintained during periods of rapid growth in hardware and software systems. In 1971, when it was perceived that rapidly increasing complexity called for new approaches to installation management at MCAUTO, total CPU "power" in the St. Louis installation in terms of equivalent System/360 Model 195s was approximately 1.75. The ASP systems were processing an average of 39,000 jobs per month, calling for nearly 52,000 tape mounts and 16,000 disk mounts. The IMS and graphics systems were in an early phase of implementation and had only limited usage. During this period unscheduled system restarts (IPLs) averaged 22 per system per month. By mid 1975 CPU "power" had been increased 1-17% and the number of ASP jobs was 78,000, tapes mounts 122,000, and disk mounts over 30,000 per month. In addition, two IMS systems were processing almost 600,000 transactions each day and the graphics system was supporting fifteen 2250 display units, two shifts per day, six days per week. By this time the unscheduled IPLs had been reduced to an average of 6.7 per system per month. During this period there had been overall software and hardware technology improvements, but these improvements were not as significant as the greatly increased exposures resulting from fast growth, greater complexity of interconnected systems, massive installation rearrangements, and hugh on-line systems. Those factors are what make the re­sults cited above important, because they mean a foundation has been established for continued growth. COMMUNICATIONS, THE KEY: The factor that is most influential in effecting MCAUTO's successful operation of the previously described configura­tions, is the communication flow, both upward, downward, and through DP and user organizations. MCAUTO manage­ment has set an availability target of 96-98% -a formidable challenge in view of the installation's complexity. A series of scheduled, structured planning and review meetings has been a key factor in meeting this challenge, and the desired target is seldom missed. Both operations and programming management people, from supervisors to the vice president of computer serv­ices, are involved in daily, weekly, biweekly, and triweekly re­view and planning meetings as illustrated in Figure (5). Although all MCAUTO DP matters are covered in these meetings, graphics is in continual address and given high priority treatment due to its magnitude and MDC importance. 280 The result is that management is well informed and respondsquickly to problems, and also that most problems are avoided and those that do occur are resolved with minimal impact on productivity. Non-regularly scheduied meetings, such as the RESPONSE/LOCKOUT TASK FORCE, are formed on an ad hoc basis and are extremely important in consolidating an over­view of all factors and their interrelationships to graphic response. Beginning in 1971 in response to outstanding problems, the re­view and planning meetings have since undergone many changes.At first they were attended by members of top management responding to crises; today they bring together a cross section of functional departments and management levels. FIGURE 2 MDC-STL: CONSOLE GROWTH AND SYSTEM SOFTWARE EVOLUTION FIGURE 3 MDC-STL: CAD/CAM SYSTEM DEVELOPMENT HISTORY 281 FIGURE 4 MDC-STL: MAY 1976 GRAPHICS CONFIGURATION Daily Meetings -Possibly the most crucial meeting, from the operations viewpoint, is the planning meeting held each morn­ing, chaired by the technical coordinator from operations and attended by operations supervisors and first-level managers from various operating and programming areas. They evaluate the previous day's operations, diagnose any equipment or software problems that have occurred, suggest solutions, and plan the schedule for all activities for the new day or the weekend. One form of input to this session from the graphics community is the user's log. Figure (6) is a general user log sample and Figure (7) is one that is more project-oriented. By correlating precise time period of log entries, the planning group can correspond­ingly determine trouble sources. Comment notes on these fig­ures are typical of input feedback from the graphics user. In order to direct the decision making process, firm prioritized guidelines have been established for this group to function as follows: (1) fix system bugs, (2) implement planned hardware with its associated task, (3) improve user response, (4) improve total system performance, and (5) accommodate general en­hancements. At 1:30 PM the vice president of computer serv­ ices meets with the directors of operations and systems pro­gramming to review the new operating plan as well as the 282 status of unresolved problems. Immediately after this meeting, the new operating plan for the next immediate day and for weekend period is distributed and put into effect. Weekly Meetings -Hardly a week goes by in which no equip­ment change occurs; e.g., you don't bring graphics work to a fixed console location. The operating philosophy that best "makes graphics pay" is to place the terminal wherever the project is located. This may also mean following the peak phases of activity as they move from advanced design, detail design, and manufacturing. MCAUTO's operations, programming, and facilities personnel meet weekly with hardware/software vendors to plan activities for the coming weekend, and perhaps for the following one. This may not only be relative to new graphic consoles, but perhaps the addition of on-line disk packs in support of increased or new project users. To maintain normal production, changes, whether to add or replace equipment, move devices, or install an engineering change, are made during regularly scheduled maintenance that takes place on Sunday. Changes recommended for inclusion in the weekend schedule are reviewed by operations managers, who also meet weekly. Reliability, as indicated by summaries of systems performance, engineering changes, and equipment installations are all care­fully reviewed. Changes approved for inclusion in the weekend plan are then submitted during the Friday morning planning meeting. Biweekly Meetings -Strategic and tactical planning for long­range equipment changes is done in biweekly meetings of operations, facilities, technical services, and hardware vendor marketing people. These meetings involve reviews of the current backlog (on-order equipment), evaluation of business trends and new product announcements, and determination of short term needs to facilitate migration to new components. Planning for a new application or a major change, such as a new version of GSP (Graphics Support Package) or the installation of a new CPU, is handled by ad hoc committees. Members of these committees are selected in a way that provides broad representation of all affected areas. Depending on the scope of the assignment, meetings are scheduled as needed. Triweekly Meetings -This meeting organized and chaired by Systems Programming (CAD/CAM), is attended by pertinent MCAUTO departments and CG user representatives from the McDonnell Aircraft and Astronautics Companies. Problems, if there are any, and plans for new requirements are dealt with; also suggestions may be given to programming or operations for their consideration and response. Figure (8) illustrates the plan­ning document used to monitor all pertinent new CAD/CAM FIGURE 5 activities and discussed at each session MCAUTO: PLANNING/COMMUNICATION, THE KEY FIGURE 6 COMPUTER GRAPHIC CONSOLE USER LOG General 283 FIGURE 7 COMPUTER GRAPHIC CONSOLE USER LOG CADD Project Oriented Response Lockout Task Force -This ad hoc group, also chaired by Systems Programming (CAD/CAM), is activated, as required, in the continuing interest of achieving and maintaining satis­factory response and reliable graphics performance. A spirit of mutual cooperation exists, which leads to a willingness to assume responsibility, an ability to compromise, and an understanding of the diverse but highly interdependent functions represented. article_rec.title: Three-dimensional man-machine interaction

abstract.par: The film accompanied by this paper illustrates an experimental system for real-time Computer-Aided Geometric Design of three-dimensional parametric surfaces. A detailed description of the system is given in another paper by the author(1). Its principle features are that it operates in real-time, all geometric interaction with the surfaces is accomplished with a 3-D Wand, the surfaces are viewed in 3-D using a head-mounted display, and the surfaces are mathematically represented using parametric spline surface patches.The two principle computing components of the system are a PDP-10 computer and an LDS-1 display computer. The PDP-10 acts as a host to the LDS-1. Its main tasks each 1/30 second are to compute the 3-D Wand and head-mounted display positions and to incrementally update the geometries of the surface patches being designed by the user. During the same time period, the LDS-1 loads its digital matrix multiplier with the room-to-head transformation matrix provided to it by the PDP-10, displays on the head-mounted display's CRT's a line drawn rendering of all of the parametric surface patches that are within the 40 degree field-of-view of the display and displays a small cube to represent the current position of the Wand.The user of the system initiates a design sequence by selecting a patch description file from the PDP-10's file system. He then puts on the head-mounted display and uses the 3-D Wand with its control buttons to grasp the patches, which appear to float before him in the room, and make appropriate changes to their geometry. After a design sequence he may save the new surfaces on the PDP-10 file system and select certain views of the surfaces to be rendered as a continuous-tone shaded picture with hidden-surfaces removed.The first part of the film described here shows the system in real-time operation. During this part, several free-form surfaces are manipulated as the camera records the action on a line-drawing monitor. The second part of the film illustrates a continuous-tone, shaded rendering of a design sequence. The continuous-tone rendering was produced "off-line" using pertinent viewpoint information that was saved during the design sequence. The final few minutes of the film depict the construction of a Klein-Bottle.

abstract.par: A computer program, the Line Drawing Editor (LDE), that allows convenient modification of computer representations of simple line drawings has been designed and implemented. The distinguishing feature of the LDE from the multitude of interactive graphics programs that accomplish the same function is the use of a computer controlled TV camera for input and program control rather than conventional interactive input devices such as light pens or data tablets. A graphical editing language allows the LDE user to indicate, by marking the drawing in appropriate fashion, the changes that are to be made. The drawing, which was generated on a hardcopy output device, with the added edit information is placed in front of the camera. In successive phases the LDE computes a two dimensional homogeneous transformation relating the viewed drawing and its computer description, locates the lines added to the drawing, parses the added lines according to the edit language and finally uses this information to update the drawing description.

fulltext.ft_body: THE LINE DRAWING EDITOR, AN EXPERIMENT IN COMPUTER VISION John F. Jarvis 4E610 Bell Laboratories Holmdel, New Jersey 07733 A computer program, the Line Drawing Editor (LDE), that allows convenient modification of computer representationsof simple line drawings has been designed and implemented. The distinguishing feature of the LDE from the multitude of interactive graphics programs that accomplish the same function is the use of a computer controlled TV camera for input and program control rather than conventional interactive input devices such as light pens or data tablets. A graphical editing language allows the LDE user to indicate, by marking the drawing in appropriate fashion, the changes that are to be made. The drawing, which was generated on a hardcopy output device, with the added edit information is placed in front of the camera. In successive phases the LDE computes a two dimensional homogeneous transformation relating the viewed drawing and its computer description, locates the lines added to the drawing, parses the added lines according to the edit language and finally uses this information to update the drawing description. The Line Drawing Editor (LDE) is a computer pro­gram designed to allow creation and modification of computer representationsof line drawings. The distinguishingfeature of the LDE from the multi­tude of interactive graphics programs that accomplish the same functions is the use of a computer controlled TV camera for input and pro­gram control rather than conventional interactive graphics input devices such as light pens or data tablets. Perhaps the earliest example of such conventional interactive graphics program is Sutherland's SKETCHPAD[1]. Schematic diagrams representing logic circuits have been used as the particular drawing type processed by the LDE since specializationto a specific drawing category appears necessary to provide a drawing syntax for many of the processes to be described in subsequent sections of this paper. Without such a syntax only very limited results could have been achieved. The LDE is used by marking,with a graphical editing language, the desired changes on a drawing previously generated from its computer description. After all desired changes have been marked on the drawing it is placed in front of the camera and the LDE program is started. In successivephases the LDE then computes a two dimensional homogeneous trans­ form relating the viewed drawing with its computer description, finds all lines added to the drawing, parses these added lines into the allowed editing operations and finally updates the drawing description data base. The edit functions provided in the LDE have been modeled after similar facilities available in interactive graphics programs and include move, copy, delete, addition of lines and addition of drawing symbols by name from a predefined library. Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. 288 Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Motivation for this project has come observing that users of existing interactive graphics facili­ ties carefully plan their work sessions and appropriatelymark a copy of the drawing before actually using the interactive graphics system. This preplanning serves to minimize the time spent at the interactive graphics console. This project represents a formalization of this preplanning into a language that can be read and interpretted by both the system users and a computer program, the LDE. The implementationof the above ideas as a compu­ ter program was designed primarily to demonstrate a concept rather than as an attempt to produce a working design aids system suitable for drafting room usage. Proving the soundness of or searching for serious flaws in a concept allows considerable simplification of the implementationeffort relative to what is needed to build a functioning production system. The first major restriction is the limitation of both the class of drawings processed by the system and the graphical edit language entities to those that can be constructed from variable length straight lines of four orientations, that is slopes of 0, a, and ±1. The second major restriction is that no processing of textual information, which forms an important part of actual schematic diagrams, is attempted. Successfully dealingwith textual information with an LDE like program will be much more difficult than handling arbitrary line orienta­ tions and curves. A good example of an inter­ active graphics program for the maintenance of schematic drawings in a production environment is the LOGIGRAF program of Mancusi and Wild[2]. Very approximately,one half of the schematic drawing data base is devoted to the storage of textual information in this system. The processing steps used to find and interpret lines according to the edit language are analogous to the steps in compiling a textual computer language; i.e., one written with an alphabet of alphanumeric characters. However, in the LDE the added lines, "characters", must first be found, a step which is completely trivial in processing textual languages. After the added lines are found, (a step paralleled by the lexical analysis phase of processing a textual language) they are assembled into commands in a procedure analogous to parsing. The final processing operation is to modify the drawing description according to the edit commands, a function analogous to program execution in the textual language simile. The host computer system for this project is a large DEC PDP-11/45 which includes a cache memory, demountable disks, industry compatible 9-track magnetic tape and a floating point processor. The system operates under control of the BTL developed UNIX timesharing system[3]. The most important restriction imposed on the LDE by this system is the limitation of core resident program and data to 64K (1K=1024) bytes. A PDP-11/20 is attached as a peripheral to the 11/45 and serves as a con­troller for graphical displays and a camera. A description of the display system which incorpor­ ates Owens-Illinois512-60 plasma panels is given in [4]. The camera is a EMR 659D Optical Data Digitizer[5]. The LDE requires hardcopy produced from drawings described in a data base in the 11/45 file system. These are produced on a FR80 microfilm recorderwhich is driven from a magnetic tape. An existing drawing representationtechnique, the Area Organized Data Base[6] is used for maintainingdrawing descriptions. Use of the system enables the use of small incore buffers while existing programs provide for drawing entry and production of drawings on the local displays and the FR80 microfilmrecorder. Entry is done using a simple hierarchic description language with the atomic or primitive features being lines, rectangles and points. These primitives are supplemented by a symbol facilitythat allows named collections of the primitives to be manipu­ lated in much the same way the basic constructs are. The purpose of the edit language is to specify to the LDE desired changes to be made to the drawing. In analogy with interactive graphics approachesto such editing, a fundamental set of edit operationsmust include the functions of MOVE, COPY, DELETE and ADDition of lines and drawing symbols. Rotation and reflection oper­ ations are also fundamental interactive graphics functions but have not been included in the LDE at this time due to problem of perceiving the results of these operations. An edit operation consists of a set of lines, the edit command, which specify the desired operation and other information needed to indicate what is to be modified and where it is to go. The additional edit commands include the POSITIONERwhich is used to place items being moved or copied, a BREAK com­ mand to limit the extent of line editing and a GROUPing mechanism needed when an edit operation is to manipulated more than one symbol or line. Addition of symbols is done with the ADD command, which also requires the DIGITS 0-9 to indicate which symbolis to be added. One specific symbol, the solder dot (SDOT), is used to indicate that crossinglines are to be considered as connected. The solder dot is used often enough to justify a separate edit command for it. Addition of new lines to the drawing is accomplishedwhen the added lines cannot be interpreted in terms of the edit language. In the above description capitalized words correspond to the names of the edit commands that have been provided in the LDE. Figure 1 shows the set of edit commands which were designed to satisfy the requirements listed above. With the exception of the DIGITs, the language design allows all commands to be drawn in four possible orientations. In additionto these, an arbitrary size rectangle is used for the GROUP command. The GROUP command is the only one not subjected to a maximum size restriction. Examples of valid edit operations constructed ac­cording to these rules are given in Figure 2. The meanings of the four constructs given in this figure are as follows: A) A symbol, type 14, oriented vertically is placed at the location of the ADD symbol. B) The symbol and two lines enclosed by the GROUP are copied and moved. Only a vertical translation is made and it corresponds to the distance between the edge of the GROUP intersected by the COPY command and the long arm of the POSITIONER. C) A line segment delimited by the two BREAK symbols is deleted and replaced by the three line segments forming a "U". The "U" is not interpreted as a copy as it is not syntacticallycorrect as a copy operation. D) A drawing symbol, in this case a simple rectangle, is moved upwards and to the right. This list is in no way exhaustive and is only meant to indicate some of the operationspossible with the language. Another important aspect of the language definition consists of specifyingthe execution order of the set of edit operationsthat have been determined to exist for a particular LDE execution. This is a nontrivial problem as each edit operation can change the context of the following operations. An example of an ambiguous situation occurs if the positioning symbol from one operation intersects the selection operator for a different operation. The specification of execution order appears to be complex both perceptuallyfor the user and from an implementationstandpoint. Although some progress has been made in this area clearly a good deal more remains to be done. The design of the edit language and the parsing procedureshave been arrived at empirically. Al­ though there has been a substantial effort made to define and understand two dimensional grammers (for example see the recent paper by Ota[7]) very little theoretical guidance is available for designing picture grammars as compared with the guidance that theories of one dimensional grammers give the designers of programming languages[8]. Reference [7] also contains an extensive bibliog­ raphy on earlier work in the area of two dimen­ sional grammars. Two main uses of the LDE or an LDE like program can be postulated, the modification of an existing drawing or the initial entry of a drawing into a computer data base. An example of the LDE usage is given in Figures 3 and 4. Initial entry of a drawing starts with a null drawing, only the boundary square and just uses the commands for the addition of information to the drawing. Further­more, there is nothing to be compared with during the line finding phase so that step simplifies considerably. Figure 3 shows hand drawn edit information superimposed on an existing drawing that was processed to what is shown in Figure 4 by the LDE. In a sense the LDE represents a counter example to the slow but steady trend from batch to inter­active usage of computing systems. Indeed most of the arguments for batch vs. interactive com­puting that are made in the realm of software development probably apply to computer graphics as well. For a noninteractivegraphical program to be used instead of an interactive one the economic gains must outweigh a number of obvious disadvantages. The primary ones in this case being substantial increases in program complexity and the requirements of error free interpretation and specification of the desired editing. The equipment costs for both a fully interactive graphics system and a noninteractivesystem using a camera or other imaging device for input should be comparable. The economic advantage of the noninteractive (LDE like) system arises as the contact time in the noninteractive system should be substantiallyless than doing the same job on a fully interactive system. Most of the design difficulties in the creation of the edit language and the program which interprets it derive from the loss of the one parameter naturally available to any interactive program, the temporal ordering of the sequence of commands presented to it. This loss is evident at the lowest levels of processing, the separation and identificationof individual edit commands and at the highest levels as the edit language must include rules to specify the order of command execution. The cost at the lower levels is increased processing time due to the sorting and exhaustive search strategies employed while at the higher levels perceptual problems are incurred. For the reasons given above it appears that the first attempt to produce a production program of this type should concentrate on the initial entry of drawings into the computer data base. Most of the language design and program implementationproblems will be made easier by such a restriction. However, in the context of this paper, the input of a drawing is much more than the detection and recording of a set of vectors. In addition to the obvious data entry commands for drawing symbols, lines and solder dots the COPY operation is a valid part of the input repertoire allowing a substantial economy in the preparation of certain drawings. Since the absence of temporal orderingproduces so many difficulties it should be obvious that the temporal ordering conveys a great amount of information besides the obvious location and selection operations that are normally perceived. The careful study of the ordering and construction of command sequences in interactive systems will no doubt yield improved accuracy and economy of usage of graphical terminal equipment. The present LDE program is not suitable for production usage because of the simplifying assumptions made during its design. In order to build a system for production work a number of factors must be considered. First, a careful evaluation of sensor quality in terms of signal to noise, linearity and stabilitymust be made. Better signal to noise performance can lead to simpler algorithms for line finding. A resolution of at least 500 x 1000 lines will be needed to interpret drawings on a 11 by 14 inch sheet. Resolution requirements will increase propor­tionally for larger sheets. If textual infor­mation is to processed additional factors of 2 to 5 will be needed. In addition to the higher resolution manipulationof text on a schematic diagram will require processes to recognize text so that the appropriate recognition techniques may be used. Procedures to enable such classifi­cation are being researched by Wild[9]. Since the number of picture elements, thus the time spent in line finding operations, increases with the square of the resolution, care must be used not to overspecify the resolution. The line finding routines offer the best hope for improve­ ment in accuracy and speed as there is essentially no theoretical or deep understandingto this process. Unfortunatelythis criticism is generally true of most attempts at line and edge finding, not just the present program. For further information on line and edge finders see Fram and Deutsh[lO], who give a description and comparisonof several line and edge finders currently in use. Finding lines and edges is only part of the problem as the instances of edges and lines must be assembled that appears capable of extension to more complex representations is the Hough transform [11,12]. However with ade­ quate signal to noise performance in the sensor it should be possible to build fairly simple hard­ware to do the initial processing steps needed to extract the line information from the drawing with a substantial gain in processing speed. In summary, the LDE functions as it was designed to. All the drawing manipulation and addition functions designed have been implemented and work. The LDE is a possible precursor of future programs that can further automate many of the remaining tedious drafting jobs. Much of the technology exists now to build similar programs suitable for production use. Whether such a program could at this time provide benefits greater than the costs could only be determined with more study. The LDE also demonstrates the closeness of much of pattern recognition and interactive graphics. Pattern recognition can be used to replace all or part of the temporal orderingprovided by the users of interactive terminals. Finally, the language aspects of communicatingwith a computer system provide a fertile area for research as the language design phase offers the best hope for clarifying the information exchange that takes place when an individual communicates graphically with a computer system. article_rec.title: PRIMS
article_rec.subtitle: an interactive system for the design of hybrid circuit layout

abstract.par: PRIMS is an interactive system to be used in the layout of hybrid circuits. The layout involves positioning integrated circuit chips and resistors on a substrate surface. Conducting paths are then defined in order to make interconnections between chips, external connection pads positioned around the edge of the substrate, etc.PRIMS is actually a language which includes commands for defining regions corresponding to integrated circuit chips, and for causing the system to define a tree of conducting paths to interconnect a set of points. There are also commands for displaying a partial layout, for editing the layout, and for generating plotter code for the final layout.

Hadlock Mathematics Department Florida Atlantic University Boca Raton, Florida ABSTRACT. PRIMS is an interactive system to be used in the layout of hybrid circuits. The layout involves positioning integrated circuit chips and resistors on a substrate surface. Conducting paths are then defined in order to make interconnections between chips, external connection pads positioned around the edge of the substrate, etc. PRIMS is actually a language which includes commands for defining regions corresponding to integrated circuit chips, and for causing the system to define a tree of conducting paths to interconnect a set of points. There are also commands for displaying a partial layout, for editing the layout, and for generating plotter code for the final layout. 1. Hybrid Circuits and Circuit Objects. A hybrid circuit to us will be a circuit made up of integrated circuit chips, resistors, et cetera. Moreover an edge (or portion) of one region is interior to the other region. Also, edges (or portions) are deleted if they coincide and are opposite in direction. the packaging technique involves the positioning of the integrated circuit chips and resistors on a substrate surface. Conducting paths with a minimum Having defined the concept of rectangular region, we can define in broad fashion the purpose of PRIMS. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 293 2. Interactive Circuit Layout. Circuit layout using PRIMS occurs in two phases. In the first phase, called the definition phase, both user and system are involved in creating compo­nents and conductor trees. In the second phase, called the edit phase, both user and system are involved in modifying or duplicating components and conductor trees. Also in the edit phase, the system, in response to the appropriate command, generates and stores in a file, the code for graphics display, plotter artwork, or for cutting rubylith masks. In the definition phase, the user will probably begin by defining conductor trees consisting of single points around the substrate edge. These correspond to pads to be used for external connections. To some extent, the environment (in which the hybrid circuit will be used) will dictate the cyclic order of these pads. The user will probably then, through system commands, create some components corresponding to integrated circuit chips or resistors. He may then have the system create some conductor trees. The creation of components, pads and conductor trees will continue with the user obtaining hardcopy displays at the terminal upon request. Upon completing the definition phase, the user initiates the edit phase during which he may shift, scale, rotate, reflect, duplicate, or make local peri­ meter changes to individual regions (corresponding to integrated circuit chips, resistors, or conducting paths). After making all apparent changes, the user will normally save the layout and request plotter code. After inspecting the artwork generated by the plotter, the user may retrieve the layout for further changes or else generate code for the rubylith mask cutter. 3. Circuit Representation. Two different representations are used for the circuit layout. During the definition phase, the task of routing conducting paths requires a grid representation of the substrate and circuit objects. During the edit phase, the grid representation is too detailed and cumbersome. Consequently, during the edit phase, each circuit object, component or conductor tree, is represented by a linked list of points on the peri­meter of the region. That is, the corner points of the perimeter are listed in clockwise order and this list of points represents the circuit object. The collection of perimeter lists re­presents the hybrid circuit layout. Each method of representation is employed by the user (the conceptual representation consisting of drawings) and by the computer (the machine re­ presentation consisting of arrays and pointers). In order to give the reader an overall understanding of PRIMS and its various commands, conceptualizationsof the two machine representations are given, along with the user's conceptual represen­ tations. The grid representationassumes the substrate is divided into a uniform grid by a series of horizontal and vertical grid lines. The user should begin the layout process by choosing the grid unit (5, 10, 15, 20 mils). The choice is some­ what arbitrary, the constraints being these. Conducting paths are of uniform width and will be considered by the system to be of width equal to the grid unit until the edit phase. On conversion to perimeter lists, a setoff (supplied by the user) from the grid line is made for all regions. Thus if the eventual width of conducting paths is to be 10 mils, a 20 mil grid unit with 5 mil setoff would suf­fice. The setoff information alone is sup­plied to the system. When thinking about the layout in grid representation, the user thinks of position and dimension in terms of grid squares. In Figure 1 below appears a layout with two components (1 and 2) and a conductor tree (3). To provide the necessary information to the system, the user numbers grid lines as he would those of a rectangular coordinate system. The coordinates of a grid square are the rec­ tangular coordinates of its lower left corner. Component 1 is a rectangle with lower left corner at (1,2) and having width = 3 and height = 4. Similarly 2 is the composition of two rectangles. One has lower left corner (6,1) and width = 6 and height = 2. The other rectangle has lower left corner (9,1) and width = 3 and height = 3. The conductor tree 3 connects squares A through E with coordinates respectively : (10,5), (4,4), (2,1), (10,4) and (5,1). A numbering scheme is employed by the system for naming circuit objects. The numbers used, for the most part, are those supplied by the user. Thus, for defining and editing these objects, the user would use the numbers 1, 2 or 3 (or others of his choosing). The machine-grid-representation employs several arrays, the main ones be­ing GRID and KROOT. Each grid square is represented by a 6 bit byte in the array GRID. The byte stores information about the grid square such as the type of circuit object (component or conductor tree) to which it belongs. A direction (East, North, West or South) is often assigned to a grid square and then this information is stored in the byte re­presenting the square. Basically, the byte is divided into 3 fields of 3 bits, 2 bits and 1 bit. The first field is used for circuit type (component, conductor, free or buffer) and, if conductor, the first field also tells the relative position of the square in the tree. The second field is used for direction or for buffer level. The third field is a status bit for the routing algorithm for free squares or buffer squares. For component squares, the third field differentiates between perimeter and internal squares. In the machine-grid-representation, direction has several applications. The machine-grid-representationof a conductor tree is a directed tree. The user gives the squares to be connected by the tree, designating one square as root. The coordinates of the root square go in the array KROOT in location n where n is the name of the tree being created. In the directed tree repre­sentation, there is a directed path from every square in the tree to the root. This offers a means of identi­fying a conductor tree (the ability to do so is essential in routing). Simply trace the tree to its root, scan KROOT to match coordinates and take the location as the name of the tree. (An alternative would be to store the circuit object identificationin every grid square belonging to it, doubling the amount of storage for only 64 possible objects). The machine-grid-representation of components also uses direction. Each perimeter square is assigned a direction so that one traces the perimeter in clockwise fashion by following these directions. The lower left corner of a component consisting of a single rectangle is used as a root. For more complex components, it will be some corner assigned by the system during composition of the rectangles. In any case, the coordinates of the root are entered in KROOT, again in the location given by the name of the object. Direction is essential in the system's approach to creating conductor trees. Initially the conductor tree consists of just the root square. Each of the other squares (to be connected) is connected to this tree using a shortest path algorithm that creates a minimum distance tree (here distance is a linear combination of actual distance, turns, X­overs and buffer costs). This minimum distance tree is represented as a directed tree with root being the square to be con­nected. As soon as it becomes possible to add a conductor tree square to the minimum distance tree, an optimum connection has been found. The system traces the path to the root (the square to be connected) changing the circuit types of the path squares from free or buffer to conductor (except where crossings occur) and re­versing the directions. Finally, direction also has ap­plication in converting from grid to peri­meter list representation. Since adjacent squares can belong to circuit objects of the same type, the type information is not sufficient to delineate between regions. However adjacent squares of the same type belong to the same region if either is directed into the other. Perimeter list representation,in contrast to grid representation, is very simple. The user may think of it as lists of corner points encountered in traversing the perimeters in clockwise fashion or in counter-clockwisefashion. Any corner is valid as a starting point and either order is acceptable. The machine representation employs an array P together with an array LNK for storing these lists as linked circular lists. An array KTOP stores pointers to the peri­meter lists. A conductor tree created in the definition phase, (and named K), would have its root coordinates stored in the Kth location of KROOT. During the edit phase, a pointer to the list of corner points on its perimeter would be stored in the Kth location of KTOP. Thus conversion does not change region names. An example of the machine-grid-re­presentation (actually a conceptualization of it) of a circuit layout is given below. The user's version of the perimeter list representation of the same layout is also given. Note the offset supplied by the system in conversion from grid to peri­meter list representation. Fig. 2.b -User's Version of Perimeter Lists for Regions 1, 2, and 3 4. The Interactive Layout Process: Definition Phase. The purpose of this section is to illustrate the use of PRIMS by showing how it might be used in defining a sample layout. First some general comments are necessary concerning the nature of PRIMS and the format of PRIMS commands. PRIMS is an interactive software system and, as such, responds to specific user commands. The intention here is to provide a tool for the user experienced in hybrid circuit layout. For the most part, the user makes decisions and the system is involved in bookkeeping and calculations necessary for editing or for artwork generation. Only in the area of routing, after the locations of the points to be connected have been determined by the user, does the system make decisions. And here the user may intervene and dictate the routing if he wishes. The format of PRIMS commands is simple and nearly uniform. Every command is composed of a 2 character operation code followed by a 2 character operand name. The operation codes are listed in Appendix 1. The operand name is usually a 2 digit number used as the name of the region affected by the command. Commands to INitialize or Halt require no operand and the PRINT command requires an operand which designates the output device. The layout process will usually be­gin with the INitialize command. A rectangular border corresponding to the size of the substrate is 1st established, the user giving lower left corner (normal­ ly 0,0) width and height. Next the user provides the system with cost information which will be used to optimally route conducting paths. Costs for distance, turns, X-overs, additional X-overs, a X-over limit, and 4 buffer costs are given. The user will have either a partial layout or else a complete trial layout in mind. In the latter case the system is only being used to decrease the large amount of information needed to describe a complete layout in plotter code terms. Also since the PRIMS runstream is a more conceptual description than is plotter code, errors are easier to locate and cor­rect in a PRIMS runstream file than a plotter code file. Figure 3 is a simple layout for the purpose of illustrating the PRIMS definition phase. Figure 3. -Two Components and Two Conductor Trees. (The run named 9 by PRIMS is still regarded as part of tree 8 in spite of the Xover.) The two components are defined after the INitialize command using the CM com­mand. Naming them 1 and 2, PRIMS would prompt the user for the position. -size information. The user would respond with 13,12,6,3 and with 17,7,7,3 for the components in Figure 3. The conductor tree consisting of a single horizontal run from (7,8) to (16,8) might be named 5, have root (7,8) and 1 additional point to be connected at (16,8). The other conductor tree might be named 8 and is similarly constructed. The two trees would be defined with commands CN5 and CN8. Following each command, the system would prompt the user for the coordinates of the root, number of additional points, and their coordinates. The user would respond with (7,8), 1, (16,8) and (15,16), 1, (21,5) for the trees in Figure 3. At this point, it seems appropriate to digress from the illustration of PRIMS commands and to go into some detail as to the mechanics of conductor tree construction. Basically, the approach is to regard the grid as a graph. Grid squares are regarded as vertices, each having at most 4 neighbors corresponding to the grid squares to the East, North, West and South. In constructing the tree, the root is regarded as the initial conductor tree. Each subsequent point is connected to the existing conductor tree. If the user responds with 4 as to the number of additional points, 4 separate paths would be constructed, one to connect each point to the existing tree in the order in which they are supplied by the user. For each point T = (x, y) a least cost path is selected using a shortest path algorithm (at­tributed by Dijkstra) which builds a minimum distance tree rooted at T. (Root here is used in the directed tree sense.) The algorithm proceeds by adding to the tree, the unattached vertex nearest the root. Generally this requires scanning each tree vertex and considering each unattached neighbor. Thus the general step (adding a vertex to the minimum distance tree) requires a number of steps proportional to the number of vertices in the mini­ mum distance tree. Essentially there are at most 4 + 2 (n-l) additions and as many comparisons to be made where n is the number of vertices in the tree. This bound stems from the fact that in the grid graph each vertex (grid square) has at most 4 neighbors. Each time an unattached neighbor is added, the net increase of unattached neighbors to the tree is 2. If m is the final size of the tree when the conductor tree is reached, this adds up to at most (4 + 2 (n-l) = m(m + 3) additions n=l and comparisons. Now the minimum distance tree grows out from T with no special inclination to grow in the direction of the conductor tree. In the interests of speeding up the shortest path algorithm and at the risk of coming up with a greater than least cost path, a 'topological' technique is used. The rectangular hull of the ter­minal squares (end squares) of the exist­ing conductor tree and the next square to be connected is the smallest rectangle containing these squares. A series of concentric rectangular frames is con­structed. The frames are centered about the hull and are constructed of buffer squares of successively higher levels as you move away from the hull. By including a buffer cost of the speci­fied level for each buffer square of that level in the path, the minimum distance tree is influenced to grow in the direction of the existing conductor tree. X-overs are still avoided if the X-over cost is high relative to the buffer cost. In Figure 3, conductor tree 8 was routed by the system so as to X-over conductor tree 5 since the costs given made the butter frames in­fluence the route to stay within the hull. At any time during the definition phase, the user may obtain a terminal display of the layout with a PR 3 com­mand. The operand 3 used with the PRint command is for displaying the layout in grid representationat the terminal. The figure below demonstrates the use of PR 3. The user specifies the rectangular portion of the chip to be displayed by giving lower left corner coordinates, width and height. The bordering rectangle of c's was established during initializationand keeps the routing algorithm from wandering off the edge of the substrate. Fig. 4 -a Terminal Display of a Layout The final command of the definition phase is always a CV command which has the effect of converting the layout re­ presentation from grid to perimeter list. The conversion process is ac­complished first by collecting all the straight line segments occurring in the perimeters of regions corresponding to components or is done by conductor trees. This two passes, one vertical and one horizontal, over the array GRID. In the vertical pass, a window consisting of 4 grid squares with coordinates (i,j), (i+l,j), (i+l,j+l), and (i,j+l) is passed over the entire array, serving to determine all vertical segments. Similarly, the horizontal segments are determined during the horizontal pass. A clockwise traversal of peri­meters assigns a direction to each segment, i.e., the direction in which it is traversed (East, North, West, South). In displacing segments to accomplish the set-off from grid lines, East segments are displaced downward and have a terminal position below the horizontal grid line with which it previously coincided. For this reason, East segments are referred to as BH Segments (Below Horizontal). Similarly, North segments are RV segments (Right Vertical), West segments are AH segments (Above Horizontal) while South segments are LV segments (Left Vertical). The segment tree is organized into 4 sub­ trees, one for each segment type. With­in a subtree, there is a branch for each column or row (depending on the subtree type) row containing segments. The branch is a linked list of segments occurring in the corresponding column or row. Grid squares designated as root squares are given special attention in conversion. The 1st time they come under scan within the 4 square window, a segment must be originating, under scan or terminating since root squares occur only on perimeters of components or conductor trees. The segment being determined is designated as a root segment and the status of the square is changed from root to non-root. In this way, a 1-1 mapping of region names onto root segments is established. The region name is stored in the segment tree with its root segment. After the two passes, all segments have been determined and entered into the segment tree. Perimeter lists are constructed by processing this tree. The tree is scanned until a root segment is located. A perimeter list will be con­structed for the region corresponding to this root segment. The idea is to trace out the perimeter in clockwise fashion, entering corner points into the perimeter list as they occur as common endpoints of two successive segments traversed. Of two successive segments, one will be vertical and the other horizontal. The type of vertical segment determines the direction of horizontal displacement; the type of horizontal segment determines the direction of vertical displacement. The necessary computation for the offset is performed as the point is entered into the perimeter list. In tracing out the perimeter, the rule is simply that segments must alternate between vertical and horizontal. It may very well occur that two segments have a common endpoint. However, by giving preference to right turns and, given the direction of the turn, picking the proper type, the right segment is selected by searching at most two sub­trees for a segment which articulates with the last. The following figure illustrates the use of the CV command. The resultant perimeter list representation is printed. The lists are printed as they are formed in the order in which the cor­ responding root segments are discovered in the segment tree. This would be the perimeter list representation of the layout in Figure 2. The addition of a region is the result of a X-over. The system automatically appropriates the first unused name after the name of the conductor tree. In this case 9 was the first unused name after 8. The system is now in the edit phase. Some of the commands used in this phase are illustrated in the next section. 5. The Interactive Layout Process: Edit Phase The purpose of this section is to illustrate the use of PRIMS during the edit phase. It may be that no changes are desired. At this point a PR 1 command will generate plotter code from the perimeter lists, a fairly straight forward task. The plotter code in figure 6 consists of two com­mands: (x,y,4) means (move to position (x,y) with pen up and (n, 0, 2) means move distance r at an angle 0 with pen down. Generally the user will wish to modi­fy the layout created during the defini­tion phase. The edit commands fall into four general categories: commands for duplications, for non-rigid transforma­tions, for rigid transformations, and for input/output. To illustrate some of the commands, the simple layout in Figure 7.a is assumed to have been produced during the definition phase. This layout is con­verted using the CV command and now some edit commands are employed to produce the layout in Figure 7.b. The first command after the perimeter lists produced by the CV command is a STep command. ST 5 will produce copies of 5 to be given successive integer names starting with 6. There will be 3 copies, the 1st of width .5 . They will be shifted so as to have intervening intervals of 1.5 and each copy will be produced from the pre­ ceding using a scale factor of 1. in the X direction. Similarly, a series of conductor runs extending downward from the bottom edge of component I is created with the ST10 command. The PAtch command replaces a portion of the perimeter list with a 'patch' list. In this case a conducting run, extending out from the left side of region 1, is created. To use the PAtch command, two points, P and Q, on the existing perimeter are needed. In clockwise order, let P occur followed by a list of points X (pos­sibly vacuous), followed by Q. The user inputs PYQP where Y is the patch list. Note that P is repeated to terminate the input. In the example, P = (5.25, 6.25), Q = (5.25, 10.75) while Y = [(5.25, 8,25), (2.25, 8.25), (2.25, 8.75), (5.25, 8.75)]. X is vacuous. Since rectangles can have minimum dimension 2, this conducting run could not have been accomplished during the definition phase through composition of rectangles (repeated use of the CM com­mand). Figure 6. -Plotter Code For the Perimeter lists in Figure 5. Figure 7.b -The Layout After Being Modified During Edit Phase Several other edit commands perhaps require comment in addition to the ex­planation in Appendix 1. While the PA command is useful for major perimeter changes, it is cumbersome in correcting the coordinates of a single point (this kind of error is apt to occur when the user inputs a perimeter list during edit using the ReaD command). For single point corrections, the user employs the PLug command. Prior to doing so, he would employ the DuMp command to display the perimeter list containing the point in error. The link or pointer is displayed along with the coordinates of each point. This link is used to reference the point to be corrected by PLug. While PAtch and PLug affect non-rigid transformations, SHift, SCale, ROtate, and ReFlect affect rigid transformations. All of these latter except SHift involve the rectangular hull of the operand region. For example, SC K would have the following effect on region K. If P is the center of K's hull, each point Q on K's perimeter is transformed into a point Q' by scaling the X,Y distances of Q from P. ACKNOWLEDGMENT The design and development of PRIMS would not have been possible without the interest of and discussions with a number of people at the Naval Avionics Facility. In particular, Tom Higbie and Robert Lafara provided much insight into the nature and constraints of hybrid circuit layout. article_rec.title: Computer-aided coarse grid layout technique for photomasks

abstract.par: A comprehensive computer-aided mask layout technique has been developed which permits quick conversion of LSI circuits into working photomasks. It is an efficient solution to the problem when the demand for customized circuit layouts greatly overshadows the more standardized techniques. No computer background or programming experience is required. This approach allows the designer to quickly compose high-density mask layouts using simple free-hand line symbols. These easily drawn symbols, representing complex circuitry, utilize a standard device-level building block library which simplifies the conversion of LSI circuits into photomasks, and permits the designer to generate up to 100% of the layout without leaving his desk.

fulltext.ft_body: COMPUTER-AIDED COARSE GRID LAYOUT TECHNIQUE FOR PHOTOMASKS Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee.Siggraph 76, July 14-16 Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Ronald G. Geer TRW Defense & Space Systems Group One Space Park, R6/2517 Redondo Beach, CA 90278 1-213-536-1947 A comprehensive computer-aided mask layout technique has been developed which permits quick conversion of LSI circuits into working photomasks. It isan efficient solution to the problem when the demand for customized circuit layouts greatly overshadows the more standardized techniques. No computer background or programming experience is required. This approach allows the designer to quickly compose high-density mask layouts using simple free-hand line symbols. These easily drawn symbols, representing complex circuitry, utilize a standard device-level building block library which simplifies the conversion of LSI circuits into photomasks, and permits the designer to generate up to 100% of the layout without leaving his desk. 1. INTRODUCTION The computer-aidedcoarse grid layout technique is a flexible approach with outstanding features that has been found to be invaluable when itis imprac­ tical to standardize special circuit configura­tions[3]. This concept facilitates the creation of customized high-density cell and die layouts through the use of a device-level building block library based on a coarse grid (> 5pm) interconnect scheme. Not only does this layout technique signi­ ficantly reduce the typical die design time, but it also offers the design engineer a very efficient means of interfacing with an iterative graphics design system. See Figure 1. 2. COMMONLY USED PHOTOMASK LAYOUT TECHNIQUES A brief description of the three most commonly used LSI photomask layout techniques is presented to illustrate some of the inherent design restric­ tions associated with each approach. 2.1 Standard Manual Layout Approach Manually creating LSI photomask layouts involves the generation of master artwork at large scales to permit accurate photoreduction of the geometric details. The physical size of such drawings, some measuring up to 30 feet, are impractical to handle. It is a major task to properly check and revise these drawings, not to mention the documentation and storage requirements. 2.2 CAD Layout Approach with Standard Devices TRW's iterative graphics design system (Applicon Graphic System/700) reduces the composition of LSI circuit layout drawings through interaction with the designer and an on-line computer. Standardized metal interconnectand device geometries are de­ fined on a 1pm working grid and stored into the computer memory as digital information. The de­ signer interfaces with the system through a combin­ation of a remote digitizer and a CRT console. He then recalls copies of the required devices from the memory and positions them at specified coor­dinates on the master drawing file as required. The finished drawing is stored inmemory until required for production of plotted drawings for record purposes, or for the generation of the mag­netic tape which issent to a photomask fabrication facility. Although the typical LSI photomask design cycle is greatly reduced, experience has shown that there are some restrictions, as listed below, which occur once the basic drawing file isplaced in the com­puter memory. . Itisimpractical for more than one person at a time to implement changes to a parti­cular drawing file by means of CRT editing. . CRT editing iscostly due to availability of allocated computer time. .A change inthe basic metal interconnect of device geometry usually necessitates a major drawing file redesign. . The approximate time required for a change isinverselyproportional to the basic working grid unit. A small working grid requires more time. 2.3 CAD Layout Approach with Standard Cells Most computer-aideddesign systems are based on the standard cell building block concept. Groups of individual devices are combined into geometric "standard cells", such as gates and flip-flops, and stored into the computer memory. The operation of positioning and interconnecting on the master die drawing can be performed automatically or man­ually. This isvery efficient inthat the die de­sign time issignificantlyreduced; however, there are some characteristicswhich can restrict the creative productivity of the LSI engineering group, such as: . Fixed Cell input/output node locations. . Fixed Cell signal and power buss line widths. . Inefficient interconnect density due to cell interfacial restrictions. . Generally larger die size due to internal cell restrictions. 3. CAD LAYOUT APPROACH WITH COARSE GRID A new layout scheme isbeing used which eliminates these problems. This LSI photomask layout concept isactually a combination of all three of the pre­vious layout techniques to provide a fast method of creating and revising "customized" circuit cells from scratch, using a standard devices building block library. See Figure 2. Figure 2 -Standard 5pm Grid Devices (B)Actual device composite of all levels. This approach basically allows the design engineer to compose his rough circuit layouts using simple line symbols to represent the devices within the circuit, and to interconnect the devices on a >5pm grid with simple point-to-pointlines, representing metallization,as required. Figure 5A shows a typ­ ical rough (free-hand)cell layout. This rough layout isthen digitized directly into position on the master drawing file of the computer memory. The degree of efficiency inusing this technique depends on the degree of compromise inobtaining a practical rough layout grid. Three problems were successfully solved during the development of this technique: . Determination of appropriate grid for rough layout, . Definition of devices such that a symbolic interconnect centerline falls on the 5pm grid, and . Generation of 5um grid device spacing guide. 3.1 Determination of Grid for Rough Layout Two factors were responsible for the decision to select a practical rough layout grid size with increments of 1/10 inch = 5m and 1/2 inch = 1 mil (by definition). First, dimensional criteria established Metal-1 (first of two metallization levels) width to be 8um minimum, and metal-to-metal spacing to be 2um minimum. The centerline-to-cen­ terline spacing of Metal-1is10um minimum. Metal-2 (secondmetallization level) minimums are 18um width and 7um spacing, with centerline-to-cen­ terline spacing of 25um. The second reason for selecting this particular grid was based on experimentationwith various digitizers. Itwas found that internal command recognition restrictionsmade itdifficult to digitize from a rough layout and accurately posi­tion the devices on specified coordinates when the grid spacing was less than 1/10 inch. 3.2 Definition of Device with Symbolic Centerline 3.3 Guide for 5 Grid Device Spacing A family of standard devices has been created with all levels defining each device associatedwith a centerline on the 5um grid, even though some actual geometries are designed to the nearest 1/4um (Fig­ure 2B). Each device has its own unique symbolic centerline arrangement to permit device recogni­tion. This isnecessary when the design engineer generates his rough layout, and later when the circuit is digitized into the master drawing file of the computer memory. The 5pm device spacing guide (See Figure 3) isan essential aide required during the composition stage of a circuit layout. Itshows the minimum spacing relationship of all possible device con­ figurations and combinations. Each device has four positive reference code points. These code points, located along the left side and bottom borders of the spacing guide, are cross-referenced to obtain the minimum grid spacing. This particu­ lar guide shows how 11 basic devices can be arranged in 526 different positions, accounting for every practical arrangement required during an average die design. Figure 3 -Guide for 5um Grid Device Spacing Figure 4 -Basic Cell Schematic Diagram 4. APPLICATION OF 5um GRID INA TYPICAL DIE DESIGN Initially, the designer verifies compliance with five basic prerequisites before beginning the actual layout. . Circuit islogically divided into blocks of cells at 125X with prelim­inary bussing diagrams. . Schematics contain all the necessary information, denoting special con­straints, matched pairs, high current devices, etc. . Rough stick figure interconnect drawings establish interface require­ments. .Signal interconnect isestablished to be on Metal-1whenever possible. .Buss interconnect isestablished to be on Metal-2 whenever possible. After the basic prerequisites have been satisfied, each cell layout ina typical die design involves the following six steps: Step 1 The design engineer obtains a standard device handbook for the applicable technologyand makes same size copies of the 500X 5um grid devices (Figure 2A) and the 5um device spacing guide (Fig­ ure 3). Step 2 The layout iscreated on stabilized, reproducible 1/10 inch (transparent) grid paper infree-hand sketch style. The 500X device template isslid into position under the grid paper, allowing the design engineer to quickly outline the applicable symbols as required. The devices are interconnectedon the 5um grid using a solid line to repre­sent Metal-1,and a dashed line to represent Metal-2 (Figure 5A). The cell circuit layout terminates at logical interface points. Step 3 Reference designators are assigned to each component inthe circuit layout inaccordance to the schematic diagram (Figure 4). Length adjustments are indicated for each resistor that must be adjusted tighter than the 5um grid permits. Step 4 The approved layout isdirectly digi­tized into position on the master drawing file of the computer memory. This isaccomplished through the use of a digitizing procedure built around a simple point-to-pointsingle stroke coordinate system. The starting refer­ence point (dot on left side of device-- Figure 3)locates the device and the second reference point (dot on right) orientates and stretches the geometry as desired. Single dot devices are assumed to have a second reference point one grid increment to the right of the starting point dot (by definition). Step 5 A 500X symbolic check plot (Figure 5B)isgenerated from the computer memoryand compared with the initial roughlayout (Figure 5A). The rough layoutand the symbol plot are superimposed over a light table and checked for diff­ erences--the fastest method of finding digitizing errors. Finally, a complete composite isgenerated (Figure 5C). Step 6 Intermediate die plots are generated at 125X and/or 250X as the various cells are digitized into position on the master drawing file. These plots are checked to verify that the peripheral components and circuitry cells are progressing as planned per basic prerequisites. After the design iscompleted and approved, the stored digital information iscopied onto amag­netic tape and sent to a photomask fab­ rication facility. 5. ADVANTAGES OF COARSE GRID APPROACH This technique offers an efficient solution to the problem when the demand for customized circuit layouts isgreater than the more standardized techniques[2,3]. Some of the outstanding advan­tages are listed below: . No special computer background or program­ ming knowledge isrequired. . Simple line device symbols permit gener­ation of free-hand circuit layouts, repre­senting complex circuitry, which can be digitized directly into position on the master drawing of the computer memory. . Digitizing time of an average layout is reduced from several days to a couple of hours. . Symbolic plots reduce the average plottime of a typical cell from one hour to 15 minutes. .CRT editing isreduced to a minimum by virtue of the efficient manner of placing the cell layout information into the master drawing file of the computer memory. . Changes are easily implemented and seldom necessitate major drawing file redesign. .Final layout check procedure iscompat­ible with automated evaluation techniques. 6. OTHER APPLICATIONSOF COARSE GRID APPROACH This technique can be easily extended to other graphic applications. The process issimilar to LSI approach inthat the devices are created with symbolic centerlines falling on a desired grid. Then a border rectangle isplaced around the cen­terline establishing a unique identification sym­bol with four positive reference code points (Figure 3). The spacing increments are determined to be the minimum coarse grid spacing acceptable between any two positive reference points. Some of the other graphic application areas which would benefit from this approach are listed below: . Printed circuit layouts. . Multilayer circuit layouts. . Thick and thin film hybrid circuit layouts. SUMMARY The computer-aidedcoarse grid layout technique has been successful in reducing the design time of customized high-density cell and die photo­ mask layouts. Demonstrationshave shown that the overall photomask layout time has been reduced by more than 400%. This asset improves die qual­ ity by permittingmore time to be devoted to circuit function design effort. The design engineer is provided with a simplified layout concept which facilitates quick conversion of LSI circuits into photomasks. This technique reduces the typical die design time through the use of a standard device-level building block library, and it allows the designer to generate up to 100% of the circuit layout without leaving his desk.
